fields.headline: Quiet man at the helm
fields.trailText: At the end of last week's Test match at Centurion Park, England's coach, Duncan Fletcher, could be spied punching the air just as vigorously as his captain, an unusual display of emotion. As a former captain of Zimbabwe, he knows what it's like to be the underdog and how important it is to treasure the snatched victory. Fletcher has had a good, anonymous tour; it's been good partly because he's been so anonymous.
fields.body:
At the end of last week's Test match at Centurion Park, England's coach, Duncan Fletcher, could be spied punching the air just as vigorously as his captain, an unusual display of emotion. As a former captain of Zimbabwe, he knows what it's like to be the underdog and how important it is to treasure the snatched victory. Fletcher has had a good, anonymous tour; it's been good partly because he's been so anonymous.

Fletcher has offered a stark contrast to his high-profile predecessors, David Lloyd and Raymond Illingworth. Both of these were media-friendly (keep them going long enough and they were bound to say something indiscreet in the end). Fletcher has appeared before the press when required - usually after a bad day - and has been blunt, brief and as honest as he can be without betraying his loyalty to his players. For much of the time he has been content to observe, to learn, and to run a good practice.

Crucially he has been a believer in the primacy of the captain (his predecessors were never so sure about that). Nasser Hussain has visibly been the man in charge and Fletcher has allowed him every freedom. All the signs are that they are building up a strong and fruitful rapport. This is how the top international coaches now operate.

In Australia, Geoff Marsh and recently John Buchanan scurry invisibly in the background, supporting their captain. Graeme Ford (Graeme who?) does the same for Hansie Cronje. These men are confident enough and sufficiently devoid of ego to let the captain rule since they recognise that this is how cricket teams function best.

I expect Fletcher's influence to increase in terms of the assessment and selection of players, but he will continue to allow Hussain to be the central figure. At least this tour has not been as inconclusive as so many of its predecessors in terms of future selections even if some of the conclusions to be drawn are negative.

Even so, Fletcher has probably joined the rest of us in a raising of the eyebrows when assessing his one-day squad. Today England embark upon their first match in the triangular series when they meet South Africa in Bloemfontein. But, Hussain aside, the tour's three batting successes - Alec Stewart, Michael Vaughan and Michael Atherton (just about) - have all left the country. The one-day squad were picked too early and the populist demand to plan for the World Cup in 2003 was prominent in selectors' minds in September. Chairmen concoct four-year plans; captains and coaches fret about the next game.

At this stage victories are more important than blooding newcomers, which is why the absence of Stewart, in particular, must be galling. A change of tack has been tacitly admitted with the call-up of Craig White to replace Andrew Flintoff. White is already the wrong side of 30, and with the best will in the world it's hard to imagine him being prominent in the 2003 World Cup.

Even more extraordinary and a more damning indictment of the September selections is the possibility that Mark Alleyne might be England's wicketkeeper today in place of Chris Read. Alleyne, 32 in May, wore the gloves at Potchesfstroom. In the past Alleyne has been an emergency keeper. I dread to think what Stewart makes of this. I don't suppose Read is too chuffed, either. If England persist with this policy at Bloemfontein today, we can conclude that Read would have been better off working behind some bar in Nottingham or Paignton this winter rather than spending three months ferrying drinks to his new colleagues. At least then he could have gone home at night with a chance of retaining some peace of mind.

There's still plenty to sort out.

fields.headline: Tributes
fields.trailText: 'This is a very sad day for cricket. I have lost a close friend - and so has the game of cricket. He was probably the finest journalist I met and I have known him all my career, both as an player and an umpire at cricket grounds all around the world.'
fields.body:
'This is a very sad day for cricket. I have lost a close friend - and so has the game of cricket. He was probably the finest journalist I met and I have known him all my career, both as an player and an umpire at cricket grounds all around the world.'

Dickie Bird, former Test umpire

'You always respected what he wrote, he had a great love of the game which came over in all his writings.He was a real cricket man, he believed in standards, and keeping them high.I think he found it a little hard coming to terms with the modern game - one-day cricket and coloured clothing, that sort of thing. But he was a highly-respected journalist and will be greatly missed.'

Bob Cottam, England bowling coach

'He gave his whole life to the game of cricket. He became a supreme journalist with very strong views. He always tried to do the best for the highest principles of the game. Cricket loses an enormous friend in Jim who gave his whole life to the game.'

Lord Cowdrey

'He was a wonderful cricket writer and very well respected in his field. It's very sad'

Mark Ealham, Kent and England.

'This is the end of an era of great cricket writers. I still looked forward to reading what he wrote in the Daily Telegraph even in his old age. I don't think all Yorkshiremen were his greatest favourites, but you cannot take away his ability with the pen.'

Fred Trueman

'Jim Swanton was not the greatest stylist, but he was the most authoritative commentator of the game. He was a man of his time and he could be incredibly pompous. But he was extraordinarily professional and a wonderful journalist.'

Michael Parkinson

webTitle: United and Arsenal: the story of the Nineties

fields.headline: United and Arsenal: the story of the Nineties
fields.trailText: Oct 90 United 0 Arsenal 1
fields.body:
Oct 90 United 0 Arsenal 1

David Seaman is the only player not involved in a 21-man brawl between the sides. Both clubs are charged with bringing the game into disrepute. Arsenal subsequently have two points deducted, and United one.

Mar 94 Arsenal 2 United 2

Eric Cantona is sent off and Roy Keane booked in a fierce battle at Highbury. Twice United take the lead through Lee Sharpe; twice Arsenal fight back.

Nov 96 United 1 Arsenal 0

Nigel Winterburn's own goal leads to Arsène Wenger's first defeat on English soil as ugly clash between Ian Wright and Peter Schmeichel turns into racism row.

Feb 97 Arsenal 1 United 2

Three goals, six bookings, a manager on the pitch and a scuffle in the tunnel that requires police intervention. Wright and Schmeichel clash once more.

Mar 98 United 0 Arsenal 1

Marc Overmars scores the only goal to hand Arsenal the edge in the two-team title race.

Apr 99 United 2 Arsenal 1 *

Ryan Giggs's wonder goal in extra-time books United's place in the FA Cup final at Wembley but captain Keane is sent off for a crude challenge on Overmars. Dennis Bergkamp has chance to seal victory for Arsenal but his 90th-minute penalty is saved by Schmeichel.

Aug 99 Arsenal 1 United 2

Frederik Ljungberg scores for Arsenal but two strikes from Keane give United a vital win at Highbury.

*FA Cup semi-final replay

Overall record in the 90s

Arsenal won 7 United won 9 Draws 7

fields.headline: How we'll miss cricket's doyen
fields.trailText: He may have been 92, but the news of the death of Jim Swanton comes as a shock. He seemed so indestructible. The last time I saw him at an editorial board meeting of The Cricketer magazine in November he was moving more slowly, but he was as dapper as ever in his pin-striped suit, and his mind was still sharp as a razor. As usual he took a moment to chide those directors who had not managed to contribute to the latest issue.
fields.body:
He may have been 92, but the news of the death of Jim Swanton comes as a shock. He seemed so indestructible. The last time I saw him at an editorial board meeting of The Cricketer magazine in November he was moving more slowly, but he was as dapper as ever in his pin-striped suit, and his mind was still sharp as a razor. As usual he took a moment to chide those directors who had not managed to contribute to the latest issue.

Swanton himself kept writing to the end. The doyen of all cricket correspondents wrote his first piece in May 1926 for All Sports Weekly , a profile of Frank Woolley; his last appears in this month's Cricketer . In between he wrote more than eight million words, mostly on cricket but also, sporadically, on football, rugby and golf.

After leaving Cranleigh, he worked with the London Evening Standard from 1927-39. Then after the War, during which he was a prisoner in the hands of the Japanese, he was the Daily Telegraph 's cricket correspondent for 30 years. In the meantime he was appointed editorial director of The Cricketer in 1966. He was also on hand when the first live cricket commentaries were broadcast. Soon his summaries of the day's play in those familiar patrician tones became minor works of art. 'But let me begin by reading the card...'

In addition to all that, Swanton wrote more than 20 books on the game as well as founding his own itinerant cricket team, the Arabs CC, who roamed the Commonwealth and often included the likes of Richie Benaud and Colin Ingleby-MacKenzie. He himself was a useful cricketer who appeared for Middlesex against the universities in 1937 and 1938. And he helped to launch the writing careers of many of our established correspondents. John Woodcock, Christopher Martin-Jenkins and, very briefly, Scyld Berry all began their careers in cricket in Swanton's employment, dictating, though never having the temerity to amend, his copy. No wonder his autobiography was entitled, albeit with uncharacteristic modesty, Sort of A Cricket Person.

There have always been those, quite often his closest friends, who felt that Swanton's pomposity needed to be pricked now and then. Brian Johnston, when spotting smoke emanating from a distant St John's Wood chimney, once famously remarked: 'Now they've elected Swanton Pope.' In his latter days the accusation had less force; in my experience Swanton was increasingly capable of laughing at himself and his pathological aversion to coloured clothing, the no-ball law, unshaven cricketers, the sweep and, heaven forfend, the reverse sweep.

Attending Cricketer board meetings with Swanton present were a joy. Often the agenda would be discarded and the topic of conversation would shift on to the relative merits of Woolley or Bradman or Hammond.

Then came the realisation that Swanton had seen all these men play, that he knew most of them personally. In fact Swanton was told that he was in his pram when WG Grace made 140 for London County against Forest Hill in 1907, though he never presumed to describe that innings. But he could tell you which way the wind was blowing at Lord's when Woolley, his cricketing hero, opened the batting for England with Jack Hobbs in 1930. His longevity added to his authority.

The one regret of his professional career must have been his absence from the greatest cricketing story in history, the Bodyline tour of 1932-33. During the summer of 1932, when working for the Evening Standard , he was covering the game between Essex and Yorkshire at Leyton when Holmes and Sutcliffe scored a record 555 for the first wicket. His paper was, in Swanton's words, 'last in the queue' for the one public telephone box available and his copy missed the edition.

As a consequence he was not sent to Australia; instead the job went to the paper's tennis correspondent, Bruce Harris. There is scope for thinking - albeit mischievously - that Bodyline would not have taken place had Swanton been there. It's not difficult to imagine him striding up to Jardine and saying, 'Now, look here Douglas, this has got to stop', and Jardine sedately acquiescing.

He was undoubtedly an establishment man. With tongue in cheek (I think) he accosted me when he heard that I was going to start scribbling for this newspaper a decade ago: 'What are you doing working for that pinko rag?' In the corridors of power at Kent, where he served on the committee for decades, he would have been in favour of the likes of Chris Cowdrey and Matthew Fleming rather than the more proletarian Chris Tavare or Steve Marsh. In his last piece, which encompassed the men of influence of the last century, he included amateur stalwarts such as Lord Harris, Plum Warner, Gubby Allen and Harry Altham, men of his ilk. Raymond Illingworth was always unlikely to be included. But also there was Sir Frank Worrell.

Swanton was not so blinkered as many of his peers over the issue of South Africa. Throughout his lifetime he spent many happy months in Barbados, which may have contributed to his spotting the evils of apartheid sooner than many in the cricketing establishment.

He was stunned by the omission of Basil D'Oliveira in 1968 and after much agonising wrote that the 1970 tour of England by the South Africans should be called off. This was radical stuff for the Telegraph cricket correspondent. At an election party soon after at the Savoy, he recalled how the then deputy editor had expressed surprise at Swanton's smiling presence: 'Oh, I thought you had gone over to the enemy.'

Swanton remained an independent, quick-witted thinker to the end. From now on Cricketer board meetings will be gloomier affairs.

fields.headline: Gavin needs a break
fields.trailText: Gavin Hamilton's ankle problem could hardly have come at a more inopportune time.
fields.body:
Gavin Hamilton's ankle problem could hardly have come at a more inopportune time.

It ruled the Yorkshire all-rounder out of Thursday's warm-up match against the North West in Potchesfstroom on Thursday, and Wednesday's second game of the limited-overs series against South Africa in Cape Town may be his first chance to play in the triangular tournament.

After proudly appearing in the opening match of the Test series, Hamilton has not figured much on the South Africa tour - and he sees the one-day joust against the host nation and Zimbabwe as his chance of going home with something to remember.

Hamilton, 25, bagged a pair on his Test debut, while his 15 overs of seam went for 63 in South Africa's solitary innings.

He performed with credit for Scotland in last year's World Cup, but the Test arena proved to be a bit of a shock to the system, initially at least.

An aggregate of 217 runs at an average of 54.25 was an example of his potential to compete in the international arena but, as he points out, the pressures of playing for England are obviously much greater than pulling on a Scottish sweater.

'The one-dayers are mas sive for me now. I don't want to go back home having played just one Test and not featuring in the one-dayers,' said Hamilton.

'The next World Cup is the long-term goal. The one-dayers are a kind of redemption for me; I need to pull the tour round.

'It's not quite worked out for me, but the first four weeks of the tour went so well for me and it's only the last two months I've been kicked back down to earth.

'I need to try and get back up there because once you're out of the scene it's tough on tour because of the amount of games that limit you in terms of team selection.

'It was tough and I never experienced anything like it in that first Test. It just hit me like a storm, but I'm not going to change anything because I've come this far and I'll take it step by step.'

With Hamilton sidelined for Thursday's match, Yorkshire's Craig White - the replacement for the injured Andrew Flintoff - stole the moment to make an impression with a bristling 50 from 37 balls and must be a fair bet to play in the first match of the triangular tournament against South Africa in Bloemfontein today.

Worcestershire's Vikram Solanki, too, made out a case join him in the opener, after making a wristy 38 in Potchesfstroom.

Rolexed referees: Italians lose interest

While the Italian Football Federation and Fifa, the world body, continue top-level investigations into alleged Serie A bribery, reaction from media sources, and now top Italian psychologists, has been dismissive: it's not corruption, say the experts, it's a 'cultural nicety'.

The row, which ignited when Italian Soccer Federation president Luciano Nizzola ordered referees to return expensive gifts given to them by top clubs, was condemned last week by Franco Ferrarotti, a sociology professor at Rome's La Sapienza University. 'For years, messages of "Best wishes" were accompanied by a present,' says Ferrarotti. 'Heads of industry sent them to government bureaucrats, politicians sent them to journalists. It is an Italian custom'.

In this respect, he says, the 41 Rolexes given to refs by Roma owner Franco Sensi at a cost of £42,000 was quite 'normal.' Football federation spokesman Stefano Balducci has quietly agreed. 'It's the way things are done in Italy. We can't put a cap on gifts that teams give. But clubs should know when something goes beyond ethical bounds. A basket of fruit would be fine, because it's a basket of fruit. A gold watch crosses that line.'

Officially, though, the federation's investigations continue, as do those of Italian prosecutors who have made a tidy sum out of Serie A scandal in the past few years with football-tax evasion, the use of banned performance-enhancing substances, and attempts to fix matches chief among the cases. One team were even forced to defend accusations of providing prostitutes for referees before games.

Insiders, though, think the matter will be allowed to drop - and last week's shoulder-shrugging press agreed: Italy's three daily sports papers have now turned on Roma, but only for being found out.

'The moralistic mood will prevail for a while,' says Ferrarotti. 'But in the end it will be more superficial than substantive. The gifts will continue, just secretly.'

Sign on, sign on

Roy Evans Terry Fenwick and Denis Smith have joined a select group of out-of-work managers hoping to find a job via the internet.

The League Managers' Association have published CV's of the cream of the currently available talent: lists of honours, coaching qualifications and personal statements are available for 29 potential new bosses. And, in the fine tradition of CVs, all is sometimes not as it seems.

Terry Fenwick, for instance, although loathed at Portsmouth for helping bring the club to their knees during his spell in charge between February 1995 and January 1998, insists: 'I look back on my first managerial position as a real success. Despite the severe financial restrictions within the club, I was greatly able to reduce the club's financial deficit.' Fenwick then fails to mention his even more controversial spell at Crystal Palace - shortly after he left, Palace, like Portsmouth, entered administration.

Evans, meanwhile, is typically succinct with his statement - 'Thirty-five years at Liverpool during which time the club were the most successful in England and Europe' - but ex-Barnsley boss John Hendrie shows no sign of bitterness. 'I am a bubbly character with infectious enthusiasm. I'm a good organiser and very honest.' Lots more at www.leaguemanagers.com

Struggling Romanians sent dead pig

Cash-strapped Romanian second division club Olimpia Satu Mare have been given a pig and a calf by local sponsors after they ran out of money to buy food for their players.

According to local paper Gazeta Sporturilor: ' The pig was slaughtered and sent with other animals to a mountain resort for the team's winter training session.' Olimpia, like most of Romania's clubs, are facing a long-standing shortage of funds, coupled with sponsorship laws that discourage companies from getting involved. Last year, a goalkeeper moved to a rival club in exchange for a truck-load of firewood - and in 1998, another top team sold their best player for two tons of meat.

Own a blow-up Becks

It's time to lay off Becks. According to David's father, Beckham has become the most picked-on player in the history of British football. But now young fans have been handed an ideal chance to show support for their idol by buying this week's edition of FBX (For Boys eXclusively) Magazine , which is giving away free blow-up Beckham dolls to its young readers. At least the kids don't mock Becks and all he stands for... they'll cherish the dolls, won't they? Maybe not. 'What to do with your blow-up doll? FBX is offering readers a special prize for the funniest letter or picture.'

:david.hills@observer.co.uk

Tales from the tabs

£56M Rivaldo record transfer

Lazio are on the brink of a massive £36 million, £20m-salary deal to prise Rivaldo away from Barcelona - Alex Ferguson is ready should the talks falter.

Solly's worth the lolly, Sugar

Spurs boss George Graham has told Alan Sugar to start spending or lose Sol Campbell: Campbell wants a new £50,000 a week deal - Sugar isn't keen.

And the rest...

Arsène Wenger has slammed suggestions that Marc Overmars is about to leave Arsenal - 'The situation concerning Overmars is simple,' says Wenger. 'People announcing they are going to sign him are not serious'; Juventus have confirmed they are prepared to release Daniel Fonseca to any Premiership club willing to take him on loan; Spurs are ready to make a firm bid for Chris Sutton once Chelsea's European campaign ends; Gerard Houllier has ruled out making any Liverpool 'panic buys' to cover the absence of Robbie Fowler; Everton boss Walter Smith has warned he needs new players to keep the club safe from relegation; Bradford manager Paul Jewell plans to complete two signings this week; Derby have released Russell Hoult to Portsmouth on loan - but could be set to move for Bournemouth star Ian Cox; Everton have denied preparing a bid for Rangers' out of favour midfielder Jorg Albertz; Titi Camara's cousin Momo Camara is expected to sign for Leicester this week; Bryan Robson is chasing a mystery South American striker after deciding against a fresh bid for Palace's Matt Svensson; QPR midfielder Paul Murray is set to join Newcastle on loan with a view to a permanent move; Southampton are watching Norwegian full-back Alexander Aas of Odd Grenland; Tottenham are considering a summer move for Romanian international Constantin Galca; Forest's Gianluca Petrachi is set to join Perugia ; and Charlton have agreed a £1m deal for controversial Jamaican striker Ricardo Fuller of Tivoli Gardens.

fields.headline: Explain... disputed goals
fields.trailText: While Kevin Phillips still demands the credit for a goal he scored at Watford via a fortuitous deflection, the issue has ceased to matter to anyone but the player himself and Watford's Robert Page, who no doubt would be more than happy to see his own goal expunged from the records.
fields.body:
While Kevin Phillips still demands the credit for a goal he scored at Watford via a fortuitous deflection, the issue has ceased to matter to anyone but the player himself and Watford's Robert Page, who no doubt would be more than happy to see his own goal expunged from the records.

As far as the nation's punters are concerned, the issue is long forgotten. There is no industry standard when it comes to such decisions, but individual bookmakers decide for themselves a system for definitively identifying a goalscorer. So Ladbrokes go with whatever the Press Association say (that's an own goal in Phillips' case), while William Hill use whatever the majority of the nation's newspapers publish the following day. Most spread-betting organisations make up their own minds, presumably after watching Match of the Day. Either way, the issue is settled within hours of the end of the game.

'Sometimes the Press Association are forced to change their minds at a later date,' admits Ladbrokes' Sean Boyce, 'normally when the club are keen to award a goal to a particular player, and there have been occasions when we and other bookmakers have paid out for bets made on both [the player originally credited with the goal, and the player who later claims it], although that's something that we're keen to avoid.'

It is a recognised problem within the betting industry, which is unsatisfied with the current situation whereby two punters who place identical bets at different bookmakers could have varying degrees of success. The Independent Betting Arbitration Service are being set up to provide unbiased decisions.

But, more than money, it is the version that finds its way into the history books that is most important. In the case of disputed Premier League goals, there is a 'Disputed Goals Panel' (that's what they are generally referred to, rather than an official title) who meet irregularly to decide on such matters. Their first meeting of the season is due in the next few weeks, so, for poor Kevin Phillips, the wait is almost over.

webTitle: Viduka the main threat to Killie

fields.headline: Viduka the main threat to Killie
fields.trailText: Jason Thomas previews tonight's clash between Kilmarnock and Celtic.
fields.body:
The mid-winter break came at a bad time for Celtic, according to their head coach, John Barnes. However, if Barnes's fears about ring-rustiness are justified in tonight's clash with Kilmarnock at Rugby Park, it will clearly suit the opposition nicely for Celtic's striker Mark Viduka to be one of the men affected by it.

Viduka, of course, is the Celtic player who ended the first half of the season in the best form, as reflected by his Premier League player of the month award. Having scored a total of 19 goals this season - including a hat-trick in Celtic's 5-1 home win over Kilmarnock in October - he is also the player who has done the most to keep them in reasonable touching distance of Rangers at the top.

That Viduka has responded so well to the challenge of compensating for the loss of a scoring figure of Henrik Larsson's stature reflects creditably not just on his ability, but also his temperament.

In a Daily Record poll of Premier League defenders yesterday - on the rivalry between Viduka and his Australian counterpart at Rangers, Craig Moore, for the Premier League player of the year award - Dundee United's Jason De Vos puts it this way: 'The loss of Larsson has ironically proved to be the making of Viduka.

'All eyes were on him, with people wondering if he could fill such a gap, and he has done it in some style. You have to give him credit because the pressure was great.'

However, that pressure has been nothing compared with the turmoil he experienced when Celtic bought the 24-year-old Australian from Croatia Zagreb last season - a transfer that brought him so much abuse from Croatia fans that he went AWOL to his family's home in Melbourne and was barred from Celtic's winter-break base in Spain by Fergus McCann.

At that time, he even considered quitting the game and going into his father's construction business. 'I try not to think of that episode in my life,' he says. 'I prefer to concentrate on the positive things, and I would say that joining Celtic was the smartest thing I have ever done.'

Inevitably, the men he has played against since being installed as Celtic's main striker look on it rather differently. Kilmarnock's Under-21 international Jim Lauchlan, who is expecting to be handed the job of dealing with him today, says: 'One of the things which make him make him so difficult to play against is his upper body strength.

'They [Celtic] like to just roll the ball into him, and to be honest, there is nothing you can do to get the ball off him. You just cannot move him.'

As one might expect of a striker with his build, Viduka can appear sluggish. But as Lauchlan points out: 'He has quick feet.'

Viduka himself attributes his success over the past six months ('the best period of my career') simply to the higher level of training and coaching at Celtic. 'I have also got to know the other players better,' he adds.

The extent to which he has grown in confidence is perhaps best illustrated by his willingness to show his general ball- skills as well as his finishing ability. Referring to Celtic's habit of embellishing their biggest wins with seemingly arrogant tricks, he says: 'I really love it when we are three or four goals up, and I can relax and enjoy myself.

'If I see the opportunity do do a little trick, then I will take it. It is not as if I am looking to take the mickey out of anybody.'

For tonight's match, though, against a team in relegation trouble, nobody should be surprised if Viduka and Celtic have to settle for a more pragmatic approach to achieve their quest.

Barnes, pointing out that Kilmarnock have proved strong in defence, if not attack, says: 'We are going to have to show a lot of discipline and patience to break them down.'

Kilmarnock's manager, Bobby Williamson, whose team were unlucky to fall 1-0 to Celtic - through a late, hotly disputed Mark Burchill goal - in their last league meeting, at Rugby Park in September, says: 'We have some good players but we need to learn the lessons of what went on before the break. We have been playing well and creating chances, but have let ourselves down with one or two mistakes.

'People may say we have created unrealistic expectations over the last few years, but I don't see it that way.

'I have brought a few new players in to try and freshen things up, and injuries mean that the continuity of the last couple of seasons has been missing. But there is enough quality to improve our results and we will - don't worry about that.'

Williamson may be able to call on Gordon Marshall for the first time, after the former Celtic goalkeeper suffered a knee injury before the start of the season.

Wing-back Gus MacPherson is also set to return, but the fitness of new signing Tosh McKinlay will have to be assessed before he is granted a Kilmarnock debut against his old club after his move from Grasshoppers.

Also on the debit side, Ally McCoist, Dylan Kerr and Paul Wright have already been ruled out. 'But we are not moaning,' Williamson insists. 'We know we can give them a game.'

fields.headline: Twaddle makes sense for Motherwell
fields.trailText: St Johnstone, the team with the Premier League's worst home record - and the third worst in the country behind Clydebank and Albion Rovers - again left their McDiarmid followers frustrated yesterday when they were held to a 1-1 draw by Motherwell.
fields.body:
St Johnstone, the team with the Premier League's worst home record - and the third worst in the country behind Clydebank and Albion Rovers - again left their McDiarmid followers frustrated yesterday when they were held to a 1-1 draw by Motherwell.

This was St Johnstone's eighth successive home match without a win, and what made it particularly galling for them was that they were 1-0 ahead five minutes from the end.

The goal that put them ahead, scored by Graham Jones near the end of the first half, was hard luck on the Motherwell winger Kevin Twaddle, who had caused the Saints' defence a number of problems.

He continued to do so in the second half, notably in the 52nd minute when he hit the woodwork for the second time. But perhaps his best moment came in the 67th minute when he stopped Jones scoring again.

Jones looked certain to score when he found himself with the ball at his feet eight yards out from goal. But Twaddle, who had helped him create the chance by losing possession, got back to produce a decisive tackle.

Unfortunately for St Johnstone, Steve McMillan ensured that all his good work would not go in vain by equalising in the 85th minute.

If any team had cause to be confident of starting the second half of the Premier League programme with a victory, it was Dundee. They won all four of their matches against Hearts last season, and this season all but one of their six league wins have come away from home. Yes terday, though, the pattern was halted, with Hearts overcoming them 2-0.

The goal that put them in the right direction was a just reward for their willingness to adopt a positive attitude from the start. Hearts might easily have achieved the breakthrough after just seven minutes, when Darren Jackson sent a 25-yard shot just past the left post after good link-up play between Steve Fulton and Colin Cameron.

They went even closer when Scott Severin saw his close-range shot deflected on to the crossbar by a fine Robert Douglas save, and finally made a deserved breakthrough after 17 minutes through a clinical finish from Gary Wales.

At that point, Dundee brought themselves to life in attack, with Shaun McSkimming giving a demonstration of why they have been so dangerous on enemy territory with a 25-yard piledriver that hit the bar. But Hearts made it 2-0 through Darren Jackson in the 50th minute - courtesy of a terrible clearance from goalkeeper Robert Douglas.

Still, Douglas can claim that at least he stopped Hearts making it 3-0. Within 90 seconds of his boob, he produced the best save of the match, from Colin Cameron.

fields.headline: Transfers 'don't need medicals'
fields.trailText: Premiership football clubs could be buying players with serious illnesses and injuries without knowing it, according to senior figures within the game.
fields.body:
Premiership football clubs could be buying players with serious illnesses and injuries without knowing it, according to senior figures within the game.

For transfers no longer need medical clearance following a change in the rules by soccer's world governing body Fifa.

It is also claimed that increasing financial pressures on managers to get results means some are unwilling to make sufficient checks before deciding whether to complete signings, especially on players from abroad, while others are willing to conceal injuries to ensure transfers go through.

Transfer deals only used to be concluded once players had passed a rigorous examination by doctors. Such scrutiny led to many deals being called off at the eleventh hour.

But, after the case of Jean Marc Bosman - which won freedom of movement for players in Europe, Fifa has made a special amendment to its transfer regulations rendering the medical hurdle a thing of the past. It states: 'A transfer between clubs shall not be made subject to the positive results of a medical examination.'

Alan Hodson, the FA's chief medical officer, believes that managers are now willing to accept the new arrangements for business reasons. 'What are you going to do,' he asked, 'if a foreign player turns up to sign 24 hours before a transfer deadline without the proper medical papers? If he's good enough, you'll be tempted to sign him.'

Arsenal's Nigerian striker Nwankwo Kanu's move from Ajax to Inter Milan almost collapsed when he was diagnosed as suffering from a serious heart defect. The entire deal came close to being called-off and the problem was rectified through surgery and Kanu resumed his career.

For transfers no longer need medical clearance following a change in the rules by soccer's world governing body Fifa. It is also claimed that increasing financial pressures on managers to get results means some are unwilling to make sufficient checks before deciding whether to complete signings, especially on players from abroad, while others are willing to conceal injuries to ensure transfers go through. fields.headline: Post-Rio brio from Ferguson
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson's players will be hoping their warm-weather training will pay handsome dividends against Arsenal while the manager himself believes they are more than ready for a big game.
fields.body:
Jaap Stam would like to get one thing clear. 'People keep talking like we've been away on holiday,' he said. 'We haven't. We have been working very hard on the training pitch.'

Arsenal had better take note, not that Manchester United's winter break in Brazil has gone unnoticed in north London, because both Stam and his manager agree the defending champions are ready for a big game.

'Of course it is likely to be physical against Arsenal,' Stam said. 'We are prepared for that, and we are the sort of team who can play it both ways. We always set out to play football, but we don't have a problem if things get a little heated. It's part of the game and our team is full of players who can look after themselves. I think Arsenal are a little bit the same. Neither of us is willing to put up with being bullied.'

The Dutch defender is relatively new to this country, but it does not take long to appreciate that games between United and Arsenal tend to involve an extra bit of spice. A keen rivalry is natural given that the two clubs have dominated the past decade, but there are points to be scored at virtually every level of confrontation, and even the two managers, in their vastly different ways, enjoy winding each other up.

Arsène Wenger only made the briefest comment last week on United's good fortune in fixing up warm-weather training facilities for themselves while everyone else was taking part in the FA Cup, but Sir Alex Ferguson was ready and waiting with an answer. 'He's right,' said the United manager, not in the least defensively. 'We've had a great preparation for this match. A bit of sun, some really good training; the results might have been disappointing but it was still a great trip. I think there's a freshness to our team now and that could be important.'

Contrary to the impression given a fortnight ago, Manchester United will not receive an automatic invitation into next year's Club World Championship on the strength of their victory over Palmeiras in Tokyo last year. Fifa now intend to make an announcement in March concerning the venue and format of the next competition, and which teams might be taking part. Only two things are certain. One is that withdrawal from the FA Cup is not an option for English teams next season. The other is that Ferguson and United will still be keen to take part. 'We would be delighted to go back, wherever and whenever it is played,' Ferguson said. 'Someone said it might be in Tahiti next year, and we would definitely be up for that.'

A workaholic like Stam might detect a certain facetiousness here, but at least Ferguson is being consistent. He has always argued for a winter break, and he is not about to deny that Fifa have just handed exactly that to Manchester United. The only problem is that everyone else will soon want the same. 'People like myself have been talking about winter breaks for years,' Ferguson said. 'But the fact is that existing competitions are getting bigger. Fixtures are expanding everywhere you look, there are more internationals, more Champions League games and so on, so that top players are hardly getting a summer break any more, let alone a winter one.'

Something will have to give, but Ferguson is not saying what. Either that or he simply doesn't know. 'I don't want to give my own opinion because it's too controversial,' he said. 'Uefa would argue that the League should be reduced, they would like to see every country play a maximum of 34 games, but I think English football might be different from the rest. The Premiership is such an exciting league it might be hard to make a decision to reduce matches. I don't think it would be popular and I don't know who would vote for it. But I do think it's worth trying to take a break at this time of year. We have certainly felt the benefit in training. It's always difficult to judge how well the team is going when you have had a break from matches, but the lads are expecting a big game on Monday and they are ready for it.'

Arsenal realise defeat at Old Trafford would leave them too big a gap to close in their 15 remaining League games after tomorrow. Wenger might draw some comfort from the knowledge that one of United's games in hand is at Elland Road, but the other two are against Middlesbrough and Sheffield Wednesday, and will have been played within the next 10 days. 'We've acted quickly to fill in our blank dates,' Ferguson said. 'We don't want a backlog of fixtures when the Champions League starts up again. Potentially we have nine more Champions League games to play, I certainly hope we play that many, and with 19 Premiership matches left we have 28 games to fit into just over three months. So the Arsenal game is not really a crunch game in terms of the title because it comes a bit too early, but it should provide a better barometer as to how each club is placed.'

Arsenal are placed at a disadvantage by the absence of Tony Adams and virtually all their recognised strikers, though Ferguson does not expect anything less than a hard game. 'The roles are reversed from the game here two years ago when we were the ones missing a few important players,' he said. 'Arsenal won that day, but there was nothing between the sides. Arsenal are always going to be formidable, and though Arsène has added a few players to his squad, he still has a solid core of experience. You always have to work hard to win these matches, the main thing is to ensure you are ready for them, and this time I think we are.'

Stam certainly is. Team spirit is currently so high, he reckons, that not even Roy Keane's renegotiated wages are a subject of dressing-room discontent. To a man, the Manchester United players are behind their captain. 'When Roy agreed his deal everyone was really pleased for him, because we think he is worth it,' Stam said. 'But most of all we were pleased he was staying; we all enjoy playing alongside him.'

fields.headline: Irwin packs up
fields.trailText: Denis Irwin quit international football yesterday with a surprise announcement after winning 56 caps for the Republic of Ireland.
fields.body:
Denis Irwin quit international football yesterday with a surprise announcement after winning 56 caps for the Republic of Ireland.

Irwin, Manchester United's 34-year-old full-back, said he was retiring because he wanted to spend more time with his family.

'I'm quitting because of the time demands on international footballers nowadays,' he said. 'I've three young kids [Liam seven, Lauren four, and Katie, who is almost two] and I want to spend more time with them and my wife Jackie.'

Irwin said he informed the Republic of Ireland boss, Mick McCarthy, of his decision on Friday and he was 'very understanding' about it. McCarthy asked Irwin if he would stand by in case of an emergency, but Irwin declined: 'I said no. I want to make a clean break. I will be 37 when the next major finals come around and that's if Ireland qualify. Now is the best time to go.

'I've found in the past few years that I'm away from home a lot more due to the increasing number of games United are playing in Europe and more and more internationals.'

Irwin made his senior international debut on 12 September 1990 in a 1-0 friendly win against Morocco at Dalymount Park, having joined United from Oldham Athletic in July that year.

He was the first player to be capped at six levels, under-14, under-16, youth, under-21, B and senior.  Cheap exports of young players from third world countries to Britain and other major soccer nations could be stamped out, Fifa president Sepp Blatter said yesterday.

Blatter, visiting Ghana, co-host of the African Nations Cup which started yesterday, said Fifa wanted to introduce a minimum age for players before they could be sold by their original clubs. He is also against big clubs setting up training camps abroad to lure young talent .

'It is time to fight against the exodus of young players from Africa,' he said. 'It is not merely an African problem. It is a worldwide problem. Fifa is well aware of this.

'We have studied this problem and we are working on a solution. It's about creating an age limit before which a player can't be transferred.'

fields.headline: Dyer's higher calling
fields.trailText: Barnsley 5 - 1 Blackburn
fields.body:
Barnsley gave their promotion rivals a sharp dig in the ribs with this emphatic win over in-form Blackburn. This Barnsley side looks better than the one which won them promotion three years ago. It has more pace, more skill in attack and a more effective midfield in which the muscular Robin Van Der Laan is outstanding.

Four goals in the first 33 minutes set Blackburn on their heels and their manager, Tony Parkes, was honest enough to acknowledge that his side 'were not at the races'.

He added: 'We were poor, we defended badly. If Barnsley had wanted to score more they could have done.'

The goals came in quick succession. After only four minutes a corner from Darren Barnard was partially cleared and came to Van Der Laan on the edge of the area. He hit a fierce volley that crashed onto the underside of the bar and may even have crossed the line. Not to worry, it bounced out to Bruce Dyer and he headed in with Alan Kelly stranded.

Four minutes later Rovers were level. Per Frandsen, having been impeded, got up and hit the free-kick through the Barnsley defensive wall from 25 yards and past a stranded Kevin Miller.

On the quarter hour Barnsley regained the lead. Good work by Neil Shipperley running across the Rovers' defence set up Craig Hignett for a shot which hit Kelly's legs. Hignett made no mistake from the rebound.

Then Shipperley himself scored. Barnard's dipping cross from the left was dummied by Dyer, allowing Shipperley to shimmy past Christian Dailly to leave himself a clear chance from five yards.

Number four was scored by Barnard - once again after good work by Dyer. Barnard carried the ball past two players before making enough room for a left-foot shot that gave Kelly no chance. Unhappily for Barnsley, Barnard injured himself in the process.

The second half was nothing like as entertaining. Blackburn looked to have self-preservation rather than aggression on their minds though Miller was called on to make splendid saves from Damien Duff and Nathan Blake and finally from Blake again, pushing a close range header past the post. Hard as Peacock and Jason McAteer worked to keep their side on the move it was Barnsley who were to score again. This time a through ball from Nicky Eaden reached Dyer who, given far too much time and space, turned his low shot past Kelly's right hand.

fields.headline: Hunt sinks Canaries
fields.trailText: Norwich 0 - 3 Charlton
fields.body:
Andy Hunt made a triumphant return to his former home county yesterday when his hat-trick took Charlton four points clear at the top of Division One. Hunt opened the scoring against the run of play just before the break and struck twice in the space of five minutes late in the second half to secure a sixth successive league win for Alan Curbishley's side.

The margin of victory flattered the visitors, however, and had Norwich managed to capitalise on their early domination, the outcome could have been very different.

The Norwich manager, Bruce Rioch, summed up the game when he said, 'We've gone out there and played really well and yet lost. I think everyone watching would agree it was never a 3-0 game, but sometimes matches go that way. Charlton took their chances and we didn't and that was the deciding factor in the end.'

Hunt, who had an unsuccessful trial with the Carrow Road side in the early Nineties, opened the scoring on 42 minutes, sidefooting home Graham Stuart's in-swinging corner from close range, his half-volley going in off the crossbar.

He struck again on 73 minutes to put the game beyond the battling home side, with Robinson again the provider, his astute ball from the halfway line putting his col league in the clear. Hunt's first effort went through the half-hearted block of the goalkeeper Andy Marshall before trickling into the net. Four minutes later Hunt's triumph, and Norwich's misery, was complete as the in-form frontman - and Charlton's leading goal scorer - made it 3-0, heading home a right-wing cross from Robinson who completed a hat-trick of assists.

The late goals were rough justice on the Canaries who had dominated the early part of the game against a strangely out-of-sorts Charlton, who struggled to get to grips with the late withdrawal of skipper Mark Kinsella with a stomach bug.

'I had a right blast at them at half-time,' said the manager, Alan Curbishley. 'I gave them a few days off and they looked very sluggish but, fortunately, Dean Kiely made some good saves early on. In the end, we scored our goals at the right time and I'm delighted to have got the points, even though we didn't play as well as we can.'

Kiely made four good stops before the break, the best on 19 minutes when he dived bravely at the feet of Iwan Roberts during a frantic goalmouth scramble. Five minutes later the Norwich top scorer wasted his side's clearest chance of the match as he sidefooted wide of an open goal.

Norwich continued to look the better side and had chances to draw level in the second half, one Matt Jackson effort being headed off the line by Stuart. But Charlton's defence weathered the storm and kept their hopes of an immediate return to the Premiership very much alive.

webTitle: Time to celebrate as England blow Proteas away

fields.headline: Time to celebrate as England blow Proteas away
fields.trailText: England began the one-dayers as they did the Test series: plucky underdogs blooding three blushing debutants - this time Vikram Solanki, Chris Read and Graeme Swann. But here, thankfully, any similarity ends. Today England beat - walloped - South Africa. And, unlike the South Africans at Jo'burg, they didn't even win the toss.
fields.body:
England began the one-dayers as they did the Test series: plucky underdogs blooding three blushing debutants - this time Vikram Solanki, Chris Read and Graeme Swann. But here, thankfully, any similarity ends. Today England beat - walloped - South Africa. And, unlike the South Africans at Jo'burg, they didn't even win the toss.

On a slow pitch which helped all the bowlers, the South African top order were blown away and, for once, their elongated batting order couldn't quite make up the lost ground. Gough got Kirsten in his first over, and Benkenstein and Cronje in his fourth. If there was some luck in Cronje's downfall, there was none in that of Jacques Kallis, bowled with a beauty on Gough's return when he was threatening a lynch-pinning hundred. Gough's coltish, bounding, eagerness was back, as was his variation - the off-cutter and the trademark reverse-swing. Andy Caddick was miserly, and also held a fantastic diving catch to get rid of Strydom, while Craig White picked up three wickets in his first England appearance since March 1997. The measure of England's command was that the world's greatest one-day hitter, Lance Klusener, got his first ten runs in singles, and was caught in the deep as soon as he broke the shackles. He made 27, a score that any opposing captain would be happy to give him.

If you were being picky, you'd say that England took their foot off the accelerator in the middle overs. From 23 for 4, South Africa should never have been allowed to reach 184. It was also a shame that Hussain didn't let Graeme Swann bowl his full quota. Though his penchant for bowling Hick paid off (with the wicket of Klusener), he should have given Swann more of a chance to get over his nerves, especially as he extracted more turn in five overs than Tufnell did in the entire Test series. One ball in Swann's first over pitched 18 inches outside off stump, spun past leg and went for four byes past the bemused Read.

South Africa had recovered from low totals before - 199 was more than enough against Sri Lanka in the World Cup. But this time the bowlers, deprived of Allan Donald, couldn't do it. After a slow start against the ginga ninjas Pollock and Terbrugge, Nick Knight and Hussain boxed very cleverly, their powerful lofted strokes some consolation for a seriously disillusioned crowd. Knight's soft-shoe shuffle made you ask yet again: just why was it that he didn't he play a single World Cup game? They added 165 - more than any pair of openers had ever managed against South Africa in a one-dayer (and they play a lot of them).

While these two put on their caps and enjoyed themselves, the South Africans, especially Cronje, looked furious. They can't have been expecting England to give them much of a run for their money, let alone a sound thrashing (by nine wickets with more than ten overs in hand). South Africa had won 11 of the previous 13 matches between the sides and are, at least, the second-best one-day side around. England hadn't played an ODI since the World Cup, where they covered themselves in contempt. And South Africa were the team with continuity and experience: even without Donald, Rhodes and Cullinan, they had seven survivors from their last World Cup match to England's four.

So hooray. A victory this big will, and deserves to be, a real morale-booster for England. But one boring note of caution. There was once a triangular tournament in Australia, which England started off brilliantly, winning four of their first five matches - only to lose six of the next seven. It was this time last year.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears here every Tuesday.

But here, thankfully, any similarity ends. Today England beat - walloped - South Africa. And, unlike the South Africans at Jo'burg, they didn't even win the toss. On a slow pitch which helped all the bowlers, the South African top order were blown away and, for once, their elongated batting order couldn't quite make up the lost ground. Gough got Kirsten in his first over, and Benkenstein and Cronje in his fourth. If there was some luck in Cronje's downfall, there was none in that of Jacques Kallis, bowled with a beauty on Gough's return when he was threatening a lynch-pinning hundred. Gough's coltish, bounding, eagerness was back, as was his variation - the off-cutter and the trademark reverse-swing. Andy Caddick was miserly, and also held a fantastic diving catch to get rid of Strydom, while Craig White picked up three wickets in his first England appearance since March 1997. The measure of England's command was that the world's greatest one-day hitter, Lance Klusener, got his first ten runs in singles, and was caught in the deep as soon as he broke the shackles. He made 27, a score that any opposing captain would be happy to give him. If you were being picky, you'd say that England took their foot off the accelerator in the middle overs. From 23 for 4, South Africa should never have been allowed to reach 184. It was also a shame that Hussain didn't let Graeme Swann bowl his full quota. Though his penchant for bowling Hick paid off (with the wicket of Klusener), he should have given Swann more of a chance to get over his nerves, especially as he extracted more turn in five overs than Tufnell did in the entire Test series. One ball in Swann's first over pitched 18 inches outside off stump, spun past leg and went for four byes past the bemused Read. South Africa had recovered from low totals before - 199 was more than enough against Sri Lanka in the World Cup. But this time the bowlers, deprived of Allan Donald, couldn't do it. After a slow start against the ginga ninjas Pollock and Terbrugge, Nick Knight and Hussain boxed very cleverly, their powerful lofted strokes some consolation for a seriously disillusioned crowd. Knight's soft-shoe shuffle made you ask yet again: just why was it that he didn't he play a single World Cup game? They added 165 - more than any pair of openers had ever managed against South Africa in a one-dayer (and they play a lot of them). While these two put on their caps and enjoyed themselves, the South Africans, especially Cronje, looked furious. They can't have been expecting England to give them much of a run for their money, let alone a sound thrashing (by nine wickets with more than ten overs in hand). South Africa had won 11 of the previous 13 matches between the sides and are, at least, the second-best one-day side around. England hadn't played an ODI since the World Cup, where they covered themselves in contempt. And South Africa were the team with continuity and experience: even without Donald, Rhodes and Cullinan, they had seven survivors from their last World Cup match to England's four. So hooray. A victory this big will, and deserves to be, a real morale-booster for England. But one boring note of caution. There was once a triangular tournament in Australia, which England started off brilliantly, winning four of their first five matches - only to lose six of the next seven. It was this time last year. Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears here every Tuesday.

webTitle: Boo boys turn on goal-shy Fulham

fields.headline: Boo boys turn on goal-shy Fulham
fields.trailText: That Fulham are one of eight Nationwide League teams in next weekend's FA Cup fifth round did not count for much among their fans when a 1-0 home defeat by Grimsby led to Kevin Keegan's old team being booed off the field.
fields.body:
That Fulham are one of eight Nationwide League teams in next weekend's FA Cup fifth round did not count for much among their fans when a 1-0 home defeat by Grimsby led to Kevin Keegan's old team being booed off the field.

Fulham have not scored in the league since November. Even with Geoff Horsfield and Barry Hayles missing, it was surprising that they even failed to do so against a team with the First Division's worst defensive record.

Little wonder that Fulham's manager, Paul Bracewell, a man who does not come across as the life and soul of the party at the best of times, seemed particularly intense on this occasion.

'If you have good chances and don't take them, you don't win games,' he pointed out. 'Grimsby had one half-chance and they took it [through Jack Lester from Kevin Donovan's cross n the 56th minute]. At the moment we just need to stick a goal away. But this is where we find out who is with us.'

Manchester City manager Joe Royle, whose team lost by the same score at Sheffield United - and fell four points behind Charlton at the top - was in a similarly gloomy mood. City, who beat United 6-0 at home in August, rarely tested United goalkeeper Simon Tracey, and Royle admitted: 'I am desperately disappointed. This was easily our worst performance of the season.'

The irony of the defeat was that the decisive goal came from midfielder Michael Brown - his first since being signed by United from City earlier this month. Moreover, United were also helped by an excellent performance by striker Alex Notman, who is on loan to them from... Manchester United.

But it was Brown who pleased United's manager, Neil Warnock, the most. 'He covered every blade of grass and looked a quality player,' Warnock enthused. 'What also delighted me was his discipline. He was at Manchester City for a long time - he loved the club - and I did not want him to make a fool of himself.'

While Charlton were gaining their sixth successive win, Ipswich stretched their unbeaten run to 13 matches with a 1-1 draw at Bolton. They had to come from behind for the point - clinched with a Matt Holland goal five minutes from the end - and their manager, George Burley, was more than satified with that return if only because of the conditions. He said: 'It wasn't the type of pitch where we could knock the ball across the back because there was hardly any grass on it.

'It's okay having new stadiums but surely one of the most important things is to get the pitch right. However, the surface wasn't great for either side and you just have to get on with it.'

Rotherham be leading the Third Division, but the team attracting the most attention are Swansea, who established a club record of eight successive wins by overcoming Macclesfield 1-0.

That scoreline, which brought them their 14th clean sheet of the season - is typical of Swansea. Referring to their high number of 1-0 wins, their manager John Hollins, under intense fire from the fans when his team were struggling just a few months ago, joked: 'We do like to keep them on the edge of their seats. Actually, even when I talk about our matches, I get knackered.'

No doubt, it is the same for Swansea's goalkeeper, Roger Freestone, the player Hollins singles out as having played the biggest part in their transformation.

Freestone, 31, was originally brought to Chelsea from Newport when Hollins was manager at Stamford Bridge, but made little more than 50 first-team appearances there in four years before signing for Swansea in 1991. 'I was only 18 when I left Newport, and was too naive,' he says. 'I just was not strong enough. You do need to be strong with people - Peter Schmeichel is a perfect example - and it is only since I came back to Wales that I have acquired this characteristic.'

However, even for Freestone, Swansea's habit of winning matches by the slenderest of margins can be hard to take.

'My nine-year-old son is starting to play football now and is showing quite a lot of ability as a goalie,' he says. 'But I would much rather that he was an outfield player. When you are in a team who do not score a lot olf goals, goalkeeping can be a horrible position sometimes.'

webTitle: Old Firm may cut and run if England get World Cup

fields.headline: Old Firm may cut and run if England get World Cup
fields.trailText: Scottish football is facing a fight that will make the Battle of Bannockburn look like the Highland Games.
fields.body:
With Scottish Premier League - like Manchester United - having had a winter break you would have thought that apart from a few boring pictures of Celtic and Rangers players sunbathing in the Med with topless women there would have been little for the Scottish papers to report. You would have been wrong. Scottish football is facing a fight that will make the Battle of Bannockburn look like the Highland Games.

James Alexander Gordon will now have to learn two new names to read out on Saturday's Sports Report , Elgin and Peterhead. These two Highland League teams have been voted into the Scottish League to replace the two extra teams going into the Premier League next season. They haven't got there because they are the best teams: they aren't. What counts is the size of their grounds and number of supporters.

In fact half of the teams in the Scottish first division are not eligible for promotion simply because they do not have 10,000 all-seat stadiums. Such rules mean that whole regions of Scotland such as the Borders don't even have a league team to support. Borders team Gala have once again failed the entry test so local kids who have turned their backs on rugby union in droves have no big games to go to.

The Highland League have lost five of their teams to the Scottish League in recent years, yet this so-called promotion is no guarantee of financial success as Inverness Caledonian Thistle have found out. Having merged two Inverness clubs and built a new stadium they are holding their own in the first division.

According to the local papers, however, Inverness are said to be more than £2 million in the red. The problem is that the Inverness punters have hardly come out in their droves to watch their new team. Walking through the streets of Inverness at Christmas I never saw any one in a 'Cally' shirt. In fact most of the kids and older blokes were wearing Celtic or Rangers shirts, and the two lads sitting behind me at the game against Clydebank wore Rangers scarves. Given the problems that Inverness have faced, it's surprising that the Highland League teams are so keen to join the Scottish League.

The Old Firm want to do precisely the opposite. We all know that Rangers and Celtic could fill Ibrox or Parkhead even if they were playing a pub team. The problem is that such fixtures don't bring any TV money and that's essential if the two big clubs want to compete with the best in Europe. Even the ratings for the Old Firm games shown live on Sky are well below those of English Premiership matches. The big two are now beginning to think the unthinkable, leaving their own domestic league.

Talk has resurfaced recently about the setting up of a new 'Atlantic League' with the big teams in Holland and Belgium. The Glasgow teams think that their future lies outside Scotland and they know that TV will be far more interested in Rangers v Ajax or Celtic v PSV Eindhoven than games against Inverness Caledonian Thistle.

The new league is a serious proposition, but the real end game for the Old Firm is entry into the English Premiership. There are already plans for Celtic and Rangers to pay the Scottish League compensation for their loss, but there is one big obstacle in their way. That, of course, is the old problem of Britain having four football teams and our proper reluctance to give that up. The age-old argument is that if Scottish teams play in the English League then we would have to have a British team.

People forget that we have Welsh teams in the English League and yet Wales still have a separate national team. This argument is even weaker now that Uefa have allowed international status to anyone who wants it.

The hot word in Glasgow is that Rangers and Celtic will make their move as soon as England have been awarded the right to hold the 2006 World Cup, which is now looking odds on. No one will dare suggest a British team then. The big English clubs are all very keen to let the Scottish teams in, knowing that they will not only guarantee sell-out gates but also the much-needed TV revenue.

Scottish fans may not like to lose their two biggest clubs to England, any more than we like the Champions League, but if they all supported their local clubs like Inverness Caledonian Thistle then it probably wouldn't happen.

fields.headline: Only a game? Rubbish
fields.trailText: Friday proved to be another bad day for Luddites as Subbuteo was axed because of increased competition from computer games. Talk about childish.
fields.body:
Friday proved to be another bad day for Luddites as Hasbro announced that they will no longer manufacture Subbuteo because of increased competition from computer games. Talk about childish.

Their argument that the emergence of a spate of silly little games involving diddy men running around on a TV screen to the accompaniment of a commentary by Barry Davies could ever threaten the age-old craft of crawling around the carpet and flicking very realistic miniature footballers around a piece of green baize to the accompaniment of one's own commentary is so patently absurd that it doesn't merit contradiction. So what if sales have slumped marginally. Are there no businessmen left with sufficient gumption to take a long-term view?

Like many adherents, my first Subbuteo set was the Continental Club edition - reproducing all the thrills of real football by FINGERTIP CONTROL with 00 SCALE self-balancing teams, goals, balls, players, pitch etc.

It was 1970, it cost £3.50 and provided more than a decade of pleasure. My first game was against Dad - he was United, I was City - and won by him 4-3 in extra-time after a hotly disputed penalty. Where, oh where, was Andy Gray and his video recorder when you needed him? It was a poor decision and not without repercussions. I never played my Dad, or indeed anyone else, ever again.

For the next 10 years, my Subbuteo habit was a solitary one. I was more than content to play the game they were calling 'chess with commentary' on my own. At the epicentre of entertainment was Frampton City (see graphic) who were - years before Elton John - owned by the guitar hero Peter Frampton, and - years before Man. United - won Trebles for fun. What a team. Think of Tony Bullshot, regular winner of the European Golden Boot. And Didi Sumatra, 'the Hummingbird of Juventus'. And, of course, Big Ron Huddlestone. And Oak, and Price, and Drago.... Heroes every one.

There were bad times. Few of the Frampton faithful will forget when a vengeful younger sister encroached on the pitch during a crucial game against Aston Villa and trod on McCool, breaking both his legs above the shin. It was the end for McCool. Subjected to endless hours of debilitating Airfix-glue treatment, he emerged a less enthusiastic, and considerably shorter, man. Glue is notoriously difficult to get off and - years before Paul Merson - McCool would become a victim of substance abuse.

But the good times easily outweighed them. I spent hours, no years, on my hands and knees re-enacting entire league championships. It was a time-consuming business. Leaving aside the actual playing there was an entire set of comprehensive statistics to be kept up-to-date - years before Carling Opta - and the weekly Frampton City programme to be produced, complete with forthright column from Peter Frampton entitled 'On the Carpet'.

Inevitably, given Frampton City's domination of the domestic scene, I turned my attention to the international game and the workload just got heavier. God knows the amount of time I spent listening to Radio 2 waiting for national anthems to be played so I could tape them and replay them before the start of each international. Jean Metcalfe's Family Favourites - for our boys overseas - proved to be especially productive in this regard.

Healthwise, playing Subbuteo with myself for such a long period had some damaging side-effects. Anyone who has spent their adolescence crawling around carpets will be aware that, in later life, your knees become puffy, red and arthritic.

The mental memories associated with the game were potentially even more acute. These arose because if, say, Blatter is taking a penalty with one hand while Bonetti or Sprake tries to save it with the other knowing which way he is intending to kick it the whole business lacks any element of surprise. To overcome this it was necessary to develop a personality so comprehensively split that your left hand did not know what your right hand was doing. A personality, that medically speaking, might be termed as advanced paranoid schizophrenia.

On the plus side, anyone who has played Subbuteo to county standard will attest that when they finally put away their little men and go out and meet real women they will have no difficulty handling a clitoris. No such skills can be gleaned by wasting your time on a Playstation Control Pad.

As I reached puberty, I began to accessorise. I bought more and more stands to enable Frampton to play at one of the first all-seater stadiums in the country. The team were cheered on by ever-increasing hordes of miniature plastic fans. And, at the height of my game, I invested in a two-and-a-half inch - three times the Subbuteo average height - specialist throw-in taker.

This rampant materialism - take note Man United, Arsenal, Chelsea et al - was to lead to the downfall of Frampton City.

It was a rainy night at Roker and Frampton needed a win to clinch their ump-teenth consecutive League Championship. Utilising the over-sized thrower, Trodden propelled a throw-in from way inside his own half some 50 yards down the pitch and on to Bullshot's head. He was standing 30 yards from goal, but such was the pace of the throw that the ball deflected off his trusty forehead and rocketed into the top corner of the net. All goal competitions ceased. I leant over to celebrate with Tony, slipped, and fell horribly on the pitch. Ker-runch. An entire team was wiped out in an instant. Little shards of plastic littered the green baize. Frampton City, and I, would never play again.

fields.headline: Wilson revival continues
fields.trailText: Tottenham 0 - 1 Sheff Wed
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
For all those in relegation peril, the formula for a change in fortunes has become clear. Watford will probably be at this very moment composing a letter to their MP begging him to criticise the club's management.

With their second consecutive Premiership win since the four Sheffield Members spoke up, Wednesday climbed off the bottom of the table for the first time since last August, their confidence stoked by a worsening Tottenham Hotspur team, whose season is in danger of declining rapidly after a promising start.

The pattern for the game was immediately visible, with Wednesday content to let Tottenham pass the ball around until they reached the attacking third of the pitch before seeking to break up the movement and attempting to steal a goal on the counter.

It was no bad strategy although it relied on Pavel Srnicek being on form when Spurs did find a way through, usually via David Ginola's crossing or Darren Anderton's neat one-touch passing through midfield.

The goalkeeper duly excelled himself. He was, though, grateful to see the ball go wide after Stephen Clemence had seized on Alan Quinn's poor clearance and set up a chance for Chris Armstrong, whose backheel looped up for Anderton to glance off target.

Grateful, too, when a flowing move between Clemence and Anderton set up Ginola only for his curling shot to thump down off the bar. From the rebound, Srnicek turned aside Iversen's shot at his near post, as he also did with Armstrong's shot soon afterwards.

When Wednesday did break out, there were warning signs, usually via the precise passing of Wim Jonk. First he set up Ian Nolan for a drive that was just wide, then found Gilles De Bilde for a volley that was hooked straight at Ian Walker. Third time lucky. After Gerard Sibon had neatly touched on Quinn's ball in from the left, Jonk teed up Niclas Alexandersson and he calmly sidefooted Wednesday into a sucker-punch lead.

Watford will probably be at this very moment composing a letter to their MP begging him to criticise the club's management. fields.headline: United fail to impress
fields.trailText: Dundee United 0 - 0 Hibernian
fields.body:
The Scottish winter break was extended by an extra week as Dundee United and Hibernian produced a tame, goalless draw at Tannadice.

Both sides had enjoyed recent trips to warmer climes and gave every indication they wished they were still enjoying the sun.

Certainly a chilly afternoon on Tayside was of little interest, with United unable to bounce back from the December stutter which has threatened their hopes of Uefa Cup qualification.

Kenny Miller's fourth-minute effort and a good save by Nick Colgan from Antoine Preget were the briefest of highlights in a contest which failed to ignite passion from either set of supporters.

Dundee United went into the match having lost three of their last four games before the break and were looking for a swift revival.

Alex Mathie was brought in for his first start of the season after a three-month loan at Preston; Icelandic defender Siggi Jonsson was back after a toe injury; but £150,000 new boy Jim Hamilton had to be content with a place on the bench.

For Hibs, the 18-year-old midfielder Ian Murray made his surprise debut and Paul Lovering was back after three months out with a knee injury.

Both teams began eagerly but much of the early play was too fast to be cohesive. Kenny Miller made a couple of fine runs off the ball for Hibs and Alan Combe was forced to make a save after Miller ran on to a Mixu Paatelainen pass into the area.

At the other end, Nick Colgan collided with Steven Thompson when the Hibs keeper came out to save from Preget, who had latched on to Thompson's header from Jason de Vos's chipped free-kick.

But, basically with too many interruptions from the referee's whistle, the game lacked any flow.

After such a mind-numbing start, the crowd were scarcely able to believe the flurry of three shots in as many minutes with which the home side opened the second period.

Thompson forced Colgan into making the save of the match when he fired in from the edge of the area.

When Hibs' Russell Latapy was withdrawn on the hour, a victim of his exertions for Trinidad against Morocco in midweek, the game lost one of its most creative forces.

But still it was Combe who was having to make the most telling saves.

Mathie went close for United when he ran on to a short back-pass from Mathias Jack, only to see Colgan save his effort. It was his last contribution before Hamilton made his entrance.

Joaquim Ferraz followed as a replacement for Thompson. But the new-look strike-force could not revive a game which had long since passed beyond any form of life.

fields.headline: Saints punish Everton
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 0 Everton
fields.body:
Everton unwittingly eased the pressure on their former player, Southampton's manager Dave Jones, by falling to their first defeat in nine games and handing the Saints only their second win in the same period.

It was appropriate that Everton's defending, which might be described in football parlance as criminal, was punished by a former policeman, Jo Tessem, who gave Southampton the lead early in the second half.

And it was another defensive mistake that allowed midfielder Matthew Oakley to make it 2-0 and effectively seal victory ten minutes later as Everton paid the price for failing to make the most of their chances and being over-ambitious in defence.

Steve Simonsen, on after only six minutes for his Premiership debut after Paul Gerrard had collided with Kevin Davies, had little chance with either goal, as Southampton quickly established a two-goal lead within 12 minutes of the restart.

Both goals were the result of kamikaze defending from Everton. After 47 minutes, David Unsworth sent a casual clearance from his own penalty area straight to Davies, who teed up Tessem for a shot which flew in from 25 yards, with Simonsen getting a hand to the ball but unable to stop it.

Ten minutes later it was Richard Dunne's turn to foul up, as the Everton right-back went on a suicidal run out of defence. It ended inevitably with Southampton winning the ball back and breaking with numerical advantage, allowing Matt Oakley to fire another long-range shot past Simonsen.

Everton almost hit back immediately, with Kevin Campbell having a diving header tipped over the bar by Jones, and then denied by a superb tackle from the outstanding Dean Richards. Don Hutchison had a first-time shot through a crowd of players well saved by Jones, while at the other end Pahars had a shot saved by Simonsen and then shot wide of the far post.

Campbell shot just wide in the closing stages, John Collins had a shot brilliantly saved by Jones, and Francis Jeffers put a header straight into the goalkeeper's hands from close range as Everton staged a late rally, but the result was never in doubt.
