webTitle: Paulo strikes back to silence critics

fields.headline: Paulo strikes back to silence critics
fields.trailText: Leicester 1 - 3 West Ham
fields.body:
What a difference a week makes. Paulo Wanchope, hammered for his glaring miss against Aston Villa, was the toast of West Ham yesterday after two goals gave his side their first Premiership victory since November 27.

They were too good for a Leicester side who simply ran out of resources and steam after their recent cup exploits. With Tommy Goodwin, a 19-year-old defender making his debut, Leicester initially started well. Emile Heskey was denied by a save low down by Shaka Hislop, while both Stuart Campbell and Theo Zagorakis were not far away with equally firm drives.

However, against the early run of play, it was West Ham who went ahead through the much-maligned Wanchope, who slid the ball home after patient build up had produced a neat through ball from Frank Lampard.

It was Wanchope's first goal for three months. Not to be outdone Heskey replied with his first goal since late November, but this time it was all his own effort. The big man made space for himself just outside the penalty box before beating Hislop with a thumping low shot.

While this was happening Joe Cole lay prone in the Leicester penalty box and before play restarted after the goal Paolo Di Canio looked to be having a word with the referee, David Elleray, as to why he had not called a halt as soon as Cole went down.

Whether Hislop was injured trying to keep Heskey's goal out was unclear, but West Ham were forced to replace their goalkeeper two minutes later with Craig Forrest. Steve Lomas was another casualty after a challenge by Zagorakis, and his injury looked a severe one. A stretcher was called immediately Lomas went down in what did not look a bad challenge.

West Ham regained the lead in first half injury time, Wanchope chasing the ball as it came loose to the left of the Leicester goal and slipping it past Pegguy Arphexad from an angle.

Heskey spurned the chance of a second equaliser after seizing onto a miss hit back pass from Marc Keller and West Ham took full advantage to go 3-1 ahead. Substitute Michael Carrick played in Wanchope, who set up his striking partner Di Canio to fire into the bottom corner.

fields.headline: Owen left hamstrung
fields.trailText: Liverpool 0 - 0 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Middlesbrough appear to be stirring from their sick bed but the agony continues for Liverpool. Kevin Keegan was at this game to see Michael Owen last 28 minutes before succumbing to yet another hamstring injury.

Just two games into his fourth comeback in under a year, Owen stayed down in the penalty area after attempting to reach a cross from Vladimir Smicer and immediately signalled he would have to come off. With Robbie Fowler out for two months Liverpool's attacking prospects now look bleak, as do England's.

Bryan Robson wants Middlesbrough fans to show patience and judge him at the end of the season, and on this evidence that seems fair enough, although the amount of patience required could be gargantuan.

Presumably with damage limitation in mind after their horror show at home to Derby last week, the visitors turned up with five men strung across the back and Paul Ince and his two midfield partners sitting just in front. Perhaps the point gained justified the unappealing sight of eight purple shirts clustered behind the ball, but eventually even Juninho will lose patience if his team insist on being so umambitious.

With Hamilton Ricard dropped to substitute, the Brazilian was mostly marooned upfield with just Andy Campbell for company, yet though Liverpool poured forward, it was revealing that Mark Schwarzer had nothing to do in the first half whereas Sander Westerveld had to make two crucial interventions.

The first should stand the Dutch goalkeeper in good stead should he wish to try a new career as a centre-half. After 20 minutes Juninho played Ince through but either through surprise at the flag staying down or vertigo at being caught so far upfield the former Liverpool captain halted momentarily, whereupon Westerveld came miles out of his area to dispossess him with a perfect sliding tackle.

The Kop enjoyed that, just as they roared approval when a peeved Ince was booked seconds later for a foul on Smicer, but the home supporters were already fretting at the paucity of chances being created from overwhelming possession when Owen's injury deepened the gloom. The silence was so marked that half the ground must have heard his resigned shout of 'hamstring' to the Liverpool bench.

The considerably less threatening Erik Meijer was sent on as substitute, more in hope than expectation, and Liverpool continued to look to each other in vain for ideas. Gerrard was lively, and Smicer showed some skilful if inconclusive touches, but even though Boro were only doing about two per cent of the attacking their incisiveness almost embarrassed the home side. Juninho brought a diving save from Westerveld and might have done even better had he managed to bring the ball to the ground more quickly.

Owen might have had a goal in the 17th minute but for alert defending by Gary Pallister, but the best Liverpool could manage in his absence were a couple of Patrik Berger long shots and a strike on the turn by Smicer which rolled a foot wide of Schwarzer's right-hand post with Meijer arriving fractionally too late to steer it in.

It said much about Liverpool that for much of the match Sami Hyypia looked their most likely scorer, although they threw everything at their opponents in the closing seconds.

Whatever was bothering Boro last week, their commitment on this occasion could not be faulted.

fields.headline: Moore begins rout
fields.trailText: Rangers 5 - 0 Aberdeen
fields.body:
Rangers marked the restart of the Premier League campaign by moving seven points clear at the top yesterday.

This emphatic victory against the bottom of the table side shifts the pressure onto Celtic, who face Kilmarnock today.

Rangers took a grip of the game in the nine minutes before the break with three goals. Aberdeen had little answer and had it not been for veteran keeper Jim Leighton they could have been more seriously embarrassed.

Rangers began at a fierce pace and former Scotland keeper Leighton reacted superbly in the 11th minute to block a fierce shot from van Bronckhorst. He then did well to hold onto a fierce 25-yard shot from Jorg Albertz and then Rangers skipper Lorenzo Amoruso knocked a long-range effort just wide of the target.

Rod Wallace should have put the home side ahead after good running by Arthur Numan but his finish was wasteful.

The pressure finally told and Rangers raced into a two-goal lead in the space of three minutes. Craig Moore made the breakthrough in the 36th minute with a powerful header into the corner for only his second goal of the season following an inswinging corner from Giovanni van Bronckhorst.

The Dutch midfielder added the second with a snap shot from 25 yards that deceived Leighton. Wallace squandered a good chance in the 42nd minute when the ball skidded off his boot after Albertz and van Bronckhorst had linked up.

Aberdeen were becoming demoralised and a minute later Arthur Numan grabbed the third with a fine left-foot finish inside the area.

Arild Stavrum found himself in a good position for the visitors two minutes after the break. But his shot was weak and keeper Stefan Klos was able to save comfortably.

Wallace was looking short on confidence and snatched at a chance, enabling Leighton to parry the ball to safety. But the little striker got his reward on the hour when he tapped the ball in after a surging run by Andrei Kanchelskis.

Wallace was inches away from getting a second six minutes later when his effort came back off the post following a good through ball from van Bronckhorst.

Zerouali should have pulled a goal back for Aberdeen but somehow mishit his shot in front of goal after Whyte's header had rattled the post.

Rangers added a fifth goal in the 82nd minute with Barry Ferguson's first of the season after Wallace had played the ball into his path.

They have now scored 13 goals in three league games against Aberdeen, who remain rooted to the foot of the table.

fields.headline: Double strike halts Magpies
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 2 - 0 Newcastle
fields.body:
A vital and deserved win for Wimbledon which takes them above Newcastle, who paid a heavy price for defeat.

Well, £1 million to be precise, as that is what they must now give Everton for sending Duncan Ferguson out for his 30th appearance, so activating a bonus clause in his initial £7 million transfer. Ferguson has taken 14 months to reach that mark, the time it may take Bobby Robson to get Newcastle going again. Wimbledon, meanwhile, are once again back on course for survival.

Newcastle initially looked more like the home team. Their supporters filled most of the ground, physically and vocally, and their players made all the early running.

It was not one-way traffic, as Wimbledon often looked dangerous on the counter, most notably through Marcus Gayle on the left wing. But it took two good saves from Neil Sullivan to prevent Newcastle from beginning another goal rout.

The Scotland international made his first stop at the near post after Alan Shearer had run on to a 17th-minute Kieron Dyer pass and shot from an angle. Sullivan made a near-identical save from Dyer eight minutes later, but this time he also had to cope with a deflection off Hermann Hreidarsson.

Next to have a pop was Gary Speed, who struck a 30-yard free-kick so powerfully that Sullivan must have heard it whistling towards him like a bullet with his name on it. Fortunately for Wimbledon, it soon had Sullivan's hands on it after he made a good, low save to his left.

Wimbledon should have been in front by the break. First, Steve Harper made a flying save to keep out a 36th-minute Gayle header and then Carl Leaburn pulled a shot wide when it looked easier to score five minutes later. Carl Cort also went close.

Wimbledon's persistence was rewarded with a fortunate goal two minutes into the second half. An Alan Kimble free-kick led to confusion in the Newcastle penalty area and Harper's attempted punch clear bounced off Robbie Earle's unsuspecting knee and straight back past him into the net.

Maybe the lumpy excuse for a pitch played a role, but Dyer's miss on the hour, when sent clear by Kevin Gallacher, looked a shocker and indicated that Newcastle's fate was already determined. And so it was when the unmarked Gayle headed in a Kenny Cunningham cross nine minutes later.

fields.headline: Chelsea are stifled
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 0 - 0 Chelsea
fields.body:
John Gregory, in self-imposed exile from the touchline in response to a revival which coincides with his shuddering exhortations being out of earshot, can be quietly proud of another effective performance from his improving team. And it could have been a whole lot better had a possible goal not been apparently missed by the officials.

It was the match's first significant moment. Casual defending on Chelsea's part would have gifted Villa the lead had the men in charge concluded that Ed De Goey apparently dragged the ball over his line as he clumsily controlled a backpass from Emerson Thome.

Only later was the referee's interpretation seen to be vindicated. Only the over-sympathetic would blame the swirling wind which cut through Villa Park.

It was an almighty let-off, yet De Goey seemed more rocked than relieved. He was not enjoying himself, flinging jumpy, hopeful punches as Villa thrust a series of dangerous balls at the heart of the frazzled Dutchman's box. Every time he was under the cosh, the Holte End buzzed with mocking anticipation.

fields.headline: Chances go for Burton
fields.trailText: Derby 0 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
Derby's home record is as poor as any in the Premiership, while Coventry have not won away all season; the result was surely a foregone conclusion. So it proved in a high tempo game that lacked nothing in effort but everything in quality finishing.

Branko Strupar was back in Derby's starting line-up in place of Malcolm Christie, the former shelf-stacker who scored two goals on his league debut at Middlesbrough last week. The continued absence of Youssef Chippo and Mustapha Hadji on international duty, and Carlton Palmer's suspension, meant a Coventry recall for the manager's son, Gavin Strachan, while the Peruvian internationals Israel Zuniga and Walter Zevallos, signed on Friday for a combined £800,000 from Melgar, did not feature.

Buoyed by back-to-back victories, Derby started confidently, but their delivery into the box was far too close to Magnus Hedman, and they looked vulnerable on the break.

Cedric Roussel, whose loan move from Ghent was made permanent in midweek, almost scored a spectacular opener. He met Noel Whelan's cross with a brilliant, goal-bound overhead kick but Mart Poom dived well high to his left to catch the ball.

Derby's best chance before the break fell to Deon Burton, who sprung Coventry's offside trap thanks to Strupar's neat flick. But he crashed his shot against the crossbar from 15 yards. Strupar himself came close when he headed Stefan Schnoor's curling free-kick a yard wide.

Having written in the match programme that Georgi Kinkladze would be restricted to cameos, the Derby manager Jim Smith introduced him at half time in place of Steve Elliott, and switched to a flat back-four. Kinkladze immediately set off on a mazy run from the half-way line reminiscent of his Manchester City best, but his final shot flew over the bar.

Steve Froggatt should have scored for the visitors when he found himself free in front of goal, but hit the post on the turn from 10 yards. Then Derby had a great chance. Once again Kinkladze was the architect, sending Burton clear, but the shot was woeful.

fields.headline: Bradford clean up
fields.standfirst: Bantams achieve vivtory on the day they swoop for Collymore
fields.trailText: Bradford 3 - 2 Watford
fields.body:
Bradford City opened talks yesterday designed to breathe life into the moribund career of Aston Villa's Stan Collymore and their own Premiership survival chances.

Hopes of the latter were enhanced in a convincing victory over fellow strugglers Watford, who suffered their seventh defeat in eight Premiership matches.

Manager Paul Jewell, armed with a reported £5 million budget to spend before the transfer deadline, is prepared to take what would be a considerable gamble on a player whose inflated opinion of his own worth recently saw him turn down a move to France's Montpellier.

A late consolation goal from Heidar Helguson, who turned in a cross from Robert Page, concealed the comfort of a Bradford victory achieved despite losing impressive keeper Matt Clarke after an accidental collision with Paul Robinson in the 71st minute.

An encounter between the Premiership's least productive attack - belonging to the hosts - and the worst defensive team did not hold much promise for a feast of offensive football. Indeed, it should come as no surprise that it took a disastrous piece of defensive play from the visitors to gift Bradford an opening goal.

After 24 minutes, an attempted one-two between Dean Windass and Dean Saunders was only halted by a blatant foul on the former, committed jointly by Robert Page and Paul Robinson. Peter Beagrie stepped up to convert City's seventeenth goal in 23 league games this season.

It could have been a turning point in Bradford's season, considering the significance of an encounter that even the most amateur pundit might have earmarked last summer as an important relegation 'six-pointer'.

As it transpired, it took them all of nine minutes to surrender momentum and advantage.

Xavier Gravelaine looked to have delayed his pass toolong as Bradford retreated in numbers, but the Frenchman hesitated cleverly, eventually passing to the new Icelandic striker, Heidar Helguson, who was overlapping into space on the left.

His low cross found Micah Hyde, who swept the ball in from close range. It was the response that the game needed, providing an inspiration to two teams who are barely capable of adopting a defensive approach even if they so wished.

Four minutes after the equaliser, Watford conceded their forty-ninth goal of the season when Gareth Whalley collected a loose ball 40 yards out and was allowed to advance without even the threat of a challenge.

Finally, 25 yards from goal and with the Watford defence at last considering an end to their inertia, Whalley unleashed a left-foot shot that went in off the right-hand post.

The first period ended in controversy when Saunders appeared to catch defender Steve Palmer with an errant elbow, the Watford man staying on the field for treatment as the remaining players headed towards the dressing room.

But it was in the opening five minutes of the second half that the game swung tellingly in the favour of the home side, Watford missing an early opportunity to equalise for a second time and Bradford scoring a vital third goal.

Gravelaine was the man responsible for the miss, volleying wide from a dozen yards after a cross from Des Lyttle had fallen invitingly into his path. That error looked all the more costly in the 50th minute when an excellent cross from Windass was deflected out of play for a corner.

Beagrie's inswinging dead ball curled towards the head of defender Andrew O'Brien who looked as surprised as anyone else in the stadium as his attempted flick-on found the back of the Watford goal.

fields.headline: 'Colonial' Charlton under fire
fields.standfirst: The strain is showing for two former Manchester United greats... but both come out fighting
fields.trailText: Sir Bobby Charlton reacted furiously yesterday after being accused of colonialism by the South African sports minister as the World Cup 2006 bidding process became personal.
fields.body:
Sir Bobby Charlton reacted furiously yesterday after being accused of colonialism by the South African sports minister as the World Cup 2006 bidding process became personal.

Sir Bobby's responses to questions about crime and security in South Africa in a televised interview last weekend caused uproar in the South African camp. 'He's talking rot,' said Ngconde Balfour, minister of sport and recreation in South Africa. 'I respect Bobby Charlton as a great player but he shouldn't say these things.

'We have fought colonialism for years. We are sick of colonialism. Don't patronise us.' His comments were made at a reception hosted by the South African High Commission in Accra, where four of the five bidding countries for 2006 made presentations last week.

England, South Africa, Germany and Morocco are in the Ghanaian capital to address Fifa dignitaries ahead of the African Nations Cup, which kicked off here yesterday afternoon.

Brazil stayed at home to host Fifa's site inspection team.

Sir Bobby said: 'I am appalled and hurt by this personal attack. For over 25 years I have been coming to Africa to do what I can to help the development of football here. I haven't done so because I had to but because I wanted to.

'The whole world knows about and discusses the problems of crime and violence in South Africa. It's not something that I have raised. It's reported in newspapers around the world. It's no good South African politicians trying to deflect the blame onto me.

'We will continue to promote the positive case for England. That's what matters. Ours is a positive campaign and it will remain so.'

One of the 24 Fifa executives who will select the 2006 venue in July, Botswana's Abdul Bhamjee, was present when Balfour gave his anti-England speech to a gathering of a hundred local media and businessmen. Bhamjee kept a diplomatic silence afterwards.

Balfour said England had based their bid not on their own strength but on 'deceit and downright lies' in trying to highlight security fears in their main rival's bid.

'Show me a man who says his country does not have a crime problem and I'll show you a liar,' he said.

'I personally took the Queen of England around the streets of Alexandria on her recent visit to South Africa... and she came back without a scratch. If they [England] take the Queen as an example perhaps they will stop talking this rot.'

The rot, according to Balfour, came in an interview (13 January) when Sir Bobby was asked about crime in South Africa. Sir Bobby responded: 'Every now and then somebody sends me a copy of a South African newspaper which tables all the problems they have had. A World Cup given to a country at the wrong time, and I don't just mean South Africa, would be a disaster.'

England, who will be back canvassing in Africa in March, have to make a bid presentation to world football's continental federation in the next few months. Ghana was the first stop; next they go to Paraguay, then the Caribbean. The 2006 bid director, Alec McGiven pointed out that Sir Bobby had coached children from every country in Africa except Libya.

Last Tuesday Sir Bobby attended the launch of a community youth football project in two of Accra's most deprived areas, and he had done 'an enormous amount of work' on the continent.

McGiven added: 'We are all very upset by this attack. It's totally unnecessary and is spoiling the good relations that exists between the rival bids. We are determined to get on without these distractions.'

Bookmakers William Hill make South Africa the even-money favourite to win the July vote. England are next at 5-4, Germany third in the betting at 4-1 and both Brazil and Morocco are rank outsiders.

webTitle: Time for League to back the refs

fields.headline: Time for League to back the refs
fields.trailText: The arrogance of the Premier League knows no bounds, it seems. Now they believe they are powerful enough to determine how games should be played.
fields.body:
The arrogance of the Premier League knows no bounds, it seems. Now they believe they are powerful enough to determine how games should be played.

There was much self-congratulation during the week when it emerged that the League had written to referees urging them to cut down on red and yellow cards, the letter resulting in a mere 19 bookings from nine games last weekend, compared with the usual average of 40. The move was hailed as a triumph for common sense.

Forgive this column dragging its heels in the rush of enthusiasm. It would like to know what power the League have to communicate with referees, let alone 'indicate' - as their missive puts it - that 'avoiding cheap cautions is the way ahead'. It would also like to know whether the League have considered the full implications of their unilateral stand.

There are those of us who thought that responsibility for the running of the English game was down to the Football Association and their council. They, in conjunction with the European and world bodies, Uefa and Fifa, also decided on refereeing issues to try to ensure consistency in all countries in these days of growing international competition.

How naive. Such a viewpoint ignores the bloated self-importance of a Premier League who have gorged on television coverage and money to the extent that they now believe they have the right to override the FA. Lancaster Gate's referees' department has twice talked to all national-list referees this season to remind them of the worldwide guidelines. These, rather than the League's self-hyped intrusion, may better explain why yellow cards now average 2.74 per match compared with 4.47 last August.

By encouraging leniency and a possible deviation from what happens in other countries, the Premier League might think they are improving their own product. Instead they are indulging clubs and misleading spectators, who then become unused to the stricter standards elsewhere and cry foul when the English are punished. Take Sol Campbell's 'goal' for England against Argentina at the World Cup, disallowed for Alan Shearer's elbow on Carlos Roja. 'Would have been allowed in the Premiership,' said some. And that is precisely the problem. Had Shearer been pulled up more often, he might not have committed the foul and a winning goal might have stood.

On which subject, it was interesting to hear Thierry Henry, who has played in France and Italy, saying that he has had to develop use of the elbow as protection since coming to Arsenal. This just as the Premier League were blowing their own trumpet. Forget the stuff about the elbow being part and parcel of the game. Certainly Sir Alex Ferguson doesn't believe it. 'It's nonsense - and when was the last time you saw a player with a facial injury after playing against us?' he once said after I had questioned him over Manchester United's physical aggression.

Take David Beckham's red card against Necaxa in Brazil. 'Wouldn't have been a sending-off in the Premiership,' someone said. Again, that is precisely the problem. Beckham might well have got away with it. Leicester's Robbie Savage did with an even worse 'tackle' on Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu the same week. It would help if Sir Alex didn't decry the referee for his dismissal of Beckham; would help, too, if the Arsenal manager, Arsène Wenger, condemned the physical excesses of his side as vehemently as Savage's instead of expecting us to believe that he had not seen other incidents when he managed to see that one.

Referees, in some misguided attempt to please the paymaster of the Premier League, should not lose sight of their duty. In October, England play Germany in their opening World Cup qualifying match. There would again be much gnashing of teeth were, say, Beckham sent off for an offence 'that would only have been a yellow card in the Premiership'. Here the FA should take heed. The England team have had an appalling disciplinary record in recent years.

Last week Lancaster Gate were unwilling to comment on the Premier League's intervention. With an air of diplomatic detachment, they were simply hoping the issue would go away. You can only hope that internally they take a tougher line if the country's players are to be best served.

There is a meeting planned soon between the FA, the Premier League, the Football League, referees and the League Managers' Association. The managers will probably see it as a chance to air their views to officials. They should also be willing to listen to the referees' point of view in a less heated environment. If, for example, the guidelines on the tackle from behind are enforced, they might see fewer of their players injured.

'The trouble with referees,' an American basketball player once lamented, 'is that they just don't care which side wins.' Long may that continue.

fields.headline: Libya's explosive sporting cocktail
fields.trailText: Thanks to the Gadaffi family, football is becoming a window on to one of the world’s most secretive countries as new stadiums shoot up from the sand and big names are drafted in to help raise the game’s profile.
fields.body:
In Tripoli, capital of Libya, they tell the joke about the taxi driver with a foreigner in the back of his cab. 'Listen,' whispers the driver. 'Do you want to go to a place where you can get a drink?" 'Yes,' says the foreigner. 'And where there are women?' 'Yes!'

'There isn't one,' says the driver.

Justin Marozzi, author of a forthcoming book about the country, says: 'In Libya football is the chief form of social life and entertainment. Manchester United are hugely popular.' In Tripoli games between the two biggest clubs draw crowds of 100,000. Now, thanks to the Gadaffi family, football is becoming a window on to one of the world's most secretive countries. Saidi Gadaffi, 27-year-old son of Colonel Muammar, has decided to play for the national football team. Saidi does not play for a club - as he is chairman of the Libyan FA, that would be improper - so he has hired Piet Hamberg, a Dutchman who coaches El-Ahli, Libya's biggest club, as his private trainer.

Saidi has been pumping much of Libya's oil money into football. Stadiums are shooting out of the sand. This week Carlos Bilardo, who coached Argentina to the World Cup of 1986, became manager of the national team, appointed on the advice of Saidi's friend and mentor Diego Maradona. The disgraced sprinter Ben Johnson (apparently the world's worst footballer) is the team's athletics coach.

Saidi is doing everything he can to take Libya to the 2002 World Cup. Getting the country noticed around the world fits the Gadaffi philosophy. Saidi's father used to do it in a different way, but after the Libyan bombing of the Pan Am plane over Lockerbie in 1988 he retreated into his tent. Gadaffi is wary of the sport. He knows that in a dictatorship the only place where people can gather and shout is the football ground.

The only public dissent against the Gadaffi regime in recent times occurred at a Tripoli football game on July 9, 1996.The US state department says trouble began when the team supported by Gadaffi's sons Saidi and Muhammad scored a suspicious goal that was allowed by the referee. The crowd then reportedly began chanting anti-Gadaffi slogans, whereupon the sons and their bodyguards shot first into the air and then into the crowd. People stampeded out of the ground and onto the streets, where they stoned cars and continued chanting the slogans.

The Libyan government later admitted that eight people had been killed and 39 injured. However, the US state department notes reports of up to 50 dead. It calls the riot 'the last display of public discontent and resentment towards the government'. Extraordinary events and because they occurred at a big football match, they were shown live on television. For the first time Libyans could see that dissent existed. A European then working in Tripoli says that after the game people suddenly began approaching her with complaints about the regime.

No wonder that Gadaffi devoted most of the last chapter of his Little Green Book to an attack on spectator sport. 'It is stupid for crowds to enter a restaurant just to look at a person or a group of person eating,' he wrote. 'The same holds true of the crowds which fail to practise sport themselves because of their ignorance.'

In 1982, when Libya hosted the African Cup of Nations, Gadaffi gave a two-hour speech. Libya hopes to host the cup again in 2004, but it is just possible the colonel won't be around to repeat the trick.

fields.headline: Cut. It's a rap...
fields.standfirst: Ice Cube, who stars in Gulf war movie  Three Kings, is one of the growing number of hip hop artists with box-office clout. But don't expect any rhymes.  Mark Morris explains how Hollywood got wise to a new generation of stars
fields.trailText: Ice Cube, who stars in Gulf war movie Three Kings, is one of the growing number of hip hop artists with box-office clout. But don't expect any rhymes. Mark Morris explains how Hollywood got wise to a new generation of stars
fields.body:
Take a look at the US box office charts and you'll see Next Friday sitting proudly at the top. Next Friday? You won't have read about it in any of the lists of films to look out for this year, commercially or artistically. The pundits are calling it a surprise hit, though they should have seen it coming.

The sequel to 1995's knockabout ghetto comedy Friday is typical of several trends. It proved that, despite the wealth of future classics playing in American cinemas, unpretentious comedies can always win the day. And like last year's The Best Man, it shows that mainstream African-American comedies can cross over.

Along with The Spy Who Shagged Me, it also indicates that a slow-burning video hit can set up its sequel for success at the cinema - Friday spent 100 weeks lurking in the video charts. But most of all it is confirmation that the 30-year-old executive producer, writer and star of Next Friday, Ice Cube, has arrived in the movie big time. Hip hop has had some kind of relationship with the movies for years, going back to Wild Style in 1982 and early embarrassments such as Krush Groove. But unlike rock music and the movies, things have progressed. Throughout the Nineties rappers have been given a chance to play roles in films which move beyond their music persona. And more than a handful have turned out to be decent actors. Will Smith and Ice T spring to mind, but the list extends to Busta Rhymes doing a voice for the Rugrats movie.

There is also a niche audience for films starring rappers and no one else which has been served by New Orleans hip hop entrepreneur Master P, who churns out cheap, nasty and profitable films that will never make it this side of the Atlantic.

Former rapper Ice Cube stands out from the crowd. He has a three-picture deal with New Line, and Next Friday has taken $17 million in its first week, despite the fact that comedian Chris Tucker is not there to repeat his starring role from the original film. Ice Cube says this is because Tucker 'doesn't smoke weed or use profanities now', but Tucker's escalating salary - currently $4m a movie, against a total budget of $10m for Next Friday - might have had something to do with it.

There is nothing profound about the film. The plot has Compton homeboy Ice Cube being sent to live with relatives in the sub urbs, and a typical gag involves getting a vacuum cleaner stuck to someone's face while trying to get rid of marijuana fumes. The reviews have been harsh, but even if Ice Cube were worried about that - and I suspect he isn't - he's got the respectability angle covered. Before Next Friday reaches British audiences we'll have a chance to see him in David O'Russell's much praised Gulf war adventure-satire Three Kings. This puts him in the company of George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg - an ex-rapper of sorts - and Spike Jonze as US soldiers going in search of Saddam's gold just after the ceasefire. It's an excellent, unpredictable film in which Ice Cube plays a deeply religious soldier.

He's good in it, but that's no surprise either - his acting has been good since his first film. 'I kind of fell into it,' he says. 'I wasn't really thinking about acting, but I ran into John Singleton in 1988. He was telling me he had this script. I didn't really pay him attention.'

Singleton's film was Boyz 'n the Hood , named after a song Ice Cube wrote when he was 16. The film was made in 1991, with Ice Cube playing Doughboy, the childhood friend of Tre (Cuba Gooding Jr) who cannot steer clear of violence on the streets. Ice Cube had had no acting training but he fired his acting coach after a couple of days on the advice of the film's star, Laurence Fishburne. Fishburne was proved right when Ice Cube got excellent reviews.

Since then he has made regular excursions from recording to appear in mainstream films, including Walter Hill's Trespass (1992) and the risible Anaconda in 1997. But it was Friday that turned him from a rapper who acted into a force in the movies. He says the reason he wrote the script is because he was bored on tour in Europe. There were two obvious blueprints he could have followed: the harsh realism of Boyz 'n the Hood or the Scarface pastiche of New Jack City. He ignored them both.

Friday is about one day in the life of two amiable losers - played by Ice Cube and Chris Tucker - from South Central LA. The film has an anti-gun moral and Ice Cube plays the baffled straight man led astray by Tucker. He was standing his hard man rap persona on its head. And it worked.

As it happens, the life his character leads in Friday is closer to Ice Cube's upbringing than the gun-toting world of his records. Born O'Shea Jackson, his family was stable, both parents had decent jobs and he did well at school. The song 'Boyz 'n the Hood' was written before he had ever seen a drive-by shooting or played a part in gang warfare.

Friday led to Ice Cube's debut as a director with The Players Club . 'I was starting to direct my own videos because they weren't coming out exactly how I wanted, so I started trying to learn from directors I was working with, picking up traits just to help myself. It got to the point where I said, "I'm ready. Next time I write another film, I'm going to direct it." The film cost only $5m and picked up $23m at the box office.

The easy assumption is that Ice Cube's film success has come on the back of his music career. But the hip hop world has a ferocious turnover, and for most fans Ice Cube is a figure from the past. He explains: 'When you do movies you can't promote records, so those records suffer.'

At 30, Ice Cube must realise he has a better future as an actor and filmmaker than trying to compete with the latest young hardcases. It's a calculation others have made. Queen Latifah now has a solid acting career that doesn't lean at all on the fact that she used to make records. Starting out well as an opinionated waitress in Jungle Fever and briefly starring in her own sitcom, Latifah can currently be seen in The Bone Collector and heard as the voice of a character in Bringing Out The Dead.

So why do rappers - be they hardcore stars like Ice Cube or pop idols like Will Smith or Marky Mark - make the transition to the screen in a way few pop stars can manage? L.L. Cool J suggested in Interview magazine recently that 'creating, memorising and performing rap music comes from the same part of the brain as acting does. Rock 'n' roll is about singing; rap music, to a certain extent, is acting.'

L.L. Cool J's acting career has also picked up as his music has tailed off. Recently he was in Halloween H20 and the expensive shark flop Deep Blue Sea and he now has a substantial part in Oliver Stone's American football epic Any Given Sunday . His theory about rappers and acting is one that comes up most times the question is asked. It's certainly true that hip hop is saturated with film imagery. But there is no easy explanation of why Ice Cube is a better actor than David Bowie, just the consistent celluloid evidence that he is.

There's one exception that should be made. The rapper who had the biggest potential to be a film star was the late Tupac Shakur. But unlike the others he was not a gangsta rapper first and an actor second. He was a drama school product who became a rapper and adopted the tough guy persona when gangsta rap took over hip hop. And he paid the ultimate price for it.

Tupac was a fine actor, and in films such as Gridlock'd he played characters with a vulnerability that matched his delicate face - rather than the 'Thug Life' tattoo he had on his stomach. A rapper who shares Tupac's Fame -style education is Mos Def, contemporary hip hop's most thoughtful major figure. He has had parallel music and acting careers from the start, but his profile as an actor should really take off when Spike Lee's next film, Bamboozled , comes out. 'Mos is great,' Lee enthused recently.

All of which leaves only one question: when's the Puff Daddy film - and can we do anything to stop it? It turns out that Puffy was scheduled to appear in Any Given Sunday , but dropped out at the last minute. Then it was announced he had taken an option on King Suckerman , by the excellent Washington-based crime novelist George P. Pelecanos. But that was two years ago, and nothing more has been heard. Perhaps the reputation of rappers in the movies will be left intact, after all.

Hip-hop hurray for Hollywood: screen rappers (dead and alive)

Queen Latifah: A pioneer of female rap, the self-styled 'Queen of hip hop' took her tough image to the screen in 1996's hit Set it Off. Currently in The Bone Collector.

Tupac Shakur: Showed natural ability in Gang Related and Gridlock'd. A sensitive perfomer with a great movie career ahead of him, he was shot dead in 1996.

Will Smith: The rapper/movie star has little credibility in rap circles but his clean-cut appeal and engaging persona have made him one of Hollywood's most bankable stars.

 Three Kings opens on 3 March.

webTitle: Arsenal aim to up the ante

fields.headline: Arsenal aim to up the ante
fields.trailText: The Highbury faithful are quietly concerned about diminishing spirit. Where is the traditional resilience, the last-minute crusades, the penchant for a good old reliable one-nil?
fields.body:
Will it be Roy Keane and Patrick Vieira reprising the eyeballing session started at Highbury earlier this season? Could it be Alex Ferguson asking Arsène Wenger if the postcard arrived? Perhaps Silvinho might remind Gary Neville about the joys of defending against Brazilians. Or Andy Cole might ask Martin Keown for his favourite Champions League memory. Whoever the protagonists, avid voyeurs of events at Old Trafford tomorrow night would be amazed if 90 minutes of Manchester United versus Arsenal didn't throw up a frisson of antagonism.

This fixture has provoked bile for well over a decade now. The roots can be traced to an increasingly tense series of vendettas dating back to an ugly encounter in 1987 when Norman Whiteside wound up the inexperienced teenager David Rocastle until he became so distraught he saw red for retaliation.

The following year it was United who felt aggrieved. In an FA Cup tie at Highbury, Brian McClair sent a last-minute penalty and potential equaliser high into a delirious North Bank, and Nigel Winterburn sauntered over to express an unusual interpretation of sympathy. Next up, Tony Adams's sliced own goal in Manchester resulted in the painful beginning of years of donkey baiting and ee-aw braying.

The needle jabbed to a deeper level altogether in 1990 with the infamous 21-man Old Trafford brawl. A simmering encounter reached meltdown when Winterburn and McClair slashed open old wounds, the Scottish striker unable to resist punishing an insanely late tackle from the Arsenal left back with a few choice boots in the ribs. And they all came piling in.

Rocastle was one of the first on the scene. 'If you see your team-mates in trouble you go in, within the laws of the game, to try and help them out,' he recalls. 'It was nothing malicious towards Man United's players, but it was our team-mate, our little blood brother, in trouble. They were kicking Nigel like it was a nightclub brawl. It just epitomised Arsenal's team spirit. We went in there and we stuck up for each other. At Arsenal, we never, ever started any brawls - we just finished them.'

It was all part of a siege mentality encouraged by George Graham, which, Rocastle believes, made a significant impression on Ferguson. He explains how the Londoners were expected to beat a hasty retreat from Lancashire, tails between legs. 'But we went into the Man United players lounge with our heads held high,' he counters. 'I think a lot of rival managers, including Alex Ferguson, admired our spirit and tried to instil some of that in their own teams.'

This, remember, was the time when United's extravagant underachievers had gone more than two decades without the necessary steel for a championship, while Graham's never-say-die Arsenal conquered through an attitude as imposing as their ability. How the dynamic has changed. The bullish United-against-the-world atmosphere fuelled by Fergie is an intrinsic thrust behind their sensational successes during the Nineties.

Meanwhile, down at Highbury, the faithful are quietly concerned about diminishing spirit. Where is the traditional resilience, the last-minute crusades, the penchant for a good old reliable one-nil? Not so noticeable these days. Instead of the will to make things happen, which Tony Adams has embodied over the years, some appear resigned to letting things happen (and with that demeanour they usually don't).

It is all well and good showing hunger for the big occasion, but appetite for the humdrum has been sorely lacking of late and has led to maddening inconsistency. Although Wenger referred to convincing triumphs over Leeds and Sunderland as turning points, Arsenal's frustration is that the wheel spun into reverse immediately afterwards with uninspiring draws against Sheffield Wednesday and an injury-ravaged Leicester.

'It bothers me a lot,' says Wenger. 'It has something to do with Highbury and the fact we do very well at home, but at the moment we don't look like having the same belief away. I think it's linked with psychological factors. I feel a great potential in the team and wonder, "Will they achieve what is in them?" That is my concern at the moment, and that's why Man United will be a big test for us.'

It is, he acknowledges, the most powerful turning point of the lot because a clash of this magnitude has the capacity to transform his team's sense of conviction, as it did in 1998 when victory at Old Trafford propelled them to the Double. 'The feeling we could win the League came out of that game,' Wenger says. 'That togetherness was quite natural because everyone was convinced we would win the League. Man United on Monday night could be a basis for the rest of the season. It will be a huge boost to get a result.'

Such is the game's importance that Wenger is contemplating playing for the draw. 'It's not in my habit and in my way of thinking, but on the night I'm not sure we have too many options,' he admits. 'A draw wouldn't be bad because it would not be over. One of their three games in hand is Leeds away.' The fact the other two are Sheffield Wednesday and Middlesbrough elicits a wry smile.

Although Arsenal's striking deficiencies seem to tip an already overloaded balance in bronzed, rested United's favour, Wenger still bristles with confidence. You sense he's thriving in the role of underdog in this particular battle. 'Every team enjoys feeling like it's us against the world,' he muses. United certainly do. If Arsenal are to put a dent in the Treble-winning machine, they need to rediscover that camaraderie of old.

Instead of the will to make things happen, which Tony Adams has embodied over the years, some appear resigned to letting things happen (and with that demeanour they usually don't). It is all well and good showing hunger for the big occasion, but appetite for the humdrum has been sorely lacking of late and has led to maddening inconsistency. Although Wenger referred to convincing triumphs over Leeds and Sunderland as turning points, Arsenal's frustration is that the wheel spun into reverse immediately afterwards with uninspiring draws against Sheffield Wednesday and an injury-ravaged Leicester. 'It bothers me a lot,' says Wenger. 'It has something to do with Highbury and the fact we do very well at home, but at the moment we don't look like having the same belief away. I think it's linked with psychological factors. I feel a great potential in the team and wonder, "Will they achieve what is in them?" That is my concern at the moment, and that's why Man United will be a big test for us.' It is, he acknowledges, the most powerful turning point of the lot because a clash of this magnitude has the capacity to transform his team's sense of conviction, as it did in 1998 when victory at Old Trafford propelled them to the Double. 'The feeling we could win the League came out of that game,' Wenger says. 'That togetherness was quite natural because everyone was convinced we would win the League. Man United on Monday night could be a basis for the rest of the season. It will be a huge boost to get a result.' Such is the game's importance that Wenger is contemplating playing for the draw. 'It's not in my habit and in my way of thinking, but on the night I'm not sure we have too many options,' he admits. 'A draw wouldn't be bad because it would not be over. One of their three games in hand is Leeds away.' The fact the other two are Sheffield Wednesday and Middlesbrough elicits a wry smile. Although Arsenal's striking deficiencies seem to tip an already overloaded balance in bronzed, rested United's favour, Wenger still bristles with confidence. You sense he's thriving in the role of underdog in this particular battle. 'Every team enjoys feeling like it's us against the world,' he muses. United certainly do. If Arsenal are to put a dent in the Treble-winning machine, they need to rediscover that camaraderie of old.

fields.headline: Interview: Alan Milburn
fields.standfirst: January 23 2000: Alan Milburn , the most unpopular Minister in the Cabinet is still upbeat about his ability to save the NHS
fields.trailText: The man rated as the most unpopular Cabinet Minister is so Blairite he has even caught some of            the Prime Minister's mannerisms.
fields.body:
The man rated as the most unpopular Cabinet Minister is so Blairite he has even caught some of the Prime Minister's mannerisms.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn rams his messages home over and again with the zealous sincerity of a Tony Blair, occasionally even deploying hand gestures similar to his chief's. Blairite catch-phrases, such as `sus-tained modernisation', pepper his conversation.

`People haven't fully grasped the depth and breadth of the modernisation programme,' he claims. The most noticeable difference is the Geordie accent, though even that is much softened by constant contact with Londoners.

He certainly has a point when he claims the changes he is introducing to the NHS have not yet caught on with the public. The Health Service is reckoned to be the biggest single cause of the drastic fall in Blair's personal standing in the country in the opening weeks of the year.

Some individual horror stories , particularly that of Mavis Skeet, whose operation for throat cancer was cancelled four times until it became too late , are so bad that Milburn admits he has no excuse to offer.

`When ghastly things happen in hospitals, it is obviously an awful thing, and Mrs Skeet is a particularly awful case,' he said. `I don't shed responsibility for any of this. It is terrible when these things happen.

`We acknowledge that we have a lack of capacity in the Health Service, and secondly that that takes time to put right.' But there ends the mea culpa. For the rest of an hour-long interview in his Whitehall office, Milburn was ebullient, argumentative, bursting with plans and statistics, and exuding optimism.

`Waiting lists are coming down. We have the biggest hospital building programme this country has ever seen. We have got every casualty department in the country being modernised, new services like NHS Direct and more nurses returning to the NHS. These are big changes, but they are just the start.'

The way Milburn tells it, last week's apparent U-turn , when an extra £11 billion promised by Tony Blair one day turned out to be no more than an aspiration two days later , was just a technicality. The extra money is on the way. All NHS staff , including the often forgotten non-medical staff , are in line for generous pay awards. The man who only months ago, as a Treasury Minister, was sternly holding down public spending has transformed into Mr Spend, Spend, Spend.

He vowed there would be `more investment, and sustained investment over a period of years , because we need sustained increases in income if we are going to have the sort of modern health service people quite rightly want to see'.

To get that extra money, he is willing to upset Treasury mandarins who cannot bear the idea that taxpayers should be told which parts of the tax they pay goes into what public service. In Treasury jargon, it's called `hypothecation', and is to be sternly discouraged. But Milburn says: `I've got a fairly open mind about hypothecation. I think there are down sides as well as up sides.

`I welcome the fact that the Chancellor decided that if tobacco taxes were increased that money will essentially be hypothecated for the NHS. That will be very helpful for next year. There are good arguments to say maybe we could do more there.'

Though he refused to utter the £11bn figure , which came from experts analysing Blair's words on television a week ago, rather than from the Prime Minister himself , Milburn confirmed every detail of the arithmetic that produced it. Health spending in the UK is below the European average by about 1 per cent of our gross domestic product. Barring an economic catastrophe, the difference will be made up in five years, and all that extra money will go into the NHS.

When the Tories accuse Milburn of being ideologically opposed to private healthcare, they have a point. `The private healthcare market in Britain is in trouble and isn't expanding,' he said. `The growth in health spending in the UK, on our plans, will come from growth in the NHS. I think that's the right thing to do, because I think it's the fairest and the most efficient means of getting healthcare to the majority of people.

`All expenditure, whether it is public or private, is of course dependent on the economy. Let's not pretend that if we had a system of private health insurance in our country, as the Conservatives want, that it wouldn't be susceptible to economic fluctuation. It would actually be more sensitive to economic fluctuation.

`And why? Because if you are having to insure yourself against health risk, then if you lose your job or you have lower disposable income, the first thing to go is private health insurance.'

Once he has started on the subject of private medicine, it is hard to get him off. It is as if a hidden streak of Old Labour left over from his days as a young left-wing activist is peering through. `I do believe absolutely that the Conservatives have made the most profound political misjudgment,' he claimed. `They have walked off the playing-field. They have abandoned the postwar consensus on health. They have put all their eggs in the private health insurance basket. They have got themselves into the deepest political water.'

The calculation that the Tories have blundered, giving him an avenue of escape from an embarrassing political crisis, may explain why he appears little concerned his standing is roughly equivalent to that of the former manger of his favourite football team, Ruud Gullit.

`Let's not pretend I'm the only Health Minister in the world in the hot seat. Healthcare systems the world over are under pressure. Some of these problems just go with the territory.'

fields.headline: American Beauty's Wes Bentley
fields.trailText: In American Beauty, Wes Bentley is a former mental institution inmate who sells drugs, spies on his neighbours, all the time with a preternaturally calm look on his face. It's the kind of edgy role young actors cherish but few could pull off. Bentley is so eerily good, he holds his own with Oscar-tipped Kevin Spacey in their scenes together.
fields.body:
In American Beauty, Wes Bentley is a former mental institution inmate who sells drugs, spies on his neighbours, all the time with a preternaturally calm look on his face. It's the kind of edgy role young actors cherish but few could pull off. Bentley is so eerily good, he holds his own with Oscar-tipped Kevin Spacey in their scenes together.

American Beauty, perhaps the best American film of last year, is a bittersweet drama (or should that be dark comedy) revolving around a dysfunctional suburban family. It's an unusual, uncompromising film in many ways. One of them is its acute observation of both middle-age and teenage characters and relationships. At a time when teen films are a genre of their own, American Beauty handles the mid-life crisis of parents Spacey and Annette Bening as well as the youngsters' storylines.

Spacey and Bening head the cast, but the film is actually an ensemble piece with strong contributions from Bentley and two more relative newcomers Thora Birch and Mena Suvari.

Spacey was impressed by Bentley role in the unlikely hit. 'This movie is clicking with young people because the teen roles are portrayed with such maturity and honesty,' he says. 'It's a serious expression of the rootlessness a lot of kids feel. And that hinges a lot on how deep Wes's performance goes.' He makes dope-smoking and voyeurism look cool. Like Spacey, Bentley dropped out of the prestigious Julliard School. He left after a year figuring he had learnt enough about theory. It was time to act.

The post-American Beauty exposure has made Bentley a rising star in the teen firmament, putting him on magazine covers and chat shows. 'It's okay girls' is the message - he's a 'weirdo' in the movie, but off screen what a hunk. With the film likely to garner a string of Academy Award nominations next month, Bentley is one of the millennium's first It-boys.

Director Sam Mendes picked the 21 year-old over 30 young actors, impressed by his 'intensity and delicacy'. Nothing in Bentley's previous screen CV suggested his ability. His debut occured in a barely seen European indie film called Three Below Zero . Next, he played the tiny role of a racist rapist in Jonathan Demme's Beloved, a role he took without reading the script or knowing the cast list. When he found out he rang up his Methodist minister dad in a bit of a state. 'But dad, it's Oprah Winfrey. I have to rape Oprah Winfrey.' Actually, he didn't have to assault the First Lady of Television. The rape occurs in flashback featuring another actress (Lisa Gay Hamilton) as Oprah's younger self.

Those blink-and-you-miss-me roles are now firmly in the past. In The White River Kid, he plays the serial killer lead role opposite Antonio Banderas. For the moment, spoilt by the success of American Beauty, the easy route is not an option. 'I want to be in stuff with characters. I live to play these extreme feelings.'

Five things you should know about Wes Bentley

1 He was born and raised in Little Rock, Arkansas.
2 Since his success he's got lots of nice phone calls from former bullies at school.
3 He didn't have a professional photo when he turned up to audition for American Beauty director Sam Mendes so he brought a polaroid instead.
4 Both his parents are United Methodist ministers.
5 To prepare for a role as serial killer he rented wildlife videos to study the killer instinct.

webTitle: Scottish banks add to bids for NatWest

fields.headline: Scottish banks add to bids for NatWest
fields.trailText: Natwest's two Scottish suitors are set to raise their bids for the bank this week as the £22 billion takeover battle approaches its climax. Both Bank of Scotland and its Edinburgh rival, Royal Bank of Scotland, will add a cash top-up in an attempt to break the four-month deadlock.
fields.byline: by Paul Farrelly and Heather Connon
fields.body:
Natwest's two Scottish suitors are set to raise their bids for the bank this week as the £22 billion takeover battle approaches its climax. Both Bank of Scotland and its Edinburgh rival, Royal Bank of Scotland, will add a cash top-up in an attempt to break the four-month deadlock.

NatWest's final defence document, due tomorrow, will indicate special payouts of up to £4bn from surplus capital and disposals, including Ulster Bank and fund manager Gartmore. Last year's profits may exceed market forecasts of £2.2bn.

This weekend BoS was leading the fray. Its cash and shares offer - worth £12.95 per NatWest share - stood 6 per cent ahead of RBS' £12.25. NatWest shares closed at £12.10 on Friday.

BoS has already lifted its bid once, however, and RBS's powerful supporters and stronger balance sheet give it more firepower. RBS has Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano (BSCH) and insurer CGU on its side, and may yet recruit more allies from BSCH's continental network, which includes France's Société Générale, Germany's Commerzbank and Italy's Sao Paolo IMI.

On Friday, BoS signed up the Prudential in a deal to sell on NatWest's £400m life insurance arm if it wins. However, City sources ruled the Pru out from buying a stake in BoS to boost its armoury.

Both Scots banks formally have until a week tomorrow to declare their hand.

webTitle: Out of the chaos, Ghana make it happen

fields.headline: Out of the chaos, Ghana make it happen
fields.standfirst: Ayew 57 | Foé 20
fields.trailText: Ghana 1 - 1 Cameroon
fields.byline: Brian Oliver in The National Stadium, Accra
fields.body:
With less than 24 hours to kick-off at the African Nations Cup, the first international tournament of the new millennium, the stadium that was to host the opening game between Ghana and Cameroon, was a hive of activity.

Workmen were chopping and hammering on carpenters' benches that blocked one of the exits behind the scoreboard end and there were bits of wood with nails sticking out of them lying on the floor.

Red, gold and green drapes were being wound around the speaker pylon, serving the popular enclosures (admission: 50p). Off-cuts of carpet littered the floor of the old press centre, where fax machines remained unopened in their boxes.

To the side of the main stand an artist was painting the letters on a Rothmans advertising hoarding to be lined up alongside Coca Cola, Gillette, Duracell, Amstel, Total and Mastercard, by the time the match went out live all around the world. Others were brushing on another coat of paint to the roof of the tennis complex behind the VIP entrance. The PA system was being tested and there was still too much echo from the stand opposite (admission: £1.20).

'Arh, look at this,' said a TV commentator from South Africa, who has seen the last six tournaments. 'Absolutely normal. The match will kick off on time. Everything will be sorted.'

And so it was, much to the delight of a full house who saw an entertaining game in which Rigobert Song of Liverpool was the man of the match. By yesterday morning everything was in order and it was just as well the PA was up to scratch because there were people to entertain from 5am, eleven hours before kick-off.

By noon the National Stadium was full - but what was the crowd? According to various magazines previewing the Nations Cup, the capacity was 25,000, 30,000, 40,000 and 50,000. It looked like 30,000.

By 2pm several bands were in full swing, the PA was drowned out and there was a huge roar as three men painted from hair to toe in Ghana's colours, ran a lap of the track around the pitch. The Mexican waves that preceded a spectacularly tuneful and colourful opening ceremony appeared to have been co-ordinated by the tournament organisers.

In the section that doesn't go in for the wave were Sepp Blatter, Michel Platini, Roger Milla, Franz Beckenbauer, Sir Bobby Charlton, executives from four 2006 World Cup bids, the 2002 South Korea World Cup organisers, the Asian Football Federation, the Confederation of African Football, and last to arrive, but not least, the President of Ghana, Jerry Rawlings.

There has been an unbearable amount of brown-nosing, with officials from both Fifa and CAF suddenly becoming 'His Excellency' in the style of the top men at the International Olympic Committee. Just to ram home the point, CAF decided to award Juan Antonio Samaranch their Gold Order of Merit. Milla got a silver.

CAF's re-elected president, the Cameroonian Issa Hayatou, sucked up to Blatter at every opportunity and had a blast at European agents for taking so many young Africans, many of them teenagers, away from their continent and leaving far too little, if any, of the profits behind.

This tournament, which is being co-hosted by Nigeria, features 352 players, of whom more than 200 play at all levels in Europe.

While Congo field men from BV Cloppeburg and Bureholzhausen in the German Regional Leagues, Nigeria have 17 stars from the top divisions of Europe. Among them are Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu and Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro, who will play against Tunisia in Lagos today when, who knows, the atmosphere might match that in Accra.

Also today in Kumasi, the second venue in Ghana (Nigeria's other host city is Kano) Lucas Radebe of Leeds and Manchester United's Quinton Fortune will hope to help South Africa, the beaten finalists in 1998, start with a win against Gabon.

The Coventry pair, Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo, start on Tuesday when Morocco play Congo in Lagos. Back in Accra tomorrow Celtic's Olivier Tebily hopes to line up for Ivory Coast against Togo.

Yesterday, Cameroon fielded Marc-Vivien Foé of West Ham and Song, a popular captain, with teammates who call him 'the German' because he is so efficient.

He was more than efficient yesterday, setting up Foé's goal before seeing a shot hacked off the line four minutes later.

Song, known by the less sophisticated 'Songey' at Anfield, defended exceptionally and must have been disappointed his team were not home and dry by half-time. Pierre Wome, Patrick Mboa and Sorelle Njitap all shone against spineless opponents.

The second half was a different story, thanks in part to the changes made by Ghana's Italian coach, Giuseppe Dossena - a team mate of Gianluca Vialli in Sampdoria's 1991 title-winners.

Ghana, who had used all three subs by the 67th minute, equalised through Kwame Ayew, brother of the former African Footballer of the Year, Abedi Pele. They deserved their draw in a fast and hard game and the crowd seemed happy enough.

Ghana: Kingston, Kuffour, Baidoo, Gargo (Edusei, 55), Nyarko, Ahinful (Ofori-Quaye, 36), Akonnor, Gyan, Johnson, Ayew, Addo (Appiah, 67)

Cameroon: Alioum, Mayer,Song, Kalla, Wome, Njanka, Fotsi Njitap, Foe, Olembe (Mettomo, 81), Job (Ndiefi, 64), Mboma (Eto'o, 80)

He was more than efficient yesterday, setting up Foé's goal before seeing a shot hacked off the line four minutes later. Song, known by the less sophisticated 'Songey' at Anfield, defended exceptionally and must have been disappointed his team were not home and dry by half-time. Pierre Wome, Patrick Mboa and Sorelle Njitap all shone against spineless opponents. The second half was a different story, thanks in part to the changes made by Ghana's Italian coach, Giuseppe Dossena - a team mate of Gianluca Vialli in Sampdoria's 1991 title-winners. Ghana, who had used all three subs by the 67th minute, equalised through Kwame Ayew, brother of the former African Footballer of the Year, Abedi Pele. They deserved their draw in a fast and hard game and the crowd seemed happy enough. webTitle: M&S bid fails to find City front man

fields.headline: M&S bid fails to find City front man
fields.trailText: Entrepreneur Philip Green is struggling to find someone to chair a group he is trying to assemble which could bid for Marks & Spencer, say insiders.
fields.body:
Entrepreneur Philip Green is struggling to find someone to chair a group he is trying to assemble which could bid for Marks & Spencer, say insiders.

Green has accepted that he cannot take the chair himself. He is thought to have approached Allan Leighton of Asda, Terry Green of Debenhams and Richard North, formerly of the Burton group and now with Bass, who would all take leading executive roles in the group. But he still needs someone acceptable in the City to front the venture. He is understood to have failed to find anyone willing to take the post.

Green has had to concede publicly that he is considering a bid for M&S, currently worth nearly £9 billion. He is also thought to have studied the possibility of making a bid for Arcadia or Storehouse.

Storehouse is valued by the stock market at less than £150 million - just one-eighth of the figure it stood at in summer 1998. Arcadia, whose share price fell further last week, is worth less than £100m, but the company is also saddled with around £300m in debt.

The price of M&S shares fell by 28p, equivalent to 8.5 per cent, last week as the City became increasingly sceptical about the likelihood of Green having any success in putting together a bid for the retailer.

A takeover of M&S would dwarf Green's acquisition of Sears last year, which was worth little more than £500m. Tesco has refused to rule itself out of the running for M&S, but the company is unwilling to bid first.

webTitle: Straw faces Lords revolt on racism

fields.headline: Straw faces Lords revolt on racism
fields.trailText: Home Secretary Jack Straw faces a second stinging defeat in the Lords this week, this time over a race relations Bill introduced in response to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.
fields.body:
Home Secretary Jack Straw faces a second stinging defeat in the Lords this week, this time over a race relations Bill introduced in response to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

Labour and Liberal Democrat peers believe the Bill does not go far enough to outlaw the sort of institutional racism that led to the failure of the police investigation into the murder of the black teenager. The cross-party alliance will oppose the Government unless Ministers agree that public bodies such as the police will have a duty to weed out 'indirect discrimination'. This would cover the deeply embedded racist 'canteen culture' which the Macpherson report identified as the main cause of delay in the police inquiries into the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

Critics say the Bill will make no practical difference in cases such as that of Lawrence, where the inquiry found no evidence of direct racism among the officers involved. Tory peers will also join the revolt unless the Government offers clarification of the legislation.

Straw is this weekend believed to be working on a last-minute deal with peers to save him the embarrassment of a second defeat in a fortnight. Last week the Lords threw out a Bill to curb the right of defendants to demand jury trial in a rebellion led by Blairite Labour peer Helena Kennedy.

Early this week Straw will meet Liberal Democrat Lord Lester of Herne Hill, who has been leading the opposition to the Bill, in an attempt to avoid another clash when it reaches report stage in the Lords on Thursday.

Civil rights campaigners were stunned when the Bill failed to cover indirect discrimination. In the Lawrence report inquiry chairman William Macpherson insisted the full force of race relations legislation should be brought to bear on the police and that this should include all forms of institutional racism. Lester last night told The Observer : 'I sincerely hope Jack Straw will carefully consider the arguments before next Thursday. It is entirely in his hands.'

It is thought the Government is wary of legislation that could initiate a series of inquiries into racism in major public institutions such as the police, the prisons service and even government itself. The Commission for Racial Equality, which would carry out any such inquiry, has consistently said the new legislation as it stands will fail to root out the racism at the heart of British society.

Spokesman Chris Myant said last night: 'It is hard to find anyone in the black and Asian communities to say what the Government is doing is right.'

Sources close to Straw last night said the Home Secretary had been impressed by Lester's arguments and believed a compromise could be reached before Thursday.
