fields.headline: Coup ghosts wait for Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Britain's detention of the ex-tyrant has changed the way Chileans see him, giving hope of justice to the families of the dead. Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Sofía Prats remembers the friendly, avuncular figure who regularly visited the family home with his wife more than three decades ago. She little thought then that one day she would be working to have the amiable, uniformed visitor charged with murdering her father and mother.
fields.body:
Sofía Prats remembers the friendly, avuncular figure who regularly visited the family home with his wife more than three decades ago. She little thought then that one day she would be working to have the amiable, uniformed visitor charged with murdering her father and mother.

Sofía's father, General Carlos Prats, was commander-in-chief of the Chilean armed forces and Defence Minister under the late President Salvador Allende. When rumours of a planned military coup surfaced in 1973, Prats asked his fellow generals for their public support and, when that was not forthcoming, he resigned.

After the coup in which Pincohet seized power and Allende died, Prats was suspected of planning a counter-putsch on behalf of the elected former government. He was forced to appear on television urging that there be no resistance to avoid further bloodshed.

Exiled to Argentina, he and his wife, also named Sofía, were killed by a car bomb planted by the Dina, Chile's secret police, in Buenos Aires in September 1974.

'I have seen Pinochet once since,' said Prats's daughter, who is now mayor of the working-class district of Huechuraba in the Chilean capital, Santiago. 'It was in December 1974 in his office where we asked him to request the Argentine authorities to investigate our parents' deaths.

'He was very insensitive. He said he would ask them, but the letter he sent just said the family had asked him to enquire, nothing more.'

Finally, the Argentines, having long dispensed with their own military junta, are investigating the assassinations. A judge, María Servini, has already been to Chile as part of her investigation and, says Sofía Prats, plans to try to interview Pinochet and, if necessary, apply for Chile to extradite him to Argentina to stand trial.

Ms Prats, whose grandfather was British, says Pinochet's detention in Britain has changed the way he is perceived in Chile. 'It has meant he is no longer seen as untouchable. It means justice can be obtained and that the effects of things that happened long years ago are felt around the world.'

Ms Prats, who remained in Chile during the dictatorship and belongs to the centre-left Party for Democracy, believes that, by presenting himself as too senile to stand trial, Pinochet will find himself facing a dilemma. 'If he decides to continue as a senator, he would accept that he is mentally fit for trial. In that case he would have to accept being prosecuted,' she said. If he retires to his home, as his family may recommend, he would become a spent, peripheral figure, something he - like his chief supporter in Britain, Baroness Thatcher - might find it hard to accept.

While the murder of Carlos Prats had international reverberations, it was eclipsed two years later by another car bomb killing by Dina, this time in Washington. The victim was Allende's former Foreign Minister, Orlando Letelier, who had been lobbying with some success to prevent arms sales and suspend loans to Chile.

Fabiola Letelier, Orlando's lawyer sister, wants Pinochet to answer for that, and she agrees that his detention in Britain has had a major effect on the Chilean psyche. 'Now Pinochet is a different person, he is not the dictator with all the power,' said Letelier. Her brother was stripped of his nationality by Pinochet. Orlando's photograph, with his words, 'I was born a Chilean and will die a Chilean', is on the wall of her room.

She said: 'What was wonderful was that Pinochet was absent for the whole election. We are grateful to the Spanish lawyers for that, and because it has brought about a change in international law, which is important for all of Latin America.'

The Letelier family has received some justice in the pursuit of the former Minister's killers. The former head of Dina, Manuel Contreras, who was one of Pinochet's most ruthless enforcers, is now in prison, as is one of his assistants, Brigadier Pedro Espinoza. The exiled Cubans who assisted in the bomb plot in Washington were jailed in the US, but Pinochet personally has never been called to account for the murder.

Fabiola Letelier is disappointed that he will not now stand trial in Spain, and feels that the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, should have published the full medical details of the former dictator's condition. She believes that Pinochet was coached to feign senility: 'One day he is walking in his garden in England, the next he is depressed in a wheelchair.'

But, like Ms Prats, she is determined that her brother's case, and Pinochet's alleged complicity in it, will go to court, even though she accepts that the chances of him being punished are slim: 'Prison for Pinochet? Never,' she said reluctantly.

Juan Guzmán, the energetic Spanish judge who is investigating 57 cases against Pinochet, does not accept the general's claim of senility and has no intention of dropping the cases. Guzmán asserts that, because 'the disappeared' are still missing, the crimes are continuing, and are not governed by an amnesty introduced to cover the period of the coup. His investigation of what is known in Chile as the 'caravan of death' - a rolling series of executions of prisoners in different parts of the country - is going speedily.

'I don't think the armed forces will want him to be declared senile,' says Ms Letelier, who has a permanent police bodyguard because of death threats. 'It would be humiliating for them and the only way for him to be excluded from the judicial process would be for him to be declared insane.'

She believes that, unless Pinochet voluntarily confines himself to hospital on his return, he could be stripped of his senatorial immunity from prosecution by the courts. If he was tried, it should be a special tribunal. 'All the judges and members of the military court are people who have been nominated by Pinochet, so it would be a denial of justice. The armed forces are still not subordinate to the civil authorities.'

There are many ghosts waiting for Pinochet when his plane touches down, among them those of Carlos Prats and Orlando Letelier. When Prats went into exile, he sent the dictator a letter. 'The future will tell who was wrong,' he wrote. 'If what you did brings overall good to the nation and social justice reigns, I shall be glad to say I was wrong in seeking a political solution that would avoid the coup.' Many Chileans have long ago made their own judgment.

fields.headline: Video Releases
fields.standfirst: Our Daily Bread | The Lost Son | Le Diner de Cons | Place Vendome
fields.trailText: Our Daily Bread | The Lost Son | Le Diner de Cons | Place Vendome
fields.body:
Our Daily Bread

(1934, U, Academy Video, VHS Rental/Retail)

This important contribution to the BFI's series of New Deal movies is a rare instance of a major director putting his money where his liberal mouth was. King Vidor couldn't get MGM to bankroll this pro-Roosevelt picture about an urban middle-class couple who inherit a bankrupt farm during the Depression and create a co-operative community, so he mortgaged his home to make a film that the credits proclaim as 'Inspired by Headlines of Today'. The dynamic 12-minute ditch-digging finale, in which water is brought to the farm's ailing crops, draws on Soviet cinema and is classic textbook stuff. The film was deliberately held up by United Artists lest it influence the 1934 election in which Socialist author Upton Sinclair was running for governor. The video includes two examples of the phoney vox-pop newsreels made at MGM to discredit Sinclair.

The Lost Son

(1999, 18, Metrodome, VHS, Rental)

The third feature film directed by ace cine matographer Chris Menges, this brutal thriller stars Daniel Auteuil as a leather-jacketed, chain-smoking French ex-cop scraping a living as a private eye in London. He goes into vengeful redemptive mode when a rich European family hires him to find their missing son and he stumbles across a vicious international paedophile ring. Menges makes clever use of locations at once familiar yet unexploited, and Auteuil is a powerful presence. The supporting cast (Nastassja Kinski, Katrin Cartlidge, Ciaran Hinds) promises more than it delivers.

Le Diner de Cons

(1998, 15, Pathé, VHS Rental/Retail)

In Francis Weber's brief, fast-moving, well-performed comedy, a Parisian publisher (Thierry Lhermitte) belongs to a club of supercilious sophisticates who compete weekly to bring the most stupid guest to a dinner party. He never gets to the current meeting because he's ricked his back, his wife has walked out on him and he's stuck in his flat with his intended victim, a dim, accident-prone accountant (plump, bald Jacques Villeret), whose hobby is making match-stick versions of the Eiffel Tower. This is the kind of French boulevard farce that rarely reaches Britain nowadays. No doubt like Weber's My Father the Hero and Three Fugitives it'll be remade in Hollywood.

Place Vendome

(1998, 15, Artificial Eye, VHS Retail/Rental)

Catherine Deneuve gives one of her best performances as the alcoholic widow of a king-pin of the exclusive French jewellery world reacting to his mysterious suicide and her possession of a cache of dodgy diamonds. Nicole Garcia's thriller is as polished as the gems it centres on and as dark and labyrinthine as the conspiratorial international subculture she explores.

fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Tomorrow will see one of the rites of passage in the build-up to the presidential elections in November: the Iowa caucuses.
fields.body:
Tomorrow will see one of the rites of passage in the build-up to the presidential elections in November: the Iowa caucuses.

The Democratic and Republican Parties each will hold precinct meetings at more than 2,100 locations across the state, including schools, libraries, fire stations, grain co-ops, even private living rooms. Here is a guide to the methods and meaning of a sometimes mysterious process:

Q. What is a caucus?

A: A party meeting at the precinct level at which citizens express their candidate preferences and pick delegates to their county conventions. It's the lowest level of party politics.

Q: Who takes part?

A: Anyone who is old enough to vote and a member of the party is eligible, but traditionally only a small number of Iowans shows up - about 10 per cent of the state's 1.8 million registered voters.

Q: What happens at a caucus?

A: Participants, led by a chairman or chairwoman, indicate their preferences for their party's presidential nomination, pick delegates to their county conventions and discuss party business, including their party platforms. About half the people leave, then those who are the real activists get down to brass tacks.

Q: What happens next?

A: Those chosen at the caucuses go to the county convention, where delegates are then selected for the district convention. This happens again at dis trict meetings and again at the state convention, where delegates are named to attend the party's national convention. In the end, Iowa Republicans will send 25 delegates to their national convention. Iowa Democrats will send 47.

Q: Why are the numbers different?

A: The Republicans hold a head count at their precinct caucuses, reporting real numbers. One head, one vote. The Democrats use a mathematical formula to determine support in percentages.

Q: How did all this get started?

A: 'It was something of an accident of history,' says Drake University professor Hugh Winebrenner. A commission appointed following the riots outside the 1968 Democratic National Convention recommended proportionate representation and affirmative action.

Iowa Democrats adopted a rule that there must be a month between the caucuses, county, district, state and national conventions, which led to the caucuses being held in January. 'They claimed they didn't realise what they had done. But it took them very little time to realize they were first in the nation. They have vigorously defended that position ever since,' Winebrenner says.

Q: How does the future look?

A: The future of the Iowa Caucuses is dependent on the national parties, but there is a lot of support among activists for keeping Iowa's first-in-the-nation status. Quite a few candidates have had their chances and profile boosted in Iowa. Some have praised the direct contact with supporters the Iowa campaign allows in these days of television campaigns.

'It fits into their idea of democracy as well,' Winebrenner says.

'All of them yearn for a simpler day when you get out and do what they do in Iowa and New Hampshire. They feel good at the end of a day.'

The Republican challenger, John McCain, has made little effort in Iowa, and may come to regret it.

fields.headline: Full steam ahead
fields.standfirst: There are a few things worth getting cold and wet for. A sticky sponge pudding is one
fields.trailText: There are a few things worth getting cold and wet for. A sticky sponge pudding is one
fields.body:
There seems hardly to have been a day without rain the past few weeks, and I have lost count of the times I have arrived home for dinner dithering with cold and soaked through to my shirt. Which would be fine if I was Colin Firth or Charlie Dimmock, but I am not. What I really want to hear as I hang my woolly hat to dry is the hiss and bubble of a steamed pudding rattling in its pot on the stove. Of course, there is no such thing, but once I am out of my sodden boots and the kettle's on, then in theory at least there could be.

It takes about 20 minutes to get a steamed pudding ready for the stove. You beat the eggs and sugar 'til they are as light as a Mr Whippy cornet, fold in flour, a handful of dried fruits and a shake or two of spice, then scoop the batter into a pudding basin and tie it up like a Christmas present before putting it on to steam peacefully while you make the rest of your supper. It is lifted an hour or two later from its steaming bath, as comforting as an old sweater, and you realise there are a few things actually worth getting cold and wet for.

As a nation, we may have grown out of making steamed puddings, but I am not sure we have really grown out of eating them. Order the treacle sponge in a restaurant and you will find an air raid of pudding spoons heading for your plate for 'just a little taste'. Need I add that they will all come from those who previously had smugly turned away the dessert menu. No chef worthy of his toque could fail to offer a hot pudding nowadays, no matter what the logistical nightmare of getting hot chocolate sponge going out in fine nick all through dinner.

If, as I believe, hot nursery, suety puddings are a part of our national culinary identity, then why do we so rarely cook them at home? My guess is partly due to the fact that our central heating tends to come from radiators rather than food, and our desire for a meal high in stodge has generally lessened somewhat to take on the lighter cooking of the Mediterranean. And who honestly wants a fugged-up kitchen with rivulets running down the windows and pools of water on the windowsills? Yet I have rarely known a dome of pastry or sponge with a steady drizzle of treacle, marmalade or jam meet with many refusals.

The Victorians were fond of fruit puddings made in a crock basin and cooked in steam, yet the sheer jollity and generosity of a figgy pudding or pippin-stuffed apple hat seems at odds with the gloomy don't-talk-at-the-table meals one imagines going on in the larger upstairs-downstairs households. Cookery books of that period are full of suet puddings, while recipes for jam roly-poly (better known to all schoolchildren as dead man's leg), the appetisingly named spotted dick, and Sussex pond pudding, with its filling of brown sugar, butter and a whole lemon, continue well into the latter years of the twentieth century. It is only in the past few years that such heartwarming food has suddenly fallen from grace.

There is nothing difficult about making most steamed puds. The sponge is nothing more complicated than a cake batter, and its habit of absorbing the treacle or sauce that you so generously put in the bottom of the basin and mysteriously vanishes during cooking is soon rectified by an extra jugful on the table. Suet pastry is by far the easiest of all pastries to make, and contains relatively very little of the dreaded saturated fat anyway. It's only once a winter, after all. Problems arise with the cooking more often than in the making. You need to keep the water out - once it gets inside the necessary swaddling of greaseproof and muslin, you will end up with a soggy pudding. This is one occasion to go to a bit of trouble in the kitchen. I suggest you wrap the bowl in buttered, pleated greaseproof - the pleat will stop the paper tearing as your bonny pudding rises and shines - and secure it round the rim of the bowl with both a rubber band and some string. Then you need to do the same with foil, or better, I think, some cheap muslin. I say better because it is easier to lift the pudding from the scalding depths by its tuft of fabric.

Too much is made of turning out the finished pudding. Despite the fact that I have proudly upturned two apple and marmalade hats and an apricot and lemon sponge this week, I still think they can be served from the basin without shame. It is just culinary exhibitionism, really, but anyone who cites a stuck pudding as a reason not to make them should take note that it is a rather weak excuse not to have another go.

You will need a jug of something to accompany even the most heavily treacled mound. I do think custard is over-egging the pudding, so to speak, and I would always take the cream route. It seems more pleasing with the moist sponge or sticky, suety filling. None of that tiresomely fashionable crème frache, either. Such a British pudding deserves nothing less than a jug of double cream. 'What? Suet, eggs, sugar and double cream. Is he trying to kill us?' I can hear you cry. Not at all, I am simply trying to show you a good time.

Steamed apricot and lemon pudding

If you can't get hold of the squashy, ready-to-eat dried apricots, then soak the firmer variety in water for an hour or so before draining and chopping them. Serves 8

4 heaped tbsps lemon curd

150g butter

120g unrefined golden caster sugar

150g ready-to-eat dried apricots

2 large free-range eggs

170g self-raising flour

the grated zest and juice of a lemon

You will also need a buttered 1-litre pudding basin, some greaseproof paper, tin foil or muslin and some string.

Lightly butter the pudding basin, then spoon the lemon curd into the bottom. Put the butter and sugar into the bowl of a food mixer and beat until white and fluffy. Meanwhile, chop the apricots finely. The simplest way to do this is to cut them into thick slices then blitz them in a food processor until they look like chopped candied peel. Add the eggs to the butter and sugar - it will curdle a bit, but it doesn't matter - then slowly fold in the flour. Slowly mix in the apricots, then the lemon zest and juice.

Bring a pan of water to the boil, enough to come a third of the way up the basin. You may have to adjust this when the full basin goes in, and top it up as the pudding cooks. Scoop the mixture into the buttered basin.

Cut a piece of greaseproof paper to fit the top of the basin, so that some hangs over the edges, and butter one side of it. Fold a pleat into the paper so that it will not tear when the sponge expands. Lay the folded paper over the top of the pudding, then cover that with tin foil or muslin, and tie it securely. I use string and a rubber band.

Put the pudding into the water. Cover with a lid and steam for an hour and a half. You can turn the pudding out, though it tastes just as good spooned from the basin.

Apple and marmalade suet pudding

This might appeal to those who find steamed puddings too cloying. The apples are tender but keep their shape; the marmalade and the juice of the apples bubbles down to a sweet-sharp sauce. I do think it needs a jug of pouring cream, though. And you might like to add a few cloves or a pinch of mixed spice to the apples. Serves 6

200g self-raising flour

100g grated suet

a little water

800g dessert apples

the juice of half a lemon

8 tbsps marmalade

You will also need a buttered 1-litre pudding basin, some greaseproof paper, tin foil or muslin and some string.

Peel the apples, core them and cut them into thick wedges. Toss them with the lemon juice.

Put the flour into a mixing bowl, add a pinch of salt and the suet, then pour in enough water to make a stiff dough. This is usually about 6 tablespoons of water, but the amount will vary somewhat according to the flour. Your dough should be soft enough to roll out easily.

Shape the pastry into a short, thick sausage. Cut thin slices from the dough and press them into the bottom and sides of the buttered pudding basin so that the entire area is covered, leaving enough dough to roll out for a lid.

Spoon the marmalade into the apples, mix together, then pile into the lined basin, scraping all the marmalade in, too. Roll or pat out the remaining dough to fit the top of the basin. Wet the edge of the pastry - you can use water, but a bit of marmalade is even more effective - and press the edges together so that the apples are sealed in pastry.

Cut a piece of greaseproof paper to fit the top of the basin, so that some hangs over the edges, and butter one side of it. Fold a pleat into the paper so that it will not tear when the dough expands. Lay the folded paper over the top of the pudding, then cover that with tin foil or muslin, and tie it securely. I use string and a rubber band.

Bring a pan of water to the boil and put the pudding into it so that the water comes about a third of the way up the basin. You may have to top it up as the pudding cooks. Cover tightly with a lid and leave to steam for a good two hours until well risen. You can turn out the pudding, though it tastes just as good spooned from the basin.

fields.headline: Bark with bite
fields.standfirst: Yellow, coral-red and purple-black... some barks add more than ornamentation to a winter display
fields.trailText: Yellow, coral-red and purple-black... some barks add more than ornamentation to a winter display
fields.body:
At this time of year, we are all hungry for flowers. Snowdrops, hellebores and aconites go some way towards appeasing that hunger, but however lovely they are - and the combination of snowdrops and hellebores is one that I look forward to as eagerly as I do any flowers of high summer - they are not enough. They are like the jewels stitched on to an Elizabethan gown, but until the spring florification the dress remains hidden.

Nevertheless, there are other rich colours to be had at this time of year, even though it will not involve a single flower. A number of barks shine with jewel-like brilliance in the depth of winter, especially now, in the month or two between the sap beginning to rise and the first leaf buds emerging. They would be diminished by the brightness of spring, let alone the glare of summer, but are the brightest thing in the landscape on a grey, even wet, January day. Cometh the hour, cometh the plant.

A number of trees, such as acers and birches, have decorative skin-like barks, but I am thinking now about shrubs or trees that can be pruned to behave like a shrub and which will produce their firework show of bark in a year or two. The best-known and perhaps, for all its ubiquity, the best, is the dogwood Cornus alba, which has brilliant stems in shades of crimson. It is the new growth that shines the most, and if you coppice them back hard to a stool a few inches from the ground, the smooth, whippy stems grow up thicket-thick like a haze of intense coral. They look fantastic en masse, and if you have got the room to grow them in a large group (although this can make your garden look like a corporate parking area), the trick is to cut half of them back entirely every other March. A less drastic measure is to cut half of each shrub back each year.

All the varieties of C alba grow in almost all conditions (hence their invariable use in municipal and corporate planting), but they thrive in rich, slightly damp soil in full sun. C alba 'Sibirica' (sometimes called 'westonbirt') is the most common, principally, I suspect, because it does not get too big and therefore is better suited to small gardens, but there are a number of C alba varieties, all red shoots except C alba 'Kesselringii', which has melodramatic purple-black stems. If you have more space, C amomum is a more vigorous shrub and has purple shoots (and blue berries). Both are striking, if not cheery. The common dogwood, C sanguinea, has rich stems and wonderful, deep-purple autumn leaves (there are miles of dogwood hedges along lanes around here), and the cultivated variety 'Winter Beauty' or 'Winter Flame' has all its robustness with orangey stems. C stolonifera 'Flaviramea' has shoots that are yellow ochre at the tips, maturing to a rich olive green at their base. In my own garden, it seems to produce much denser growth than C alba and shimmers rather than glows. These niceties matter on a bleak January afternoon. Shimmer or glow, these dogwoods all mix well together, especially if they are all grown in moist soil with air and light around them.

There are some willows that have fabulously bright skins on their branches that can also be cut back hard every year to encourage more vigorous, vivid growth. I cannot overstress the point that shrubs grown for their bark should be cut back very hard - the harder you cut them back, the more vigorous the resulting growth, and the more dynamic the growth, the more intense the colour between December and March. With dogwoods, they have to be cut ruthlessly to the ground, but willows can be pollarded, which means retaining a single stem or trunk and making your pruning cuts at any height off it, reducing it for a few weeks to little more than a knob-topped walking stick. But it will soon resprout, and as the years go by, this point will become gnarled and knotty and the trunk will gradually get bigger, while its haircut shoots and contracts annually.

While the dogwoods will grow anywhere, willows have a preference for damp soil, though they will struggle on in chalk or sand. But give any willow some nice, soggy ground to get its roots into, and it will feel thoroughly at home. One of my pet hates is the 'Kilmarnock' willow, which achieved quite unwarranted popularity a few years ago and now sits looking like a tassellated standard lamp in a million gardens. It can look OK-ish, if clipped into a lollipop - a ball sitting on its trunk - but if your soil is at all rich, it would be far better to grow one of the coloured-stemmed willows. There is a good choice. The golden willow, Salix alba 'Vitellina', with yellow stems veering towards a yolky orange, or S x rubens , the scarlet willow, S alba 'Britzensis', which is more vermilion than scarlet. S daphnoides has purple stems coated in cottony bloom. S irrorata is also supposed to have a spectacularly luminous white coating over purple stems. I have never grown this, but I must get one.

Although willows and dogwoods look best in groups, there is hardly any need to buy them in bulk (unless you are impatient) because they all take very easily as hardwood cuttings, especially the willows. When I cut them back in early March, I always stick a group of 20cm-long stems in a row in a corner of the seed bed, perhaps adding some sharpsand to the narrow trench first. They can be planted out the following autumn.

A few of the ornamental brambles have stems that are covered in a white bloom over winter, which makes them starkly ornate. There is Rubus biflorus, which has green shoots beneath the white waxy covering, R thibetanus, which has underlying brownish purple stems and ferny leaves. R thibetanus 'Silver fern' is particularly ferny and the bloom apparently almost blue. I have never grown it, but am tempted by this description. The problem with these ornate brambles is one of space. I do grow the R cockburnianus 'Goldenvale', primarily for its lime-green foliage in spring and summer, but it also has wonderful winter stems, a pinky red dusted with a white bloom. This also takes terribly easily from cuttings, and I have found that it quickly becomes invasive if you don't keep it cut back, as it roots wherever the arching stems touch the soil. Prune it like another bramble, the autumn fruiting raspberry, and cut the whole thing to the ground each spring, which will stymie any incipient suckers and encourage new growth. The true Cockburnianus seems to have a whiter bloom than 'Goldenvale', and is probably a better bet for winter display.

A number of trees, such as acers and birches, have decorative skin-like barks, but I am thinking now about shrubs or trees that can be pruned to behave like a shrub and which will produce their firework show of bark in a year or two. The best-known and perhaps, for all its ubiquity, the best, is the dogwood Cornus alba, which has brilliant stems in shades of crimson. It is the new growth that shines the most, and if you coppice them back hard to a stool a few inches from the ground, the smooth, whippy stems grow up thicket-thick like a haze of intense coral. They look fantastic en masse, and if you have got the room to grow them in a large group (although this can make your garden look like a corporate parking area), the trick is to cut half of them back entirely every other March. A less drastic measure is to cut half of each shrub back each year. All the varieties of C alba grow in almost all conditions (hence their invariable use in municipal and corporate planting), but they thrive in rich, slightly damp soil in full sun. C alba 'Sibirica' (sometimes called 'westonbirt') is the most common, principally, I suspect, because it does not get too big and therefore is better suited to small gardens, but there are a number of C alba varieties, all red shoots except C alba 'Kesselringii', which has melodramatic purple-black stems. If you have more space, C amomum is a more vigorous shrub and has purple shoots (and blue berries). Both are striking, if not cheery. The common dogwood, C sanguinea, has rich stems and wonderful, deep-purple autumn leaves (there are miles of dogwood hedges along lanes around here), and the cultivated variety 'Winter Beauty' or 'Winter Flame' has all its robustness with orangey stems. C stolonifera 'Flaviramea' has shoots that are yellow ochre at the tips, maturing to a rich olive green at their base. In my own garden, it seems to produce much denser growth than C alba and shimmers rather than glows. These niceties matter on a bleak January afternoon. Shimmer or glow, these dogwoods all mix well together, especially if they are all grown in moist soil with air and light around them. There are some willows that have fabulously bright skins on their branches that can also be cut back hard every year to encourage more vigorous, vivid growth. I cannot overstress the point that shrubs grown for their bark should be cut back very hard - the harder you cut them back, the more vigorous the resulting growth, and the more dynamic the growth, the more intense the colour between December and March. With dogwoods, they have to be cut ruthlessly to the ground, but willows can be pollarded, which means retaining a single stem or trunk and making your pruning cuts at any height off it, reducing it for a few weeks to little more than a knob-topped walking stick. But it will soon resprout, and as the years go by, this point will become gnarled and knotty and the trunk will gradually get bigger, while its haircut shoots and contracts annually. While the dogwoods will grow anywhere, willows have a preference for damp soil, though they will struggle on in chalk or sand. But give any willow some nice, soggy ground to get its roots into, and it will feel thoroughly at home. One of my pet hates is the 'Kilmarnock' willow, which achieved quite unwarranted popularity a few years ago and now sits looking like a tassellated standard lamp in a million gardens. It can look OK-ish, if clipped into a lollipop - a ball sitting on its trunk - but if your soil is at all rich, it would be far better to grow one of the coloured-stemmed willows. There is a good choice. The golden willow, Salix alba 'Vitellina', with yellow stems veering towards a yolky orange, or S x rubens , the scarlet willow, S alba 'Britzensis', which is more vermilion than scarlet. S daphnoides has purple stems coated in cottony bloom. S irrorata is also supposed to have a spectacularly luminous white coating over purple stems. I have never grown this, but I must get one. Although willows and dogwoods look best in groups, there is hardly any need to buy them in bulk (unless you are impatient) because they all take very easily as hardwood cuttings, especially the willows. When I cut them back in early March, I always stick a group of 20cm-long stems in a row in a corner of the seed bed, perhaps adding some sharpsand to the narrow trench first. They can be planted out the following autumn. A few of the ornamental brambles have stems that are covered in a white bloom over winter, which makes them starkly ornate. There is Rubus biflorus, which has green shoots beneath the white waxy covering, R thibetanus, which has underlying brownish purple stems and ferny leaves. R thibetanus 'Silver fern' is particularly ferny and the bloom apparently almost blue. I have never grown it, but am tempted by this description. The problem with these ornate brambles is one of space. I do grow the R cockburnianus 'Goldenvale', primarily for its lime-green foliage in spring and summer, but it also has wonderful winter stems, a pinky red dusted with a white bloom. This also takes terribly easily from cuttings, and I have found that it quickly becomes invasive if you don't keep it cut back, as it roots wherever the arching stems touch the soil. Prune it like another bramble, the autumn fruiting raspberry, and cut the whole thing to the ground each spring, which will stymie any incipient suckers and encourage new growth. The true Cockburnianus seems to have a whiter bloom than 'Goldenvale', and is probably a better bet for winter display. One of the most striking dogwoods, it has stunning red autumn leaves on red shoots and grows to a height and spread of 3m. Plant supplied in a 2-litre pot. webTitle: Liam Fox: a suitable case for (private) treatment?

fields.headline: Liam Fox: a suitable case for (private) treatment?
fields.standfirst: And why Straw is wrong about juries' prudence
fields.trailText: The best thing I had to look forward to this year was satirising Government's preferred line of attack on the Tories in the run-up to the next election. It would be cheering to dissect accusations that the Conservatives had 'lurched to the Right' from a Labour Party which hadn't so much lurched as lunged across the central reservation of British politics and in to the far-Right lane. The voices of the most shameless perception-managers would surely falter when they were asked how 'moderate' New Labour had contrived policies on the powers of juries to deliver true verdicts that were more extreme than their supposedly mad opponents. Their discomfort and mendacity would have kept me in work for months.
fields.body:
The best thing I had to look forward to this year was satirising Government's preferred line of attack on the Tories in the run-up to the next election. It would be cheering to dissect accusations that the Conservatives had 'lurched to the Right' from a Labour Party which hadn't so much lurched as lunged across the central reservation of British politics and in to the far-Right lane. The voices of the most shameless perception-managers would surely falter when they were asked how 'moderate' New Labour had contrived policies on the powers of juries to deliver true verdicts that were more extreme than their supposedly mad opponents. Their discomfort and mendacity would have kept me in work for months.

If what follows is written with a certain bitterness, it is because the Conservatives are determined to deprive me of my simple pleasure and possibly my living by forcing the admission that Tony Blair is telling the truth about them - a dirty job which I never thought I'd have to be the someone to do.

In the Commons last week, William Hague and Liam Fox, his health spokesman, were filled with outraged innocence after Blair condemned them as lurchers who were planning to privatise the NHS. Labour was presenting an 'offensive caricature', they said, presumably without knowing that a tape of Fox addressing a delighted audience of private-health insurers and wide-eyed free marketeers from the Adam Smith Institute at last year's Conservative Party conference was doing the rounds. It has him describing how he will gut the health service and revive the foul climate which allowed the City to perpetrate its most systematic fraud of the last century.

That he can think this way suggests that the Conservatives have either reached a stage of dangerous pottiness of their own accord or that they have mis taken the isolated and self-congratulatory mood of reactionary London for the spirit of the country itself. If your social life consists of meeting the type of person who is invited to Spectator lunches, it is easy to believe that 'everyone' agrees that Neil Hamilton is innocent and Michael Portillo could be Prime Minister and Trollope is a far greater novelist than Dickens and, as all the rightist papers said last week, that the NHS must be privatised in whole or part. You are as likely to be as surprised when fierce attachment to the service destroys politicians who threaten it, as you were by the Labour landslide or the mass wailing for the martyred Saint Di.

The insurers were so eager to hear Fox they turned up at an 8am breakfast rally entitled 'NHS plc: Are Markets Good for Your Health?' Fox began with a mild criticism of their industry. His complaint was not that private operators provided an incredibly inefficient and costly alternative to the health service, or that they allowed the wealthy to queue jump, or that they were parasites exploiting the skills of state-trained doctors and nurses, but that their products were 'all far too expensive, too inflexible and not styled towards individual patients' - who we will doubtless have to learn to call customers if we're ever unlucky enough to find him in office.

He had come to help them restyle themselves and make their fortunes. The Conservatives would revive their businesses with the help of an apparently innocuous promise to the electorate. Their 'Patients' Guarantee' would make admitting those needing life-saving surgery the highest priority for the NHS under a Conservative government. Few people objected to the guarantee when it was proposed - but, as Fox said, 'no one has picked up yet what it actually means' - people 'haven't thought through the implications of what we're doing'.

If 'you are seeing the sickest people first it inevitably means that those with the in-growing toe nail or the cyst will have to wait,' he explained. 'They will have to find other ways of getting the treatment required, perhaps by having private medical insurance.' The reduction of the NHS from a universal service to a rump dealing only with grave illnesses would suit the insurers who have no desire to meet the open-ended costs of, say, caring for a man with Aids and would much rather organise neat, quick operations. By ignoring expensive nuisances, 'the private sector could offer new health care products for the lowest priority illnesses'. If you needed a new hip, in other words, you would have to go private if you had the money or wait for months or years in pain if you would not or could not pay.

Among his friends, Fox could afford to be explicit about the trickery behind the Patients' Guarantee. 'What we are starting is perhaps a Trojan horse' in the health service, he said.

The poor would be hit twice when his footsoldiers overran the unsuspecting citadel. Not only would they be unable to afford to play the system, but their taxes would subsidise the tax breaks for the private insurance taken out by wealthier people. That the Conservatives can consider taking from the poor to give to the rich shows they remain the party of the poll tax. I hear that Fox is now toying with the alternative of forcing everyone to buy insurance and that some of his colleagues are starting to worry about the electoral consequences of his adoration of the private sector. In Blackpool, he happily admitted his desire to relieve a fraudulent industry when he cried 'what we're proposing could revolutionise private insurance in the way we revolutionised pensions in the 1980s'.

His party's pension revolution was the swindle that euphemistic business journalists call 'the pensions mis-selling affair', as if insurance companies earned plump commissions by fooling millions in to abandoning perfectly good occupational pensions and paying through the nose for paltry private alternatives as accidentally as a confused shop assistant short changing a customer.

The financial pages are still stuffed with reports of the fines imposed on insurers and the costs of compensating their victims - now £12 billion and rising. Which, then, of the following options is madder? That Fox expects to be taken seriously when he appears to know nothing about the disgrace of the insurance industry? Or that he knows all too well and will nevertheless unleash the same spivs on the NHS?

Highlights of Liam Fox's speech (Real audio)

When Jack Straw's name comes up and you snort that a child could mould a better man out of Plasticine, Third Way colleagues protest. 'Granted he's an authoritarian who pretends to be fighting for the common people against the Hampstead élite while removing the rights of the same people to dispense justice on juries, but he's not all bad. Think of Pinochet!' they shout (or, rather, shouted). 'Think of his stand on racism!'

To be fair, they once had a point. Straw himself cites his decision to hold an inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence as the sole difference between his policies and Michael Howard's. Unlike many Conservatives, New Labour does not have a racist language and the Home Office is anxious assure us that its plans to throw citizens out of jury rooms will not lead to black defendants being punished by prejudiced magistrates. Straw has been quoting research to any one who will listen that 'proves' that magistrates are if anything more likely to acquit ethnic minority defendants than white suspects.

Yet the nice manners and discourse of Blairism conceal much. Every now and again the mask slips and the real fears of the élite are shown in all their foolishness. It is hard to imagine a more characteristic member of the new establishment than David Lipsey. He was a journalist - political editor of the Economist in the early Nineties - who demonstrated his worth to the Government and was rewarded with seats on inquires into the future of the health service and elevation to the peerage. In last week's debate in the House of Lords he gave a frank assessment of why juries' right to determine innocence or guilt in relatively serious cases should be quashed.

'I should like to make a point about the black community,' he said. 'At least some of them may opt for trial by jury in the hope that they will get an "O.J. Simpson." They hope there will be enough black jurors who are fundamentally hostile to the criminal justice system.'

This careless destruction of Straw's pretence that he is supporting the many against the few is hard to better. Repressive governments hate juries because they give ordinary people power. And what happens? Those dark, lumpen faces we glimpse from our people carriers stick together and make a mockery of our wigs and institutions.

Nor were his comments an aberration. The marvellous Helena Kennedy, who should have her statue outside the Old Bailey for leading the defence of jurors, explained that the Home Office research wasn't as definitive as it seemed. Other studies Straw forgets to mention showed pretty conclusively that the Irish faced discrimination at the hands of magistrates. Take the Irish out of the 'whites' and you discover what most people know in their guts is true: blacks and Asians are far more likely to be convicted by magistrates.

Sound clip two 'I think what we're proposing could revolutionise private insurance in the way we revolutionised pensions in the 1980s. Consider this, if patients know their treatment is graded, the private sector could offer new healthcare products for the lowest priority illnesses.'

Sound clip three 'We therefore have to come forward with a completely new system. What we're starting is perhaps a Trojan horse, because with the Patient's Guarantee, most of them haven't thought through the implications of what we're doing or the remendous opportunities that will be made available by what we're doing.

But over the coming months we will unveil a programme for a different model of healthcare, which not only will guarantee to the sickest people in the country they'll get much quicker treatment and much more ven treatment across the country than they can possibly hope for at the present time, but that many people will be able to get access to private care much more cheaply than they get at the present time.'

fields.headline: Banker with Euro vision
fields.standfirst:
The 'sick' single currency is a remedy for the ills of Europe, according to ECB President Wim Duisenberg
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The president of the European Central Bank is a passionate believer in the integrity of individual European cultures and the need for every country to choose its own social model. He is also an economic liberal: this combination would in Britain make him a paid-up Euro-sceptic, or at the very least a triumphant member of David Owen's New Europe group.
fields.body:
The president of the European Central Bank is a passionate believer in the integrity of individual European cultures and the need for every country to choose its own social model. He is also an economic liberal: this combination would in Britain make him a paid-up Euro-sceptic, or at the very least a triumphant member of David Owen's New Europe group.

But Wim Duisenberg, the chain-smoking Dutch liberal socialist, has come to the opposite conclusion: the route to individual liberty, and to cultural and political diversity in Europe is the stability of the European single currency.

Duisenberg could hardly say anything else, of course, but British Eurosceptics and the ECB President cannot both be right. After the first year of the euro's trading, the sceptics would say they have had the better of the argument. The euro has depreciated by nearly 15 per cent and has threatened to breach the one dollar level; monetary policy is set too tight for sluggish Germany and Italy, yet too loose for booming Portugal and Ireland; and the President of the European Commission has warned Italy that its successful membership of the euro cannot be sustained if its inflation rate does not fall quickly to the European average. The currency is creaking at the seams.

But from the 35th floor of the Euro Tower in Frankfurt's financial district, the prospect is rather different. Duisenberg bridles at the criticism that the euro is already a depreciating currency. 'I always find it a bit unfair to say that the euro has fallen by 12 to 14 per cent. What you do then is compare the current rate of the euro with the exchange rate that emerged on one day - 4 January last year. It is more relevant to compare the rate over the last three months with the very stable rate of between 1.08 and 1.10 [against the dollar] that existed prior to the birth of the euro in 1997 and 1998. Depreciation vis-à-vis that rate - that is relevant, and there is no denying it.'

It is not all black. He cites German exports as one notable beneficiary, but is quick to point out that in France and the Netherlands the recovery has been led by domestic demand rather than by exports. As for the currency creaking at the seams, he is scornful. 'We have delivered what we promised; that is, more or less price stability. Europe would not have had such a low average interest rate level without the euro.'

He thinks the euro has given a new dynamism to Europe. Along with the single market, it has dramatically opened things up: 'Enhancing the liberalisation of and openness of the European economy _ The euro has contributed to the fast European economic recovery, which was in a sluggish condition, almost a slump, at the end of 1998 and beginning of 1999, so that there is now much healthier growth than was anticipated almost a year ago.'

He is sharply critical of the German and French nationwide collective wage bargaining systems: 'Over the 15 years from 1982 to 1997, wage costs per unit of output in both countries have grown on average by 2.4 per cent, consistently exceeding productivity growth over such a long period and undermining the competitiveness worldwide of German and French exports.'

He wants both countries to copy the Dutch and break the system down so that wage increases can reflect local differences. He is watching uneasily the biggest German engineering union - IG Metall - pitching for 5.5 per cent this month, as that will become the benchmark for wage settlements across Germany.

As for the US, he says: 'What we're seeing is remarkable growth and productivity. I am not sure how much it can be explained by the permeation of information technology. Is the economy on a path of permanently higher productivity growth? Will it fall back to its old path? It is too early too judge.'

On the other hand: 'One thing I am convinced of is that the current wave of extra productivity growth which has started in the US will spill over into the rest of the world, and in particular to Europe. Things here always happen later than in the US. Maybe we are seeing US developments in some pockets of Europe - for instance in countries such as France, the Netherlands, Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Denmark.'

I suggest that all six coun tries have simply benefited from low interest rates both in the run-up to euro membership and now; and that the removal of the exchange rate risk in their interest rate structure has been very stimulative. He is dismissive: 'You must be more of a monetarist than I am,' he laughs.

Interest rates can impact on growth only via investment, and the responsiveness of investment to interest rates is very low, he argues. What he does note is that the European money supply has grown at an annual rate of 6 per cent for months, but even that growth has been partly generated by the euro itself; business has been using euros to finance a wave of mergers and acquisitions. It's a very delicate judgment, deciding on Europe-wide eco nomic conditions: 'There is no slack in Portugal, in the Netherlands, in Belgium or in Ireland; they are close to overheating. Elsewhere, the opposite is the case, in particular in Germany and Italy. We look at the European economy as a whole. It makes our work somewhat more difficult, and we are still in the learning process.'

The ECB has set itself the demanding objective of securing a Europe-wide inflation rate of somewhere below 2 per cent. The British government, by contrast, has pitched the target at 2.5 per cent as the centre of a range that can move 1.5 per cent either side of the target, and requires the Bank of England to explain if inflation exceeds those parameters - so that too little inflation is as 'problematic' as too much. The British criticism of the ECB is that it does not do the same because it is obsessed with price stability, building in a deflationary bias to its policy-making.

Duisenberg rebuts the charge. 'If our analysts were to indicate that we might be in for a period of negative inflation or deflation, I would be as concerned as I would be if it was the other way round - that we would be heading for a period where inflation were to exceed the 2 per cent limit we have set for ourselves. The only reason we have not announced a range with zero at the bottom is that we are not sure yet how much the measurement bias in European inflation figures may overstate the actual inflation rate.'

And what about British entry to the euro? He hopes that Britain will join, and recognises that Britain has a different financial structure in which short-term interest rates, particularly in the housing market, play a larger role than in Europe and could pose problems. But Ireland, with a similar system, has joined without lower interest rates igniting inflation. 'Inflation in Ireland is around 2 per cent, despite fears of overheating. But with the pound trading at close to DM3.20, entry at current exchange rates would lock in a punitive degree of uncompetitiveness. Duisenberg is uncompromising. The ECB would not connive at any pre-entry devaluation of the pound to ease British entry.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.standfirst: Derek Jacobi gradually takes on John Bayley's persona as he reads Iris: A Memoir
fields.trailText: Derek Jacobi gradually takes on John Bayley's persona as he reads Iris: A Memoir
fields.body:
Iris: A Memoir/ Iris And Friends

John Bayley

Read by Derek Jacobi

HarperCollins, approx. 6 hrs

Buy it at BOL

When John Bayley first encountered 34-year-old Oxford don Iris Murdoch he found her features 'blunt' and believed she was a safe bet to fall in love with, in that nobody else would find her attractive. Later, he realised that everybody was in love with her and through their 43-year marriage, his feelings for his beloved wife never dwindled, even when Iris's brilliant mind had been reduced to the confused state of an Alzheimer's sufferer.

The first of this two-part collection, Iris: A Memoir deals with Bayley's memories of their early days together and then the realisation that her mind is being paralysed and disintegrated by this terrible and mysterious affliction.

The second part, Iris and Friends, focuses more on the latter stages of her illness. This is not melancholy, though it is very moving. Bayley finds solace in the memories of his own childhood, his 'friends' as he calls them. He finds nothing but 'compensations' in her illness, 'lucid moments, cuddles, humour' and enjoys the hours when she sleeps so he can 'plunge back into the cool river of memory'.

Although frequent thoughts of double suicide enter his mind, he abandons them, understanding that suicide is only a good idea 'at the time, for the time' and that it is not a friend to him or Iris.

It is a mark of Derek Jacobi's brilliance that the listener forgets that he is the reader. With humility, Jacobi relinquishes his own persona to take on that of Bayley. It is crucial to the authenticity of the reading and few could accomplish such a difficult task.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Natalie Angier's blistering response to 'masculinist psychosis', plus The Ugliest House in the World, Anne Frank: The Biography, The Crime of Olga Arbyelina and Columbus Day
fields.body:
Woman: An Intimate Geography
Natalie Angier
Virago £8.99, pp398
Buy it at BOL

Public opinion is increasingly gripped by a masculinist psychosis writes Angier, an American journalist. Male evolutionary psychologists claim to have uncovered the essence of human nature - men are naturally more promiscuous and aggressive than women. Angier's response is blistering: women deserve better than cartoon definitions of sexuality. Drawing on science and anthropology, she maps the biological complexity and diversity of female bodies as the basis for social liberation.

Take hormone replacement: Angier says many women feel the menopause is natural and are rejecting the tablets so enthusiastically foisted on them by doctors. Though her powerful - if sometimes schmaltzy - feminist critique is primarily written for women, Angier hopes men will also read her book. I don't know many who would, but perhaps they should.

The Ugliest House in the World
Peter Ho Davies
Granta Books £6.99, pp230
Buy it at BOL

The stories in this cosmopolitan debut collection explore the bumping up of small lives against social confines. Ho Davies conjures exotic images: a Welshman arrives in Patagonia dragging a safe. After building a bank around it, he befriends Butch and the Kid, outlaws trying to go straight. But they jump him, their dreams dashed by their easy love of the gun.

Ho Davies satirises colonialism as a young officer in the Zulu War farts his way through a dinner party at Rorke's Drift. In the title story, a doctor visits his isolated father in North Wales and has to stand by him after a local boy dies in an accident. The writing is distinctive - often funny, but shot through with loss.

Anne Frank: The Biography
Melissa Müller
Bloomsbury Paperbacks £7.99, pp330
Buy it at BOL

Müller's sensitive biography begins in urgent prose with the discovery of the Frank family in the Amsterdam annex where they had hidden from the Nazis for 25 months. Their arrest frames what follows. Anne's development from chatterbox child in Frankfurt, to spirited, argumentative teenager in Holland is embedded in a deft multi-stranded narrative full of biographical and historical detail.

The fortunes of the Franks are clearly placed in the context of growing anti-Semitism in Germany and later in Holland. Müller evokes the claustrophobia of annex life, Anne's adolescent frustration and simmering resentment of her mother. The afterword by Miep Gies - who helped hide the Franks - questions how far Anne's experience symbolises the Holocaust's victims. In answer, this book affirms the rich specificity of Anne's life.

The Crime of Olga Arbyelina
Andrei Makine
Sceptre £6.99, pp277
Buy it at BOL

In the summer of 1947 Olga Arbyelina is found dazed next to a dead man on a riverbank near a French village. She is a White Russian princess living in a small émigré community, bringing up her haemophiliac son alone. Olga confesses to murder but is not believed and the case is dropped.

The narrative elegantly slips across time, summoning up lost worlds - Olga's childhood on a rural Russian estate, her marriage in Thirties Paris. With crime novel suspense, Olga slides into a monstrous nightmare. During the harsh winter of 1946 Olga gradually discovers what her son has been doing to her. Makine's touch is light and sure, his evocation of heightened reality and the French countryside reminiscent of Alain Fournier. A haunting study of maternalism, madness and 'life's strange back rooms'.

Columbus Day
Janette Jenkins
Vintage £6.99, pp217
Buy it at BOL

Jessica, the narrator, is 10 and accustomed to her family's eccentricities. Her young, beautiful mother, Olivia, drags Jess all over the country in her obsessive quest for the father who abandoned her as a child, while Jess wishes her own father were more like her friends'.

Olivia's quest takes her and Jess to windswept Blackpool; the narrative carefully weaves together glimpses of Jess's home life - her mother's drinking, her father's frequent absences and fondness for pornography - with convincing evocations of the rainy chill of an English seaside town.

But increasingly Jess is forced into taking the adult role as her mother's flightiness slips gradually into madness. The narrative voice is tender, suggesting the simplicity and resilience of childhood without becoming mawkish. An intelligent and insightful first novel.

 Reviews by Tristan Quinn and Jane Perry.

fields.headline: Designs of the times
fields.trailText: Naomi Klein's No Logo is a riveting, conscientious piece of journalism and a strident call to arms
fields.body:
No Logo

Naomi Klein

Flamingo £14.99, pp490

Buy it at BOL

Have you ever been to Nike Town? It is as close to hell on earth as any modern shopping experience outside Ikea can conceivably get.

Inside the gigantic flagship megastore on Oxford Circus, ordinary citizens drift, lost, from themed section (trainers) to themed section (other trainers). They stumble into one another like unhappy zombies, numbed by the pounding music. You see them browsing on shelved displays (more trainers), many already carrying bags emblazoned with the brand's trademark 'swoosh'.

And nearly all of them are actually wearing Nike trainers, even as they shop for more. They are Just Doing It.

Naomi Klein is a brave woman indeed. For this is the grim heart of the subject she has undertaken to investigate. No Logo contains her findings: a riveting, conscientious piece of journalism and a strident call to arms.

Her starting point is a paradigm shift that she identifies as having taken place in the first part of this century: corporations changed from selling products to selling brands. Coke, Nike, Disney, McDonald's. The continuing profitability of these corporations is invested in an immaterial set of 'brand values'; in associating their products with a lifestyle.

Klein doesn't claim that selling snake-oil - or 'value-added' to use the corporate jargon for why the orange tick sewn on to your trainers costs you 60 quid - is a new phenomenon. Her project instead is to make clear the extent to which the Brand now supersaturates our everyday lives - and to chart the implications that has for freedom of speech; labour relations and, ultimately, political authority.

It is axiomatic to Klein that the economic logic of the branded corporations is savagely inflationary. Advertising spending is subject to a law of diminishing returns. She quotes one ad man saying: '[Consumers] are like roaches - you spray them and spray them and they get immune after a while.'

The insatiable search for virgin, unbranded space has dovetailed neatly with a contraction of the public sector on both sides of the Atlantic. Corporate sponsorship has crept into schools and universities - in the process creating conflicts of public or academic interest as well as solving funding problems. At the same time, the corporations in question are expanding aggressively, and across international boundaries. Starbucks cluster-bombs the competition out of the High Street; Microsoft gobbles up rivals or levers them out of the market with software bundling.

The results: profits are ploughed back into advertising and expansion while the proportion of investment in boring bits such as the product and the workforce plummets.

Factories are closed, production is contracted out to un-unionised sweatshops in stinkingly corrupt regimes, and Western shopping centres are filled with easy-hire, easy-fire temps paid well under the odds.

The book is packed with enlightening statistics and extraordinary anecdotal evidence. All 50,000 workers at the Yue Yen Nike factory in China would have to work for 19 years to earn what Nike spends on advertising in one year. The $181million in Disney stock options Michael Eisner exercised in 1996 is enough to take care of his 19,000 Haitian workers and their families for 14 years.

In her book, Klein says there's evidence to suggest that - in order to build brand cachet in the inner cities (whence it trickles down to the all-important white suburban kids who think they're Ali G) - Nike and Hilfiger turn a blind eye to piracy.

Klein herself went through American higher education at a time when student politics focused overwhelmingly on issues of representation and speech; on the race and gender issues stigmatised by the right as 'political correctness'. She now feels they missed a trick: 'The need for greater diversity - the rallying cry of my university years - is now not only accepted by the culture industries, it is the mantra of global capital.'

The second half of the book looks at resistance, and Klein joins the dots to argue for an increasingly coherent anticorporate movement. At its crux is indignation that international branded corporations are starting to behave like privatised governments, bringing us closer to William Gibson's vision of a world in which they actually more or less supplant local or even national governments.

Many of these companies actually turn over more money than all but a few nation states. Internationally through the WTO and locally through lobbying and the threat of job losses, they exert decisive pressure on political policy.

The question is how to make them publicly accountable. The insight is that it is precisely the visibility and the transnational nature of the big brands which makes them vulnerable. It's that old theorist's favourite, 'immanent critique' (Klein, peppily, prefers 'political jujitsu') - using the momentum of a larger enemy against them. 'Adbusters' turn 'Joe Camel' into 'Joe Cancer' with a spray can; human rights groups fly a teenage sweatshop worker in for a televised tour of Nike Town. Co-opting the opposition works both ways.

Klein is aware of an important irony: her book is published by Flamingo, which is an imprint of HarperCollins, which is owned by a certain, um, ravenous global media monopolist. Her mentions of Murdoch are few and timid; but she'd no doubt argue that this is jujitsu in action.

This isn't the work of a scattershot anticapitalist, or a flaky apologist for some hippy Utopia. At its best, No Logo is fluent, undogmatically alive to its contradictions and omissions, and positively seethes with intelligent anger.

 Sam Leith edits Peterborough for the Daily Telegraph.

It's that old theorist's favourite, 'immanent critique' (Klein, peppily, prefers 'political jujitsu') - using the momentum of a larger enemy against them. 'Adbusters' turn 'Joe Camel' into 'Joe Cancer' with a spray can; human rights groups fly a teenage sweatshop worker in for a televised tour of Nike Town. Co-opting the opposition works both ways. Klein is aware of an important irony: her book is published by Flamingo, which is an imprint of HarperCollins, which is owned by a certain, um, ravenous global media monopolist. Her mentions of Murdoch are few and timid; but she'd no doubt argue that this is jujitsu in action. This isn't the work of a scattershot anticapitalist, or a flaky apologist for some hippy Utopia. At its best, No Logo is fluent, undogmatically alive to its contradictions and omissions, and positively seethes with intelligent anger.  Sam Leith edits Peterborough for the Daily Telegraph.

fields.headline: Everything but the kitchen sink
fields.standfirst: Does Michael Darlow's biography of Terence Rattigan show the sophistication required to do justice to changing views of homosexuality?
fields.trailText: Does Michael Darlow's biography of Terence Rattigan show the sophistication required to do justice to changing views of homosexuality?
fields.body:
Terence Rattigan
Michael Darlow
Quartet £25, pp530
Buy it at BOL

Michael Darlow's book, which is a revision of an earlier one (co-written with Gillian Hodson and published in 1979), aims to reveal Rattigan as a more subversive figure than he could seem when he was uncrowned king of the West End theatre. Rattigan was brusquely dethroned in the Fifties with the arrival of the movement known as the 'kitchen sink', which had no patience with craftsmanship and the implicit.

The problem didn't lie in Rattigan's unfamiliarity with the sink - not to mention the kitchen - but elsewhere, in a bedroom where no women were entertained. Authenticity was suddenly the touchstone of drama, while the laws against his sort of private life (and the censorial office of the Lord Chamberlain) remained firmly in place.

Now that gay men's lives can be examined, and even to some extent taken for granted, a book like this one needs some sophistication - a sense that attitudes have a history. It's not enough to say, of schools like the one which Rattigan (born 1911) attended, Harrow, that they were 'breeding grounds of the worst kind of male chauvinism'. Of course they were. It's just that male chauvinists were called sons of Empire then.

It was a rare homosexual of Rattigan's vintage who didn't agonise over the reasons for his dismal orientation, and to look for them in his parents. Darlow seems to have made no progress beyond such Freudian pieties, announcing ominously that Terence 'grew up to side with his mother against his father'.

Quite right too. Frank Rattigan led Vera a merry dance with his affaires (Darlow's preferred spelling throughout), and his undignified exit from the diplomatic service badly dented a prosperity that had seemed secure. Still, Frank opposed Terence's desire to be a playwright only until his promise was recognised, and then provided modest backing.

When Rattigan was a success, his father enjoyed the philandering opportunities which the theatrical world offered in profusion. When Frank by mistake opened a letter from a hotel manager in Paris complaining about Terence's conduct with another man, his shocked diatribe was undercut by a confession of his own. Frank had given Terence's gramophone to a lady friend, and would he please not tell Mum?

Nor was Vera Rattigan a smothering mother out of the text books. When Terence was undecided as to which of two plays he should submit to a theatre manager, her advice was brisk rather than indulgent: better give him a good farce than a bad drama.

Darlow quotes Rattigan's contemporary Cecil Beaton on the shame he felt about his desires, and perhaps it's reasonable to assume a similar response in another young man. But Darlow concedes that it is 'quite probable' that Terence had an affair, while a schoolboy, with the racing correspondent of the Daily Express, a family friend who also gave him tips on the gee-gees, which hardly suggests inhibition.

Rattigan started off as a stern critic of Noël Coward, though when fashions changed in the Fifties they formed a defensive alliance of dinosaurs - dinosaurs in dressing gowns. But Rattigan's attitude to love doesn't seem so far from the older man's. Coward regarded passion as something to be dreaded and endured, rather than wished for, a sort of flu of the heart. Rattigan's first success, French Without Tears, featured a character who has learned to separate sex from love and thereby spared himself the routine torments. Rattigan, too, seems to have kept his lovers at arm's length, indulging their tantrums but resisting their claims.

A partial exception was Kenneth Morgan, who lived with Rattigan in the late Forties, then left him for another man and shortly afterwards killed himself. Rattigan's 1952 play The Deep Blue Sea, which in its first draft treated a homosexual 'affaire', opens with a suicide attempt using the same means (gas fire).

The case for Rattigan as a confessional playwright, dutifully made by Darlow, pretty much begins and ends here, with the notion that Morgan's suicide was a fertile trauma. It doesn't really add up. Rattigan was shaken by Morgan's death, but as much as anything because a police inquiry could implicate him (Morgan left two suicide notes, neither of them for Rattigan). There are signs of a less than forgiving attitude to Morgan, both in Rattigan's life and his art: he used his influence to hamstring the acting career of the man for whom Morgan left him, and he gave the surname Morgan to the showgirl in another play.

In fact the passion in Rattigan's plays was, at least initially, his friends'. He borrowed trauma from Vivien Leigh's life (her attempt to run off with Peter Finch thwarted by fog at the airport) for his screenplay The VIPs, and more from Margaret Leighton (her marriage to Laurence Harvey, previously having been kept by a man) for Variation on a Theme, from Kay Kendall (leukaemia) for In Praise of Love. His use of an ex's death-wish as dramatic material is less an act of atonement than business as usual - but why shouldn't it be? That's to demand authenticity all over again.

There's actually a stronger case to be made for Rattigan as a political dramatist. His first produced play, First Episode, co-written with a fellow undergraduate, Philip Heimann, dealt with the intimacy between two young men, and how it resists the involvement of one of them with a woman. Rattigan's great professional regret was the failure of his 1949 play based on Alexander the Great, Adventure Story. Michael Darlow analyses this in Freudian terms (Frank Rattigan in the unlikely guise of Philip of Macedon), but to put on stage a military hero in whose tent no women were entertained has another dimension.

In the war Rattigan, brought up to equate homosexuality with cowardice, had found something more than adequacy under fire in himself and his friends.

Rattigan's first drafts were bolder than his final ones - in Separate Tables, for instance, the Major's offence was originally homosexual. But that isn't to say that these are 'really' gay plays. For Rattigan there was no theatre but mainstream theatre (that's what his maligned Aunt Edna figure was devised to argue).

The recent production of the play that used the gay version was a fascinating experiment, not a belated act of justice.

It was a valid test of Rattigan's powers of construction, to change something basic and see how much and how little was different. In the same spirit, it would be fascinating to see a production of The Winslow Boy which assumed that the smug little beast was guilty.
