fields.headline: Forbidden fruits
fields.standfirst: Serious writers are queuing up to pen unpaid erotica. Maybe they're just bawd, says Robert McCrum
fields.trailText: Serious writers are queuing up to pen unpaid erotica. Maybe they're just bawd, says Robert McCrum
fields.body:
It is one of the commonplaces of English literary history that almost every writer you can think of, from Chaucer to T.S. Eliot, liked, from time to time, to turn their hand to pornography. Mostly, this was confined to the bottom drawer, but you can, none the less, construct a plausible narrative of English literature through its bawdy passages.

'Bawd' itself originally meant 'a person employed in pandering to sexual debauchery'; a 'bawdy-house' is an old term for a brothel; and 'bawdy' means 'pertaining to, or befitting, a bawd', ie lewd, unchaste, obscene. So bawdiness in English life goes back to the Merrie England of Doll Tearsheet, Jonsonian codpieces and The Miller's Tale.

Similarly, the idea that the delights of sex and literature can be shared, privately, among a small circle of like-minded, educated people also has long antecedents. In the literary world, it was largely confined to the Court.

Its finest exponent, John Wilmot, the second Earl of Rochester, lived a life of almost self-conscious libertinage, abducting the gorgeous, much-courted heiress Elizabeth Malet at the tender age of 18. He settled into a state of habitual bawdiness, dividing his time between domesticity in the country and several mistresses, notably the actress Elizabeth Barry, in London.

Few in the English literary tradition have ever written as frankly about sex. His legend was secured by his death at the age of 33. Many people consider him to be one of the wittiest poets in the language, and he was admired or imitated by, among others, Marvell, Swift, Pope and Tennyson. Graham Greene wrote an entertaining, and typically irreverent, biographical account of his life, Lord Rochester's Monkey.

These two ancient cultural strands have come together in a surprising way in the current popularity enjoyed by a very peculiar publication dedicated to all kinds of bawdiness, the Erotic Review. Thanks to its glamorous and well-connected editor, Rowan Pelling, this formerly obscure literary magazine has become the place in which many seemingly staid English writers want to be seen, the place in which established names such as Auberon Waugh, Russell Hoban, Tim Parks, Malcolm McLaren, Boris Johnson, Kathy Lette and Bel Mooney, often writing for nothing, are only too happy to be found holding forth about dildos, sodomy and many other matters too blue to be fully explored in a Sunday newspaper.

The fact that these saucy contributions are paid for not in cash, but in flirtatious lunches with Ms Pelling's wicked friends, reinforces the idea that eroticism is, or should be, a matter of pure pleasure. The Erotic Review conveys an almost eighteenth-century delight in the physicality of sex. Never mind its smirkingly tasteful covers or its old-fashioned line-drawings - the Erotic Review is very bawdy indeed.

Written and edited by metropolitan wits, conceived as a postmodern homage to bawdiness, the magazine is received by its 30,000 subscribers as a sly, transgressive pleasure that lacks the banality of outright pornography or the 'dirty mac' shamefulness of the girlie magazine. Its appeal lies in its secrecy, its knowing discretion, its unconscious projection of literary group sex, in which (apparently) some contributors send each other lubricious Valentines through its pages.

If pornography is an assault on sexuality, then the Erotic Review's celebration of sex is emphatically not pornographic. The Christmas issue contained 'Diary of a Sex Fiend', an essay about fox-hunting entitled 'Venereal Pursuits', and 'Vagina Flagellata', an amusing fantasy subtitled 'Or, the Proletarian Scientific Academy's Glorious Five-Year Struggle Against Western-Inspired Sexual Ignorance in its Ranks, and the Subsequent Great Surge towards a More Enlightened Future with Sturgeon-Flavoured Knickers', interspersed with bawdy cartoons and adverts for Viagra, chatlines and erotic massage.

This combination of literature and titillation makes it exceptionally popular in certain circles. Pelling believes her subscribers are 'middle-aged men who want to show that there's life in the old dog yet'. She is about to launch a 'charm offensive' for women subscribers, though the magazine's schoolboy humour and distinct air of misogyny may inhibit a big take-up among women.

Pelling insists, however, that her readers and contributors are 'not sad people. They're the kind of people who have made, as it were, a pact with themselves that there's still an area of harmless wickedness they'd like to express.'

In the rebellion against suburban mores represented by a purchase of the Erotic Review, there is a fascinating commentary on English life. Pelling tells the story of a family friend who twitted her mother about her daughter's disgusting occupation and then admitted: 'Actually I've just bought it for Gerald for Christmas.'

The magazine offers the frisson of forbidden pleasures. And to writers this is irresistible. Where once there were waiting lists to join the Groucho Club, or to get into the Ivy in less than six months, there is now a queue of English writers simply longing to receive an invitation, in Pelling's flowing calligraphy, to write for the Erotic Review.

Pelling seems to delight in her status as a 'rank amateur' and boasts that almost none of her staff has any magazine experience. To her the Erotic Review is this 'tiny tin-pot thing' that works because it is tongue in cheek, flirtatious, uncensored and emphatically not PC. The success of the Erotic Review is all the more fascinating for being accidental. Some magazines spend massive budgets in search of It: the Holy Grail of topicality and fashionability. Here is a poorly printed magazine that by virtue of coming up with an original angle on sex and the English language has contrived to rival, among subscribers, the exclusivity of the London Review of Books or the reader-loyalty of the Lady.

Whatever the reason for its success, the Erotic Review shows every sign of being required reading for what one commentator has dubbed 'the Naughty Noughts'.

fields.headline: Understanding LBJ
fields.trailText: The latest installment of Robert Dallek's biography of Lyndon Johnson conjures up a time of pride and protest
fields.body:
Flawed Giant: Lyndon Johnson and his Times 1961-1973

Robert Dallek

Oxford University Press £12.99, pp754

Buy it at BOL

'Hey, hey, LBJ, how many kids did you kill today?' Few Americans now approaching 50 or beyond, from whichever side of the draft-dodging fence they came, will not have a ringing memory of hearing that chant - and feeling it in their solar plexus - while the United States tried to bomb, gas and shoot communist Vietnam into oblivion in the Sixties.

As John Kennedy's running mate in the 1960 Presidential election, Lyndon Baines Johnson was thrust into office with the events on that grassy knoll in Dallas in November 1963 that left JFK dead from an assassin's bullet.

The only American President to have been sworn into office aboard an aircraft, Johnson was at the centre of further tumbling American electoral records when he trounced Republican Barry Goldwater in the 1964 presidential poll that gave him what he thought was a massive mandate for his subsequent domestic and foreign policies.

The only problem, as Robert Dallek's monumental concluding volume of Johnson's life points out, was that LBJ had never effectively spelled out, then or subsequently, what he was going to do. And so, in four short years - but 48 long months - Johnson blew all of his huge popular support and left the White House a broken man when Richard Nixon busted him out of office in 1968, leaving a confused and divided United States in his wake.

Exploiting American openness, Dallek draws on an immense amount of material - official papers as well as oral history from some 10,000 tapes of recorded conversations - to show in readable and scholarly detail, devoid of partisan profiling, how Johnson could have been a contender for one of America's greatest statesmen.

In civil rights and other social policy aimed at alleviating poverty and ignorance, LBJ was a visionary. His idea of the 'Great Society' resulted in some of the most forceful social legislation since FDR's New Deal of the Thirties, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964 attacking racial segregation, the Voting Rights Act of 1965 which outlawed literacy tests aimed at preventing Afro-Americans voting, and the Medicare bill also of 1965 which still provides the basis of American healthcare policy.

But his nemesis was the Vietnam war, exposing not just his flaws as a President but the dark complexities of his personality, which by the end amounted virtually to a clinical paranoia, according to Dallek. This is the second volume of Dallek's life of LBJ, and as such steals a march on the brilliant work of Robert A. Caro, whose first two volumes of a promised four-part Johnson biography, the Path to Power and the Means of Ascent end with his controversial election to the Senate in 1948.

For now, though, to read Dallek is to be transported back with startling clarity to those tumultuous years of pride and protest, whether or not one had been there at the time.

fields.headline: Sheep ahoy
fields.trailText: Colin Tudge brings clarity to cloning in The Second Creation, his account of how Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell made Dolly
fields.body:
The Second Creation

Ian Wilmut, Keith Campbell and Colin Tudge

Headline £18.99, pp362

Buy it at BOL

Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell make improbable mad scientists. The former's benign, bearded features most closely resemble those of an earnest school teacher, while the latter has the demeanour of a folk-singer down on his luck. Both are quiet, family men, happy with their lot. Boris Karloff and Vincent Price they're not. Yet the two researchers possess a strange, fearsome, and quite unjustified reputation. If you believe some pundits, they are Frankenstein, Moreau and Strangelove rolled into two and made flesh.

And the reason for this opprobrium is simple, of course. The pair carried out one of most astonishing scientific feats of the last century: the cloning of Dolly the sheep from a single cell sloughed from the udder of an adult Finn-Dorset ewe three years ago.

It was an event that stunned the world, and triggered a tsunami of ethical alarm and moral hand-wringing by the world's politicians and religious leaders. Indeed, Dolly's creation probably defined the last decade more precisely than any other incident, for it revealed - in stark, albeit rather fleecy terms - how close our scientists have come to mastering the forces of life. Hence the consternation. Next thing, we will be cloning human beings, creating monstrous regiments of Saddam Husseins in the process, ran the headlines.

It is a notion that Wilmut and Campbell find distinctly distasteful, and ultimately unlikely. The creation of Dolly was an extremely subtle, intricate and complex act and to caricature it as a technology whose only implication was for the making of Xerox copies of dictators was silly and harmful. The Second Creation - in which the two researchers relate their versions of events to science writer Colin Tudge - therefore provides a welcome opportunity to bring a proper sense of perspective to a still highly fevered and often very ill-informed debate.

And the book certainly does that. It firstly provides an admirable chronicle of the birth of the world's first fatherless mammal, describing the science involved in intricate, but never baffling detail. The Second Creation is, if nothing else, commendably readable.

More importantly it reveals that although science is sometimes convoluted and seemingly arcane, it is actually the handiwork of 'ordinary blokes', as Tudge describes his two co-authors. Science is mankind's greatest adventure, and we can all take part, in other words. Nor should we fear the end result.

The consequence of Dolly will not be the manufacture of massed ranks of marching madmen, but the development of techniques that will help biologists to save endangered species, and to clone animals that can help provide treatments for cystic fibrosis and Parkinson's disease. These points are of critical importance.

I have one minor quibble, however. As science editor of The Observer, I broke the news of Dolly's remarkable conception on the front page of this newspaper on Sunday, 23 February 1997. The tale was quickly taken up by the wire services and within hours reports of Wilmut and Campbell's achievement were being broadcast across the world, ultimately reaching the ears of a rather apprehensive President Clinton who ordered a panel of leading biologists to report on the ethical implications.

Wilmut and Campbell had expected the news to be released and presumably received, somewhat more sedately, on 27 February when they were scheduled to publish a paper in Nature on the science involved in cloning sheep. I got there first, however, and am accordingly accused in The Second Creation of breaking Nature's embargo. This claim is incorrect, for I had obtained my information elsewhere (and not from the source that is alluded to in this book), a point that was accepted by all concerned at the time. Fortunately the authors have since agreed to set the record straight in future editions.

In any case, this small issue should not detract from a fine piece of science journalism by Tudge, the craftsman who has spliced the individual stories of Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell into a seamless whole. In doing so, Tudge has helped take the horror out of science, and placed it where it has always been: in the mainstream of human activities.

webTitle: Let's hear it from the workers

fields.headline: Let's hear it from the workers
fields.trailText: Adam Thorpe scrutinises the world of work from diverse angles in Shifts
fields.body:
Shifts

Adam Thorpe

Cape £14.99, pp238

Adam Thorpe prefaces this new collection of short stories with a quote from Kafka's diary, with which any would-be writer or artist will concur wholeheartedly: '...if I did not have to go there [to the office], I could live calmly for my own work and should not have to waste these six hours a day.'

The world of paid work, a necessity for most of us, is the uniting theme of this collection, and is scrutinised by Thorpe from diverse angles. Most surprising is that he has chosen to consider the ways in which a person's occupation often defines his or her sense of identity through a variety of manual, non-cerebral professions - some skilled, some mundane, some highly unusual - but all a refreshing change from the postmodern vogue for novels about writers or academics writing novels about writers.

The stories are all first-person narratives and, taken together, feel uncannily like a series of Talking Heads monologues; it's tempting to read them aloud in the appropriate accent. As readers of his novels will know, Thorpe has an acute ear for the cadences of speech; here he creates his narrators vividly through linguistic tics and repeated phrases - though there is a sense that his delight in his characters' idiosyncratic voices at times overrides the content of the narrative.

This is not to say that he hasn't done his research extremely thoroughly. The narrators range across decades and continents, including, among others, a dustman nearing retirement, a German blacksmith's wife, the foreman of a timber-mill in pre-Independence Congo, a young Pakistani factory worker and an Australian stone-mason in Mediterranean France. The details of the various professions involved are equally meticulous, and it's encouraging to note that in his acknowledgements, Thorpe thanks a Monsieur Fuster 'for showing me how a mattock is made'.

Some of these narratives are really impressive. The title story, a Ghanaian refugee's account of coming to Britain in the Sixties with the hope of studying, is both heart-breaking and optimistic in its depiction of ignorance and casual racism, in the face of which the innocent narrator is forced to modify his hopes and his integrity - though, crucially, without abandoning either:

'I was proud of my room even with the smell, the lack of proper daylight and the fizzing sockets. I wandered about the area and noticed other squats like ours, cheek-by-jowl with cleaned-up houses bearing brass plaques in which tapping typewriters could sometimes be heard. The little caffs, full of steam and smoke, enabled me to read a book all morning for a few pennies of warmth.'

'Bins', the opening story, boasts a splendid narrator who is pure Alan Bennett: 'And that gravel was murder to trot over, with a 10-ton bin on your back. Like a bloody donkey on the beach at Cromer, you felt like sometimes. Now my youngsters moan about Lord So-and-So not depositing his wheelie out at the end of his drive, or at the tradesman's entrance, or wherever happens to be the most convenient for them. "Do you really expect Lord So-and-So to lug out his wheelie along 300 yards of deep gravel for your bloody convenience?" I snap back. "Work!" '.

That the collection is uneven is a result of Thorpe's ambitious breadth of subjects. The most successful stories are those with English narrators because the author is writing in English, which may seem an obvious point, but in a book where authentic narrative voice is the driving force, it is an important one. Creating a French or German narrator with a convincingly idiomatic voice in English (where the reader is supposed to take it as read that they are telling their tale in their native tongue) requires a leap of imagination that is tricky when the story follows one with an English narrator. The real difficulty with Shifts is that, although most of the stories work individually, as a collection there is not enough change of register between them.

webTitle: They'll do anything to get you into bed

fields.headline: They'll do anything to get you into bed
fields.trailText: David Foster Wallace's virtuoso collection, Brief Interviews with Hideous Men, leaps boldly into the tricksy thickets of metafiction
fields.body:
Brief Interviews with Hideous Men

David Foster Wallace

Abacus £9.99, pp273

Buy it at BOL

David Foster Wallace's novel Infinite Jest, which a friend of mine nicknamed 'Infinite Book', weighed in at 981 pages, with a further 97 pages of footnotes. Brief Interviews with Hideous Men is, well, briefer, being a collection of, short stories or, more accurately, as Wallace himself puts it, 'not vignettes or scenarios or allegories or fables, exactly, though neither are they really qualifiable as short stories (not even as those upscale microbrewed Flash Fictions that have become so popular in recent years - even though these belletristic pieces are really short, they just don't work like Flash Fictions are supposed to).' That is the problem, or maybe the delight, of this book; there is almost nothing to say about it that isn't already said, or acknowledged, within the work itself.

And yet, that might suggest it is part of (Wallace again) 'the tired old "Hey-look-at-me-looking-at-you-looking-at-me" agenda of tired old S.O.P. metafiction'. Which it isn't. Wallace can work within the apparent form of such games, and even write about such games or (by extension, inevitably), write about writing about such games. Yet he also writes fictions - plausible, or detailed, or insanely detailed, or sad or disturbing fictions - that seem, eerily, to centre on the same concerns about communication that those metafictional, postmodern, wearily ironic games do; which is to say these short fictions are, in short, about how we can't or don't talk to each other. And though they are very very funny, they are also deadly serious.

The first piece, on page zero, establishes the ground of the collection (as that pagination suggests). Entitled 'A Radically Condensed History of Postindustrial Life', it reads:

"When they were introduced, he made a witticism, hoping to be liked. She laughed extremely loudly, hoping to be liked. Then each drove home alone, staring straight ahead, with the very same twist to their faces. The man who'd introduced them didn't like either of them, though he acted as if he did, anxious as he was to preserve good relations at all times. One never knew, after all, did one now did one now did one."

The double- or triple-bind of the situation - that infinite, spiralling recession in those final words - is the dilemma of any 'relationship': that there is a hideous mismatch between how we try to appear to others (to please them, to appear cool, because you never know, do you now?) and how we are, or perceive ourselves to be; and if they are doing this to us (and they are, because, after all, we are anxious to preserve good relations), then we are in a pickle.

A very similar pickle, of course, to the knots and tangles of metafiction and postmodern irony, but a much more serious pickle because metafiction, after all, is just a game, a slick, knowing, trying-to-be-cool game. Wallace plays on the problem from different angles, in different styles and formats, with different characters. 'The Depressed Person', which won an O. Henry award, painstakingly follows the loops and spirals of depressive self-obsession and self-loathing, twinned with the depressive's awareness of how repulsive such self-absorption is, and how manipulative it can appear, which feeds back into further depression and self-loathing, and so on; by turns the story inspires dark laughter, pity, and real irritation; but it describes with punishing accuracy the cruel way in which depression consumes its victims and their friends.

Self-absorption, one way or another, afflicts all the interviewees in the book, who range from men who manipulate women into bed by lies, strategies and even, at their most manipulative, an attempt to flatter by a sham-honesty about how manipulative they are. The stories are funny, clever, often disturbing; and what makes them still more so is the fact that some of these 'hideous men' are employing feminist critiques to affirm the very misogyny those critiques were supposed to have exposed.

There is a moral tone to the work that belies its facility with the tricksiness of postmodernism. In the two pieces titled 'The Devil Is A Busy Man', two anecdotes treat a similar problem from different angles; is altruism possible, given how suspicious we are of each other's - and even our own - motivation? 'Signifying Nothing' is a bold piece which could be about child abuse, or repressed memory, or power relations in a family. The fact that it is impossible to say for sure, and the terrible multiplicity of meanings that could attach themselves to that title, represents the dilemmas and uncertainties of all such cases. The question of how much honesty is possible or appropriate in relationships pervades the volume.

Yet the most 'literary' and least 'realist' pieces address these questions with just as much passion and bravery. 'Tri-Stan Sold Sissee Nar to Ecko' is a futuristic account of television entertainment executives rendered as mythic Gods and characters; thus enacting its own target, which is the appropriation of classic myths for cheap entertainment. Along the way there are some pertinent shots at how unoriginal this sort of playfulness is, and how it does not flatter an audience to point out to them the artificiality of art. Wallace's loathing of the speed with which popular entertainment can appropriate criticism and repackage it as yet more entertainment recurs in his work, but seems particularly venomous here, beneath some rather neat jokes.

He could, of course, be accused of merely colluding with the vapidities of a modern culture where everything is put into inverted commas. (One of Wallace's characters insistently puts in those inverted commas as he speaks, a gesture punctuating the text as 'f.f.', or '[flexion of upraised fingers]', a staggeringly annoying gesture which one sees all too often and is nicely observed here.) But when one reads 'Octet', a virtuoso piece of imploding metafiction, one doubts it. Wallace comes as close as is possible to asking for trust, offering sincerity, dealing with empathy and the writer-reader relationship.

Indeed, at one point he says: 'None of that was very clearly put and might well ought to get cut. It may be that none of this real-narrative-honesty-v.-sham-narrative-honesty stuff can even be talked about up front.'

That line is more than a joke. It sums up the difficulty tackled by the entire book, in that it asks for a leap of faith that we take it seriously. The alternative is a world of infinitely receding mirrors-in-mirrors, self-mockery, nihilism, of which there is an uncanny image at the end of the book: 'giving up the ghost entirely for a blank slack gagged mask's mindless stare - unseen and unseeing - into a mirror I could not know or feel myself without. No not ever again.' This is a book of formidable creative intelligence, and real moral purpose.

fields.headline: It's gone pair-shaped
fields.trailText: Sex is pretty much everywhere in William Sutcliffe's new novel, The Love Hexagon
fields.body:
The Love Hexagon

William Sutcliffe

Hamish Hamilton £9.99, pp216

Buy it at BOL

What makes love triangles quite so painful - and quite so interesting - is their irresolvability. Unless some ménage à trois arrangement can be arrived at, one party will always be left out.

The geometry of the love hexagon, however, means that despite the complexity of the original shape, it can always collapse into three pairs and no one need feel excluded. And so it happens in William Sutcliffe's excellent new novel about six young Londoners who insist on falling in and out of bed and love with one another. Lisa, Guy, Josh, Keri, Graham and Helen couple and uncouple faster than goods trains at Clapham Junction, until at last they pair off with some permanency to live (we must presume) unhappily ever after.

The formula may sound a bit trite, but The Love Hexagon is several cuts above most generation sex novels. For one thing, Sutcliffe is an extremely perceptive psychologist. He includes a complicated epigraph from Freud about sexual bondage which at first seems intellectually at odds with the easy-going atmosphere of the book. But it proves to be spot on.

As the sextet fumble their way around each other, Sutcliffe explains why they are doing what they are doing, or why they think they are doing what they are doing, and his explanations ring very true indeed. He pushes his subject - twentysomething city life - onto the black leather couch and subjects it to some good old-fashioned psychoanalysis; the result is like a ruder, funnier version of Friends with voice-overs from Frasier.

Are You Experienced?, Sutcliffe's second novel, was recently sold to Hollywood, and he seems to have half an eye on film rights for The Love Hexagon as well. It reads frequently like a screenplay, with block caps to indicate RAISED VOICES, and lots of present-tense description ('Lisa walks into the kitchen, wearing socks, knickers, and a bra - She looks at Guy'). The effect is to make everything move faster, and seem more immediate - in particular the sex scenes.

Sex is pretty much everywhere in the novel. There are several gruesomely embarrassing sex scenes, a few rather sexy ones, and one magnificent long diatribe by Keri about Josh's sexual technique ('eventually he massages himself into enough of a stiffy to somehow ram it up, and it's like a cucumber in a sandpit and the whole thing actually hurts - but he goes on and on and on, thinking he's being really unselfish'). Sutcliffe also does a good line in lad-mag gags about body odour, penile hygiene and the like.

Behind this breezy bawdy, a very sharp-penned satirist is at work. Sutcliffe has picked his targets carefully: the über-tart with a soft heart (Keri), the serial monogamist (Guy), the kooky quipster (Graham), the petulant bitch (Lisa), the depressive (Helen), and the brooding solipsist (Josh). Between them, they demonstrate most of the popular neuroses associated with being twentysomething. Sutcliffe has zeroed in on those people most likely to read his book - young Londoners.

There are several gruesomely embarrassing sex scenes, a few rather sexy ones, and one magnificent long diatribe by Keri about Josh's sexual technique ('eventually he massages himself into enough of a stiffy to somehow ram it up, and it's like a cucumber in a sandpit and the whole thing actually hurts - but he goes on and on and on, thinking he's being really unselfish'). Sutcliffe also does a good line in lad-mag gags about body odour, penile hygiene and the like. Behind this breezy bawdy, a very sharp-penned satirist is at work. Sutcliffe has picked his targets carefully: the über-tart with a soft heart (Keri), the serial monogamist (Guy), the kooky quipster (Graham), the petulant bitch (Lisa), the depressive (Helen), and the brooding solipsist (Josh). Between them, they demonstrate most of the popular neuroses associated with being twentysomething. Sutcliffe has zeroed in on those people most likely to read his book - young Londoners.

fields.headline: Fat and furious
fields.standfirst: Alexei Sayle's buttoned-up comic genius spills over the page in his collection of pitiless tales, Barcelona Plates
fields.trailText: Alexei Sayle's buttoned-up comic genius spills over the page in his collection of pitiless tales, Barcelona Plates
fields.body:
Barcelona Plates
Alexei Sayle
Sceptre £12, pp216

You can't get much further from the Aga than these 14 bleak, funny, pitiless tales. (I'm surprised Alexei Sayle didn't call them contes and reel in the half-pun). One of them features Nic and Tob, a comedy double-act on television, whose 'arrival on the comedy scene had fortunately coincided with the rise of stupidity, the public having tired of being shouted at by fat men about things that weren't their fault as a form of light entertainment.'

It's not long since Alexei Sayle was the fat git in a suit shouting at us about things. Not so much fat, I thought, as boundless comic energy buttoned in, and then squeezed out into a television series. In hardback, the tone is cooler, harder. Nic and Tob at the BBC Club bar overhear one top executive say to another: 'You know I've been thinking that maybe we should do more than pander to the lowest taste of the idiot public, chasing every will o' the wisp, voguish fad. Perhaps as a public broadcast organisation we should try to illuminate the world with a bright pure light of elevating joy.' (As it turned out, the man had been in the middle of a nervous breakdown and was soon fired, becoming an organic baker in Penrith.)

Nic and Tob try to prevent this demented change of broadcasting policy by becoming voodoo priests and so manipulate the dead souls of the BBC Light Entertainment Department to their advantage. So that's the answer. I've often wondered how it's done.

Many of the stories have punch lines. Most have the impersonality of a joke. In a joke a man goes into a pub. It's not a man called Peter, with ginger hair, a mole on his left cheek and carrying a folded copy of the Lymington Times, it's just a man about to run into a punch line. Or, quite often with Alexei Sayle, a stab line: 'The black man took him down an alley, handed over the drugs and then he and a friend tried to rob Barnaby. But Barnaby pulled out the knife he'd bought at the motorway place outside Madrid and cut them both across the face with two quick strokes, forehand and backhand, swick, swick. Swick, swick.'

This is life looked at through the wrong end of a telescope, the vision of Nathaniel West in Miss Lonelyhearts and to my mind just as good. Alexei Sayle is right. We are clearly (the politician's favourite word) minuscule creatures scurrying round this shit-heap of a country looking for an incongruous end. Some Entertainment Department. Swick, swick.

The finest story is 'Big-Headed Cartoon Animal'. A beautiful liberal couple take a holiday in California and are entranced to be surrounded in Hollywood by equally beautiful people. Towards the end of their stay they visit what Sayle coyly calls: 'The original theme park, the magic kingdom, supposedly the happiest place in the fucking world.' Here are the employees dressed as the big-headed cartoon animals, and here, Pete observes, are all the ugly folks they'd kept out of Hollywood.

While his wife enjoys the rides, Pete becomes obsessed with the cleanliness of the park, the absence of rubbish. He examines a rubbish bin and finds a small catch which allows him to hinge back the bin, revealing a circular shaft, its walls lined with the slime of a trillion junk meals dropping perhaps 50 feet into Stygian darkness.

Pete gets bumped by one of the uglies, falls down the shaft and enters an appalling world of rubbish conveyed on belts and locomotives by Hispanic slaves, towards huge furnaces which, in turn, power the rides above. Here, Pete is picked up by security guards, interrogated and punished.

Something heavy and foam-lined is slipped over his head: 'Some sort of helmet, he thought, with two tiny eye-holes to look out of. Next, a one-piece suit was put on his struggling form, then boots on his feet and his hands jammed into large heavy gloves.'

Back on the surface, Pete rushes to embrace his wife. 'All she saw was the big-headed cartoon animal that looked like a dog, but wasn't a dog, waving its paddles at her and all she heard was a distant mumbling from deep inside its big silly cartoon head'.

Talk about an inner voice... inside every fat git there's a poet trying to get out. Well, he's out.

webTitle: Sex with dead people? Even Hannibal likes to have his victims served hot

fields.headline: Sex with dead people? Even Hannibal likes to have his victims served hot
fields.trailText: Can Mo Hayder's Birdman tell a tale of murder and necrophilia in the shadow of the Dome without lurching into pornography?
fields.body:
Birdman
Mo Hayder
Bantam Press £9.99, pp361
Buy it at BOL

Thomas Harris is the figure that Mo Hayder's publishers invoke in the excited publicity for their debut author's Birdman. Like Harris, Hayder explores depravity, sexual sadism, a kind of psychopathic evil that sends a frisson of delighted repulsion down the reader's spine. Like him, she does her research and deploys shock tactics - all those peculiar, perverse details designed to probe and zap the unprotected nerve-ends; just when you think they can't possibly go any further in their depictions of foul humanity, they do. Like him, too, there's a schlocky romanticism hidden deep in the layers of worldly knowledge, and a Manichaean sense of good and evil.

Of course, Mo Hayder is unlike Harris in one important way, which her publishers are quick to exploit. She's a woman. What's more, she's glamorous, a blonde with an enigmatic smile and an exotic CV. This gives her world of baroque evil an extra twist: somehow, it's different when it is not a middle-aged man but a young woman writing about a young woman being raped, mutilated, sexually tortured, subjected to the most extreme kinds of bestiality and torture. Hayder says that she is simply writing about the things that go on all around us - the world that's always with us but that most of us don't see and can barely imagine.

None the less, she dwells lingeringly upon the horror, is at her most detailed and lyrical when it comes to what is most appalling. She embraces distaste. I guess she has to - the value of these kind of hard-boiled sexual horror stories is their ability to shock (and certainly I was shocked).

The trouble with shock is that it has rapidly diminishing returns. There are few taboos left to us today. To live up to The Silence of the Lambs, in Hannibal Thomas Harris had to turn the heroic anti-hero Lecter and FBI agent Clarice Starling into sexually involved cannibals, staring at each other across the opened skull and steaming brains of their still-living victim. Horror quickly becomes camp, nastily comic, ludicrous. Birdman is, likewise, a sickeningly baroque novel: the gothic masquerading as realism; a certain wild and pornographic imagination pegged into place by the medical jargon and the stock sentimentality of the central characters.

Birdman is set in Greenwich. Its hero, Jack Caffery, is new to the Met's murder squad, the AMIP, and his first case is the brutal killings of five young women, all ritualistically murdered and dumped on wasteland near the Millennium Dome (a site that'll be popping up in lots of novels, I'd guess). The sexual serial killer that he's after has a creepy signature: he inserts a living bird into the chests of his victims.

Caffery knows that the killer will strike again. The dark heart of the novel is necrophilia. It's a crime that is described in queasy and almost empathetic detail. Of course, there's no subject that is unfit for fiction, but some subjects are more problematical. It is hard to describe killing a woman and then having intercourse with her gradually decomposing body without lurching into pornography. Mo Hayder can't do it. I don't know who could.

Caffery is a handsome, doomy young man, with a hidden sadness in his life. It is this sadness that makes him an obsessive, tormented detective ripe for a sequel. He has, at the beginning of the novel, a girlfriend who is beautiful and brittle and rich, and who can't understand the depths of his grief; and by the end a girlfriend who is also beautiful, but who is an artist and so more sympathetic to his self-indulgent gloom.

The journey of the novel is a detective trail, but it is also a clichéd tale of Caffery's redemption - his self-forgiveness; the 'yes' he can finally say to life that contrasts with the ghastly negatives of the murderer he tracks. It's all too slick and morally assuaging, the clashing contrasts between death and life, the violent struggle between evil and good. And although there's a compelling quality about the book - its prose is a canny mix of the quasi-literary and the streetwise, it pushes all the right buttons, has a giddying kind of excitement in its escalating horrors - it left me with a nasty taste in my mouth. I felt as if I'd been had. I'd read to the end what I wished I hadn't begun.

fields.headline: Hats off, monsieur
fields.standfirst: To the French he's an institution. To us he's that man from Il Postino. But Philippe Noiret is a charmer in any language
fields.trailText: To the French he's an institution. To us he's that man from Il Postino. But Philippe Noiret is a charmer in any language
fields.body:
Philippe Noiret has his nose in Le Figaro when I arrive. His legs are crossed, his suit is three-piece tweed, adorned with a yellow hankie. A silk patterned bow-tie blooms from his neck. He looks a perfect English gentleman, with the flamboyant bulk of a French aristocrat, and a touch of something madder, a little perverse anarchy. He manages to look both welcoming and forlorn as he stands up. 'One can read Le Figaro ,' he says apologetically, 'as long as one knows in advance how reactionary it is.'

He has grown a wispy white beard and aged 40 years since his 'first real film', as he calls Louis Malle's Zazie Dans Le Métro , but he is otherwise wonderfully similar to the character he played then - Gabriel, the camp, perfumed uncle who dealt extravagant politeness and resigned melancholy in equal measure. He can't really be equated, though, with any one of his roles. 'I've played homosexuals, transvestites, assassins, bourgeois, princes, craftsmen, labourers, farmers,' he says. 'I've played everything.'

Noiret is now in his seventieth year, and he made his hundredth film more than a decade ago. He is considered, in France, something of a national treasure - he was President Mitterrand's favourite actor. And yet he is best known here and in the US for playing a venerable Italian projectionist (in Cinema Paradiso) and a famous Latin American poet (in Il Postino). This, he says, is one of the many 'paradoxes' of his career. He is often described as a character actor, as if he could really disguise himself, but his strong build and mournful, cartoonish face make a very recognisable signature, whether he uses them in the service of gravitas (as in Tavernier's Life and Nothing But), rowdy arrogance (as in his new film, The King of Paris) or light entertainment (as in D'Artagnan's Daughter).

Noiret speaks slow, florid French, with rounded vowels that seem to rise from his belly. He talks about performing texts you can 'get your teeth into', and you can really imagine him taking pleasure in chewing each word. He has a quick ear for irony, a modesty that melts effortlessly into conversation, and would probably love, if it could be couched in the right sort of prose, a good row. 'The critics were unanimous,' he says at one point, rather triumphantly, 'in dragging us through the mud!' The performance in question was a play, two years ago. It was the first time he'd been on stage for 35 years. Ironically, his new movie, The King of Paris is about a distinguished stage actor of the 1930s who is trying to get into film. The part was written for Noiret by director Dominique Maillet, before either of them suspected a return to the theatre would be on the cards. Maillet, a former journalist, had written a book about Noiret, with his collaboration. He knew everything about him, and was in a good position to tailor a role to his life and to his talents.

Noiret was born in Lille, in northern France. His father was in the rag trade, and because the company he worked for had branches all over the country, the family moved around, and ended up in Toulouse during the war. They moved to Paris in 1946, where Philippe was expelled from the lycée (his grades were awful) and sent to a school run by a Catholic order called the Oratoriens - D'Artagnan was a former pupil. There, a teacher encouraged his interest in the theatre, and invited contemporary authors - Montherlant, Julien Green - to come and give their opinion on Noiret's thespian potential.

He got work soon after he left, among other things as an extra in Jean-Louis Barrault's company. And one day a wild dream came true - Jean Vilar took him on at his Thétre National Populaire. Vilar is not much known about here, but he was the founder of the Avignon festival, and was at the time the most important figure in European theatre.

Noiret recalls that 'Vilar lived in the service of an idea, which was to bring to the theatre people who wouldn't normally go, who had perhaps never been. So he did market research in all the big commercial and industrial companies on the outskirts of Paris, and set up subscription systems with them - the tickets were very affordable. And then he did a series of little things which were very important in changing the relationship certain classes had to the theatre. For example, instead of starting the performance at nine o'clock as usual, he began at eight because he thought, quite rightly, that a lot of people could then come straight from work; you could have dinner in the theatre, as well. The programme was the entire text of the play with photographs of the production, so you left with a book. And there was often some kind of music-hall evening, so Edith Piaf came to sing, as did Maurice Chevalier.'

Noiret says the TNP is one of his fondest memories, and, he adds, the place he met his wife, Monique Chaumette, who also acted in the troupe, and with whom he still lives.

Even in his youth, Noiret played older men. 'I've always been large,' he says, 'with a deep voice, so I never had the physique for roles like valets or harlequins. I played Gérard Philipe's father when I was 24. I didn't catch up to the age I had always played until I was about 40.'

But an awareness of his size has become an essential part of his technique. 'One of the few important things you can learn in this business,' he says, 'is to always know what is on view. You know, when you first come to the cinema from the theatre you feel lost, and then you understand that there are rules you can learn. And later, as you go on, you understand that there aren't any rules, that everything you thought you understood never existed. But there is this one remaining rule, I think, which is to have an idea of the importance you have in a shot, a sense of the volume you take up.'

It would seem safe, if indelicate, to speculate that some of his volume stems from his love of food. The film which secured Noiret's international reputation was Marco Ferreri's La Grande Bouffe of 1973. The plot is simple: four friends retire to a country house in order to eat, or rather feast, themselves to death. Their meals are fantastical and over the top; many of them are based on dishes prepared by Napoleon's chef. One of Noiret's co-stars, Marcello Mastroianni, explained how the order of their deaths was decided: '[Catherine] Deneuve [his lover at the time] and I had been planning for some time to take a vacation in Jamaica, so I asked Marco to kill me off first so the trip wouldn't be ruined. Then Piccoli had another picture to make, so he was killed off. Ugo had to do something else, so he didn't want to stick around till the end, either. Noiret was like the cat that swallowed the canary.'

Last to go in the film, Noiret in the flesh has an air of the contented gourmet about him. He shared his love of fine food with another of his directors - Alfred Hitchcock. In fact, Noiret's first response to the mere mention of Hitchcock is that he was 'delicious'.

They worked together on one of the director's late films, Topaz , and Noiret has a wonderful story about their gastronomic friendship: 'The first scene we shot when we got to the studio in Los Angeles was one in which I had to eat and drink. Before the shoot Hitchcock called me over and said, "I sent for some duck pté d'Amiens for you, all the way from France, because I know that one is very good. And I've chosen a Bordeaux Cheval Blanc nineteengodknowswhat... for you. But since that wine is too good for the film, I've had it decanted into bottles of ordinary burgundy. But what's inside them is this Bordeaux - so you can drink the wine and eat the pté."'

'So,' he continues, 'we filmed the first scene. I was very moved to be on that big set at Universal, with this great director, all that silence - he terrorised people, not us, but people in general - so we film the first take, a master shot. I eat, I drink, I eat, I drink, I say nothing - I don't have any lines - I do the scene. He says "CUT!" There's a pause, and he says, "MISTER NOIRET!"' - Noiret imitates Hitchcock in a booming voice, with an English accent - 'Oh, I was a wreck - what had I done? I said, yes, sir? He said, "HOW WAS THE PATE?"'

Towards the end of our conversation I show Noiret a book I have just bought, about the films of Agnès Varda. Her first film was also one of his earliest ( La Pointe Courte , 1955). Varda had been the photographer at the Thétre National Populaire, and in the book are snaps of many of Noiret's old friends. He flicks through with a random curiosity: 'Louis Aragon - what a shit he was... Ah, Delphine Seyrig, everyone was in love with her... charming woman. Sad, that. That's the worst thing. It's not getting old. It's watching others disappear. I've a got a photo in my study which Agnès Varda took of all the TNP troupe - Gérard Philipe, Maria Casarès, Monique and everyone... I could put little crosses all over it. It's terrible.'

But before he has time to dwell on the matter he has picked up his coat, put on his hat, and escorted me, gently, outside. Almost immediately, he removes his hat again, with the sort of sweeping gesture only a true musketeer could pull off, and holds out his hand: 'It's been a great pleasure.'

 The Philippe Noiret season at the Institut Français in London runs from 27 Jan-23 Feb. The King of Paris opens next month.

For example, instead of starting the performance at nine o'clock as usual, he began at eight because he thought, quite rightly, that a lot of people could then come straight from work; you could have dinner in the theatre, as well. The programme was the entire text of the play with photographs of the production, so you left with a book. And there was often some kind of music-hall evening, so Edith Piaf came to sing, as did Maurice Chevalier.' Noiret says the TNP is one of his fondest memories, and, he adds, the place he met his wife, Monique Chaumette, who also acted in the troupe, and with whom he still lives. Even in his youth, Noiret played older men. 'I've always been large,' he says, 'with a deep voice, so I never had the physique for roles like valets or harlequins. I played Gérard Philipe's father when I was 24. I didn't catch up to the age I had always played until I was about 40.' But an awareness of his size has become an essential part of his technique. 'One of the few important things you can learn in this business,' he says, 'is to always know what is on view. You know, when you first come to the cinema from the theatre you feel lost, and then you understand that there are rules you can learn. And later, as you go on, you understand that there aren't any rules, that everything you thought you understood never existed. But there is this one remaining rule, I think, which is to have an idea of the importance you have in a shot, a sense of the volume you take up.' It would seem safe, if indelicate, to speculate that some of his volume stems from his love of food. The film which secured Noiret's international reputation was Marco Ferreri's La Grande Bouffe of 1973. The plot is simple: four friends retire to a country house in order to eat, or rather feast, themselves to death. Their meals are fantastical and over the top; many of them are based on dishes prepared by Napoleon's chef. One of Noiret's co-stars, Marcello Mastroianni, explained how the order of their deaths was decided: '[Catherine] Deneuve [his lover at the time] and I had been planning for some time to take a vacation in Jamaica, so I asked Marco to kill me off first so the trip wouldn't be ruined. Then Piccoli had another picture to make, so he was killed off. Ugo had to do something else, so he didn't want to stick around till the end, either. Noiret was like the cat that swallowed the canary.' Last to go in the film, Noiret in the flesh has an air of the contented gourmet about him. He shared his love of fine food with another of his directors - Alfred Hitchcock. In fact, Noiret's first response to the mere mention of Hitchcock is that he was 'delicious'. They worked together on one of the director's late films, Topaz , and Noiret has a wonderful story about their gastronomic friendship: 'The first scene we shot when we got to the studio in Los Angeles was one in which I had to eat and drink. Before the shoot Hitchcock called me over and said, "I sent for some duck pté d'Amiens for you, all the way from France, because I know that one is very good. And I've chosen a Bordeaux Cheval Blanc nineteengodknowswhat... for you. But since that wine is too good for the film, I've had it decanted into bottles of ordinary burgundy. But what's inside them is this Bordeaux - so you can drink the wine and eat the pté."' 'So,' he continues, 'we filmed the first scene. I was very moved to be on that big set at Universal, with this great director, all that silence - he terrorised people, not us, but people in general - so we film the first take, a master shot. I eat, I drink, I eat, I drink, I say nothing - I don't have any lines - I do the scene. He says "CUT!" There's a pause, and he says, "MISTER NOIRET!"' - Noiret imitates Hitchcock in a booming voice, with an English accent - 'Oh, I was a wreck - what had I done? I said, yes, sir? He said, "HOW WAS THE PATE?"' Towards the end of our conversation I show Noiret a book I have just bought, about the films of Agnès Varda. Her first film was also one of his earliest ( La Pointe Courte , 1955). Varda had been the photographer at the Thétre National Populaire, and in the book are snaps of many of Noiret's old friends. He flicks through with a random curiosity: 'Louis Aragon - what a shit he was... Ah, Delphine Seyrig, everyone was in love with her... charming woman. Sad, that. That's the worst thing. It's not getting old. It's watching others disappear. I've a got a photo in my study which Agnès Varda took of all the TNP troupe - Gérard Philipe, Maria Casarès, Monique and everyone... I could put little crosses all over it. It's terrible.' But before he has time to dwell on the matter he has picked up his coat, put on his hat, and escorted me, gently, outside. Almost immediately, he removes his hat again, with the sort of sweeping gesture only a true musketeer could pull off, and holds out his hand: 'It's been a great pleasure.'  The Philippe Noiret season at the Institut Français in London runs from 27 Jan-23 Feb. The King of Paris opens next month.

webTitle: Fantasy football helps schoolboys score at maths

fields.headline: Fantasy football helps schoolboys score at maths
fields.standfirst: Blunkett's push for higher standards of numeracy is given a boost as pupils get their kicks from figures
fields.trailText: Fantasy football will be enlisted this week in the battle to make maths fun and end the innumeracy of many of Britain's soccer-obsessed children .
fields.body:
Fantasy football will be enlisted this week in the battle to make maths fun and end the innumeracy of many of Britain's soccer-obsessed children .

Education Secretary David Blunkett has decided that a nationwide schools fantasy league is the way to catch the imagination of boys, who are often bored by figures. The Sheffield MP - under fire for demanding the sacking of Danny Wilson, the manager of his beloved Sheffield Wednesday - has entered his own team in the league, which has been running in 200 pilot schools since the beginning of the season.

Wilson will gain some consolation from the fact that Blunkett's team is performing 'very badly indeed', according to sources close to the Minister. This may, however, have something to do with the Education Secretary's decision to include players from Sheffield Wednesday, who have been at the bottom of the Premiership for most of the season.

'If I was as poor at my job as Education and Employment Secretary as I am at fantasy football, I'd have to sack myself,' said Blunkett last night.

The Minister's other recent foray into football has not been too successful either. Blunkett and three other Sheffield MPs proposed an early-day motion in the Commons last week suggesting that Wilson should be sacked after talks with Charterhouse, a finance house that backs Sheffield Wednesday.

Football managers rallied behind Wilson and told the MPs to stop interfering with the running of the club. Blunkett and two of the MPs later distanced themselves from the demand for Wilson's head.

Each child will pay £3.50 a year to join the fanstasy league, 20 pence of which goes to children's charity Barnardos. The league is run by a non-profit organisation which also produces maths lessons to be used with the game.

Entrants use an imaginary £50 million to buy their team of Premiership players. The performance of the children's teams in real weekend matches leads to a ranking in the fantasy league. Each week the schools will be posted the results showing the leading teams, ranked by school and individual pupil.

Ministers have decided the pilot scheme has been a huge success in persuading reluctant boys to start using maths.

After being extended to the secondary sector, it will be launched in primary schools next season.

The fantasy league forms part of Maths Year 2000, which follows last year's National Year of Reading. The Government has set itself a target of 75 per cent of 11- year-olds reaching the ex-pected level at maths by the end of 2002. In last year's tests 69 per cent of boys and girls reached that level. But by the time they take GCSEs at 16, boys fall behind girls in all subjects.

A government spokesman said: 'Boys traditionally have performed poorly and have regarded failure at maths as a badge of pride. That has got to stop.'

Prime Minister Tony Blair, who will launch the scheme on Tuesday, said: 'The football may be a fantasy, but the maths is for real. Tackling under-achievement in the three Rs is a top priority. The literacy strategy has been a huge success. This has been followed by the Government's numeracy strategy. That is starting to make a real difference.'

David Reynolds, Professor of Education at Loughborough University and the man responsible for the Government's numeracy strategy, said last night: 'We have not always taught maths in a way that children can really take to heart. This is potentially very exciting.'

The most successful school in the pilot scheme is St Thomas Moore High in South Shields, Tyne and Wear.

True to form, the single best manager is a girl from Eastbrook School in Dagenham, Essex, who will be honoured by the Prime Minister on Tuesday.

'Girls are beating boys at everything nowadays,' said Blunkett. 'Boys should see this as a challenge and make sure they aren't left behind.'

How it works

 At the beginning of the season the 'manager' chooses a team using a set budget - £50 million in the case of the schools league - from a list of real players in the Premiership (in Blunkett's team, for instance, Manchester United's star striker Dwight Yorke will have cost considerably more than West Ham veteran John Moncur).

 Each week the players are given points for goals scored, or in the case of defenders and goalkeepers, their ability to keep goals out. Points are then docked for own goals, bookings and sendings off. The teams are then ranked according to the total points scored.

 At least once a season, managers are allowed a transfer 'window' to buy and sell players, while keeping within their fixed budget.

webTitle: Madrid mourns as ETA victim is buried

fields.headline: Madrid mourns as ETA victim is buried
fields.standfirst: Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: Spanish dignitaries and grieving relatives yesterday buried the army officer killed by the Madrid car bomb that has shattered ETA's ceasefire and battered hopes of a swift solution to the separatist conflict in the Basque country.
fields.body:
Spanish dignitaries and grieving relatives yesterday buried the army officer killed by the Madrid car bomb that has shattered ETA's ceasefire and battered hopes of a swift solution to the separatist conflict in the Basque country.

Pedro Blanco Martín, 12-year-old adopted son of the dead colonel, accepted the national flag, his father's uniform cap and a posthumous military cross from the Prime Minister, José María Aznar, who led dozens of senior civilian and military authorities in mourning for Lt-Col Pedro Antonio Blanco García.

The funeral was held in the courtyard of army headquarters in Madrid. Pedro, his mother Conchita and 15-year-old sister Almudena (also adopted) sat bundled up against the chilly morning, mostly dry-eyed after spending the night watching over the coffin.

Buglers sounded their orders, colour guards saluted the coffin and a priest read from the Book of Genesis - Cain's killing of Abel. The Vicar-General, Monsignor José Manuel Estepa, castigated the killers and criticised those who refused to accept ETA's 'criminal violence' for what it is - an apparent reference to Basque nationalist leaders, including some in the Catholic Church, who want to bring radical separatists into the political fold.

The killing has stunned Spain, though the separatist group had warned that it would break its truce after 3 December, accusing the Basque political parties of not doing enough to further the cause of self-determination.

Police have already thwarted attempts to bring two huge van bombs to Madrid and to detonate a car bomb in Bilbao.

Last Friday morning, however, the terrorists finally struck. It was two degrees below zero as Blanco left his flat to meet the car that was to take him and his immediate superior, a general, to work.

The car was 10 minutes late - because of traffic jams caused by a false alarm over a suspect pack age, a delay that probably saved the general's life. As Blanco walked up to the red Renault Clio , the bombers, parked around the corner, triggered the detonations. Blanco was killed instantly, his body shattered by the blast of 45lb of explosives.

Police found the officer's charred remains 35ft from the car's twisted wreckage. They also found a tattered business card bearing the officer's name. Pedro junior was at home watching television. He ran into the next room: 'Mummy, it's Daddy.'

The family did not know that ETA had apparently been watching Blanco, although they knew the dangers, since their neighbourhood of redbrick military housing has been the site of eight attacks since 1986. Police have found no trace of the bombers .

Today at noon, tens of thousands are expected to converge on Madrid's Plaza de Colón for a march against the violence. But it will come too late for Blanco's wife and children, who said their last goodbyes at a simple, private burial in a quiet cemetery just outside Madrid.

fields.headline: After Kohl, the deluge
fields.standfirst:
The former Chancellor's silence on the source of illegal funds has put his party into freefall, says Denis Staunton in Berlin
German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Helmut Kohl moved through his cheering supporters in Bremen on Friday night like a hero returned from battle, stopping here and there to grasp a hand or exchange a warm word. When he reached the platform, the 4,000-strong gathering of Christian Democrat activists clapped, cheered and roared their approval of the man who had resigned in disgrace as their honorary chairman three days earlier.
fields.body:
Helmut Kohl moved through his cheering supporters in Bremen on Friday night like a hero returned from battle, stopping here and there to grasp a hand or exchange a warm word. When he reached the platform, the 4,000-strong gathering of Christian Democrat activists clapped, cheered and roared their approval of the man who had resigned in disgrace as their honorary chairman three days earlier.

Watching Kohl soak up the adulation, it was hard to believe that he is under criminal investigation for accepting illegal donations to party funds and channelling them through a web of secret accounts and that his political career has ended in humiliation. Earlier that day, his own party confirmed that it is considering taking legal action against the former Chancellor to force him to identify the anonymous donors who gave so generously while he was in office.

'If there is one thing I have always been incapable of, it is being a saint and presenting myself as a saint,' Kohl told his admirers. 'But when I see who is standing up now and striking moral attitudes, I have to tell you that I find it hard to bear.'

There was no doubt among the audience about the target of Kohl's barb - his successor as party leader and long-time political associate, Wolfgang Schäuble, who has now become his bitterest enemy.

When Schäuble, paralysed from the waist down since an assassination attempt in 1991, rolled his wheelchair through the door of Kohl's office on Berlin's Unter den Linden last Tuesday, he knew he was on a mission without hope. He asked Kohl to identify publicly the donors of up to two million marks (£660,000) the former Chancellor has admitted accepting in cash during his last five years in office. Forty minutes later, after an encounter aides described as 'very noisy', a grim-faced Schäuble left for a meeting of his party's 43-strong leadership executive to offer his resignation as leader.

Faced with a scandal that brings new revelations almost every day and is threatening to destroy the party that has governed Germany for most of its postwar history, the leadership backed Schäuble and forced Kohl out of his position as honorary chairman.

But as Friday's performance in Bremen made clear, Kohl is far from giving up the fight to save his reputation and is confident that he will see off the new party leadership whom he views as incompetent, disloyal upstarts.

While Kohl was relishing the limelight in Bremen, Marion Huellen was comforting her two teenage sons at their little house in Bonn following the suicide of their father. Wolfgang Huellen, who was in charge of the finances of the Christian Democrats' parliamentary party, hanged himself at his Berlin flat last Thursday. He left a note indicating he was afraid a parliamentary inquiry into party finances would uncover his own irregularities and police began an investigation into whether he may have been stealing from party funds.

Huellen's death was the most macabre twist in an unfolding scandal that has revealed to a bewildered German public a picture of their government accepting suitcases full of cash from arms dealers, laundering money through Swiss banks and adopting business practices more usually associated with the Mafia. But amid the fast-moving drama, one factor has remained constant since the scandal broke last November - Kohl's silence about the source of his illegal funds.

He claims he promised donors they would remain anonymous and he is not prepared to break his word. 'I have never in my life abandoned my honour and I will not do it now either,' he told an appreciative audience of Hamburg businessmen last week. His lawyers are understood to have advised him that, despite the criminal investigation, he is in little danger of being prosecuted on what is already known.

Some commentators have suggested that one reason Kohl will not name the donors is because they did not exist. They suggest that the money may have come from secret accounts in Switzerland and Liechtenstein used by the CDU to disguise the origin of illegal donations.

THE PARTY IN HESSE has admitted it made regular transfers from a Swiss account, disguising the money as bequests from CDU supporters. In a tasteless twist, the party claimed these non-existent supporters were Jewish Holocaust survivors.

Hesse's Prime Minister, Roland Koch, a cold-blooded careerist, admitted on Friday that four million marks in the party's Swiss account is missing. 'I hope none of you think I'm making a personal admission of guilt,' he added hastily. Most worrying for Kohl is an investigation by Geneva prosecutors into an alleged 85m marks in bribes paid by the French oil company Elf Aquitaine in connection with its purchase of an eastern German oil refinery in the early 1990s. Prosecutors last week froze accounts held in Liechtenstein by Dieter Holzer, a lobbyist with close links to Kohl, and they are investigating some of the former Chancellor's most trusted associates.

Kohl denies being bribed by Elf Aquitaine and insists that donations to party funds never influenced government policy, but files relating to the oil refinery sale disappeared mysteriously from the Chancellery before he left office.

The Christian Democrats are bracing themselves for fresh revelations today when an auditor's report on the party's finances is published, but many activists fear that the real danger to the party's future lies in its breach with its former patriarch. Kohl is convinced Schäuble has mishandled the funding scandal by making too many confessions too soon and he appears determined to destroy his successor's leadership. A meeting in Munich last week with media baron Leo Kirch has ensured that the powerful Springer group of newspapers is training as much fire on Schäuble as on Kohl. Some in Kohl's circle believe that many former loyalists will return to Kohl's banner.

Many German commentators fear that the Christian Democrats, who have seen their popular support fall by 11 per cent in recent weeks, could disappear from the political map altogether.

In Schleswig-Holstein, where the party hoped to win an election next month, activists complain that passers-by are routinely barking abuse at them. As one young activist put it: 'Sometimes I think I'm going to wake up and find it was all a horrible dream.'

Denis Staunton writes for the 'Irish Times'

webTitle: Blunkett's safety net will deprive schoolchildren of the naked truth

fields.headline: Blunkett's safety net will deprive schoolchildren of the naked truth
fields.standfirst: The Networker
fields.trailText: The Networker
fields.body:
If someone told you that the Government had implemented a plan to censor the Internet use of 12 million British subjects you would say they were scaremongering. Think again. Index on Censorship has a terrific story about the so-called 'National Grid for Learning', designed to ensure that Britain's 12 million schoolchildren do not have access to anything on the Web that is not approved by David Blunkett and the commercial contractors implementing the grid.

Blunkett regularly vies with Jack Straw for the title of the most authoritarian minister in the Blair cabinet. Even so, arrangements to censor children's use of the Net take one's breath away.

The Index article quotes from his speech introducing the Superhighway Safety Pack. 'I am determined,' he rants, 'to ensure that children are protected from unsuitable material. We all share a responsibility to make sure that children's use of the Internet is appropriate and safe.'

Suppliers to the Learning Grid are 'expected to offer adequate filtering of the material which can be accessed through their connections to the Internet'.

Ah, those magic words: 'appropriate', 'safe', 'adequate' and 'filtering' - the catch phrases of intellectual nannies, censors and authoritarians everywhere. Who is to judge what is appropriate, safe or adequate? Why, the companies supplying connections to, and material for, Blunkett's fatuous grid.

And how will they meet his requirements? Answer: by installing the kind of filtering software which is already a byword for stupidity, insensitivity and illiberality. The kind of software which - as astronomer Heather Couper told Index - prevents a schoolboy from accessing a website she has co-developed. Why? Because the site explains how to do 'naked-eye observations' of the stars from your back garden. God alone knows what Blunkett would make of the transit of Venus.

The net is buzzing with conjecture about why Bill Gates has handed control of Microsoft to Steve Ballmer. It depends what you mean by 'control' of course, but some wags have suggested it is because Gates wants to spend more time learning Linux, the open-source operating system, which is slowly but surely beginning to threaten Microsoft's hold on the network server market. If so, it would be a typically far-sighted move by a man who has always been very good at taking the long view.

For the Linux bandwagon continues to roll. The most vivid proof of this is IBM's announcement that it is seeking to establish Linux as a serious competitor to Windows in the corporate world. IBM developers are to work with Linux hackers to develop e-business software which can run on various hardware platforms.

And Netcraft - the company which surveys the Web to see what software servers are using - reported that even the Queen's website has switched to Linux. Gates's hopes of a Royal Warrant are receding.

Still with Linux, people have speculated for years about what Linus Torvalds, the Finn who created Linux, has been doing since moving to Transmeta, a pathologically secretive Californian start-up. Now we know.

On Wednesday the company unveiled a revolutionary microprocessor codenamed Crusoe - a computing engine designed exclusively with mobile applications in mind. Among the claims for this new technology are Wintel compatibility and incredibly low power consumption, which, if true, will make Crusoe processors perfect for the wireless 'information appliances' regarded as the Next Big Thing.

If nothing else, this might take some of the shine off ARM, the darling of UK investors because of its stranglehold on the mobile market. But perhaps the most significant thing about Crusoe is that it comes with Linux on a chip.
