fields.headline: Dejunk your life
fields.standfirst: Clear out the physical clutter and the mental mess will take care of itself.   It sounds far-fetched, but it's true
fields.trailText: Clear out the physical clutter and the mental mess will take care of itself.   It sounds far-fetched, but it's true.
fields.body:
Clutter. Junk. Stuff. Call it what you like, we've all got so much of it we're drowning in it. Our cupboards and filing systems can't cope with it all, so it spills out on to floors and table tops, gradually taking over our houses and our lives. How many clothes do you own (and still insist you have nothing to wear)? How many corkscrews? We're the most materially endowed generation in history - and that's our problem. Without being aware of it, the stuff we spend our lives and money acquiring has become a constant, overwhelming source of stress, affecting everything from our lifestyle choices to our personal development.

Our overfilled, cluttered houses aren't sanctuary from a hostile world anymore, or even sleek machines for living. They're messy, never finished, a constant source of stress, guilt and anxiety. Most of our time is spent working to get more stuff or to maintain the stuff we have already (cars to service, collections to add to, consumer durables to repair or replace, all that furniture to clean, objects to dust), leaving us exhausted, time-famished and trapped at our income levels, with no choice to downshift or change direction. Although we live in a culture of unprecedented plenty, we have the mindset of hoarders. Our textbooks from college, odd socks, gifts we didn't want and never use: we can't throw anything away. We've become hostages to our stuff.

Dejunking - clearing out all that clutter and living a cleaner, simpler life - has become an almost spiritual movement in the USA, an even bigger, greedier culture than our own, and is just beginning to take off here. Done properly - which means approached from an emotional and philosophical point of view as well as a practical one - dejunking is far more than an extension of spring cleaning. On one level, it involves a gradual purging of all the stuff you don't need that is clogging up your house and your life.

On another level, it's nothing short of a personal liberation.

People who have dejunked talk about the experience as a turning point, which has allowed them to reassess their lives and to feel lighter and more free than they have done for years. As the physical junk gets cleared out, other kinds of junk inevitably follow: one woman, stuck in a cold and difficult marriage, reported feelings of depression and restlessness which grew for many years. Then she started clearing out her junk, and couldn't stop. She went through her house, throwing away the detritus of 15 years. Six months later, she filed for divorce from her husband. "And hers is not an unusual story," reports Janet Luhrs, author of The Simple Living Guide (US edition) and editor of the Simple Living newsletter. "Clearing the clutter away can be very cathartic. It leaves you space - literally and emotionally. As the burden of all that stuff begins to lift, you become more aware of your emotional mess. And you start to clear that up, too."

Don Aslett is a cleaning specialist, and the author of many bestselling books about clutter control. He believes that we're addicted to stuff, investing it with magical qualities like love, security, or personal development. "By the time we emerge from childhood, we firmly believe that things make us happy," he says. "If one little thing gives us pleasure, then surely more things will increase our pleasure. And things can change us, make us better. For instance, "I can't keep my lawn as nice as Larry's. A bigger, better mower is the answer"; "the kids won't do their homework. I'm sure it'll help if we buy a computer or an encyclopedia set" or "I'm unpopular; a new dandruff shampoo should do the trick". We learn to measure our self-worth by how other people see us, and we look for more and better ways to make ourselves impressive - which translates as getting and keeping more stuff." And of course, we're wrong. In his book Britain on the Couch, the psychologist Oliver James points out that although we have many times more possessions than our parents' generation, we rate ourselves as unhappier with our lives.

Don Aslett sees dejunking as nothing less than a way to save your own life. "Junk is everywhere," he says. "It's on us, in us and around us, and we have to take back our control of it. Religious leaders, doctors, psychologists, scientists and 40 other kinds of "improvers" will all tell you the same thing. When you get the junk out of your life, everything improves - mentally, physically and emotionally."

Michelle Passoff makes her living from other people's clutter - she's a 'clutter consultant' and author of Lighten Up! Free Yourself From Clutter (HarperPerennial, US edition). "A long time ago, I noticed that when something big happened in my life, I would go on a cleaning binge. One day I had a thought: "Suppose I did it the other way around. Would a big clear-out lead to big things happening in my life?" She found that it did. "Trust me, it is liberating to let go," she insists. "It's like a balloon tethered to the ground that's been released." Dejunking, she says, goes way beyond just throwing some old junk away. "It's a truth-telling process. Getting rid of the most basic forms of clutter in the physical environment is a path towards cleaning whatever is in the way of fulfilment anywhere."

It sounds like a grandiose claim until you remember that feeling of deep satisfaction you get from sorting out a kitchen drawer or cupboard. It's such a simple thing: making something messy and dirty into something clean and tidy, imposing your own order on chaos. Imagine that feeling extended to your whole house, and then to your whole life, and you begin to see why dejunkers get so evangelical. If you want to clean up your life, we offer this beginner's guide to dejunking.

Reasons to dejunk

You are your clutter
We gain much of our identity and reputation from the stuff we surround ourselves with. It's why most of us don't like inviting people back to our houses until we know them well - it's too private, too revealing. Don Aslett calls it our 'visual autobiography'. "People treat you differently if you're drowning in clutter. If they can't sit on the back seat of your car because it's full of junk, or you're constantly borrowing pens/stamps/tissues, etc because you can't find them in your bag, they read you as disorganised, undisciplined and sloppy. The first good reason to dejunk is because people will treat you better."

Clutter steals your space
If you don't use half of the stuff you own, it isn't harmlessly lying around - it's eating into 50 per cent of your space. "Go into your wardrobe or your kitchen," advises Aslett. "Get a roll of masking tape, and tape off half of it. That's what your clutter is doing to your environment."

More clutter equals more cleaning
Housework is like tax - inevitable. But Aslett estimates that 40 per cent of the time spent cleaning is spent just handling, getting around, and moving clutter out of the way. Add on the time spent cleaning the stuff you don't need or use (all those tasteful objects, the three walls of books you'll never read again, the extra tables and stands and who knows what else), and that's a huge slice of time spent just servicing your clutter.

Clutter is a constant distraction
"Having lots of stuff around you is kind of ballast against the world," observes Janet Luhrs. "You can put all your energy into acquiring and displaying things, rather than dealing with real human emotions or interactions. I know one couple who are avid collectors of figurines, and I believe they have that collection in place of a real family."

Michelle Passoff also believes in the dark side of clutter. "People are constantly asking themselves what they should do with their lives: which relationships, which work, which direction. The truth is, that life sends us little messages and signs all the time, in the form of small events or intuitions or conversations. But you have to be alert, open and sensitive to receiving them, and we just can't be that when we're living overcrowded lives. Our stuff surrounds us and distracts us from the real purposes of our lives."

How to begin dejunking

 Start gradually. "Do a single cupboard or a couple of drawers to begin with," advises Janet Luhrs. "Start with the easy stuff. Get yourself a couple of rubbish sacks and fill them with the things you've been meaning to throw away or know you don't want."When you've done it, she says, "you'll feel good. You'll begin to see how the positive effects dejunking will have on you. You'll want to do more".

 Fill another couple of sacks or boxes with your 'Maybe' stuff. "This is the kind of stuff you've had hanging around, that you don't use and probably don't want, but you know, maybe you'll need it some day." Put all of this in boxes, with a date 6-12 months from today. "Go back to it on that date, and if you haven't had to use it by then, you don't need it. Don't even open the boxes, just throw them away."

 Know what you want to achieve. "Ask yourself what you're clearing this clutter to make room for," says Michelle Passoff. "Most people say: to feel happier, or more at peace. Those are great goals, but they aren't specific enough. What makes you happy? What do you want? What does being at peace mean to you? If you make a list of your personal goals, it will guide you towards what you need to throw away and what you need to keep."

 You don't have to throw everything away. "People worry that I'll make them throw away their most precious memorabilia," says Passoff. "But all I do is make clients look at each object in their life, and think about it. Does this object have positive or negative connotations for them? Does it keep them weighted in the past (one client still had her wedding dress from a dissolved, abusive marriage)? You should only keep things that make you feel good, function better, and contribute to the quality of your life. If you have a load of old stuff - say, your dead aunt's old shoes that you can't bear to throw away because you loved your aunt - try this: take a photograph of the shoes, put it into a beautiful frame, and throw the shoes away."

 Know the difference between dejunking and organising. "You need less things," says Janet Luhrs, "not more things to put your things in". "Being organised is a good thing," admits Michelle Passoff, "but you shouldn't get to that until you have sorted and dejunked everything else. When you're left with the good stuff, the stuff you actively want and need, then it's time to buy your filing cabinets and labels."

 Make a record. "Seriously. Take before, during and after pictures as you begin to clean up your life. It will encourage you, and let you see how far you've come," says Passoff. "Keep a dejunk diary. If you're dealing with all this stuff, a lot of emotions come up. Those letters which remind you of an old lover, the silver tea service your mother gave you. Write down how it makes you feel to contemplate getting rid of this stuff. It's all part of the cleansing process."

 Make a plan. "This is where you take an honest look at everything you have in your home. You need to know exactly what you've got," says Passoff. "Break your home up into areas - room by room, or cupboard by cupboard - and do one bit at a time. A thorough dejunk session shouldn't take less than 2-4 hours. Calculate how many of those sessions you'll need to do to get to what I call ground zero, then schedule them in."

 Understand that clutter never goes away. "So long as there is mail, delivery services, families, there will be clutter," says Passoff. "You need to keep on top of it. Dejunking helps you rethink your attitude to stuff. Shopping is so passé. Spend the money on a nice meal out or tickets for the theatre with friends." Janet Luhrs suggests that adults have pacts to only give each other gifts they can actually use - wine, food, bath treats - rather than just things.

What is junk?

Although dejunking means you will end up with a lot less stuff, it doesn't mean you have to give away everything. Most of us have so much stuff, we forget what is really valuable and what is just junk. Michelle Passoff offers these simple guidelines:

 Jumbled up stuff is junk. That's a load of stuff that doesn't go together, like the hall table with the cat's toys, unpaid bills and your daily mail, or a dresser with loose change, make-up and some notes from your evening class spilled on to it. Clutter has no logic. A good basic rule? Separate all unrelated items from each other.

 Rubbish is junk. Basically, clutter is rubbish. Three-quarters of the piles on paper on desks and tabletops are things that just haven't been thrown away yet.

 Unfinished business is junk. Scraps of paper with telephone numbers of people whose calls you haven't returned, bags of clothes standing inside the front door that you haven't given to the charity shop, letters you haven't yet responded to - this is the kind of clutter that's mobile. It follows you around, and if you leave it unattended long enough, it changes from junk into big problems.

 Indecision turns into junk. Can't decide if you'll ever wear that dress again? Can't decide whether to go to that party? Indecision is a warning sign: if you're always having thoughts like those, your unworn clothes and unanswered invitations, or abandoned painting project gradually turn into junk. Clutter is all the stuff you push aside and tell yourself you'll think about later. Fear of regret often stops people being more decisive or throwing things away. Having a more positive approach to making choices builds your confidence - and dejunks your clutter.

For more advice and information about dejunking, try the following:

www.freefromclutter.com is Michelle Passoff's website - a fund of dejunk philosophy and practical advice. She can also be emailed at www.lightenup@freefromclutter.com. Michelle Passoff will be in the UK leading dejunking workshops at the Mind, Body and Spirit Festival at the Royal Horticultural Halls, London SW1 on 28 May and 1 June. Phone New Life Productions on 020 7938 3788 for details.

Don Aslett's books are available from www.amazon.com.

Janet Luhrs's book The Simple Living Guide is also available from amazon. She publishes the Simple Living newsletter for people interested in dejunking and 'voluntary simplicity'. Subscriptions are $24 dollars a year for UK readers.

Contact: Simple Living, 4509 Interlake Avenue North, Box 149, Seattle, Washington 98103, USA. Her website is at www.simpleliving.com.

Three-quarters of the piles on paper on desks and tabletops are things that just haven't been thrown away yet.  Unfinished business is junk. Scraps of paper with telephone numbers of people whose calls you haven't returned, bags of clothes standing inside the front door that you haven't given to the charity shop, letters you haven't yet responded to - this is the kind of clutter that's mobile. It follows you around, and if you leave it unattended long enough, it changes from junk into big problems.  Indecision turns into junk. Can't decide if you'll ever wear that dress again? Can't decide whether to go to that party? Indecision is a warning sign: if you're always having thoughts like those, your unworn clothes and unanswered invitations, or abandoned painting project gradually turn into junk. Clutter is all the stuff you push aside and tell yourself you'll think about later. Fear of regret often stops people being more decisive or throwing things away. Having a more positive approach to making choices builds your confidence - and dejunks your clutter. For more advice and information about dejunking, try the following: www.freefromclutter.com is Michelle Passoff's website - a fund of dejunk philosophy and practical advice. She can also be emailed at www.lightenup@freefromclutter.com. Phone New Life Productions on 020 7938 3788 for details. Don Aslett's books are available from www.amazon.com. Janet Luhrs's book The Simple Living Guide is also available from amazon. fields.headline: The anti-disease diet
fields.standfirst: Eating well doesn't just make you feel and look better. There is overwhelming evidence that the right diet is the best defence against disease
fields.trailText: Eating well doesn't just make you feel and look better. There is overwhelming evidence that the right diet is the best defence against disease.
fields.body:
The potential benefits of eating a healthy diet have been proffered for many years - my grandmother spouted 'an apple a day keeps the doctor away', yet as simple as this adage sounds, we're more than ever recording appallingly high incidences of heart disease and cancer, flu epidemics and colds. Our environment must take some of the blame. However, a major contributing factor is that too few people have the knowledge, or inspiration, to take advantage of food's ability to keep us well. After all, the body's defenders can only derive their raw ingredients from the food we place in our stomach.

The antioxidant factor

A general healthy diet is the best framework for a healthy life. When it comes to fending off disease and minimising the effects of ageing, we need specifically to look to a group of nutrients called 'antioxidants'. These include bioflavonoids, vitamins C and E, Lycopene, beta-carotene (which the body converts into vitamin A), and the minerals selenium and zinc. This group of nutrients reduces your likelihood of developing cancer and heart disease, as well as other diseases of ageing such as arthritis and cataracts, by boosting the immune system, producing anti-cancer substances, preventing blood fats from oxidising and depositing in the blood vessels, and by their 'antioxidant' activity.

Our bodies need oxygen, but the process of oxidation (resulting from exposure to oxygen) can be harmful, creating unstable by-products - molecules known as free radicals. These molecules interact with those that make up our body's cells, causing damage and disease. While the process of oxidation has always gone on, our bodies are now producing far more free radicals as a result of stress, pollution - including cigarette smoke and car exhaust fumes - and exposure to too much ultraviolet light from the sun; so we need to boost our antioxidant intakes to counteract these antagonists.

The good news is, that since antioxidants can be found in so many foods, the body can derive all the necessary antioxidants from eating the real thing; you don't need to take supplements. A good five portions of fruits or vegetables every day will get you to the antioxidant target. If you can push it towards eight, even better, especially when you feel vulnerable or run down, or you have a strong family history of heart disease or diet-related cancers such as those of the colon or breast. This may sound a lot, but since a portion is only an apple, or a large tomato, the target can be met. Have fresh juice (made from three oranges) in the morning, vegetables or salad with your meals and pieces of fruit afterwards or in between. Nutrient values depreciate, so eat produce as fresh as possible and keep soaking and cooking time in water to a minimum. Cooked vegetables (soups, casseroles) can be healthy, but include a degree of rawness in your supply.

Sourcing your antioxidants

Vitamin C is one of the best-known antioxidant vitamins. Many people are under the illusion that they need 1,000mg a day, but the recommended daily intake to avoid disease is only 60mg. Consuming more than this can be of no real benefit unless your body has a greater than average need for vitamin C, for example if you smoke. Vitamin C is water soluble and the body cannot store excess amounts; if you consume more than you need, your body will simply excrete it. Many people take a vitamin C supplement because they fear there will be little of the vitamin left by the time the produce is eaten, after it has endured long journeys and possibly spent weeks in cold storage.

While vitamin C content does diminish with time, if we shop regularly and conscientiously, following natural seasons as much as possible, we should be able to glean sufficient vitamin C from our diet. Frozen or tinned fruits and vegetables can be rich in this nutrient, as can some processed foods where manufacturers add vitamin C to food - listed as 'ascorbic acid' on some labels. While I support the addition of vitamins to foods where appropriate, fresh, nutritious produce is the best option - you're less likely to experience other unwanted substances such as sugar and fat.

The main sources of vitamin C are fresh fruits and vegetables: a kiwi fruit or helping of steamed broccoli contains about 50mg and a large orange contains about 70mg. Other rich sources include: dark green leafy vegetables, red, green and yellow peppers, watercress, potatoes, especially new with their skins on, green peas and mangetout. Fruits: strawberries and kiwis, grapefruit and other citrus fruits, blackcurrants, rosehips, guava, mango, papaya, lychees, raspberries, nectarines and peaches.

Bioflavonoids are particularly concentrated in citrus fruits such as oranges, tangerines, clementines, grapefruit, lemons and limes, especially in the peel, skin or outer layers of plants - so candied peel and mince pies have more to them than meets the eye. Wash the produce well to remove any waxes and chemical residues.

Vitamin E is a phenomenally powerful antioxidant. Many people feel, especially my male patients who are worried about the prospect of a heart attack, that they need to take an antioxidant tablet containing vitamin E, but this is unnecessary. The suggested safe intake of 3-4mg a day is easily obtained from a well-balanced diet that includes vitamin E-rich foods such as avocados, blackberries, mangoes, tomatoes, sweet potatoes, spinach, watercress, nuts and seeds, wheatgerm and wholegrain cereal, soft margarine and vegetable oils.

Beta-carotene (converted to vitamin A in the body) is found in orange, yellow and green vegetables and fruits such as carrots, dark green vegetables, asparagus, peas, courgettes, leeks, lettuce (especially Cos), okra, parsley, tomatoes, peppers, sweet potatoes, pumpkins, apricots and peaches (fresh and dried), mangoes, passion fruit, papayas, plums, watermelons and yellow-fleshed melons such as cantaloupe.

Lycopene (present in tomatoes) is specifically good at preventing prostate cancer. Men who eat 10 portions of tomato-based foods a week - this could be tomato sauce, a Bloody Mary (a glass being a portion), tomato ketchup, or tomato and mozzarella salad - can reduce their risk by up to 40%.

Selenium is needed in tiny, but regular amounts. It is mainly found in foods grown in soil, but their selenium content varies. Modern farming practices have reduced the amount of selenium found in the produce, which has led to some scientists advocating a supplement. However, based on current research there is no call for this, as even the reduced levels of selenium are adequate. Selenium is also found in nuts, sunflower seeds, wholewheat bread, milk, hard crumbly cheeses, eggs, chicken, lean meat, offal, fish and shellfish.

Plants contain the majority of antioxidant vitamins and selenium - so we need only add some zinc-rich foods to make up the complete antioxidant quota.

Zinc-rich foods include shellfish, canned sardines, turkey, goose, lean meats, offal, Parmesan and other hard crumbly cheeses, eggs, wholegrain breads and rice, nuts and seeds (including peanut butter and tahini), wheatgerm and wholegrain cereals, pulses, lentils, green vegetables, dried fruits, passion fruit. You should ideally have a zinc-rich food three to four times a week - a portion being a couple of eggs, a chicken breast-sized piece of lean red meat or a small tin of sardines served on slices of wholemeal toast. If you know you've been cutting corners with your diet or been under a lot of stress (which increases the rate at which the body uses up antioxidants), include a portion of zinc-rich food every day to give your antioxidant levels a top-up. Keep water intake up to 2.5 litres a day.

Improving cultures

The end products of food entering our colons strongly affect the bacterial cultures and their activities. Scientists have recently found that certain bacteria which live inside our colon can produce Butyrates and other substrates which are thought to reduce the incidence of certain cancers and heart disease. This research is still in its infancy, but based on the evidence to date, it's prudent to include some bacteria (acidophilus and bifidus) in our anti-disease diet. You can take them in various forms, but I think they are most effectively absorbed from natural yoghurt. Look out for 'live' or 'bio' yoghurts with these substances. A good daily dosage would be 20mg which can be found in a small pot of yoghurt. For those with sensitive digestions, seek the approval of your GP before taking these bacteria.

webTitle: How do you buy home exercise equipment?

fields.headline: How do you buy home exercise equipment?
fields.standfirst: If you want to take home   exercising further, you may want to invest in some more serious equipment. Our experts give their advice
fields.trailText: If you want to take home   exercising further, you may want to invest in some more serious equipment. Our experts give their advice
fields.body:
 Product placement is vital: 'Some people get the machine home and realise they feel stupid peddling away in their lounge with the family around - or the neighbours walking past,' says Professor Stuart Biddle. 'Look at where the machine can go, and if you can't dedicate a "hideaway" room to it, ask yourself if you're prepared to use it no matter who's around. If not, a home programme won't work for you, no matter how fancy the equipment.'

 Know your goals: You have to choose the machine that meets your goals - so if you want to burn body fat, you need to buy cardiovascular-based equipment. Those who want to tone up should look at multi-gyms or freeweights. 'In an ideal world go to a few sessions at a health club and see which machine you like best,' says Matt Roberts. 'If you hate the bike after three gym visits, you won't use one at home.'

 Look at how well it's constructed: 'Uncomfortable or wobbly equipment destroys home workout plans,' says Professor Biddle. 'You can't reach any kind of intensity, you don't feel like you've worked out and you don't get results.' Check that 'heavy use' areas like steps or peddles are sturdy and that frames are strong and hardwearing. The machine should be heavy enough not to wobble when you shake the frame. Reputable stores will let you try a machine before you buy.

 Don't be fooled by fancy programming: While it's good to be able to alter speeds, resistance and incline, pre-programmed routines don't necessarily make for a better machine. 'It's better to spend money on construction than gimmicks,' says Elesa Argent from Holmes Place, Barbican. 'It's easy to liven up a workout on your own by altering speed and resistance.'

 Best buys: 'For CV work, I don't think you can beat a cross trainer,' says Matt Roberts. 'It works the whole body at once and gives a thorough workout. But don't skimp on quality. A wobbly cross trainer is worse than useless.' Therefore, if you're watching the budget, Elesa believes that a rowing machine would make the better choice. 'It gives an excellent all-round tone-up, and there's a lot less that can go wrong.'

webTitle: Virtual mafia pushes plastic fraud to £190m

fields.headline: Virtual mafia pushes plastic fraud to £190m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Credit card fraud soared by 40 per cent last year. Organised criminals using the Internet have fuelled the rise to a record £190 million, security experts warned.
fields.byline: Nick Paton Walsh and Sarah Ryle
fields.body:
Credit card fraud soared by 40 per cent last year. Organised criminals using the Internet have fuelled the rise to a record £190 million, security experts warned.

Consumer spending on credit and debit cards in December rose by £500m to £14.5 billion, the Credit Card Research Group will announce tomorrow. One in every thousand of those transactions was fraudulent, according to credit security firm Apacs. The Home Office admitted last week that cyber-crime is booming.

Counterfeiting is responsible for 10 per cent of total fraud, according to Apacs. The rest is believed to be due to the rise of Internet and telephone sales.

Experts warn that a counterfeiting technique known as 'skimming' is more popular than ever. A genuine card is swiped through a card-reader, its data copied and used to make new magnetic strips for fake cards.

Organised gangs, believed to have Mafia and Triad links, recruit skimmers, often in restaurants or petrol stations, according to the security firms.

Up to 80 per cent of skimming is being attributed to Chinese Triads and the fear is that workers are recruited not just in Britain but also in their native country before they reach the UK. The National Criminal Intelligence Service recently said Triads are mainly responsible for trebling credit fraud between 1994 and 1998.

Mastercard's European security operation Europay's regional risk manager Paul Lucraft said: 'The greatest risk at present comes from highly organised international gangs who move across borders, and between jurisdictions. They use credit card data stolen from around Europe to make fraudulent credit cards. These cards are then used to buy bogus goods at a bogus retailer, through which the money reaches the fraudster.'

Fraudsters look for a country where retail security is weak, and target consumers to gain genuine card details to use elsewhere.

The revelations suggest Britain's security lags behind Europe, making it attractive for criminals. Chip cards which can protect information are not due to be issued before 2002. Even then, only half of Britain's retailers will use them. Valuable time is being wasted because security companies and retailers cannot agree on a method of cost-sharing for installation.

fields.headline: Wobbly enough to defy gravity
fields.standfirst:
Comment

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Comment
fields.body:
Fathoming Jellyworks is like trying to wrestle with a mound of the wobbly, kids' party staple itself.

The miracles needed for the firm to justify its 20-fold share rise and £200 million price tag are enormous enough. For new investors to profit, returns on its investments will have to be more spectacular than hedge funds' wildest dreams. And Guinan and Rowland will have to show near-superhuman foresight by investing early and cheaply in sure-fire winners.

Each time they put money into other Internet investment funds, you're only backing their judgment of other people's nous. So the likely returns diminish exponentially. Three of Jellyworks' biggest investments are in other 'incubator funds': Antfactory, WorldCap and Grand Central Holdings.

But why not ask, instead, whether you know exactly what Jellyworks already has. The answer is a resounding 'no' - it refuses to disclose the size of its stakes, and the prices paid per share, in all its investments. Last week chairman Edward Guinan said he would come back to us on these and other specifics, such as when precisely the Rowland family took each of its stakes. He never did.

Evaluating the prospects of each firm is hard enough (much of Matchnet's dating website, for example, is still 'under construction'). But without this basic data, you can't tell what stake Jellyworks has in their success.

Jellyworks' start-up structure is also confusing. The Observer asked Guinan why it had taken an option over the Rowland family's investments. Why not simply put them in Jellyworks from day one?

'The accountants' attorneys raised questions,' he said. 'It would have had to go to the valuers. It was suggested the simplest way was to create an option. It [the alternative] looked as if it would add £50,000 to the costs. It would have taken lots of time, with people running round for days over Christmas.'

There are other niggles. First, the sudden change of mind on domicile: between the AIM admission notice on 6 December and the prospectus eight days later, the firm switched from Guernsey to the UK. Three (presumably Guernsey-based) non-executive directors were dropped in favour of one non-exec, Ashley Ward of Orchestream. The vehicle for the Rowland family holding also changed.

Second, the exercise of 831,000 options in lieu of fees by Jellyworks' advisers, Fiske and Nabarro Wells. Unlike other locked-in investors, Guinan says, the advisers have been free to deal since. How many shares, you may ask, have they sold?

A third is Guinan's own purchase of 150,000 Jellyworks shares at between 50p and 52p. That came a day before the firm's surprise investment in Grand Central and a £1m placing of Jellyworks shares at 60p each. Guinan's buying was seen as a sign of confidence, and the shares shot up. To spend £75,000 on stock and see the value of rest of your shares and options rise by £6m is a very profitable way to show confidence.

Jellyworks would dismiss this as nitpicking. But it is the impossibility of ascertaining the stakes Jellyworks has that defeats valuation. You have to believe that the prices others will pay will spiral higher than whatever it paid. You have to suspend your belief not only in human fallibility, but in gravity itself.

The Observer asked Guinan why it had taken an option over the Rowland family's investments. Why not simply put them in Jellyworks from day one? 'The accountants' attorneys raised questions,' he said. 'It would have had to go to the valuers. It was suggested the simplest way was to create an option. It [the alternative] looked as if it would add £50,000 to the costs. It would have taken lots of time, with people running round for days over Christmas.' There are other niggles. First, the sudden change of mind on domicile: between the AIM admission notice on 6 December and the prospectus eight days later, the firm switched from Guernsey to the UK. Three (presumably Guernsey-based) non-executive directors were dropped in favour of one non-exec, Ashley Ward of Orchestream. The vehicle for the Rowland family holding also changed. Second, the exercise of 831,000 options in lieu of fees by Jellyworks' advisers, Fiske and Nabarro Wells. Unlike other locked-in investors, Guinan says, the advisers have been free to deal since. How many shares, you may ask, have they sold? A third is Guinan's own purchase of 150,000 Jellyworks shares at between 50p and 52p. That came a day before the firm's surprise investment in Grand Central and a £1m placing of Jellyworks shares at 60p each. Guinan's buying was seen as a sign of confidence, and the shares shot up. To spend £75,000 on stock and see the value of rest of your shares and options rise by £6m is a very profitable way to show confidence. Jellyworks would dismiss this as nitpicking. But it is the impossibility of ascertaining the stakes Jellyworks has that defeats valuation. You have to believe that the prices others will pay will spiral higher than whatever it paid. You have to suspend your belief not only in human fallibility, but in gravity itself.

webTitle: Cuts force secretaries to diagnose cancer tests

fields.headline: Cuts force secretaries to diagnose cancer tests
fields.standfirst:
Staff crisis as poor pay drives lab scientists to quit
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Thousands of lives are being put at risk because overstretched hospital laboratories are having to use untrained clerical staff to diagnose blood and cancer tests. The crisis in the laboratories is one of the worst examples of the exodus of non-medical staff from the NHS which has prompted the Government to offer an unprecedented three-year inflation-busting pay deal.
fields.byline: by Anthony Browne and Andy McSmith
fields.body:
Thousands of lives are being put at risk because overstretched hospital laboratories are having to use untrained clerical staff to diagnose blood and cancer tests. The crisis in the laboratories is one of the worst examples of the exodus of non-medical staff from the NHS which has prompted the Government to offer an unprecedented three-year inflation-busting pay deal.

The Institute of Biomedical Science, which sets the quality and safety standards in NHS laboratories, said standards had slipped and misdiagnosis of cervical cancer smear tests and HIV tests were inevitable.

The institute has carried out a survey of 1,000 NHS laboratories, which carry out 100 million medical tests a year. The survey reveals that pay rates of qualified scientists are so low and recruitment problems so severe that in some areas the service has almost broken down.

Almost 90 per cent of laboratory managers said they had fewer staff than needed, almost two-thirds had used unqualified staff, and one in 10 laboratories had resorted to using clerical staff for scientific duties. A third of NHS laboratories admitted the quality of service was falling.

Alan Potter, chief executive of the institute, said: 'If you have a staff that is overstretched, underpaid and really fed up, that's a recipe for making errors. The more work you do, the more morale deteriorates, the more the error rate goes up. If someone is told they haven't got cancer and they have, the consequences are dire.'

In Kent, hundreds of cervical screening tests had to be redone because of concern over misdiagnosis. Backlogs on tests are growing and in some places have reached two months. One health authority put its cervical screening programme on hold for three months because of the backlog. An East Midlands hospital manager said: 'The professional thing to do is simply to stop doing tests rather than take unacceptable risks.'

Pay rates for biomedical scientists have fallen 30 per cent behind those of nurses (whose pay has always been more politically sensitive) in the past 15 years, even though they are more qualified. They are legally required to have a science honours degree, followed by a minimum of one year's training, after which they start on a salary as low as £7,476. After five years - bringing total education and training to almost a decade - they will earn only around £14,000 - less than the starting salary for a nurse.

Along with all other hospital ancillary staff, they have been offered a deal covering 1999-2002 which guarantees their pay will outstep the rate of inflation for three years. Because of low pay, many lab scientists qualify for state benefits. One manager told his staff the only way he could help them was by filling out their housing benefit forms.

Many staff are exhausted by second jobs. A laboratory scientist, just qualified and earning £9,796 a year, said: 'I've done seven years of exams for this and I am very disillusioned. The salary is appalling. I have a second job in a bar in a club from 7pm to 1am three nights a week just to survive. Then I feel shattered in the laboratory the next day and I just go through the motions. I am beginning to feel very bitter.'

Half the laboratories have been unable to recruit staff. A laboratory manager with 15 years' experience said: 'People are having to do whatever they can. They have no choice. But do you really want a checkout assistant checking your blood, because that's what happening?'

Steve Jack, general manager in two hospitals in Peter borough, said: 'It's become very serious indeed. It's difficult to recruit, and we have had to give up recruiting for some posts.' Some laboratories are trying to make ends meet by getting drugs companies to pay for some of their staff in return for undertaking tests on their behalf. In other laboratories, high-tech diagnostic equipment - often paid for by charities - lies unused because they can't afford to train staff to use it.

Potter warned: 'If people are firefighting and struggling to do the basic service, they can't learn about new technology and techniques.'

fields.headline: You're either dying or waiting
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The best of public service, the worst of public service. A week ago I finished my stint as a porter at one of the best hospitals in the land, St Thomas'. From the high-rise wards you get a stunning view of London: the Millennium Wheel, Nelson's Column but, best of all, just across the Thames, Sir Charles Barry's Palace of Westminster.
fields.body:
The best of public service, the worst of public service. A week ago I finished my stint as a porter at one of the best hospitals in the land, St Thomas'. From the high-rise wards you get a stunning view of London: the Millennium Wheel, Nelson's Column but, best of all, just across the Thames, Sir Charles Barry's Palace of Westminster.

But even in this centre of medical excellence, bang opposite the locus of power in Britain, too many patients too often were treated late, their care neglected, their dignity insulted, in a way that was tantamount to cruelty. That may seem like rhetoric, a wild exaggeration. See it for yourself, and you come away convinced: the reality of the NHS at ground level for the patient is bleak, an insult while all around them Blair's Britain - or at least the PR - shines and glimmers. At the Accident and Emergency unit, an agony of time wasted. A waiting room with dozens of patients nursing their misery in silence. Three hours. Four hours. Five. Don't misunderstand. If there is something seriously wrong with you - a horribly bashed head from a road accident, blood gushing uncontrollably - the nurses and doctors, the whole, wonderful system, will kick marvellously into play and you will be treated in the best possible way.

The curse in the NHS is to be ill, but not life-threateningly ill. To have cut your thumb, not your artery. To have banged your head badly, but not crushed it. You go to the A&E just to have it checked. That's when you have to wait. In the modern age, when you click on information in the twinkling of an eye, or catch a train or a plane and move around the world at a speed unimaginable to your parents, it is wrong, an insult to have to wait longer than an hour. But that, under the National Health Service, is a commonplace.

Go to transport on the lower ground floor of St Thomas' Lambeth Wing. There you will see sick old ladies and dignified old men waiting... and waiting. The lifts don't work properly. There aren't enough wheelchairs. Hospital appointments get cancelled because there aren't enough staff, or they're sick, or too highly pressed. This is a scandalous perversion of the beautiful idea of a health service, free to all who need it.

Go to the geriatric wards. The tang of piss, the soft, sweet decay of faeces are constants. That's not because the nurses treat their patients with contempt. It's just that they are not enough nurses. So, young as they are, they make grim and miserable decisions. I wheeled one old man down to X-ray even though he had soiled himself. The nurse didn't have the time to wash him. It's wonderful that the Government has given the nurses a bit more money. It's not so wonderful that this extra pay comes out of the NHS budget. That means more misery, more waiting, for the patients.

A week ago, in The Observer , I noted the quiet heroism of nurses and doctors and patients. I noted their immense courage, but I accepted the status quo . On Tuesday something happened which opened my eyes. I had to give evidence to the House of Commons Select Committee on Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs about Kosovo. Yes, military intervention by the West ended the unbearable tyranny of a tiny minority of Serbs over the Albanian majority in that small province. We were right to fight.

The proceedings were attended by five civil servants... one to film, one to take a shorthand note, and three to ensure everything worked smoothly. Reporters and academics drank free fizzy water. Below, a myriad of helpful policemen showed the way to the canteen. The lifts worked beautifully, the food was fine.

And through the windows I could see the bleak tower blocks of St Thomas'. It was one of those striking moments in life. If public services can work so efficiently in Parliament, why is the same public service so bloody awful 200 yards away? It is, of course, unfair to pick on St Thomas'. There are many hospitals around the country, and GPs' waiting rooms, where the same story is so depressingly obvious that people have given up complaining.

The Health Secretary, Alan Milburn, won't do much until he comes under pressure. The solution to the problem is simple. If our schools and prisons require robust and independent inspectors, then what is so different about our hospitals and GPs' surgeries? The country is crying out for an OfHealth - independent inspectors who can bring the NHS up to standard. If that costs more money, then so be it. Its first head could be someone like Robert Winston, whose elderly mother was treated terribly in hospital. No one in casualty should wait longer than an hour. No one should suffer three cancelled appointments in a row. The NHS inspectors should be able to say: this hospital needs money.

Of course, Milburn, New Labour, and the rest of them in Westminster could do absolutely nothing about creating a new inspectorate to raise standards in the health service. But it is impossible to see life at St Thomas' and life at Westminster, and not come away with the impression that the people at Westminster are thumping hypocrites. And the patients across the Thames wait.

fields.headline: Interiew: Alan Milburn
fields.standfirst:
Alan Milburn, the most unpopular Minister, says that he is still upbeat about his ability to save the NHS
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The man rated as the most unpopular Cabinet Minister is so Blairite he has even caught some of the Prime Minister's mannerisms.
fields.body:
The man rated as the most unpopular Cabinet Minister is so Blairite he has even caught some of the Prime Minister's mannerisms.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn rams his messages home over and again with the zealous sincerity of a Tony Blair, occasionally even deploying hand gestures similar to his chief's. Blairite catch-phrases, such as 'sus-tained modernisation', pepper his conversation.

'People haven't fully grasped the depth and breadth of the modernisation programme,' he claims. The most noticeable difference is the Geordie accent, though even that is much softened by constant contact with Londoners.

He certainly has a point when he claims the changes he is introducing to the NHS have not yet caught on with the public. The Health Service is reckoned to be the biggest single cause of the drastic fall in Blair's personal standing in the country in the opening weeks of the year.

Some individual horror stories - particularly that of Mavis Skeet, whose operation for throat cancer was cancelled four times until it became too late - are so bad that Milburn admits he has no excuse to offer.

'When ghastly things happen in hospitals, it is obviously an awful thing, and Mrs Skeet is a particularly awful case,' he said. 'I don't shed responsibility for any of this. It is terrible when these things happen.

'We acknowledge that we have a lack of capacity in the Health Service, and secondly that that takes time to put right.' But there ends the mea culpa . For the rest of an hour-long interview in his Whitehall office, Milburn was ebullient, argumentative, bursting with plans and statistics, and exuding optimism.

'Waiting lists are coming down. We have the biggest hospital building programme this country has ever seen. We have got every casualty department in the country being modernised, new services like NHS Direct and more nurses returning to the NHS. These are big changes, but they are just the start.'

The way Milburn tells it, last week's apparent U-turn - when an extra £11 billion promised by Tony Blair one day turned out to be no more than an aspiration two days later - was just a technicality. The extra money is on the way. All NHS staff - including the often forgotten non-medical staff - are in line for generous pay awards. The man who only months ago, as a Treasury Minister, was sternly holding down public spending has transformed into Mr Spend, Spend, Spend.

He vowed there would be 'more investment, and sustained investment over a period of years - because we need sustained increases in income if we are going to have the sort of modern health service people quite rightly want to see'.

To get that extra money, he is willing to upset Treasury mandarins who cannot bear the idea that taxpayers should be told which parts of the tax they pay goes into what public service. In Treasury jargon, it's called 'hypothecation', and is to be sternly discouraged. But Milburn says: 'I've got a fairly open mind about hypothecation. I think there are down sides as well as up sides.

'I welcome the fact that the Chancellor decided that if tobacco taxes were increased that money will essentially be hypothecated for the NHS. That will be very helpful for next year. There are good arguments to say maybe we could do more there.'

Though he refused to utter the £11bn figure - which came from experts analysing Blair's words on television a week ago, rather than from the Prime Minister himself - Milburn confirmed every detail of the arithmetic that produced it. Health spending in the UK is below the European average by about 1 per cent of our gross domestic product. Barring an economic catastrophe, the difference will be made up in five years, and all that extra money will go into the NHS.

When the Tories accuse Milburn of being ideologically opposed to private healthcare, they have a point. 'The private healthcare market in Britain is in trouble and isn't expanding,' he said. 'The growth in health spending in the UK, on our plans, will come from growth in the NHS. I think that's the right thing to do, because I think it's the fairest and the most efficient means of getting healthcare to the majority of people.

'All expenditure, whether it is public or private, is of course dependent on the economy. Let's not pretend that if we had a system of private health insurance in our country, as the Conservatives want, that it wouldn't be susceptible to economic fluctuation. It would actually be more sensitive to economic fluctuation.

'And why? Because if you are having to insure yourself against health risk, then if you lose your job or you have lower disposable income, the first thing to go is private health insurance.'

Once he has started on the subject of private medicine, it is hard to get him off. It is as if a hidden streak of Old Labour left over from his days as a young left-wing activist is peering through. 'I do believe absolutely that the Conservatives have made the most profound political misjudgment,' he claimed. 'They have walked off the playing-field. They have abandoned the postwar consensus on health. They have put all their eggs in the private health insurance basket. They have got themselves into the deepest political water.'

The calculation that the Tories have blundered, giving him an avenue of escape from an embarrassing political crisis, may explain why he appears little concerned his standing is roughly equivalent to that of the former manger of his favourite football team, Ruud Gullit.

'Let's not pretend I'm the only Health Minister in the world in the hot seat. Healthcare systems the world over are under pressure. Some of these problems just go with the territory.'

webTitle: Pakistan's fraud police link ousted leader Sharif with British trust fund

fields.headline: Pakistan's fraud police link ousted leader Sharif with British trust fund
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Nawaz Sharif, the ousted Prime Minister of Pakistan, has been linked to a £6.1 million trust fund in Britain.
fields.body:
Nawaz Sharif, the ousted Prime Minister of Pakistan, has been linked to a £6.1 million trust fund in Britain.

Documents obtained by The Observer show that the fund, registered with a firm of lawyers in Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, was run by an American agent hired to represent six companies owned by the Sharif family. The former prime minister was a director and shareholder in at least one of the companies.

A report drawn up by investigators from Pakistan's military and civilian intelligence agencies - with help from the Federal Investigations Agency, an élite police squad - says the trust is part of 'the simplest and easiest case of money laundering [against the Sharifs]'.

The report alleges that, while his family's firms owed millions of pounds to the Pakistani exchequer and commercial creditors, the former Prime Minister was involved in a scheme to gain further multi-million pound loans using the money in the British trust as collateral. The new loans were then used to get further finance from Pakistani banks.

Several such operations were carried out, each involving instalments of more than £6m, the report says. The investigators have built up 16 separate cases of corruption to be registered against Sharif in the coming weeks.

The former Commerce Minister, Ishaq Dar, who was deeply implicated in another money-laundering operation involving bank accounts opened in London in the names of a British Pakistani family living in South-east England, has given the investigators extensive details of how the Sharifs' money was transferred out of Pakistan.

Dar is also believed to have revealed the existence of properties in Vietnam, Kenya and a second investment trust in America. It is thought that the US trust received money from the Rickmansworth trust.

None of the family's over seas assets was declared on electoral or government returns. Sources close to the investigation have disclosed that the Sharifs, who have extensive property in Britain including four Park Lane apartments, have hired top public relations firms in London and New York. The family denies any wrongdoing.

Last week Sharif, his brother and five others were formally indicted on charges of hijacking and conspiracy to murder. The charges, which carry death sentences, relate to events on the day of the army takeover last October when a plane carrying the army chief of staff, General Pervez Musharraf, and 198 other passengers was allegedly prevented from landing despite running low on fuel. fields.headline: Larger lorries loom
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Heavier lorries are set to rumble on to Britain's roads within a year in a controversial move that will enrage environmentalists and the rail industry.
fields.body:
Heavier lorries are set to rumble on to Britain's roads within a year in a controversial move that will enrage environmentalists and the rail industry.

The Government's transport advisory body is expected to give the green light to the 44-tonne juggernaut becoming the norm for road haulage. Opponents of the move fear that lifting the limit again - it was raised from 38 to 40 tonnes last January - is the 'thin end of the wedge' that will soon lead to 50-tonners and ultimately continental-style 70-tonne 'super-lorries' roaring around UK motorways and towns.

The Commission for Integrated Transport (CFIT), appointed by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott, is expected to present its report in late February or early March, arguing that increasing the limit to 44 tonnes will mean fewer lorries on roads. It is understood the Government is almost certain to accept the report, despite saying in its election manifesto that it was 'unpersuaded'.

Sources close to the CFIT insist that it will support raising the limit on two conditions: that rail freight grants are boosted substantially and that poorly enforced laws on lorry weights, speeds, emissions and driver hours are tightened.

Graham Smith, planning director at English, Welsh & Scottish Railway (EWS), the US company that controls the UK rail freight market, said the move could lead to road haulage prices dropping by 15 per cent: he faced losing up to a fifth of his business. 'It would slow the growth we have generated and put at risk our existing business.'

Meanwhile, the Government is expected to argue that heavier lorries will not cause damage to roads and bridges because their weight is spread over six axles rather than the standard five, and their size cannot increase.

James Hookham, policy director at the Freight Transport Association, said the changes would mean 14 per cent fewer lorries on the roads since with denser goods, weight limits are often reached before the container is full.

The FTA is campaigning vigorously not only for a rise in weight limits and a reduction in duty on diesel fuel, but for vehicle excise duty, or 'road tax', to be lowered to match continental rates.

Hookham denied that the FTA wanted the limit raised above 44 tonnes. But Lynn Sloman, assistant director of pressure group Transport 2000, said: 'Freight lobbyists say, in evidence given to CFIT, that 44-tonnes is seen as a stepping stone to 50 tonnes. That is appalling.'

Friends of the Earth and the Council for the Protection of Rural England claim traffic and road damage will increase.

Tony Berkeley, chairman of the Rail Freight Group, said his industry would 'go beserk'.

webTitle: Overdue clean-up for a murky market

fields.headline: Overdue clean-up for a murky market
fields.trailText: Britain's 11 million homeowners should finally hear this week how the Government plans to clean up the mortgage market. Signs point to legal restraints, under the Financial Services Act, on how borrowers are advised.
fields.body:
Britain's 11 million homeowners should finally hear this week how the Government plans to clean up the mortgage market. Signs point to legal restraints, under the Financial Services Act, on how borrowers are advised.

An announcement was originally expected before Christmas, but there has been tension between the Government (keen on regulation) and senior civil servants (not convinced), and rivalry between the Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry over who does what in a clean-up that has lots of good PR mileage.

The question for home buyers is: will it become easier to choose a loan without fear of rip-off? The short answer is yes, but there are some caveats. Lenders are likely to retain freedom to construct complex deals that borrowers will still find it difficult to compare. Those who want something simple will be steered towards the Catmarked loan, where rates will be pegged to between 1 and 2 per cent over base rate and interest must be calculated daily, to maximise the rate at which the loan is reduced.

Ironically, this week's announcement is being made after moves by the industry to improve its products and advice. But it has taken media campaigns and the threat of regulation to get this far.

Privately, some lenders are celebrating the arrival of laws to control the industry's excesses, because they believe the cost will drive out smaller players. In the long term this may cut competition but for the moment, and with opportunities to cut costs through the Internet, competition is unlikely to be too heavily dented.

webTitle: But will Vodafone win the peace?

fields.headline: But will Vodafone win the peace?
fields.trailText: There are defining moments in every takeover battle - Rocco Forte allegedly shooting in Ireland while Gerry Robinson of Granada moved into the penthouse suite of his hotels group; little Hughie Osmond holding an impromptu press conference in the courtyard of the Whitbread Brewery before beating them to the Allied punch. Now we have the historic Vodafone-Mannesmann tussle, which looks increasingly likely to yield the first successful hostile foreign takeover of a German company.
fields.body:
There are defining moments in every takeover battle - Rocco Forte allegedly shooting in Ireland while Gerry Robinson of Granada moved into the penthouse suite of his hotels group; little Hughie Osmond holding an impromptu press conference in the courtyard of the Whitbread Brewery before beating them to the Allied punch. Now we have the historic Vodafone-Mannesmann tussle, which looks increasingly likely to yield the first successful hostile foreign takeover of a German company.

Right at the beginning Chris Gent had his early victory and what looked like a defining moment in the shape of Mannesmann's misunderstanding of the rules of engagement for investment bankers and its embarrassing failure to legally prevent Goldman Sachs from acting on behalf of Vodafone.

There was further humiliation as the German government stumbled into the conflict with some unfortunate interventionist nonsense about hostile takeovers being inherently bad business. Home and dry for Vodafone? Hardly.

First, we had Orange showing stronger sales growth in mobile phones than Vodafone in the last quarter - which raised the ugly prospect of Vodafone being forced to sell off a faster-growing mobile business than its own if the bid went through.

Next, and more damagingly for the spin doctors, we had Chris Gent making impromptu comments at the England vs South Africa match in a not particularly flattering German accent. The corporate equivalent of recklessly flashing outside the off stump when your side is suffering a middle-order collapse. Suddenly things looked more evenly poised.

While nine times out of 10 the outcome of a bid is determined by the money on the table, just occasionally - particularly in these affairs dictated by the value of paper - bids can be won or lost on an unfortunate turn of phrase or a scratch in the PR veneer. But as Vodafone looked set to edge its offer slightly higher, and with Vodafone's share price rampaging upwards in the past fortnight, we look set for the foregone conclusion.

For a man culturally deprived of the hostile experience, Klaus Esser has fought gamely, adding the digital kitchen sink to his defence, concocting an alliance with Vivendi (a partnership we first revealed in these pages) to provide a frightening- sounding pan-European wireless Internet business. Useful for those poor souls who find themselves stranded miles away from their place of work next week by the strike on Vivendi-owned Connex South East. (The grim conspiracy begins to unravel - and we thought there was no synergy between rail networks and mobile phones.)

And while there is many a slip, it would take a surprise of shocking proportions for Vodafone now to lose. But when a bloody battle has been fought with such intensity, one wonders how full corporate integration will be achieved.

Gent has always been careful to stress that the merged company will be a partnership. But this seems a bit fanciful following such a drawn-out and sapping conflict; one cannot imagine the corporate cultures of the two companies melding seamlessly together, however strong their unified desire to press a Wap phone into every sweaty palm in Europe.

Gent's real battle is only just beginning. Having captured Mannesmann, the work of turning it into a Vodafone Airtouch division will be laborious and difficult in the respect that Gent will hardly be welcomed as a conquering hero by the staff he is committed to not sacking.

One of the lessons from many futile mergers is that if the hostile takeover does not obliterate the company culture of the vanquished, the wounds can fester.

And what Gent will surely know as he emerges victorious from his first hostile skirmish is that the force of personality needed to win bid battles is many miles removed from the qualities needed to run the businesses afterwards. So let battle commence.

emily.bell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Tony's empty vassals
fields.standfirst:
In the Commons the sheep bleat on message - in the reformed Lords there are a different voices
Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Something sad is happening to our democracy. It is not the fault of this Government, or the last one, or of Lord Wakeham, or Rupert Murdoch or any other single source. It is too big a thing for that. But in Britain's brief democratic history, the report of Lord Wakeham's Royal Commission on Lords reform is a moment for the whole country to reflect on.
fields.body:
Something sad is happening to our democracy. It is not the fault of this Government, or the last one, or of Lord Wakeham, or Rupert Murdoch or any other single source. It is too big a thing for that. But in Britain's brief democratic history, the report of Lord Wakeham's Royal Commission on Lords reform is a moment for the whole country to reflect on.

This last week was the one when a committee of serious, intelligent people agreed that electing politicians was not good enough. Wakeham said he wanted the new chamber to be mostly unelected so it had 'a far wider range of expertise and experience', reflected all walks of life, was more independent and was 'representative of the whole of British society'. The inescapable conclusion is that his Commission does not think democratic election can provide a chamber of experienced, varied, independent and representative people. This is offensive but also, I fear, based on sound observation.

The Commons has become a dull, whipped chamber, scarce on independent minds, with too few women and non-white British, and far too many people whose only skill is inching - perhaps I should say millimetering - up a greasy pole, having never worked with their hands or created a company or had a new thought in their safe little lives.

Yet this, as any fule kno, is not the real point. Britain could very easily have a varied, independent-minded Senate by choosing a smaller total number of people by PR for a 15-year term, on a rolling series of elections, and paying them properly. If we wanted such a thing, of course. Instead we are presented with this strange paradox. The reformed second chamber is to be made deliberately illegitimate, in the sense of being mostly unelected, because it must not undermine the mystic authority of the Commons.

Yet it is also to be 'broadly representative' of the country, both through its elected minority and in the majority of party-political appointees who would match 'the political opinion of the country as a whole, as expressed in votes cast at the most recent general election'. So we are offered a fresh chamber which will be more intelligent, more diverse, with more women and better qualified to oversee our laws and liberties, chosen independently of Downing Street - but also one which reflects the state of the nation. And this in order to 'protect' the dimmer, cowed, political hacks' chamber a few hundred yards to the east?

It reminds me a little of my father's garden, when he once planted a stake to hold up a rose-tree; but the tree died and the stake grew. Instead of saving the Commons, it all reminds us of what a sickly institution it has become. And similarly, instead of making life easy for Tony Blair, an appointed second chamber, independent commission or not, would be hard to control.

The more I think about it, the less fearful I am of a tame, 'Tony's cronies' reform. Why? Because there is no New Labour ruling class. There are far too few reliable cronies to run a country, and almost none if you are also looking, as an appointments commission would have to, for people who have status and authority in their own right. Tony Blair has been hunting for Snarks, searching relentlessly for a new establishment cadre which is loyal and tough. But after much expense of smiles, hope, soap, forks and even railway shares, this hunt has been a comprehensive failure. Narks have been uncovered in some numbers, but of Snarks there has been, thus far, no sign.

Robert Winston, the popular medical icon and New Labour peer, goes and tells the truth about the NHS to the New Statesman . He denies himself, but his words bite him back. Helena Kennedy, who once seemed to be the ultimate New Labour place-woman, a Blair baroness, turns on Jack Straw over jury trials in a display of magnificent, highly successful and gutsy disloyalty. Lady Mallalieu, ditto. Polly Toynbee, who has doughtily fought against knee-jerk oppositionism in the Guardian , goes to the Dome, and is appalled, and leaves no syllable unminced in saying precisely why.

Much the same goes for journalists, actors, rock stars and business leaders enrolled at one stage or another as Friends of Tony. Given the size of the Government's mandate and the success of the economy, there are remarkably few reliable New Labourites in New Labour's New Britain. And so it would be in an appointed chamber. Look around and you will not find a group of respected, successful and varied people who would take a place there for 15 years and do what they were told. Life has moved on. Things aren't like that any more. It would be a chamber of Winstons, Toynbees and Helena Kennedys, feeling entirely free to air uncomfortable truths, criticise and rebel. Once appointed, why would they not? And just what, exactly, would they be expected to show loyalty to?

Had New Labour developed and articulated a clear ideology of its own, they would have been able to look at it, measure themselves against it, and say yes or no. Jack Straw's latest idea, they could ask - well, does that fit with what the Government believes about society? But New Labour has deliberately eschewed the big picture and gone instead for a politics of 'practical' solutions to immediate problems, dressed in a cheery populism and conducted in a fluid, post-ideological world where there are no natural enemies or last-ditch positions of principle.

And it has been exhilarating, no doubt about that; we have watched the New Labour tide flash at lightning speed across huge English mudflats, roar up previously arid conservative creeks and drench Middle Britain. How far can this spread? How wide can it go? But the trouble with having no natural enemies is that you have no natural friends either. In good times, you can draw in previously unimaginable allies to your grand coalition. But that same miles-wide, inches-deep inundation can, with equally extraordinary speed, streak away again. The moon tugs, the economy turns nasty, and there's a great sucking sound. The Matthew Freuds of this world will not stick around and nor may many of the voters.

It is conventional, at such a point in the argument, to urge Mr Blair to be more ideological, clearer about the principles upon which his Government rests, and more realistic about who his friends and enemies are. I so move. But the truth is that similar trends are apparent right across the developed world and that one national party, clutching its Third Way in both hands, is very unlikely to remake, by itself, a coherent politics of the kind we had and lost in the twentieth century. While that is so, most people today are loyal not to political ideas, but to their own professions, experiences, institutions and instincts. The Government cannot rely on ideological loyalty, for that is Old Labour. It has power and patronage, but frankly its carrots aren't appetising compared to the money, status and prestige on offer elsewhere. A poorly-paid quango job? A seat in the Lords in return for obedience? A gong? (It has now become the fashion for journalists to leak their refusal of gongs, thus grandly awarding themselves a kind of superior, virtual honour.) Who needs it?

So, when push comes to shove, Kennedy is a human rights lawyer, not a Labour Peer. All that huge crowd baying about New Labour's iron grip at the centre, its monstrously successful gagging of dissent, are completely wrong. Its problem is almost entirely the reverse, that there is no reliable new establishment and, from the health service to its anti-jury legislation, things fall apart, to the general glee of the chattering classes. Better, therefore, to turn back to first principles. Better to try to create a reformed democracy, on proper political, liberal principles, which is what Britain needs. If doing the wrong thing isn't going to work, you might as well do the right thing.
