Once appointed, why would they not? And just what, exactly, would they be expected to show loyalty to? Had New Labour developed and articulated a clear ideology of its own, they would have been able to look at it, measure themselves against it, and say yes or no. Jack Straw's latest idea, they could ask - well, does that fit with what the Government believes about society? But New Labour has deliberately eschewed the big picture and gone instead for a politics of 'practical' solutions to immediate problems, dressed in a cheery populism and conducted in a fluid, post-ideological world where there are no natural enemies or last-ditch positions of principle. And it has been exhilarating, no doubt about that; we have watched the New Labour tide flash at lightning speed across huge English mudflats, roar up previously arid conservative creeks and drench Middle Britain. How far can this spread? How wide can it go? But the trouble with having no natural enemies is that you have no natural friends either. In good times, you can draw in previously unimaginable allies to your grand coalition. But that same miles-wide, inches-deep inundation can, with equally extraordinary speed, streak away again. The moon tugs, the economy turns nasty, and there's a great sucking sound. The Matthew Freuds of this world will not stick around and nor may many of the voters. It is conventional, at such a point in the argument, to urge Mr Blair to be more ideological, clearer about the principles upon which his Government rests, and more realistic about who his friends and enemies are. I so move. But the truth is that similar trends are apparent right across the developed world and that one national party, clutching its Third Way in both hands, is very unlikely to remake, by itself, a coherent politics of the kind we had and lost in the twentieth century. While that is so, most people today are loyal not to political ideas, but to their own professions, experiences, institutions and instincts. The Government cannot rely on ideological loyalty, for that is Old Labour. It has power and patronage, but frankly its carrots aren't appetising compared to the money, status and prestige on offer elsewhere. A poorly-paid quango job? A seat in the Lords in return for obedience? A gong? (It has now become the fashion for journalists to leak their refusal of gongs, thus grandly awarding themselves a kind of superior, virtual honour.) Who needs it? So, when push comes to shove, Kennedy is a human rights lawyer, not a Labour Peer. All that huge crowd baying about New Labour's iron grip at the centre, its monstrously successful gagging of dissent, are completely wrong. Its problem is almost entirely the reverse, that there is no reliable new establishment and, from the health service to its anti-jury legislation, things fall apart, to the general glee of the chattering classes. Better, therefore, to turn back to first principles. Better to try to create a reformed democracy, on proper political, liberal principles, which is what Britain needs. If doing the wrong thing isn't going to work, you might as well do the right thing.

fields.headline: Did Milosevic's son kill Arkan?
fields.standfirst: The list of those implicated over Arkan's murder now includes the son of the Yugoslav President, who is a big player in the fuel black market Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Last week, as details of Arkan's last moments seeped out from beneath the wall of secrecy that descended following his death, one question remained: who killed Arkan? Was he a victim of Slobodan Milosevic's son, Marko, in a turf war over the black market in petrol and diesel?
fields.body:
The four men in tracksuits and trainers crossed the lobby of Belgrade's Intercontinental Hotel to where Arkan was sitting, chatting with his bodyguards. They asked innocuously if the hotel's fitness club was open. Arkan replied that it had closed, shaking hands with the men, apparently ending a banal encounter for the leader of the 'Tigers': indicted war criminal, Serbian hero and gangster.

As two of the men turned - apparently to walk away - their companions produced guns, spraying the most notorious killer of the Balkan wars with bullets.

According to eyewitnesses, one of the assailants aimed a Heckler and Koch sub-machine gun at Arkan's face and sprayed him with bullets. One 9mm bullet entered his left eye, penetrating the brain. Another entered one of his lungs.

Arkan's wife - Svetlana Raznatovic, better know as the Serb folk singer Ceca - was shopping 50 metres away in La Frans boutique when she heard the gunfire. While the shopkeeper tried to restrain her, for fear that she might also get injured in the shooting, Ceca ran into the lobby, where she found her husband dying in a pool of blood, and tried to drag him towards the door.

A hotel guest helped Ceca bundle Arkan into a car and drive him to hospital as Ceca tried to clear his mouth of blood. She was too late. Arkan - Europe's most infamous mass murderer since World War II - was already dead.

Last week, as details of Arkan's last moments seeped out from beneath the wall of secrecy that descended following his death, one question remained: who killed Arkan? Was he a victim of Slobodan Milosevic's son, Marko, in a turf war over the black market in petrol and diesel?

Ceca had told friends that she had had a premonition of her husband's death. The night before she had dreamed that her teeth were falling out - a common enough dream, but in the pantheon of Serb folklore, this is a warning of impending death. But if Arkan was nervous about his safety in the week before his murder, he showed little sign of it, going about his business as usual.

This involved keeping up his high profile as half of Serbia's most high-octane couple, being seen in clubs, holding court at the hotel that was his base, supervising his football club, Obilic. But business as usual - as most residents in Belgrade were well aware - meant something discreetly hidden from the public gaze: running a criminal empire, largely involved in the black market for cigarettes and petrol.

A former bank robber still wanted on an Interpol warrant, Arkan's criminal activities have supplied one possible motive for the crime.

In Belgrade, however, as the local media have speculated, you do not make a move against a figure as popular and powerful as Arkan without some kind of political backing.

While Arkan appeared relaxed, friends say in private he was getting jumpy. Too many prominent figures from his violent milieu of crime, nationalist politics and paramilitaries had recently been murdered.

Arkan was said by friends to have been worried about his safety in the last few months, reasoning that he was one of the last survivors of the criminal and paramilitary leaders closely involved with both state security and the wars in Bosnia and Croatia.

Another indicted war crime suspect who was said to have led paramilitary forces in Bosnia, Slobodan Miljkovic, died in a hail of bullets in 1998 in the Serbian town of Kragujevac. The last such figure still alive is Ljubisa Buha, known as Cume, who is based in Belgrade.

Arkan had other reasons to be nervous. Despite his infamy in the international community and an outstanding warrant from the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague, his most dangerous enemies were close by, underworld and political rivals who would have liked him out of the way.

Last month Zoran Sijan, a mafia leader and Arkan's kick-boxing partner, was shot while waiting for a traffic light. In recent years a number of Arkan's other associates and friends have also been murdered.

Some of these killings were carried out in the most blatant fashion, such as the shooting of Radovan Stojicic Badza, then the Minister of the Interior and Public Safety. Like Arkan, Badza had fought in Croatia. He was shot in a restaurant on 11 April, 1997.

In September, Vukasin Gojak Vule, a close friend and security manager at Arkan's casino, was killed in front of a nightclub. Another friend, Belgrade crime boss Rade Caldovic Centa, and his wife, Maja Pavic, were murdered in Belgrade's main square.

But if Arkan was coming under pressure from other criminal elements in Serbia, he was also not making any friends with Yugoslavia's President and fellow indicted war criminal, Slobodan Milosevic, and his powerful wife Mira Markovic.

According to opposition journalists in Belgrade, Arkan was growing disaffected with Milosevic's regime, allying himself with former police officials opposed to Mira Markovic's party. He was also, they claim, making overtures to the political opposition in recent months. Perhaps more dangerous still, Arkan had voiced support for the Presi dent of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic, who broke with Milosevic and has moved closer to the West.

But it is where Belgrade's politics and crime intersect that many believe the real answer to Arkan's murder will be uncovered - in the figure of Marko Milosevic - son of Slobodan, and one of the biggest players in black market for fuel.

It is a theory that has been floated in a long article in the respected independent newspaper Vreme, which has suggested that Arkan was mur dered after trying to monopolise the fuel market, creating a conflict of interest between 'the deceased one and Marko Milosevic regarding some monopoly on the import of liquid fuels'.

'The problem is that it is being claimed that Arkan stepped on the toes of some very serious people because the sale of smuggled fuel is an extremely lucrative business,' Vreme reports. 'Names are being mentioned that are not fit to print, as well as political parties that have been consolidating business lately.'

At the heart of this version of the motive for his murder is Nato's destruction of Serbia's own oil refineries, leaving it dependent on imported fuel and creating a widespread black market. Anyone with some friends in high places, or enough cash to bribe officials, can buy a piece of the action.

Arkan, however, was reported to be getting greedy. His men were stopping trucks as they entered Serbia and paying the smugglers wholesale prices and then reselling at black market prices, effectively creating a monopoly that was cutting out other major black marketeers - including Marko.

Few in Belgrade are confident that the authorities will ever truthfully get to the bottom of Arkan's murder. For while Belgrade police have made arrests and say the case is close to completion, many observers believe that little real effort is being made to find who was behind the killings.

But one thing is intriguing. Of the three men arrested, two of them were said to be former policemen sacked or suspended for links to the underworld. Yesterday Police Colonel Milenko Ercic identified the suspects as Dobrosav Gavric, 23, allegedly the triggerman; former policeman Dejan Pitulic, 33; and Vujadin Krstic, 36.

In one of his last interviews, given to the newspaper Nezavisne Novine in the Bosnian Serb Republic, Arkan said: 'My whole life has been one mega thriller movie.' It may be a thriller that lacks a denouement.

webTitle: A bad week at the office  or the start of the end?

fields.headline: A bad week at the office  or the start of the end?
fields.standfirst: The NHS, crime figures, jury trials... Blair's troubles have broken out in a rash, bringing him his greatest test so far. 'We have been firefighting,' said one Downing Street aide. 'We've lost our grip'New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Every day Downing Street staffers prepare a one-page grid setting out the Government's daily announcements for the week, and the other key media events. It is a little symbol of the degree of control Tony Blair's team normally wields. Most weeks the plans in the grid and the actual week's events bear a close relationship.
fields.body:
Every day Downing Street staffers prepare a one-page grid setting out the Government's daily announcements for the week, and the other key media events. It is a little symbol of the degree of control Tony Blair's team normally wields. Most weeks the plans in the grid and the actual week's events bear a close relationship.

But not for the past fortnight. As a Downing Street aide admitted: 'We have been firefighting. We have lost our grip.'

The question being asked - hardly for the first time - is whether something fundamental is happening in British politics. Is this Government, about to mark its 1,000th day in power after a period of unparalled popularity, finally looking mortal?

One member of the No 10 Policy Unit admitted: 'All governments are about a process of voter disillusionment. The job of the Prime Minister is to slow the process and the task of the Opposition is to accelerate it. Up until now, we have been doing pretty well'.

But now the problems are mounting - with acres of bad news about the Health Service, Blair's personal poll rating, public spending, crime figures, the race to be London's mayor, reform of the Lords, jury trials, and the business dealings of Geoffrey Robinson. Disillusionment may finally have set in.

One semi-detached Cabinet Minister spoke of a new bout of infighting in the Cabinet, in part attributable to the recognition that some of its members may have only 18 months at most left in their job. 'They want to leave a mark for posterity.'

Another claimed that Downing Street's communications empire had been overreaching itself. Big picture messages have been undelivered. Others have been mismanaged.

Yet a third Cabinet member, this one speaking from the Left of the party, disagrees, insisting that the public remains unmoved by recent bad publicity.

There is division also among pollsters and academics over whether we are witnessing a turning point in Blair's fortunes, or simply a bad week at the office for an otherwise remarkably popular Prime Minister.

John Curtice, Professor of Politics at Strathclyde University, sounds a note of caution by challenging whether the electorate was ever really hooked on Blair in the first place. Labour may have won a 179-seat majority, but it only secured 43 per cent of the vote on a low turnout.

Curtice argues: 'It had the active support of less than one third of the electorate. In terms of share of the vote, it did better in every election between 1945 and 1970. In 1997, the Conservatives lost, rather than Labour won, and since the election Labour's biggest asset has remained the Conservatives.'

Expectations about Labour have always been limited, Curtice insists. 'Over a year ago I did a poll for the BBC which showed most people thought taxes had risen and the NHS had deteriorated. That has been reflected in Labour's performance in real elections. In the European elections, Labour's share was almost the same as the Conservatives' in 1994.'

But Curtice thinks Labour is now flirting with danger. 'For the most part this has been a Government that has avoided banana skins. It has avoided a serious disjuncture between what it said before the election and what has happened thereafter. The Bernie Ecclestone affair [which revealed that the Grand Prix overlord had made a large donation to Labour while lobbying for relaxed tobacco sponsorship rules] was very serious, and since then the past fortnight over the NHS has been the second most serious moment for the Government.'

So long as the debate about the Health Service remained a technical argument over spending, Labour was unscathed, Curtice claims, but with the appearance of grim human stories revealing the failures of the NHS, the issue went critical.

But Curtice, like others, concludes: 'The NHS crisis so far has not been so fundamental to the electorate's perceptions as the ERM crisis in 1992. Leaving the ERM overnight ruined the Conservatives' claim to be the party to run the economy. Labour remains the party of the NHS.'

Nick Sparrow at ICM, the Observer's pollster, is less sanguine about Labour's fortunes.'Blair's personal rating is on the slide. It's not a blip. The perception out there is "we voted for a change in the NHS and in education", and the perception out there is that nothing, and I underline the word nothing, has changed.

'After 18 years of Conservative rule, Labour had a difficult job managing expectations, just as the ANC did after the end of apartheid. Now, approaching the next election, Cabinet Ministers are telling the electorate "we need longer".'

Reflecting a message to Labour MPs last week by Millbank, Sparrow - who also polls for the Tories - warned: 'Labour must be concerned that its vast army of soft voters will choose to sit on their hands at the next election. If turnout falls below 1997 levels - a distinct possibility, then the result could be very bad for Labour and not easily predictable for the pollsters.'

Professor Anthony King, the respected poll interpreter for Gallup in the Daily Telegraph , does not detect huge disillusionment since, like Curtice, he does not think 1997 reflected a surge of enthusiasm for Labour. 'Many people seem to think such a huge majority reflects the high hopes of an electorate. In reality most people just thought Labour might be more honest and more concerned with the public services. Above all, they won because they thought they would be safe. As a result, they don't feel that let down. Ergo, it is rather hard for the Government to fall from grace.'

King pauses and chuckles, adding: 'Especially since the only alternative is the Tories.'

Two pollsters closer to Labour - Peter Kellner and Deborah Mattison - support King, rather than Sparrow.

Following Monday's Mirror poll showing Blair's personal approval rating had fallen from 62 to 49 - a finding that rattled Downing Street - Kellner checked back to find a similar fall had occurred in the summer when the Prime Minister was under fire over his exclusive Italian beach holiday. His rating is undoubtedly lower than a year ago, but it tends to move around with controversies.

'If you look at the tracking data on voting intentions, there has barely been any movement. If there was a seriously credible opposition, the Government would potentially be in quite a lot more trouble than at present.'

Mattison, prized by Labour for her focus group work for the party, says some women perceive the Government as too male, but most of the chatterati criticism of Blair - over jury trials, for instance - has no wider resonance.

But Tony Travers from the London School of Economics reckons a crunch point has arrived. 'After you have been in power for three years, it is very difficult to argue that you have not had enough time to change the direction of policy. It cannot be a coin cidence, however, that Cabinet Minister after Cabinet Minister is making speeches setting out their 10-year programme. They are trying to manage expectations about how long it takes to turn the Government tanker around.'

For this reason alone Blair must recognise he faces potentially his most fraught period and the pressure in the first instance may come from the party. In a revealing question and answer session with party workers in London last Wednesday, Blair constantly referred to his personal frustration at the slow pace with which Whitehall worked. 'If there is one thing I have learnt in government, it is how long it takes to get things done,' he said.

He tried to remind the party that it could not retreat on the policies that had won such a large Commons majority. He defended the decision to stick to Tory spending limits in the first 'two very tight years' by pointing out that the Government had been paying out more in interest payments than on the entire school system in England.

And he admitted he was under sustained pressure to do more. 'I have a stream of people coming into my office - all of them with good causes and all of which cost money.' He then begged the party to remember that the Government was only halfway through the first year of a more generous spending regime covering 1999-2000, and the two years thereafter.

But Mark Seddon, editor of the left-wing weekly Tribune , believes the defensive tone and pledge to increase NHS spending to the EU average marks a turning point. 'The wind is beginning to change. They are having to row back and drop some of these mantras about modernisation. A line has been drawn against further privatisation in the NHS and we now have a commitment to increase NHS spending year on year.'

Yet Seddon remains as mystified as any about the precise origins of the Blair NHS spending pledge made on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme.

Downing Street insists that Blair and Gordon Brown spoke last Saturday by phone about the NHS and agreed the idea. The Chancellor was in Scotland and Blair at his weekend retreat at Chequers.

Some Treasury sources suggest the two only agreed to hold out the prospect of year-on-year real term increases of 5 per cent - something Health Secretary Alan Milburn had already suggested on the BBC's Today programme.

Yet Blair was hardly forced into the idea under the pressure of cross-examination by David Frost. He offered the proposal, saying: 'If this July when we work out the next three-year [spending] period we can carry on getting real terms rises in the Health Service of about 5 per cent, then at the end of that five years we will be in a position when our Health Service spending comes up to the average of the European Union.'

The five-year period to which he was referring was due to end in April 2006, although Blair got into a muddle over his starting dates. The whole promise was conditional on the performance of the economy.

The briefings that followed led to a string of contradictory stories as to what the promise meant in terms of billions of pounds, adding to the sense that this was a pledge dreamt up on the back of an envelope in panic.

The imbroglio pre-empted a large part of the negotiations over the Government- wide spending review due to be completed this summer. The other spending ministries had not been informed in advance of the pledge.

It all left one disgruntled Education Minister saying: 'We badly need the equivalent of a flu outbreak in the classrooms.'

Either way Curtice reckons the big story of the past fortnight is that public spending is back on the agenda.

He says: 'Elite opinion has finally realised that the electorate had moved on from demanding ever more tax cuts. It is destabilising for Labour politicians who have spent years thinking such cuts are the only way to win elections in Britain. That may be the real significance of the past few weeks.'

Following Monday's Mirror poll showing Blair's personal approval rating had fallen from 62 to 49 - a finding that rattled Downing Street - Kellner checked back to find a similar fall had occurred in the summer when the Prime Minister was under fire over his exclusive Italian beach holiday. His rating is undoubtedly lower than a year ago, but it tends to move around with controversies. 'If you look at the tracking data on voting intentions, there has barely been any movement. If there was a seriously credible opposition, the Government would potentially be in quite a lot more trouble than at present.' Mattison, prized by Labour for her focus group work for the party, says some women perceive the Government as too male, but most of the chatterati criticism of Blair - over jury trials, for instance - has no wider resonance. But Tony Travers from the London School of Economics reckons a crunch point has arrived. 'After you have been in power for three years, it is very difficult to argue that you have not had enough time to change the direction of policy. It cannot be a coin cidence, however, that Cabinet Minister after Cabinet Minister is making speeches setting out their 10-year programme. They are trying to manage expectations about how long it takes to turn the Government tanker around.' For this reason alone Blair must recognise he faces potentially his most fraught period and the pressure in the first instance may come from the party. In a revealing question and answer session with party workers in London last Wednesday, Blair constantly referred to his personal frustration at the slow pace with which Whitehall worked. 'If there is one thing I have learnt in government, it is how long it takes to get things done,' he said. He tried to remind the party that it could not retreat on the policies that had won such a large Commons majority. He defended the decision to stick to Tory spending limits in the first 'two very tight years' by pointing out that the Government had been paying out more in interest payments than on the entire school system in England. And he admitted he was under sustained pressure to do more. 'I have a stream of people coming into my office - all of them with good causes and all of which cost money.' He then begged the party to remember that the Government was only halfway through the first year of a more generous spending regime covering 1999-2000, and the two years thereafter. But Mark Seddon, editor of the left-wing weekly Tribune , believes the defensive tone and pledge to increase NHS spending to the EU average marks a turning point. 'The wind is beginning to change. They are having to row back and drop some of these mantras about modernisation. A line has been drawn against further privatisation in the NHS and we now have a commitment to increase NHS spending year on year.' Yet Seddon remains as mystified as any about the precise origins of the Blair NHS spending pledge made on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme. Downing Street insists that Blair and Gordon Brown spoke last Saturday by phone about the NHS and agreed the idea. The Chancellor was in Scotland and Blair at his weekend retreat at Chequers. Some Treasury sources suggest the two only agreed to hold out the prospect of year-on-year real term increases of 5 per cent - something Health Secretary Alan Milburn had already suggested on the BBC's Today programme. Yet Blair was hardly forced into the idea under the pressure of cross-examination by David Frost. He offered the proposal, saying: 'If this July when we work out the next three-year [spending] period we can carry on getting real terms rises in the Health Service of about 5 per cent, then at the end of that five years we will be in a position when our Health Service spending comes up to the average of the European Union.' The five-year period to which he was referring was due to end in April 2006, although Blair got into a muddle over his starting dates. The whole promise was conditional on the performance of the economy. The briefings that followed led to a string of contradictory stories as to what the promise meant in terms of billions of pounds, adding to the sense that this was a pledge dreamt up on the back of an envelope in panic. The imbroglio pre-empted a large part of the negotiations over the Government- wide spending review due to be completed this summer. The other spending ministries had not been informed in advance of the pledge. It all left one disgruntled Education Minister saying: 'We badly need the equivalent of a flu outbreak in the classrooms.' Either way Curtice reckons the big story of the past fortnight is that public spending is back on the agenda. He says: 'Elite opinion has finally realised that the electorate had moved on from demanding ever more tax cuts. It is destabilising for Labour politicians who have spent years thinking such cuts are the only way to win elections in Britain. That may be the real significance of the past few weeks.'

webTitle: Drug past returns to haunt Gore

fields.headline: Drug past returns to haunt Gore
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: it is the story that won't leave Al Gore alone. Thirteen years after he admitted 'rare and infrequent' use of soft drugs in his youth, the dope smoke is still lingering around the Vice-President. This weekend it is threatening to engulf his campaign for the Democratic nomination for the presidency.
fields.byline: Martin Bright and Ed Helmore, New York
fields.body:
it is the story that won't leave Al Gore alone. Thirteen years after he admitted 'rare and infrequent' use of soft drugs in his youth, the dope smoke is still lingering around the Vice-President. This weekend it is threatening to engulf his campaign for the Democratic nomination for the presidency.

In an ominous re-run of the Monica Lewinsky affair, Gore's trouble began with a spiked magazine article. A chapter of a new biography, Inventing Al Gore by reporter Bill Turque, was due to appear in the latest edition of Newsweek , but was pulled just before publication. Editors thought it made too much of Gore's past drug use.

According to John Carl Warnecke, a former friend and colleague at the Nashville Tennessean, where Gore was a reporter, Gore's use of the drug was frequent and extensive, and continued until he entered Congress in 1976.

The claims threaten to ignite a damaging war between the two front runners Bush and Gore - both of whom have admitted taking drugs, although with considerable circumspection. Bush said last summer, following claims that he had taken cocaine, that he had not taken any drugs in a quarter of a century. Now Gore is likely to face the same furious media scrutiny.

The claims are all the more damaging in a country that regularly imprisons people for possessing marijuana.

The Newsweek editors were apparently concerned about the reliability of the source, a recovering alcoholic with a history of depression. Turque, who had checked Warnecke's allegations with other sources, was persuaded to agree to the extract being pulled in return for more space to explain the full context of the story.

But Warnecke took the story to the campaigning Drug Reform Co-ordination Network, which published his claims on its website.

He said he and Gore 'smoked regularly, as buddies. Marijuana, hash. I was his regular supplier. I didn't deal dope, just gave it to him.'

Asked how frequently, Warnecke responded: 'We smoked more than once, more than a few times, we smoked a lot. We smoked in his car, in his house, we smoked in his parents' house ... we smoked on weekends. We smoked a lot.'

Warnecke's strategy had a devastating effect. The story was immediately picked up by Mediagossip.com, a website regularly used by American journalists. By yesterday the story had taken Washington by storm, not because of the allegations themselves, but because of the suggestion that Gore misled the public when he made his original statement about his drug use.

In November 1987, the New York Times reported Gore as saying he had last taken the drug when he was 24. He had first used the drug at Harvard and used it 'once or twice' while off-duty in Vietnam; on several occasions while he was in graduate school at Vanderbilt University and when he was at the Nashville newspaper. He was quoted as saying, 'We have to be honest and candid and open in dealing with the [drug] problem.'

Warnecke's allegations suggest that Gore's 'occasional' use was a habit that carried on into the very week he ran for Congress in 1976.

A spokesman for Gore yesterday insisted that the Vice- President's previous statements were true and that Warnecke had backed them at the time. 'This is old news. [Gore] brought it up himself in 1987 and was definitive at that time that he's never used it since entering public office,' Chris Lehane said.

'He's said he used it in college, used it in Vietnam and used it in Tennessee, but definitely hasn't used it since entering public service.'

Warnecke now says it is now time to set the record straight, and he accuses Gore of pressuring him to keep quiet. 'He called me three times in one morning, and he said, "Don't talk to the press at all about this," Warnecke now says. 'That's a stonewall, and it's another form of lying. But I couldn't do that. But I was torn ...So I came up with this half-truth - that Al had tried it a couple of times with me and he didn't like pot.'

The new allegations about Gore come on the eve of the Iowa caucus, when voters in the Midwest state will decide between the vice-president and his main rival, Bill Bradley, a former basketball star.

fields.headline: Dissent must not be suppressed
fields.trailText: The lifeblood of an effective democracy is debate, dissent, the participation of the ordinary citizen and the building and sustaining of coalitions of view that can produce well reasoned and well grounded change. No practising democracy has succeeded in producing this paragon of democratic virtue; all suffering grievous deformations. Money politics in the US and, now we discover, in Germany; the desperate inability to break the consensus in Japan or Switzerland; the lack of ability to produce determined proactive government in Italy. Looking round the best defence of democracy is the sad claim that it is better than any alternative.
fields.body:
The lifeblood of an effective democracy is debate, dissent, the participation of the ordinary citizen and the building and sustaining of coalitions of view that can produce well reasoned and well grounded change. No practising democracy has succeeded in producing this paragon of democratic virtue; all suffering grievous deformations. Money politics in the US and, now we discover, in Germany; the desperate inability to break the consensus in Japan or Switzerland; the lack of ability to produce determined proactive government in Italy. Looking round the best defence of democracy is the sad claim that it is better than any alternative.

But the story of our new century is surely that we are going to have get better at democracy - and that the lesson starts at home. One place to begin is New Labour's treatment of dissent. The public arm-twisting of Robert Winston after he had made valid if uncomfortable criticisms of the NHS and his subsequent partial retraction of what he knew to be true was one unedifying episode; but it was trivial besides what went on in private in the run-up to the Lords vote on the withdrawal of the automatic right to jury trial in magistrates courts on Thursday. Peers were subjected to intense personal pressure, and those who dared to speak up on what they considered a vital matter of principle faced threats of organised ostracism and calls to leave the Labour Party.

Both incidents are part of a pattern of ever tighter New Labour control of the way MPs and peers behave; the parliamentary Labour Party has never been so quiescent. From the leadership's point of view this is entirely proper. Labour was elected to execute a political programme that has been largely predetermined, as Tony Blair has repeatedly made clear. In today's media environment any dissent is fallen upon by the media and blown up massively. The only safe way to proceed is for the leadership to conduct policy, and for any policy to command unalloyed support. Public criticism invites too high a political price.

This might work better if those who made policy were informed by a clear body of centre-Left principle, but New Labour's difficulty is that too much of what it proposes invites its supporters to go too far against their principles. Whether it is Glenys Kinnock criticising the disgraceful broach of the EU's own guidelines in the sale of Hawk parts to Zimbabwe, or Helena Kennedy speaking out against the withdrawal of jury trial , the Government has only itself to blame for their reaction. Neither joined Labour to prosecute Conservative policies.

Nor should they be treated as pariahs - any more than Winston over the NHS - if they go public with their criticism. How else are they to make their case? The truth is that policy is made by a small number of Ministers and advisers who should not see themselves as omnipotent. There needs to be much greater sensitivity to what the party thinks; greater debate and exchange before policy is launched rather than after it; more readiness to accept that dissent, criticism and argument are part of the cut and thrust of democracy; and much less fear about the reaction of the media.

New Labour will regard an editorial like this as so much impractical moonshine, for which we have one very practical retort: Ken Livingstone. We share the profound reserves about his candidature for London mayor, but it will be successful for one reason only - a vote for him is a vote for a different way of conducting not just policy but the treatment of dissent. Ruthless top-down politics doesn't work any more; you have to persuade and argue with dissenters. Not try to suppress them.

webTitle: Bush boldly salsas to Latino tune

fields.headline: Bush boldly salsas to Latino tune
fields.standfirst: Republicans are spending millions to win the powerful Hispanic vote The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Not many people have heard of Lionel Sosa, but as the US election year gathers momentum the Texas media consultant is going to become increasingly important. His efforts may even determine the outcome of the vote.
fields.body:
Not many people have heard of Lionel Sosa, but as the US election year gathers momentum the Texas media consultant is going to become increasingly important. His efforts may even determine the outcome of the vote.

Sosa has worked on Republican presidential campaigns since the days of Ronald Reagan, but until now he has played a walk-on part, the Hispanic called on stage for the sake of token ethnic balance. This year, he has been given a leading role, along with an awful lot of money, to win the Hispanic vote for George W. Bush and the Republicans.

His personal ascent mirrors the almost vertical rise of Hispanics, or Latinos as many prefer to be called, as a force in US politics and society. In five years they will overtake blacks as the country's largest minority group, and by 2050 they will form a quarter of the population.

With the breakthrough of Puerto Rican pop stars Jennifer Lopez, Ricky Martin and Marc Anthony, alongside sports personalities such as the Mexican boxer Oscar De La Hoya, Latino culture is now hip. Across the country, schoolchildren trying to grasp the words to Martin's hit 'La Vida Loca' are signing up in record numbers to learn Spanish. And in a hugely symbolic but little noticed cultural turning point in 1992, salsa sauce overtook tomato ketchup as the nation's favourite relish.

'While our preceding generation felt pressure to assimilate, America has now generously agreed to meet us in the middle,' says Christy Haubegger, the 30-year-old editor of Latina magazine.

'Just as we become more American, America is simultaneously becoming more Latino.'

The Hispanic electorate is now the holy grail - a huge swing vote that could win or lose the election. More than 80 per cent live in California, Texas, Florida, New York, New Jersey, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Illinois - states that account for 179 of the 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidency.

By comparison, there are a mere 56,000 Latinos in Iowa. Nevertheless, almost all the candidates in last week's party caucuses have made an effort to cultivate them. With his formidable campaign chest, however, Bush has outdone them all. Sosa bought up all the available space on Spanish-speaking media months ahead to run Bush advertisements.

Four years ago this week, the presidential hopefuls were chasing the legendary 'soccer moms', suburban women who according to the stereotype spend much of the day ferrying their children to football games. They were members of normally middle-class Republican families whom Democratic pollsters correctly identified as being open to Bill Clinton's middle-of-the-road appeal. Their seduction allowed Clinton to recast the Democrats' traditional base.

Now the Republicans are trying to do the same with the Latino vote.

Republican party chairman Jim Nicholson says: 'The Latino community is in play in this election like never before. And they're sending this message: we're open to change; persuade us; make your best case.'

A Republican poll has identified 25 per cent of Hispanic voters as open to such persuasion, and that is where Sosa comes in. He is leading Hispanic campaigns for both Bush and the Republican national party, and has produced a series of party political ads in a $10 million campaign aimed at branding the Latino emphasis on family and self-reliance as Republican virtues.

One advertisement shows four generations of a His panic family celebrating Independence Day. The grandfather, Joe Guerra, tells viewers: 'When people ask why I'm a Republican, I tell them it is because my family's values are the values of the Republican Party.'

It is a bold strategy. No one thought of Latino voters as natural Republicans before. But thanks to Bush, the Democrats can no longer take them for granted.

In November 1998, at the post-election Republican ball in Washington's Ronald Reagan Convention Centre, Bush's decisive re-election as Texas governor was on everyone's lips, if only because it was the party's sole cause for celebration. Newt Gingrich and his cohorts of zealous white puritans had been rebuffed at the polls for their obsession with impeaching Clinton.

Bush offered Republicans a reason to hope, by reaching out beyond the party's traditional base to his state's 5.7 million Latino residents. Bush's 'politics of inclusion' rapidly became the new party mantra.

Bush and Vice-President Al Gore each hold overwhelming leads among Hispanics over their nearest rivals in the party primaries. Assuming they both emerge as presidential nominees, the question hanging over the election is whether Bush can hold on to his gains in Texas and reproduce them in California, where Gore holds a two-to-one advantage among Latino voters.

webTitle: Why the press has a ball mauling Labour

fields.headline: Why the press has a ball mauling Labour
fields.standfirst:
Andrew Rawnsley analyses the headlines
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The sun glares on New Labour. A double-page spread on Thursday drooled over 'The Week That It All Went Belly-Up For Blair'.
fields.body:
The sun glares on New Labour. A double-page spread on Thursday drooled over 'The Week That It All Went Belly-Up For Blair'.

It was certainly the week when newspapers Tony Blair has devoted so much time to wooing threw up on his Government. There was such a rash of black headlines - 'crisis', 'fiasco' and 'retreat' were the words of damnation from the Telegraph - readers might think the Government was on the brink of collapse.

The Times cleared its throat on Monday with 'NHS ills will take years to cure says Blair'. It got louder on Tuesday with 'Pay soars as Blair panics over NHS'. By Wednesday, it screamed: 'Blair at bay after leap in violent crime'.

The Mail's Monday lead was Mo Mowlam's confession she had smoked cannabis. Tuesday, it got sarky about the NHS pay awards: 'Brilliant! But how will the nurses be paid?' Wednesday, it said Jack Straw 'admitted' the rise in crime 'may be a legacy of the Stephen Lawrence case'. Thursday, it mourned the 'death knell' for the RUC. Friday, the sale of arms to Zimbabwe was denounced as 'ethics and the smell of hypocrisy'.

The Mail was never a New Labour supporter. The headline to cause most choking over the cornflakes in Downing Street came from a tabloid seen as a friend, the Mirror . 'Blair's 25% poll slump', it reported. The poll did show a slump in his ratings, but hardly fatal. To 40 per cent unsatisfied, 49 per cent were satisfied, a score any Prime Minister at mid-term would kill his mother for.

There are various reasons for the press savagery. The Guardian devoted a front page to the Government's difficulties. The papers are bored with reporting success. Some journalists - stung by being seen as lickspittle to New Labour - want to prove otherwise.

The right-wing journalists Blair beguiled would never be constant friends. The Mail's harumpher, Simon Heffer, bragged about how he was charmed over tea with Blair but now says 'a Government that has got away with so much for so long looks truly vulnerable - all we need now is an Opposition who can properly capitalise on that weakness'.

With no sign this will come from the Tories, the papers - especially of the Right - will be the Opposition instead.

The headline to cause most choking over the cornflakes in Downing Street came from a tabloid seen as a friend, the Mirror . 'Blair's 25% poll slump', it reported. The poll did show a slump in his ratings, but hardly fatal. To 40 per cent unsatisfied, 49 per cent were satisfied, a score any Prime Minister at mid-term would kill his mother for. There are various reasons for the press savagery. The Guardian devoted a front page to the Government's difficulties. The papers are bored with reporting success. Some journalists - stung by being seen as lickspittle to New Labour - want to prove otherwise. The right-wing journalists Blair beguiled would never be constant friends. The Mail's harumpher, Simon Heffer, bragged about how he was charmed over tea with Blair but now says 'a Government that has got away with so much for so long looks truly vulnerable - all we need now is an Opposition who can properly capitalise on that weakness'. With no sign this will come from the Tories, the papers - especially of the Right - will be the Opposition instead.

webTitle: Nature loses plot in new winter's tale

fields.headline: Nature loses plot in new winter's tale
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: It's not just your rose-tinted childhood memory. The traditional British winter - depicted in paintings, Christmas cards and carols - really is becoming a thing of the past.
fields.body:
It's not just your rose-tinted childhood memory. The traditional British winter - depicted in paintings, Christmas cards and carols - really is becoming a thing of the past. Gone are fields glinting with frost in the thin winter sun, and icicles dangling from barns. Gone are the frozen lakes, and warmly wrapped rosy-cheeked children skating on ponds.

Instead, Britain is enjoying daffodils before Christmas, grass that grows throughout the year, and plants that bloom twice a year. Birds that used to be silenced by freezing weather now sing through the winter. Other birds that once migrated to Africa at the first sign of cold are staying put.

Britain - or at least the southern part of it - is rapidly becoming a frost-free zone, according to data compiled by the Meteorological Office for The Observer. Global warming is heating up nights more rapidly than days, making it rare for temperatures to dip below zero.

The figures show that the number of frosty nights in central England has already fallen by a third in the past 40 years. In the Sixties, the temperature dropped below zero on average 47 nights a year. By the Seventies, it did so on only 39 nights a year, and in the Nineties that has fallen again to 35. On most of those occasions it dipped below zero briefly and was not cold enough to cause a ground frost. The Met Office predicts the number of freezing nights will drop by a further 50 per cent in the next 50 years.

One key indicator watched by climatologists is ice formation on the surface of Lake Windermere. Until the mid-Eighties, it partially froze on average on 10 days a year. However, no ice has appeared on the lake since 1989.

Another key test of the severity of winter has been the date at which birds such as the song thrush and blue tit start singing again in the spring. Tim Sparks, at the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, used to monitor the event across the country as part of a range of spring tests, but not any more. 'We had to abandon the birdsong tests, because they now just sing all the way through winter. We can no longer record it as a spring event.

'We're seeing changes in two decades that you wouldn't expect to see in a lifetime. It's really quite astonishing. Nature is really confused.'

As The Observer predicted in November, last year was the hottest since records began in Britain in 1659. The main reason, however, was not hot days but warm nights.

'The nights are getting warmer at a more rapid rate than days - no one knows why, but it may be to do with the degree of cloudiness,' said Geoff Jenkins, climate change specialist at the Met Office. 'We're absolutely certain the decline in frost is due to global warming.'

The death of frost - and generally warmer winters - has had a dramatic impact on wildlife and gardens. According to the National Trust, nature has been more confused this year than any other.

Barry Champion, head gardener at Trelissick gardens in south Cornwall counted 125 plants in flower on 1 January this year - compared with 80 last year. 'It's the most advanced year I can remember,' he said. 'I had one plant flower in December when it's meant to flower in July. Other shrubs are flowering twice a year, in spring and autumn.'

Across the country, snowdrops and daffodils, traditionally seen as heralding spring, were flowering before Christmas. At the National Trust gardens in Killerton in south Devon, daffodils appeared on 14 December.

'We're certainly not getting as many frosts, and we don't have to worry about protecting plants from it in winter now,' said head gardener Andrew Mudge. 'There's virtually no dormant season now. The grass is growing all time, and we have to cut it throughout winter, which we never used to.'

In the past few years, the Trust has started to cultivate oranges in more than half a dozen of its properties. 'The crops are not bad - we're getting a few fruit per plant,' said the Trust's head of gardens, Mike Calman. 'We're getting more of a continental climate - like this winter. I mean, where is it?'

The decline of frost, and the milder winter, is increasing the range of plants that can be grown in Britain, but gardeners as well as environmentalists are quick to point out it isn't all for the good.

'You don't get something for nothing. You'll get more pests and diseases which like warmer, moister climates,' said Calman. 'Also, if plants don't go to sleep in winter, a late frost can be devastating.' Last year, a late frost killed the Trust's entire crop of apples at Sizergh Castle in Cumbria.

Dr Ute Collier, head of climate change at the Worldwide Fund for Nature, insisted the warm winters were a mixed blessing. 'Some people might think it's good for their garden, but we're also getting much stormier winters. The sea level will be rising, and we'll get more floods,' she said. 'This is only the beginning; we're at the start of the changes.'

webTitle: Tory fury at 'tapas plot' over Hague

fields.headline: Tory fury at 'tapas plot' over Hague
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo has struck a secret deal with William Hague's second-in-command to clear his way to becoming the next Tory leader, according to a highly placed source in the party.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo has struck a secret deal with William Hague's second-in-command to clear his way to becoming the next Tory leader, according to a highly placed source in the party.

The report of the deal, which underlines the bitter tensions at the heart of the Tory party as Hague's rivals vie for power, was furiously denied last night by Shadow Chancellor Francis Maude.

It shows the depth of rivalry inside the Tory party, with Conservatives who were once confident they represented the party mainstream now fearful they are being isolated by the better organised and more determined right wing.

The source claimed the Maude-Portillo pact was finalised in a Pimlico tapas bar well known as a scene of political intrigue. He said that information came from the boastful indiscretion of someone inside the Maude-Portillo political circle.

But Maude said last night: 'This is absolutely, unequivocally untrue. I have never been to this place. I have never heard of it. Also, it would have been perfectly sensible for me to have dinner with Michael Portillo. What you are printing is a story that is intended to be damaging to me, and is damaging to me.'

The source said that Maude, who had considered himself a possible right-wing challenger for the leadership after the next election, will stand aside in return for the promise of a key job in Portillo's team. Sources say Portillo's supporters have been heard boasting about their coup, and word has spread to moderate Tories already alarmed by the party's drift to the right. The deal was allegedly done in the Goya tapas bar, a favourite spot for plotting because its cellar restaurant is full of alcoves.

The battle between left and right for the heart of the Tory party has seen a group dubbed the Pimlico plotters spending months working behind the scenes, trying to make sure every new Tory MP elected next year is from the Thatcherite Right.

Insiders say they have a vast network of sympathisers in Tory seats where the sitting MP is expected to quit at the next election, and in key marginals. It has been built up through Conservative Way Forward, a pressure group backed by Thatcher and by the Democracy Movement, funded by the right-wing millionaire Paul Sykes.

The source said: 'The lurch to the right in the Tory party is happening from underneath, but it's not happening because most of the party has lurched to the right. It is happening because the right is well organised and the left of the party is so demoralised.'

A Tory member in a winnable London seat has described her surprise at receiving a cold call after sending for literature from Conservative Way Forward. The caller asked a series of questions about local issues which would help an outside candidate contest the seat, and gave out names of potential candidates approved by Conservative Way Forward. Members of selection panels have also been supplied by the group with questions likely to trip up candidates they oppose.

Former MPs who stayed loyal to John Major in the last Parliament, such as ex-Social Security Ministers Andrew Mitchell and Alistair Burt, or Peter Butler, a former parliamentary aide to Chancellor Ken Clarke, have complained that the group's tactics are frustrating their efforts to get back into Parliament.

There were protests to Conservative Central Office after Mitchell was excluded from the five-man shortlist for the plum London seat covering Pimlico. Mitchell was a protégé of former Tory chief whip Lord Wakeham, who recently rang Maude to appeal for help in finding Mitchell a seat. Friends say the Tory peer was shocked when Maude replied: 'He's not on our list.'

Maude was guest speaker last year at the Way Forward's main event, the Nicholas Ridley memorial lecture. Robbie Gibb, Maude's chief-of-staff, is widely rumoured to be the driving force behind the group, but when asked about his involvement he said: 'I wish I had the time.' His brother, Tory MP Nick Gibb, is on the group's council, and one of its organisers is Mark MacGregor. Robbie Gibb was best man at McGregor's wedding. The two are near neighbours in Pimlico and have been friends since MacGregor was chairman of the Federation of Conservative Students and Gibb a leader of the Conservative Students in the mid-Eighties.

MacGregor was behind the decision to install extra phone lines in a house in Lord North Street in 1995, as a possible campaign HQ for Portillo when it appeared Major was on the point of being ousted by the Right. He has now been selected to fight Thanet South, the seat held until 1997 by the disgraced ex-Cabinet Minister Jonathan Aitken.

webTitle: Postnatal blues can 'lower IQ of baby boys'

fields.headline: Postnatal blues can 'lower IQ of baby boys'
fields.trailText: The sons of women who suffered 'baby blues' have notably lower IQs than their schoolmates, according to new research.
fields.body:
The sons of women who suffered 'baby blues' have notably lower IQs than their schoolmates, according to new research.

With postnatal depression hitting at least one mother in seven, the findings will renew debate over the care of children in early years and provision of parental leave.

Principal researcher Dr Susan Pawlby said the IQ-depression link was strongest where the mother was depressed in the first three months - and much more significant for boys than girls.

'The research shows a continued link between depresion and later development,' she said. 'There are clear implications here for health professionals and for policy.'

The sons of mothers who were depressed had an average IQ score of 86, while offspring of non-depressed mums scored 103, according to tests on a group of children aged 11. For daughters, the gap was narrower, with scores of 94 and 98.

Girls appeared to escape the negative IQ effect, but Pawlby's team have yet to look at self-esteem and anxiety. 'We can't say yet what the effects on other measures will be for girls.'

Pawlby said in couples where fathers were closely involved in care of the child there was less risk of mothers being depressed, and urged swifter government action on paid paternity leave.

'Fathers are hugely important in the early stages,' she said. 'Both parents need parental leave, otherwise only better off fathers will be able to take time off, and they might not be the ones who most need it.' The research follows a controversial study last week suggesting fathers stay out of birthing rooms.

Public Health Minister Yvette Cooper said the Government's £500 million Sure Start programme aimed to give help in early months.

'This is extremely interesting research. We know that postnatal depression can have a severe effect on families and children as they develop,' she said. 'We must make that support for women with postnatal depression available across the country.'

Child welfare groups added to calls for more investment, including for the NHS.

Eileen Hayes, a parenting adviser for the NSPCC - which this week publishes a book, Baby's First Year , designed to help parents - said the results would force Health Ministers to reconsider resource decisions. 'A few years ago mothers spent days in hospital, surrounded by support and expertise,' she said. 'Now many are thrown out after a few hours.'

Hayes said glorification of parenthood, especially by celebrities, often made matters worse. 'There is this expectation that it will all be wonderful, and then it happens and mum actually feels exhausted and scared.'

The researchers, who are to publish their work in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, say babies suffer by lack of attention in the first weeks.

'This is when a baby is finding their place in the world,' she said. 'And it seems as if boys need it more than girls. Boys have more delayed development than girls at that stage, so a deficit of attention may affect them more.' Girl babies smile much earlier than boys.

The research - which took income and family structure into account - is the first to track results of postnatal depression into later years.

Pawlby said parents could reduce the risk:: 'Mothers who have been or are depressed should not despair. It is vitally important to spend time with your child.'

webTitle: Yes, you can be loyal to a fault

fields.headline: Yes, you can be loyal to a fault
fields.standfirst: He knows his art, he's writing a book - How could anyone who seems this presentable make a living out of being Jeffrey Archer's spokesman? :  'This is a man who, as he took Archer's flak and defended the indefensible, actually believed what he was saying. Most of it anyway'
fields.trailText: Take three quotes:
fields.body:
Take three quotes:

'I think the public have had quite enough of people lining up to kick this man's head in.'

'One of Jeffrey's great faults is that precision is not one of his strengths.'

'...'

One palpable untruth, one galloping understatement and one long, meaningful silence which tells us a lot about the extent to which this man and his God, Jeffrey Archer, feel betrayed by the Tory Party.

Stephan Shakespeare, né Kukowski, is not fascinating in himself. He's pleasant, and he's not stupid. What is fascinating is how unbelievably smitten he is, still, with his employer.

He was chief-of-staff, bottle-washer and spokesman during the mayoral campaign and right through its explosive collapse after one-time Archer admirer Ted Francis admitted lying in court for him; right through those happy November days when, as it were, the fan hit the shit and vice versa. Last week he began running Archer's Mayfair gallery for him - it's now called Shakespeare Fine Art - and speed-writing a book on the mayoral affair, with Archer's blessing, which promises to settle some vicious scores against Right, Left and press alike (its working title is Theatre of Cruelty ).

This is a man who, as he took Archer's flak and defended the indefensible, actually believed what he was saying . Most of it, anyway. His loyalty is unquestionable; his fervour evangelistic. I'm meeting him near his Barbican flat, and he keeps swinging the conversation back to Archer. 'I do admire the man. I like him and I admire him.' But he admits there's a relief in moving from politics to the (relative) cleanliness of the art world. 'The best thing is dealing with artists rather than politicians. It's more honest. You can say what you like. You can be direct if you want to.'

He was direct enough, on his first day last week, to the staff of the Bruton Street gallery about his plans to revamp it; to have a 'shop-front' approach, to pull in punters and encourage new pop art. Three handed in their resignations immediately. He shrugs. It's no problem.

He talks with love and vigour about post-Duchampian art; about Archer's Warhols and Harings, about the plans to showcase the radically left-wing Derek Boshier ('there is almost no right-of centre art, by definition,' he says). Shakespeare, you see, is going back to art, not coming to it afresh. Born in Germany, arriving here at the age of five, he spent some time in the Seventies, before Oxford, as a conceptual artist. 'Nailing down pianos, that kind of thing. And politically, yes, I was on the Left.'

What happened?

'I went to America. I was there for ten years, most of the Eighties, teaching in Los Angeles. And when I came back I couldn't believe anything Labour said. Specifically, in the schools.'

Working in a Lambeth school, where 70 per cent of the pupils were black, he says he was shocked by the gulf between what was wanted by the parents - tradition, discipline, results - and what they were getting from the 'white liberals' in charge. Especially when what they were getting was seven per cent exam success against a national average of 40 per cent. It changed his politics to Conservative, although he says his conversion was 'pragmatic, not ideological.'

Maybe not, but it was firm enough for him to stand for them in Colchester in 1997, having first changed his name to Shakespeare. He insists this was a favour to his wife, Rosamund, long connected to Stratford and wanting their children to keep the Shakespeare name. He failed, and looked around for another seat, but now admits it's 'less likely' he'll try again.

As for the Archer book he says his aim 'is to show that when you see all of Jeffrey it's impossible not to admire him'.

'No it's not.'

'But there is a complete absence of malice. You don't find people who have been hurt by him. And, look, if you attached all the stuff he's been accused of to someone else, it would be seen as minor; it's just that Jeff's so flamboyant, so vigorous, people resent him. He lives his life at a... creative level. And, as I say, not good with precision. With figures, say.'

What about imprecision with facts?

'Well, yes. But trivial ones.'

Anglia? 'He shouldn't have dealt in Anglia shares. But he was not guilty of insider trading.' Monica? 'It was a stupid thing to do. Jeffrey's very easy to set up.' Did he ever wonder, in his darker moments, whether Archer had, in fact, slept with Monica? 'No. It's just not Jeffrey.'

The evangelising continues, his soft voice rising. 'He's a risk-taker, an achiever. Jeffrey is - always was - a deeply anti-Establishment figure. But, yes, of course, that's the double-edged thing; he's also always wanted to be accepted by the Establishment, and yet he's never really been accepted, so he's tried even harder. It's his lower-middle-class upbringing; you either fight the Establishment, or try to join it.'

Risk-taker, achiever - I agree, but point out that he was also deputy chairman of the Tory Party; the risks he was taking were with the country; the achievements were for the rich.

These days Archer's enemies are not necessarily on the Left, and the sense of betrayal by the Tory party seems to run deep. 'I think they used the situation to try to score some pretty trivial points. Lies were told to do him further damage.'

In Archer's absence, and with the continuing rancour against Steven Norris and the Tories, who did Shakespeare (and, by extension, Archer) think would make the best mayor for London?

'...' The silence stretches to breaking point, and he begins to smile.

'Go on,' I urge. 'Say Ken.'

'You know I can't answer that. You know I can't say...' He grins, purses his lips and reverts to spokesman mode. 'Steven Norris would be the best mayor of London.' His eyes twinkle.

He's not a bad man, Stephan. No more than Archer is an evil one. But it's hard to feel sorry for either of them for being 'betrayed' by the Tory party. Right, boys; you and the other 55 million.

Also, he tells me that Archer's writing another novel.

He was chief-of-staff, bottle-washer and spokesman during the mayoral campaign and right through its explosive collapse after one-time Archer admirer Ted Francis admitted lying in court for him; right through those happy November days when, as it were, the fan hit the shit and vice versa. Last week he began running Archer's Mayfair gallery for him - it's now called Shakespeare Fine Art - and speed-writing a book on the mayoral affair, with Archer's blessing, which promises to settle some vicious scores against Right, Left and press alike (its working title is Theatre of Cruelty ). This is a man who, as he took Archer's flak and defended the indefensible, actually believed what he was saying . Most of it, anyway. His loyalty is unquestionable; his fervour evangelistic. I'm meeting him near his Barbican flat, and he keeps swinging the conversation back to Archer. 'I do admire the man. I like him and I admire him.' But he admits there's a relief in moving from politics to the (relative) cleanliness of the art world. 'The best thing is dealing with artists rather than politicians. It's more honest. You can say what you like. You can be direct if you want to.' He was direct enough, on his first day last week, to the staff of the Bruton Street gallery about his plans to revamp it; to have a 'shop-front' approach, to pull in punters and encourage new pop art. Three handed in their resignations immediately. He shrugs. It's no problem. He talks with love and vigour about post-Duchampian art; about Archer's Warhols and Harings, about the plans to showcase the radically left-wing Derek Boshier ('there is almost no right-of centre art, by definition,' he says). Shakespeare, you see, is going back to art, not coming to it afresh. Born in Germany, arriving here at the age of five, he spent some time in the Seventies, before Oxford, as a conceptual artist. 'Nailing down pianos, that kind of thing. And politically, yes, I was on the Left.' What happened? 'I went to America. I was there for ten years, most of the Eighties, teaching in Los Angeles. And when I came back I couldn't believe anything Labour said. Specifically, in the schools.' Working in a Lambeth school, where 70 per cent of the pupils were black, he says he was shocked by the gulf between what was wanted by the parents - tradition, discipline, results - and what they were getting from the 'white liberals' in charge. Especially when what they were getting was seven per cent exam success against a national average of 40 per cent. It changed his politics to Conservative, although he says his conversion was 'pragmatic, not ideological.' Maybe not, but it was firm enough for him to stand for them in Colchester in 1997, having first changed his name to Shakespeare. He insists this was a favour to his wife, Rosamund, long connected to Stratford and wanting their children to keep the Shakespeare name. He failed, and looked around for another seat, but now admits it's 'less likely' he'll try again. As for the Archer book he says his aim 'is to show that when you see all of Jeffrey it's impossible not to admire him'. 'No it's not.' 'But there is a complete absence of malice. You don't find people who have been hurt by him. And, look, if you attached all the stuff he's been accused of to someone else, it would be seen as minor; it's just that Jeff's so flamboyant, so vigorous, people resent him. He lives his life at a... creative level. And, as I say, not good with precision. With figures, say.' What about imprecision with facts? 'Well, yes. But trivial ones.' Anglia? 'He shouldn't have dealt in Anglia shares. But he was not guilty of insider trading.' Monica? 'It was a stupid thing to do. Jeffrey's very easy to set up.' Did he ever wonder, in his darker moments, whether Archer had, in fact, slept with Monica? 'No. It's just not Jeffrey.' The evangelising continues, his soft voice rising. 'He's a risk-taker, an achiever. Jeffrey is - always was - a deeply anti-Establishment figure. But, yes, of course, that's the double-edged thing; he's also always wanted to be accepted by the Establishment, and yet he's never really been accepted, so he's tried even harder. It's his lower-middle-class upbringing; you either fight the Establishment, or try to join it.' Risk-taker, achiever - I agree, but point out that he was also deputy chairman of the Tory Party; the risks he was taking were with the country; the achievements were for the rich. These days Archer's enemies are not necessarily on the Left, and the sense of betrayal by the Tory party seems to run deep. 'I think they used the situation to try to score some pretty trivial points. Lies were told to do him further damage.' In Archer's absence, and with the continuing rancour against Steven Norris and the Tories, who did Shakespeare (and, by extension, Archer) think would make the best mayor for London? '...' The silence stretches to breaking point, and he begins to smile. 'Go on,' I urge. 'Say Ken.' 'You know I can't answer that. You know I can't say...' He grins, purses his lips and reverts to spokesman mode. 'Steven Norris would be the best mayor of London.' His eyes twinkle. He's not a bad man, Stephan. No more than Archer is an evil one. But it's hard to feel sorry for either of them for being 'betrayed' by the Tory party. Right, boys; you and the other 55 million. Also, he tells me that Archer's writing another novel.

fields.headline: Strike looms at British Museum
fields.standfirst: The dented image of a great institution takes another battering as curators face the chop in a cash crisis crisis
fields.trailText: The dented image of a great institution takes another battering as curators face the chop in a cash crisis crisis
fields.body:
Sick of being criticised about the tussle with Greece over the Elgin Marbles, the British Museum tried to wipe the slate clean on Friday morning. It invited the world to watch as it handed over a stolen sculpture to its rightful owners in Egypt.

But the public-relations operation, complete with jolly handshakes with the Egyptian Ambassador, belies the turmoil going on behind closed doors at the museum.

Staff and management will meet with the Advisory, Arbitration and Conciliation Service tomorrow in an attempt to avert industial action. Positions on both sides are entrenched and the threat of a strike is growing daily.

Curators in every department of the museum face compulsory redundancy in the next two months. Elderly researchers and support staff will suffer most. A number of senior employees who expected to work until they were 65 have now been dismissed at 60 and the term of notice offered is at least three months shorter than the civil service standard they believe to be their right.

The row threatens to dull enthusiasm surrounding the major building development on the site, just as strike action at the new British Library marred its move to King's Cross.

Museum curators were incensed last week by news of a private deal offered to a handful of experienced staff. Four have been sacked, yet told that if they agree never to talk about the arrangement they can continue to use the museum's research facilities, much as if they were still employees. The deal, apparently appealing to their academic and professional pride, is part of a museum-wide scramble to find the money to staff the prestigious £100 million 'great court' development, designed by Norman Foster and due to open this year.

'Some of the older staff will be badly financially inconvenienced by these redundancy deals. They have made all sorts of calculations on the understanding that they would be working until they were 65,' said Alan Leighton of the First Division Association, the union which represents the curatorial staff.

The redundancy notices went out just before Christmas. Since then the three unions with membership inside the museum have been trying to improve the terms.

'There haven't been redundancies on this scale before, so the museum has never breached procedures before,' said Janice Collins, the union officer for the administrative staff. 'We haven't heard the management argument yet, but members over 60 should have been entitled to a period of notice as long as a year. I only hope the museum sees sense tomorrow.'

The dispute centres on the museum's failure to follow established civil service practice, but it is part of a general picture of disintegrating morale inside the Bloomsbury institution.

Last spring one of the younger managers, Suzanna Taverne, was appointed to work alongside the academic director, Robert Anderson. Many curators believe the partnership is proving a disaster.

'The museum is a double-headed monster now,' said one. 'The trustees have only kept on Anderson to show they are not being bullied by the Government, but there is no clear chain of command. Every department had to find a 10 per cent budget cut and they have generally chosen the weakest employees.'

Taverne argues this is not true. She and her department heads have had to target support staff who worked in roles which did not directly benefit the public,' she said. 'I understand why people are upset because the great court is something of an invisible project at the moment, apart from the inconvenience the work is causing. When it is open it will be a great benefit to all of us.'

Taverne insists that redeployment of redundant staff is going well, but she admits that the issue of standard civil service practice for redundacies is 'an extremely murky question'. She believes civil service procedure is 'inappropriate' for the kind of modern organisation the museum should become.

One curator said: 'We have not been told what we should stop doing in order to reorganise. Everyone is just being asked to work harder so the museum is not publicly embarrassed. Why didn't the trustees plan ahead?'

In fact, there is very little resentment of Taverne herself. Staff tend to feel she has inherited a financial mess and they blame the museum's board of trustees for setting up a series of big building projects without fundraising for endowments. The trustees, in turn, blame a lack of government funding. Graham C. Greene, chairman of the trustees, said: 'We have more going on here at the moment than at any time since the 1820s and, yes, changes have to be made to fund that.'

One union member said: 'Nobody wants to strike. We all want the museum to succeed, but it cannot be allowed to treat long-serving staff in this way just because of mismanagement in the past.'
