fields.headline: Robinson faces fraud inquiry
fields.standfirst: Former Minister comes under mounting pressure over the £170 million collapse of his engineering company
fields.trailText: Former Paymaster General Geoffrey Robinson came under mounting pressure this weekend as the Serious Fraud Office prepared to mount its own inquiry into the collapse of TransTec, his Midlands engineering company.
fields.body:
Former Paymaster General Geoffrey Robinson came under mounting pressure this weekend as the Serious Fraud Office prepared to mount its own inquiry into the collapse of TransTec, his Midlands engineering company.

Last Thursday the Department of Trade and Industry launched a formal inquiry into the events preceding the collapse. According to Whitehall sources, Industry Secretary Stephen Byers sent in DTI inspectors to avoid Tory charges of a Labour whitewash of the affair.

The former Paymaster-General, one of Labour's biggest bankrollers, resigned following revelations about a personal loan to Peter Mandelson.

Robinson is coming under increasing pressure to reveal how much he knew of the negotiations that Transtec held with Ford, the car makers, lasting more than a year, over problems in fulfilling a contract. The difficulties led to a £10.9m legal claim by Ford against TransTec, which was not reported in the company's accounts. Its eventual discovery led to the collapse of the company just before Christmas.

Those accounts were signed off by Robinson, then non-executive chairman of TransTec, two days after Ford submitted its claim on April 23. A week later, he quit TransTec to become Paymaster-General.

Robinson has insisted he was not informed of the claim being negotiated by his chief executive, Richard Carr. In a letter to the Financial Times this month he claimed he had no contact with anyone at Ford or TransTec about the issue.

Referring to the SFO moves, one Whitehall source said: 'There were discussions between the two offices beforehand. We have been co-operating closely with the SFO. The appointment of inspectors will not impede anything the SFO wants to do.'

Byers has taken the unusual step of appointing two DTI inspectors in the hope that the facts will be quickly established.

A separate DTI inquiry into the collapse of the Maxwell empire has lumbered on for years.

TransTec went into receivership last month with debts of £170 million, following the discovery of the £10.9m claim from Ford, which was hidden from bankers and shareholders for more than two years.

The claim was finally admitted to investigating accountants by TransTec's former chief executive and finance director shortly before Christmas. Both have since resigned and have declined to comment.

Robinson, however, has denied all knowledge of the compensation claim by Ford and the subsequent accounting cover-up. He has admitted he knew there were produc tion problems at TransTec's Northern Ireland plant which involved the supply of cylinder heads.

The former Minister founded TransTec in 1991 following a controversial deal with disgraced publisher Robert Maxwell, but resigned from the board in May 1997 on taking up his Treasury position. He was, however, still chairman when the problems with Ford first arose in 1996. He was also still in the job when Ford submitted its com pensation claim on 23 April, 1997, two days before he and chief executive Richard Carr signed off the 1996 accounts. He had left, however, by the time Carr agreed the compensation arrangement with Ford in the autumn of 1997.

Robinson resigned from the Government a year ago in the furore over a secret home loan to Byers's predecessor, Peter Mandelson. At the time the DTI was investigating Robinson's involvement with another former Maxwell company, over which he was cleared just days before TransTec's collapse.

Robinson has declined to talk to The Observer about the TransTec affair. But in a letter to the Financial Times earlier this month he denied any knowledge of the £11m liability. 'I was not informed of the submission by Ford of the claim against TransTec,' he wrote. 'The allegations that have been made about my role are totally unfounded.'

TransTec's receivers are currently selling off parts of the firm. They are understood to be focusing on how the chief executive and finance director concealed the claim from the auditors and the rest of the board.

Byers has appointed two inspectors to expedite the inquiry and believes it could take as little as six months. The issue will turn on who knows what, and whether the accounting treatment truly reflected the commercial arrangement with Ford.

Robinson was a close friend and supporter of Gordon Brown at the time of the revelations about his loan to Mandelson, then Minister without Portfolio. The leaking of the details of the loan remain a mystery.

fields.headline: Shock therapy patients to sue
fields.standfirst: Psychiatrists set to mount defence of ECT
fields.trailText: Banned in several countries, and severely restricted in many others, in Britain ECT is used around 50,000 times a year: up to 400 volts of electricity pumped into the brains of the mentally ill, often against their will.
fields.body:
When Jack Nicholson's character was subjected to ECT in the film One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, the images horrified a generation. Banned in several countries, and severely restricted in many others, in Britain the technique is used around 50,000 times a year: up to 400 volts of electricity pumped into the brains of the mentally ill, often against their will.

The aim - though psychiatrists admit they have no idea how it works - is to induce severe convulsions to make the mentally ill better, the depressed happier.

The result, say critics, is memory loss, brain damage, physical disability, paralysis and, too often, death. 'There's many patients whose brains are frankly fried,' said one campaigner.

This week the psychiatric profession - which is set to be hit by a wave of compensation claims by Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) 'survivors' - will robustly defend what is often seen as the indefensible, in a move that has been dismissed as a public relations stunt.

The Institute of Psychiatry, based at London's prestigious Maudsley Hospital, will stage a high-profile debate on ECT.

Pat Butterfield, founder of the pressure group ECT Anonymous, was invited to put the case against, but boycotted the event. 'I think it's a bit of a PR job. They're trying to gain a bit of credibility' said Butterfield, whose group has 600 members who say they've been harmed by ECT. 'We think it's beyond debate. There is so much evidence that it harms people. What we need is action.'

Dr Mark Salter, a consultant psychiatrist at St Bartholemew's Hospital - who has administered ECT himself - will be putting the case for the treatment. 'The emotional debate obscures the arguments in favour of ECT,' he insists. 'I am certainly in favour of ECT as a treatment of last resort. It's the one reliable treatment for severe psychotic depression, which can kill people.'

Some severe depression drives people to 'kill themselves for no particular reason,' says Salter. 'There is no doubt it is a physical disorder, and ECT cures that. ECT definitely saves lives. You should see someone when they are starving and dehydrating themselves to death. The change after a couple of ECTs is incredible. You are saving them and their families'.

Which is little comfort for Alex Doherty, a Glaswegian whose brother Joseph was one of the thousand people a year in Britain given ECT against their will. 'His nursing notes record 17 times when he resisted treatment or said he didn't want it,' said Doherty, whose younger brother had schizophrenia. 'The doctor didn't even get a second opinion. Joe was given eight or nine treatments against his will over eight weeks. He just wasn't Joe, he became hyper and permanently confused.'

Nursing notes show Joe told his 'carers' twice that if it carried on he would run away and jump off a bridge and kill himself. 'And that's exactly what he did. He was 30,' said Doherty. 'It was horrendous'.

ECT patients are given general anaesthetic and strong muscle relaxant to virtually paralyse them, and stop dangerous physical convulsions. Their skin is smeared with gel for electrical conduction, and electrodes are taped to the forehead.

The patient is then strapped on their back to a flat table, which pivots so patients can be turned upside-down if they vomit. One patient was recently given ECT on a fixed table, and when he started vomiting they couldn't remove him quick enough to prevent him choking. He ended up brain damaged and permanently paralysed.

Psychiatrists increase voltage until they get a twitching toe - a sign that, despite paralysing drugs, the body's nervous system is in major convulsion. The electrical storm raging through every synapse of the brain is meant to cure patients, although psychiatrists admit they have no idea how.

Rebecca Jason (not her real name), a literature graduate, went through ECT about 40 times. 'It was very easy for them to get me to agree to it, because I did not know what I was doing,' she recalled. 'It had a very profound effect on my ability to make decisions. I had panic attacks for ages. It affected my memory greatly - I could no longer remember books, or quote from them, which I used to be able to. There are certain things I've never been able to do since, like sew. I'm shaking all over just thinking about it.'

Butterfield claims half those given ECT are harmed by it. Solicitors are preparing two class actions for ECT survivors who want compensation, and hope to force a ruling on its legality. Butterfield wants ECT banned for those over 65 or under 18 and pregnant women - but most urgently on forcing people to have it.

Salter admits that, if people are given it against their will, psychiatrists should have to go to court to get permission. 'But for God's sake, carry on using it when it can save lives. Are we going to just let these depressed people die?'

webTitle: Stores go to war on organic sales

fields.headline: Stores go to war on organic sales
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Soaring demand for organic food among low-income shoppers has triggered a supermarket price war - and a row between retailers and farmers.
fields.body:
Soaring demand for organic food among low-income shoppers has triggered a supermarket price war - and a row between retailers and farmers.

Asda, the chain owned by cut-price American giant Wal-Mart, will cut prices on some products to the same levels as non-organic foods. The whole range will undercut rivals by up to 10 per cent.

Tesco, Waitrose and Sainsbury said this weekend they would 'wait and see' what impact the move will have on the booming organic market. Latest estimates say sales will hit £500 million this year, double the volume of three years ago.

The latest survey of shopping habits, for this week's BBC Good Food magazine, shows that 85 per cent of those who do not buy organic food are put off by prices. Despite this, sales are set to top £1 billion by 2002.

Asda said a significant shift in shopping trends has fuelled the price campaign and next month it will introduce an own-brand range. 'The typical Asda shopper did not fit the profile of organic buyers but that is changing quite considerably. Our feedback has shown demand for organic food coming through very strongly.' Farmers would get 'a fair price'.

The supermarket currently offers 150 organic lines - far fewer than Waitrose with 600 and Sainsbury and Tesco with about 500. Producers fear the new campaign will lead to growing pressure to squeeze margins. Hundreds of farmers have recently converted to organic farming to escape a collapse in prices for other products.

The Soil Association, which represents organic producers and monitors stringent growing standards, is furious - even though lower prices will attract more buyers.

'How do they expect farmers who incur more costs to produce better-quality products to manage if prices do not reflect those costs?' asked Simon Brenman, its agricultural development director and an organic farmer for 15 years.

'We saw this coming when Wal-Mart came into the picture. It is not possible to have something for nothing. Demand for organic produce is rising so why is there this downward pressure on prices? We believe Asda is misjudging this.'

A survey for the Soil Association showed 57 per cent of shoppers were put off by higher prices on organic food - but just as many said they were more influenced by range and quality.

Tesco said it would wait to see if Asda was able to maintain lower prices. 'We cut them to the same level as non-organic produce for a year but raised them again. We couldn't get the price down any further from the farmer.'

Waitrose said: 'Our prices are typically 20-30 per cent higher on organic food with some exceptions where we can source it cheaper. Demand is growing all the time and this year 12 per cent of our fruit and vegetable sales are organic compared with 7 per cent last year.'

webTitle: Heaney attacks Sinn Fein for barring Duchess

fields.headline: Heaney attacks Sinn Fein for barring Duchess
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Seamus Heaney, Ireland's Nobel laureate, has denounced moves by Sinn Fein to bar the Duchess of Abercorn from visiting a Catholic primary school in Co Tyrone on the grounds that she is a member of the British aristocracy.
fields.body:
Seamus Heaney, Ireland's Nobel laureate, has denounced moves by Sinn Fein to bar the Duchess of Abercorn from visiting a Catholic primary school in Co Tyrone on the grounds that she is a member of the British aristocracy.

Heaney is a patron of the Pushkin Prize, which Sacha Abercorn was trying to promote in St Mary's Primary school when Sinn Fein intervened to have her visit called off.

Heaney said he was 'dismayed' to read that the Duchess was forced to cancel her visit because of opposition from a local Sinn Fein councillor.

In a letter published in yesterday's Irish Times, Heaney said: ' Sacha Abercorn has been a passionate advocate of the value of creative writing in primary education, and for the past 12 years has been the inspiration of a cross-community, cross-border movement that has been its own reward, artistic and educational, for everybody.

'It is a poor look-out, not only for nationalists and Catholics, but for people of every party and every denomination, if the enlightened work done under the aegis of the Pushkin Prize can be so crudely demeaned.'

The invitation to the Duchess was cancelled following complaints by Sinn Fein councillor Finnbarr Conway, who claimed initially that local nationalists objected to her presence because she was related to the British royal family. When it was pointed out to him that she was not related, he amended his objections to stating that 'proud Irish people' did not want someone from the British aristocracy in a 'nationalist school'.

The Sinn Fein Assemblyman for Mid-Ulster, John Kelly, said he did not want to get into a controversy with Heaney, 'a poet I respect, especially because he is a son of south Derry'.

fields.headline: Cricket legend dies, aged 92
fields.trailText: Tributes poured in last night to EW Swanton, arguably the finest cricket writer of all, who has died at the age of 92.
fields.body:
Tributes poured in last night to EW Swanton, arguably the finest cricket writer of all, who has died at the age of 92.

The veteran journalist, who became a legend for his authoritative writings on sport, died yesterday at the Chaucer Hospital in Canterbury, Kent, after a short illness. It was once said that if John Arlott was the voice of cricket, then Swanton was its heart and soul.

Ex-England captain Lord (Colin) Cowdrey described Swanton as 'a supreme journalist with very strong views who always tried to do the best for the highest principles of the game'. Broadcaster Michael Parkinson said Swanton 'was not the greatest stylist, but he was the most authoritative commentator of the game'.

He was born Ernest William but was known as Jim and wrote under the byline E.W. Swanton. In a half-century career which included numerous broad casts on the BBC and 20 books, he became as well-known as many of the game's biggest names. He began writing as an 18-year-old for All Sports . He reported his first Test match in 1930 for the Evening Standard .

A copy of the 1939 edition of Wisden , the cricket bible, helped him pass the days when he was interned in a Japanese prisoner of war camp during the Second World War. He was with the Daily Telegraph from 1946 until 1975. He was awarded the OBE in 1965 and the CBE in 1994 by John Major, a big fan.

Born in London in 1907, his huge experience, and a love of the game nurtured watching Surrey as a boy, underlaid his undoubted authority.Often seen as an Establishment figure, he was one of the first cricket writers to decry the evils of apartheid and surprised Telegraph colleagues by urging England to cancel their 1970 South African tour.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Pensioner dies in wrong lane motorway crash
fields.body:
Pensioner dies in wrong lane motorway crash

A 71-year-old man died in a head-on crash after driving his car for 20 miles the wrong way down the M40 near High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire. The female driver of the other car escaped with minor injuries.

Old soldier fades away

Trooper Harry 'Darcy' Jones, thought to have been the final survivor of the Army's last-ever major cavalry charge, has died at the age of 103. He was one of 181 who charged a fortified artillery position defended by 2,000 Turks at Huj in Palestinein November 1917.

New age force

Essex police are considering turning to alternative remedies to tackle stress and depression. Officers on sick leave are to be offered 'stress packs' which could contain advice and vouchers for aromatherapy, acupuncture and counselling.

Ecuador handover

Deposed Ecuadorean President Jamil Mahuad gave his support to Gustavo Noboa after the former vice-president assumed the country's leadership.

Rage murder

Liberian President Charles Taylor's brother-in-law faces death by hanging or life in prison after being convicted of a road rage murder.

Hunt clash

A saboteur was arrested in a clash with a hunt members near Maldon, Essex.

Murder quiz

A French judge investigating the murder of British student Isabel Peake says there is 'sufficient' evidence to prosecute the main suspect, Sid Ahmed Rezala, the 20-year-old Algerian-born drifter awaiting extradition from Lisbon. He is wanted for questioning about the deaths of Peake and two other women.

Ahern plans abortion vote

Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern has pledged to hold a referendum on changing the country's abortion laws before the end of his term in 2002. Abortions are virtually illegal, but doctors complain the laws are unclear and force women to seek terminations in the UK.

Boys feared dead in blaze

Two boys of three and five were missing, presumed dead, and their police officer father Alan Dugan, 34, was fighting for his life after trying to rescue them as a blaze gutted their home in Strathdon, 40 miles west of Aberdeen.The boys' mother Julie was pulled from the building by firefighters. The cause of the fire is not yet known.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers are 7 9 10 40 41 44, bonus 14. Thunderball numbers are 1 7 8 18 25, Thunderball 7.

webTitle: IRA reveals secrets of its victims' burial sites

fields.headline: IRA reveals secrets of its victims' burial sites
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The secret graves of some of the Disappeared may be pinpointed by answers from the IRA to a detailed questionnaire drawn up by the Irish government.
fields.body:
The secret graves of some of the Disappeared may be pinpointed by answers from the IRA to a detailed questionnaire drawn up by the Irish government. The Provos reveal exactly how the bodies were buried, in what kind of soil were they interred and even at roughly what time of day the burials took place.

The questions were passed to the IRA two months ago and, according to sources close to the Independent Commission for the Disappeared, the Provos have answered 99 per cent of them.

Seamus McKendry, spokesman for the Families of the Disappeared group, said last night that the replies were a 'significant breakthrough' in the search for the six remaining victims including his mother-in-law, Jean McConville.

The questions included:

 In what direction was the body buried - north, south, east or west?

 What kind of soil was it, and were there rocks in the soil?

 How deep was the body placed?

 Did the burial party know the area, and did they return to it?

The last question was particularly important in the case of Mrs McConville, who was abducted and murdered by the IRA in Belfast 28 years ago. The IRA told the commission she had been buried at Templetown beach near Carlingford, Co Louth. But a 50-day dig by gardai failed to locate her remains.

The IRA's answers about her have established that the burial party came from the north Louth area and would have had detailed knowledge of the beach. Digging for all six bodies is now expected to resume next month, using the answers to the questionnaire.

'I have no doubt that the Provos are telling the truth about Templetown beach,' McKendry said. 'These answers sound very detailed and very chilling. But this shows they [the IRA] are serious about locating the bodies. We are more optimistic today than for a very long time.'

McKendry defended himself against recent criticism in nationalist newspapers that his campaigning style was counterproductive.

'I think the truth is that public pressure has forced them to return to this issue. Without the campaign these bodies would never have been handed over,' he said.

The IRA has vowed to return the bodies of the eight people it has admitted murdering and secretly burying, and has delegated some of its most senior members to hold talks with the Families of the Disappeared. They include Brian Keenan of the Provisional's Army Council, Padraig Wilson, the former leader of the IRA in the Maze prison, and Bobby Storey, who is a close ally of Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams.

A meeting between the commission and the families will take place next month. So far only three of the Disappeared have been located: John McClory, Brian McKinney and Eamon Molloy, all from Belfast.

fields.headline: Nuclear power stations 'unsafe'
fields.trailText: Britain's nuclear power stations are being run unsafely and the company operating them has been told to make radical changes or lose its Government licence.
fields.body:
Britain's nuclear power stations are being run unsafely and the company operating them has been told to make radical changes or lose its Government licence.

A damning report by Government safety inspectors warns that management failures and severe job cuts have jeopardised key operations and could lead to a catastrope.

The report by the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate is highly critical of British Energy, the privatised company that now runs most of Britain's nuclear power stations. The inspectors say the firm cut the number of expert staff before working out the jobs and skills needed to operate safely. The report, marked 'restricted' but obtained by the Observer, states: 'Our judgment is that in key safety areas... staff levels are at, and in a limited number of areas, below that required to sustain the work load and discharge the requirements of licencees.' It attacks British Energy's headlong rush to replace staff by outside contractors which it believes could 'erode' its ability to remain in control.

The watchdog offers 103 recommendations which highlight concerns over crucial operations. The NII's report will be a huge blow for British Energy directors who criticised earlier drafts. British Energy has now been forced to accept all of the report's recommendations.

Dr Helen Wallace, head of Greenpeace's nuclear campaign, said: 'This is a shocking indictment of the state of the British Nuclear industry. They are gambling with people's lives. We need an urgent review of how to phase out nuclear power in Britain.'

Since its privatisation British Energy which runs nine nuclear stations has made nearly 1,800 job cuts, and seen profits rise from £61 million to £298 million. The NII has demanded an immediate halt to staff cuts, but British Energy is planning further reductions.

A British Energy spokesman said the company had accepted the NII recommendations and was working on a plan to implement them before the end of January deadline.

webTitle: Hundreds of crippled jets put RAF in crisis

fields.headline: Hundreds of crippled jets put RAF in crisis
fields.trailText: The Royal Air Force is facing a frontline 'crisis' with hundreds of jets unable to fly, a shortage of crack fighter pilots and millions of pounds wasted on technology that does not work.
fields.body:
The Royal Air Force is facing a frontline 'crisis' with hundreds of jets unable to fly, a shortage of crack fighter pilots and millions of pounds wasted on technology that does not work. In what insiders say is a chronic problem facing Britain's air defences and strike attack force, an Observer investigation has discovered that:

 Two out of three of the UK's 186 fleet of Tornado bombers are grounded;

 Fewer than 40 per cent of other frontline aircraft, such as Harriers and Jaguars, are ready to fly at short notice;

 The Ministry of Defence has spent almost £1 billion developing a laser-guided bombing system that does not work properly;

 There is shortage of nearly 20 per cent of junior officer fast jet pilots and the RAF is having a severe problem in retaining trained pilots:

Senior RAF insiders described the situation in some areas as 'chronic' and morale in the force as 'very low'. They complain of an overstretched and underfunded air force, which is having problems getting enough aircraft airborne to ensure pilots are properly trained. They fear the RAF would have significant difficulties coping with a serious emergency or future military operations.

These latest revelations ocome a month after MoD figures showed that a third of the Army's newest tanks and more than half of its older models are not fully operational. They also follow leaked reports showing British forces were severely hampered by equipment failures in Kosovo.

MoD figures given to the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, reveal that only 53 out of the country's 186 Tornado GR1/4 bombers are ready to fly immediately, In June 1998the comparable figure was 81. The majority of other frontline jets are also grounded. Only 34 out of 90 Harriers are fully serviceable, 28 out of 76 Jaguars and 59 out of 112 Tornado F3 fighter aircraft. The majority of the RAF's helicopters are in a similar situation: only 55 out of 119 are fully operational.

While MoD secrecy makes it impossible to find the exact state of repair of the air force, one senior RAF insider said the snapshot given by the MoD painted a 'rosy picture' and the real situation was actually much worse. He said: 'The numbers given by the Government were taken at 8am; by the afternoon some squadrons would be lucky to have one plane airborne.'

Campbell, who will table questions for Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon tomorrow in Parliament, said: 'These figures are disturbing... there does seem to be a fundamental and underlying problem that needs answering.'

The alarming state of affairs within the RAF questions the role Tony Blair sees for Britain's military as being a rapid reaction force leading Europe and UN peacekeeping missions around the globe.

Tory defence spokesman Robert Key said: 'The Government has been talking big with empty wallets.The RAF simply cannot meet its growing commitments with its budgets being cut.' Since the 1991 Gulf war the RAF has lost about half of its squadrons.

According to senior RAF sources, the most scandalous issue revolves around the 'disastrous' Tornado upgrade programme run by British Aerospace - now called BAE Systems.

This was supposed to ensure that RAF bombers would have up-to-date weapon systems to ensure they could fulfil the rapid reaction role demanded of it after the Cold War.

Yet several years after the upgrade started and after a £1bn of public money has been spent, the system allowing the Tornados to use laser-guided missiles does not work.

One RAF insider close to the upgrade said: 'It is an astonishing and scandalous waste of taxpayers' money. On some of the planes it actually seems to perform worse than when the upgrade first started.'

The upgrade has been a hugely divisive issue within the RAF with many arguing it should have been carried out internally.

A similar upgrade on the Jaguar which was done by the RAF itself was highly successful, underbudget and on time. It cost less than £1m per aircraft. So far the Tornado upgrade is hundreds of millions over budget and will cost more than £6m per aircraft.

Another senior air force source told The Observer that the RAF training sytem is close to collapse. Out of the 554 junior officer fast jet pilots required, only 459 posts have been filled. With many trained pilots frustrated at the lack of time spent in the air, many are leaving to join civil airlines.

The MoD angrily refuted claims that the RAF's frontline was in crisis and said that while many aircraft were being serviced or upgraded they could be made available quickly in the event of a major crisis.

The upgrade has been a hugely divisive issue within the RAF with many arguing it should have been carried out internally. A similar upgrade on the Jaguar which was done by the RAF itself was highly successful, underbudget and on time. It cost less than £1m per aircraft. So far the Tornado upgrade is hundreds of millions over budget and will cost more than £6m per aircraft. Another senior air force source told The Observer that the RAF training sytem is close to collapse. Out of the 554 junior officer fast jet pilots required, only 459 posts have been filled. With many trained pilots frustrated at the lack of time spent in the air, many are leaving to join civil airlines. The MoD angrily refuted claims that the RAF's frontline was in crisis and said that while many aircraft were being serviced or upgraded they could be made available quickly in the event of a major crisis.

webTitle: How can I stop dreaming about my boss?

fields.headline: How can I stop dreaming about my boss?
fields.standfirst:
I've started dreaming about my boss. The dreams are vivid and filled with emotional longing and sexual desire, although I have never felt anything like this towards him in real life. In fact, a lot of the time he drives me mad. He is elusive and a complete control freak. Recently, though, the dreams have become so powerful and disturbing they are starting to affect my relationship with my husband. They stay in my head all day and I feel as though I'm keeping a secret from him. Is it possible to be unfaithful in your dreamlife? And would it help if I told my husband what's been going on?
I.R. of Newcastle Upon Tyne
fields.trailText: Moral muse
fields.body:
Love has mysterious ways of ambushing us. It can creep up under camouflage or come in a variety of disguises. One particularly perplexing ploy is to transform itself from violent hate; a person who stirs up such a powerful emotion is never going to be a source of indifference. You are falling in love with your boss, a potential catastrophe.

We like to get superstitious about dreams and imagine they are messages received via the supernatural world. Freudians talk about wish-fulfilment. Actually they come from the soup that is our recent half-digested life-experience, composed of stresses, worries and visual images. Have you ever been wakened just as you were sliding through that ante-room to deep sleep where dreams are spun together? It's a wild experience, noisy and tumultuous, like a circus, and totally devoid of morals.

I'm always amazed that part of sanity-maintenance requires us to run this gauntlet before achieving complete relaxation, and traverse it again before waking. However, most of what we experience there does not figure in our memories. I'm sure your boss features largely in this private closet, and usually you deal with him and keep him in his place. But something has caused him to bob up to the surface of your conscious level, since when he has become unsettling. You could, with a bit of determination, cause him to re-submerge, but the sexual excitement has you in thrall.

The relationship between a male boss and a female underling is full of sexual innuendo. However well-behaved he is, subliminal messages flash back and forth. I have little doubt that if you are totally ensnared you could have an affair with him. But if you are not quite in free-fall, it might be prudent to weigh the consequences; the damage to your marriage, the threat to your job and reputation. Try an experiment. Imagine him at his most undignified; put your boss in context and preserve your peaceful existence.

Readers' responses

I experienced a similar situation. After months of confusion and distress I discovered that past lives were affecting my relationship with a colleague. I eventually examined these past events with a crystal healer, with great success. A healer or past life therapist may be able to help you. P. Krystal's Cutting the Ties That Bind may also be useful.
R.Hillman

It is commonplace to have vivid sexual dreams about people to whom, in daytime reality, one has no sexual feelings. Ideally, you could work through this imagery in a dreamwork group or with a psychotherapist. There is a Newcastle-based creative psychotherapist who works primarily with imagery sequences who could help. Alternatively you can go some way yourself through objectivising your imagery through making a picture or by dancing/movement of some kind.

If you are clear about your feelings there is no reason not to tell your husband. There is a good book on sexuality and dreaming by Patricia Garfield, or Robert Moss's Conscious Dreaming (Crown Trade, 1996).

Dr. Iain R. Edgar author of Dreamwork, Anthropology and the Caring Professions: A Cultural Approach to Dreamwork, Avebury

Next week's dilemma is from KR of Cambridge

Three years ago my fiancé had a car crash. He was left with slight brain damage - his speech is slow and he is no longer the intelligent, quick-witted man that he once was. The accident happened just under a year before our wedding and we continued with our plans and got married.

Now, however, I am wondering if I have made a terrible mistake. The damage to his brain has changed his personality. He is moody, unpredictable and his career in marketing has been destroyed. He now works in a boring job with no prospects. I want to leave him but my sense of loyalty and my marriage commitment holds me back. I am still young and feel I cannot live the rest of my life with my husband. How do I leave without destroying him?

 Write to The Observer Review at the usual address or e-mail kim.bunce@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday.

Margaret Cook writes a column for Woman's Journa l .

fields.headline: Why is my child different?
fields.standfirst: Dyspraxia had scarcely been heard of 10 years ago. Now every classroom in the country has at least one child suffering from this syndrome, as  Kate Kellaway  discovered
fields.trailText: Dyspraxia had scarcely been heard of 10 years ago. Now every classroom in the country has at least one child suffering from this syndrome
fields.body:
Dyspraxia. Try saying it. It is like speaking with your mouth full, or eating an egg with the shell still on it. The word is clumsy - like the condition it describes. Twenty years ago, there was no name for it. Ten years ago, it was still hardly known. It is only in the last year or two that it has become, as one mother of a dyspraxic child puts it, a 'popular' disorder. According to her: 'Dyspraxia is sprouting like broccoli...' Parents are rushing to diagnose (and misdiagnose) their children. Every classroom is likely to contain at least one child who suffers from it. Some experts claim that 10 per cent of the population is dyspraxic.

It has been known by other names: minimal brain dysfunction; clumsy child syndrome; non-verbal learning disorder; deficits with attention, motor skills and perception (DAMP for short). These discouraging labels have all given way to developmental dyspraxia from the Greek for abnormal and doing. But what exactly is it? The more I heard (from parents at my son's school) the more muddled I felt. It sounded like a holdall into which all kinds of problems could be thrust. Was it exclusively physiological? Or psychological too? A first cousin to dyslexia or unrelated? Was it a scientific diagnosis for a clumsy child? Or a sop to parents whose children were not high achievers? And might I - excuse me while I sweep up that glass I've just dropped - be suffering from it myself? Does dyspraxia exist at all?

Madeleine Portwood is author of Developmental Dyspraxia, an educational psychologist and chair of the Dyspraxia Foundation's education committee. She explained that dyspraxia is thought to be a neurological condition, the result of an immaturity in neurone development. 'Dyspraxia results when messages are not transmitted properly in parts of the brain.'

Dyspraxic symptoms are usually evident within the first 12 months of a baby's life. Dyspraxic children do not reach their developmental milestones at the right time. As babies, they seldom crawl and walking is often seriously delayed (beyond 18 months). Dyspraxic children might suffer from some or all of the following: poor co-ordination, clumsiness, disorganisation, speech difficulties. According to Portwood, about 50 per cent of children suffering from dyspraxia can't co-ordinate lips, tongue and soft palate to produce the necessary sounds. It's not a problem with understanding, it is a problem with the production of language.

Dyspraxic children may also have illegible handwriting, a short concentration span, an inability to follow instructions, a heightened sensitivity to noise. They may be fitful sleepers and prone to temper tantrums. They may avoid construction toys and puzzles, be slow to be toilet-trained and unable to pedal a bike. They may be messy eaters and find dressing difficult. A dyspraxic child might spend so long struggling into his PE kit that he missed PE altogether. And he would not be sorry to miss it: Sport is almost always a problem for dyspraxic children. They can be hyperactive yet physically inefficient - a floundering combination of fast and slow. And they suffer - eventually and inevitably - from low self-esteem.

But take care! Madeleine Portwood warns that trying to diagnose dyspraxia by ticking off points from a checklist of symptoms is a bad idea. This is partly, I suspect, because we all resemble the character in Jerome K. Jerome's Three Men in a Boat who reads a medical textbook and decides that the only thing he is not suffering from is 'Housemaid's Knee'. We tend to recognise ourselves and our children in lists of symptoms.

But there is a more serious reason to proceed gingerly. Portwood points out that there is a considerable overlap between four developmental disorders. They are: dyslexia, dyspraxia, hyperactivity and autistic spectrum disorder. It is easy to be fooled by 'masking symptoms'.

Portwood says: 'We do children a huge disservice by identifying one disorder and failing to see another.' Dyspraxia can only be accurately diagnosed by neurologists or by clinical psychologists, not by teachers or worried parents. Dyspraxia does not start as an emotional disorder but can easily turn into one. Children with dyspraxia are usually isolated at school. Portwood says that much distress can be be avoided if the dyspraxia is diagnosed early enough (preferably by the time the child is eight). It is a condition that will not get better on its own (nor will it get worse). Many sufferers find ways of masking the condition or circumventing it as they get older.

I spoke to Alice Woodeson whose son had behaviour problems from the age of three. He was always having 'horrendous' accidents and was diagnosed as dyspraxic (80 per cent of dyspraxia sufferers are boys). Alice recalls the nightmare of taking him to see one expert after another to get her child's condition officially recognised: 'I was an absolute mess. I couldn't sleep. I'd sit up at night wondering how best to wangle my way through the authorities, to convince them that my son was not a performing monkey.' The dyspraxia diagnosis initially came as a relief. 'A parent wants a label to justify their child's behaviour.'

But the child also needs sympathetic teachers. Schools are becoming increasingly conscious of dyspraxia. But many schools are unable to rise to the challenge posed by children with special needs. Alice Woodeson explains: 'Once behavioural problems kick in, you can forget the real problems. All I ever heard from teachers was everything Jamie could not do. It all got so negative.' She battled on, overcoming problems with Jamie which she manages to turn into black comedy in the telling.

'Dyspraxic children hate having their heads touched. There were outbreaks of nits at Jamie's school and I used to have to take a torch and a nit comb into his bed while he was asleep. Or else I'd turn it into a game, putting nit-repellent stuff on his head and wrapping it up in Bacofoil. I'd do the same to my head and we would pretend to be aliens together.

Meanwhile, she was fighting to make sure that he would not be treated like an alien. She painted a 'big lazy eight' on the bathroom wall so that he could stick his hand out and trace it (dyspraxic children have problems with crossing from the right to left sides of the brain. Many of their perceptual problems seem to be caused by a malfunctioning in the right hemisphere of the brain).

Alice is chary now of saying her child is dyspraxic or of labelling him at all. She says: 'Every specialist has a different view depending on where their forte lies. It's a labyrinth. You investigate, you lose faith. And meanwhile your child is starting to fail badly.'

There is nothing imaginary about Jamie's problems. But is there, I asked Madeleine Portwood, a danger that parents will be too hasty to label children who are in fact merely unconventional? To her credit (and my surprise) Portwood says: 'Children today are encouraged to fit into a norm. Long gone are the days when children were allowed to be eccentric, gifted... Now they are often wrongly labelled. I am very concerned about young children being put under the microscope...'

So it is a delicate business. Diagnosis and misdiagnosis can cause more problems than they solve. And yet children correctly diagnosed with dyspraxia can be helped. Madeleine Portwood has pioneered a scheme for schools involving 20 minutes of physiotherapy a day to help with gross motor skills. Dyspraxic children also need to improve their spacial awareness, often with work involving a sense of direction. This is necessary before a child can progress with fine motor skills - and put pen to paper.

Children can improve dramatically. Exercises can reinforce neuro pathways in the brain, help with organisational skills, behaviour and even IQ levels. Marcia Richmond has a nine-year-old daughter who was diagnosed dyspraxic three years ago. Marcia remembers going to a specialist bookshop to find out more. No one had heard of it. There were no books about it. Now dyspraxic literature is booming.

Marcia Richmond feels her daughter has been helped by physiotherapy and perceptual training. But she is under no illusions: it is a long slog. The frustration of having a dyspraxic child is being able to 'see that there is a lot going on in your child's head that she cannot put in the right order'. The hardest thing for parents of dyspraxic children, she thinks, is to be 'patient and understanding' and yet 'demanding'. The most important thing is 'to show them they can do it. And not to give up yourself.'

Is dyspraxia a modern condition? Portwood says that while it would always have existed, it is much more widespread now. There are social reasons for this. Dyspraxia often affects children who were born prematurely (they would not have survived in the Victorian age). Dyspraxia hardly exists in Scandinavia (the incidence is less than one per cent). Portwood believes that this is because children do not start school until they are six or seven and are more involved in physical activity than children in this country. In British culture children 'spend hours in front of a computer instead of climbing' and this does nothing for their motor skills.

Many children are relieved to be described as dyspraxic because they feel they need no longer be branded clumsy or stupid. But this would not reassure Hugh Goodwin. His son reached the developmental milestones late. If Goodwin worries about anything, it is about labelling children. 'Labels damage as much as help. They introduce the divisive idea of healthy and unhealthy, well made and badly made children. These judgments deny our humanity. Everyone is a human being, rather than a successful human machine.'

Some of the names in this piece have been changed. Developmental Dyspraxia: Identification and Intervention by Madeleine Portwood; Dyspraxia: A Guide for Teachers and Parents by Kate Ripley, Bob Daines and Jenny Barrett; Dyspraxia in the Early Years by Christine Macintyre. All published by David Fulton (020-7405-5606). Dyspraxia Foundation helpline 01462 454986. Or visit their website at www.emmbrook.demon.co.uk/dysprax/homepage.htm

fields.headline: Every move you make...
fields.standfirst: Stalking is the crime of our age. But what makes one person obsessively pursue another?  Andrew Smith investigates the dark side of the information society:  'The policeman stalked her. Then the photographer stalked her. Now I am stalking her...'
fields.trailText: You can hear Tracey Morgan's distress in the patterns of her speech. Most of the time, there is a cowed, almost apologetic tone of resignation in her voice. Sometimes this gives way to accelerating anger, which she reins in quickly, no longer able to trust that the listener won't be alarmed by it. She was called Tracey Sant before she separated from the husband that her stalker, Anthony Burstow, plotted to kill. And she made headlines when she successfully prosecuted Burstow for causing her grievous bodily harm, despite the fact that there was no direct physical assault. Now he is free, having served only half of a three-year prison term. He recently changed his name by deed poll to that of her ex-boyfriend so as to dodge a restraining order and was discovered to have been keeping a diary of her movements since three weeks after his release. He has been plaguing her for seven years.

She was called Tracey Sant before she separated from the husband that her stalker, Anthony Burstow, plotted to kill. And she made headlines when she successfully prosecuted Burstow for causing her grievous bodily harm, despite the fact that there was no direct physical assault. Now he is free, having served only half of a three-year prison term. He recently changed his name by deed poll to that of her ex-boyfriend so as to dodge a restraining order and was discovered to have been keeping a diary of her movements since three weeks after his release. He has been plaguing her for seven years.

'All the while he's free, I'm under sentence, because I have to keep looking over my shoulder,' she says flatly. 'In the end, you will them to do something, just to prove you're not paranoid.'

Stalking is the crime of our times. Barely a day goes by without newspapers carrying lurid stories of people haunted by crazed individuals. Last week, it was Zoë Ball, Barbra Streisand and Lynda Bellingham. This week it will be someone else. There is a joke in Hollywood that 'you're no one until you've got your own stalker', and, accordingly, the LAPD has its own 'stalker squad', currently co-operating with Scotland Yard in its search for the killer of TV presenter Jill Dando.

The impression is that stalking is on the increase, although it might be argued that, as with rape and child abuse in years gone by, this merely reflects the increased willingness on the part of victims to go to court. What we do know is that in 1998, a year after the introduction of the Protection From Harassment Act, 2,221 were convicted of stalking. Just as alarming is the fact that detectives pursuing Dando's killer turned up 180 men who harboured unnatural fixations with her.

In the US, the situation seems clearer. The term 'stalking' is thought to have acquired its present usage after Rebecca Shaeffer, a rising actress and TV presenter, was murdered on her doorstep by an obsessive fan in 1991. By 1994, 48 US states had passed anti-stalking laws and close to 200,000 reports were investigated last year under their provisions, one fifth of which involved celebrities.

This time last year, the first case was brought to court under California's new cyberstalking law, after a man posted messages in online chat rooms, giving a young woman's address and attributing to her a violent rape fantasy which drew scores of strangers to her door. For a fee of $12, an online organisation will provide detailed information on anyone who has ever paid tax in the US. A 'stalker page' on the Internet provides a forum for enthusiasts. At a time when our casual invasion of each others' lives is becoming accepted as inevitable, the fascination with this uniquely invasive crime contains many ironies, but few surprises. It is the perfect crime for the twenty-first century.

There is nothing new about the range of psychologies behind stalking, however. If you travel to meet Liz Hodgkinson at her immaculate house in west London, you find a smart, articulate woman with two grown-up sons and a successful writing career. Ten years ago, she wrote a book about the desperate obsession she developed with another student during her first year at college in the early 1960s, and whom she took to stalking. Only in the past year, she will tell you, has she freed herself from its grip.

Leaning forward in a pastel pink armchair, Hodgkinson describes her first sight of John as if it were a car crash. He was older and more worldly and extremely good-looking, with long, floppy, 'Hugh Grant' hair (though she is amusingly quick to add that he was 'better looking - much better looking' than Grant). She started following him around everywhere, despite his lack of interest in her. She couldn't concentrate on anything else, failed her exams, became friendless and ill. This 'active phase' lasted for six months, but then 'went underground' for 20 years. During that time, she never saw him, but dreamt about him and would sometimes find herself overwhelmed by a sudden surge of emotion, thinking 'If I see that bugger again, I'll kill him'.

'That's how strong it was. I actually think it blighted my life,' she says. 'It got in the way of relationships, because I was very frightened that it would happen again. I tried my hardest not to allow myself to go out of control, because I didn't know what would happen if I did.'

Two decades on, she underwent a course of psychotherapy, at the end of which she resolved to track John down again, to resolve the issue in her own mind. She found him through an ex-wife. He had become an academic and was about to return to Singapore, where he had lived for some time. She badgered him into meeting her at the airport, now smiling as she confesses that she took along her passport, just in case. He looked old and ill. They chatted about the book she was writing, in which he would loom large. He admitted that he, too, had been marked by their original encounter, then he left. She heard nothing more of him, until last year, when she found his obituary on the Internet and the woman who had written it provided a final twist to the story.

'I think being very alone in a bleak and frightening place helped encourage the obsession. This is borne out by research into stalking. It becomes like an addiction. You know it's irrational, but you can't stop yourself. All I can say is that, even while it was happening, it felt out of character, as if some alien had taken me over.'

The nagging thought occurs that this sounds a lot like falling in love. 'The difference is that you never really feel comfortable with the person you're obsessed by,' says Hodgkinson. 'You never feel able to relax. Even when you're having the most intimate physical, sexual relationship, there's always a level of anxiety there. And I think that's why you want to control them, because you think they're going to slip away from you all the time. That's why you want to know where they are every minute of the day. If you genuinely love someone, you don't need to check up on them all the time. A psychologist has since said to me that at the moment you see the object of your obsession, your whole imagined future life passes before you. But, somewhere deep down, you know that it will never happen, which further fuels the obsession.'

The person who suffered most in Liz Hodgkinson's tale is her. Clearly, this is not always the case. The first consists of jilted lovers who refuse to accept rejection and embark on a cam paign of persuasion or revenge. This may account for roughly four-fifths of stalking cases, according to Nash.

The second type suffer from so-called De Clérambault's syndrome, or erotomania, a delusional condition in which they believe their affection to be reciprocated, despite denials. Jed Parry, the stalker in Ian McEwan's novel Enduring Love , fell into this category. So too did the motorcycle courier who was reported to be plaguing Zoë Ball last week. . Finally there is the significant minority who act out of clinical sadism and represent many of the most extreme and disturbing cases.

This pathology, according to Boon, is very difficult to 'put back in its box'. 'You can stop them doing it, but you cannot stop them wanting to do it. And they are incredibly resourceful: the range of techniques one adult might use is very wide and much more difficult to identify than with paedophiles.I promise you that with the range of techniques I am now familiar with, I could make you do anything.'

Tracey Morgan is witness to this. Typically, her problems began when she showed kindness to an isolated, depressed individual at work. Also typically, he has since transferred his isolation, inability to trust in the world and difficulty in conducting relationships of any kind to her. 'It's like walking along the edge of a cliff, not knowing if today is the day that someone's going to push you off the edge,' she explains, quietly. 'He researched my family tree, neighbours and friends, so in the end you don't have any friends, because you don't want to drag them into it, too.'

The Protection From Harassment Act has helped, she says, because victims no longer have to present evidence of physical violence in order to get injunctions and restraining orders, but, as Boon suggests, the sadistic stalker shrugs past legal impediment. Diana Lamplugh of the Lamplugh Trust which is involved in research and helping victims, considers that the law is adequate but the authorities have not yet learnt to apply it. Asked what conditions aid the creation of the sadistic stalker's personality, Boon ventures inconsistent and unpredictable parent ing as a decisive factor. 'If a father is going to come home drunk at night, let it be every night, so that the children know what to expect. The damaging thing is for your father to come home and for you to not know whether you're going to get a kiss or a kick. You come not to be able to trust relationships.

'From the research we've done, these people tend to have been raised in an environment where they have not been able to trust any relationship and, as a consequence, the only way they can have a relationship is to have one which they can have absolute certainty about. And the only way to have absolute certainty is to have absolute, unwavering control.'

A study overseen by psychology researcher Lorraine Sheridan suggests that one in five British women will be stalked at some point. The average duration of the stalking will be seven and a half years and 48 per cent will involve ex-partners, 40 per cent acquaintances, and 12 per cent antagonists who were previously unknown.

As I flicked through a thick sheaf of newspaper cuttings on the subject, I found myself again wondering whether the problem is growing, or whether we have merely been blind to its scale in the past. At that moment, a particular image caught my eye. Printed in an mid-market tabloid, it was a full-length photo of an attractive young woman walking along the pavement. She is moving away from the camera, but with her head swivelled round, as if someone has called her name - which the photographer probably has. She looks startled, a little afraid and it took time to work out that I'd seen that precise look before, in voyeuristic slasher movies, and in downmarket porn magazines. Next to her is the headline 'PC forced to quit for stalking while on duty', and an accompanying story that is disturbing, but familiar. For the first time, I saw a chain of trespasses. The PC stalked her. Then the photographer stalked her. Now I am stalking her, reading details from her life that I have no need to know.

Perhaps this is what's happening. The information revolution has merely added impetus to the rapid dismantling of the boundaries between public and private experience. When Oprah Winfrey told us we had a right to talk, that it was good to open up and confess, little did we know that this right would gradually come to be seen as an obligation. Add to this the commodification of celebrity and sex, and the idea that some poor souls might have trouble knowing where to back off and recognise the space between their own lives and other peoples' is not so very mysterious. My guess is that we had all better keep watching our backs.

webTitle: What you don't see is what you get

fields.headline: What you don't see is what you get
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera House management must be tearing out its collective hair, as yet another performance goes off the rails. Thursday's return of the Celebration of International Choreography programme started 30 minutes late and was aborted shortly before 11pm.
fields.body:
The Royal Ballet
Royal Opera House

The Royal Opera House management must be tearing out its collective hair, as yet another performance goes off the rails. Thursday's return of the Celebration of International Choreography programme started 30 minutes late and was aborted shortly before 11pm, with the last ballet, Ashley Page's Hidden Variables, still unseen. People next to me, who had paid £50 for their seats, were furious, having already endured hopeless sightlines in the supposedly improved stalls.

The botched end to the evening was all the more unfortunate because it came after a sizzling display of dancing by foreign guests and company principals. This was a far better menu of modern choreography than the pallid choice in the Royal Ballet's opening programme in December.

New to the mixed bill were Twyla Tharp's Known By Heart duet for American stars Susan Jaffe and Ethan Stiefel, and William Forsythe's quintet, The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude. The Royal Ballet's team proved that they can take on the rest of the world - an outcome in doubt earlier in the week when they mangled MacMillan's Concerto yet again. Forsythe's title summed up the central section's offerings: witty choreography for finely tuned bodies, pushed to their limits, can deliver a collective high. You scarcely dare breathe as your heart races to match the dancers' daring.

Then came the let-down: the interval dragged on and on, and no announcement was made. The house was already emptying in disgust by the time an underling, without a microphone, made a belated apology on stage. She was understandably heckled.

Jeremy Isaacs used to have the chutzpah to address audiences in person when things went wrong in the bad old days. Michael Kaiser and Anthony Dowell should have the guts and grace to do the same.

webTitle: The radical who scored our century

fields.headline: The radical who scored our century
fields.trailText: Kurt Weill Weekend |  English Bach Festival
fields.body:
Kurt Weill Weekend Barbican
English Bach Festival Linbury Studio Theatre

With grim precision, Kurt Weill's life spanned half of the twentieth century, from birth in Dessau in 1900, then flight from the Nazis in 1933 to death in New York in 1950. Just as we haven't worked out what that half-century of history means, so we still can't decide about Weill. A second-rate composer, or the authentic voice of his time? A radical experimenter, or a populist whose true home was Broadway?

Our picture of the composer is fragmentary, not least because so much of his work remains unheard here. Some missing pieces slotted into place during the BBC Symphony Orchestra's Kurt Weill Weekend. In eight concerts over three days, we got one European premiere and two UK premieres. Rightly, the focus was on stage works, but there was no Threepenny Opera, no Mahagonny, no Seven Deadly Sins , although songs from the first two featured in a late-night Weill anthology belted out by Ute Lemper. While Lemper has immense charisma she has been singing her Weill tributes for over a decade, and the show had the high-gloss finish of a greatest hits (hers and Weill's) package.

There were surprises elsewhere, however. A version of the operetta Der Kuhhandel (Shady Dealing) flopped in London in 1935 and has not been seen since; here we got Jeremy Sams's new translation of the German original. Sams's verbal legerdemain was well-intentioned, but its cleverness only made the piece sound like Gilbert and Sullivan. The satire, about arms dealers, politicians and the price of love, had some bite, and would have had more in 1935, and Weill's music was efficient, but with only occasional moments of characteristic pungency in a string figure here, a brass fanfare there.

It was a coup to include the European premiere of The Firebrand of Florence, which opens with a number of such savage sarcasm that it might be a fragment of Brecht/Weill: a hangman, eager to execute the 'firebrand' Benvenuto Cellini, mournfully informs us that 'one man's death is another man's living'. This, though, is no Brechtian epic but an American musical on a grand scale. If it ended up trapped within generic boundaries, Weill's music being too subservient to Ira Gershwin's lyrics, it was well played by the BBC Symphony Orchestra under Andrew Davis.

It was music from Weill's German period which moved me most. The Brecht settings, Das Berliner Requiem and Der Lindberghflug , proved as corrosive as ever, and the opera-ballet Royal Palace was an unexpected sensation. Iwan Goll's libretto offers a surrealist's take on the Eternal Feminine: the heroine Dejanira rejects men, wisely preferring life as a mermaid, and you couldn't wish for a more alluring mermaid than Janice Watson. Weill gave it the works, right down to the shivery tango that transforms woman into mermaid. Royal Palace was a highlight of a fascinating weekend which confirmed that, whatever the unevenness of the pieces, Weill tells us as much as any composer about the century we've just left.

The English Bach Festival (EBF) quotes a eulogy from Stravinsky in its publicity: 'One of the most distinguished and valuable musical organisations in the world today.' Stravinsky died in 1971, so his 'today' is not ours, and nor is the EBF exactly cutting-edge, theatrically or musically. This week it occupied the Royal Opera House's subterranean Linbury Studio Theatre, alternating operatic variants on the Greek myth of Orestes.

Handel's Oreste , dating from 1734, was the first of his operas to be premiered at Covent Garden, although it wasn't strictly a new piece: with Ariodante set to open thee weeks later, Handel cobbled most of it from music he had already composed for other operas. That needn't be a problem, but EBF has the quaint notion that the way to make Handel work is to attempt to re-create baroque stagecraft, including choreography.

It doesn't work. Tom Hawkes's staging was gauche, Stephen Preston's choreography graceless and Terence Emery's designs tacky. The baroque era lacked the concept of kitsch, but this production had it in spades. The cast I saw was drawn from students from the Royal Academy of Music, and perhaps the main, professional cast might have imposed itself more, but it couldn't have made a silk purse out of this. Although Frances Bourne's Oreste was more than promising, the period-instrument orchestra looked and sounded uninvolved.

It was mildly distressing to see elements of the same production serving for Iannis Xenakis's Oresteia , but if Alain Germain's staging was hardly adventurous, the music received a rousing performance under Guy Protheroe. With contrabass clarinet and contrabassoon growling angrily and a vast battery of percussion clattering mightily, energy levels were high, and the cast was clearly convinced that the ancient Greek text made sense. Gratitude, then, to EBF for this rare staging of Xanakis, a composer more respected than performed. When the same was true of Handel's operas, this Oreste might have passed muster, but it won't do now.

Iwan Goll's libretto offers a surrealist's take on the Eternal Feminine: the heroine Dejanira rejects men, wisely preferring life as a mermaid, and you couldn't wish for a more alluring mermaid than Janice Watson. Weill gave it the works, right down to the shivery tango that transforms woman into mermaid. Royal Palace was a highlight of a fascinating weekend which confirmed that, whatever the unevenness of the pieces, Weill tells us as much as any composer about the century we've just left. The English Bach Festival (EBF) quotes a eulogy from Stravinsky in its publicity: 'One of the most distinguished and valuable musical organisations in the world today.' Stravinsky died in 1971, so his 'today' is not ours, and nor is the EBF exactly cutting-edge, theatrically or musically. This week it occupied the Royal Opera House's subterranean Linbury Studio Theatre, alternating operatic variants on the Greek myth of Orestes. Handel's Oreste , dating from 1734, was the first of his operas to be premiered at Covent Garden, although it wasn't strictly a new piece: with Ariodante set to open thee weeks later, Handel cobbled most of it from music he had already composed for other operas. That needn't be a problem, but EBF has the quaint notion that the way to make Handel work is to attempt to re-create baroque stagecraft, including choreography. It doesn't work. Tom Hawkes's staging was gauche, Stephen Preston's choreography graceless and Terence Emery's designs tacky. The baroque era lacked the concept of kitsch, but this production had it in spades. The cast I saw was drawn from students from the Royal Academy of Music, and perhaps the main, professional cast might have imposed itself more, but it couldn't have made a silk purse out of this. Although Frances Bourne's Oreste was more than promising, the period-instrument orchestra looked and sounded uninvolved. It was mildly distressing to see elements of the same production serving for Iannis Xenakis's Oresteia , but if Alain Germain's staging was hardly adventurous, the music received a rousing performance under Guy Protheroe. With contrabass clarinet and contrabassoon growling angrily and a vast battery of percussion clattering mightily, energy levels were high, and the cast was clearly convinced that the ancient Greek text made sense. Gratitude, then, to EBF for this rare staging of Xanakis, a composer more respected than performed. When the same was true of Handel's operas, this Oreste might have passed muster, but it won't do now.

webTitle: The worst hitch in the House

fields.headline: The worst hitch in the House
fields.standfirst: Don't blame the staff for Royal Opera's technical problems. Blame the boss, says  Stephen Pettitt
fields.trailText: Don't blame the staff for Royal Opera's technical problems. Blame the boss, says  Stephen Pettitt
fields.body:
Poor Royal Opera . Like the Labour Government upon whose good offices its fortunes still largely depend, it promised much and has thus far delivered less. Since the trumpeted re-opening it has been business as usual, with the press as eager as ever to hurl brickbats. The charges are the old ones: a combination of incompetence and a continuing policy of effective exclusion.

The media's latest broadside was a ridiculing of the fact that the opening night of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's Gawain was disrupted by a misbehaving trap door. The bad news is that continuing teething problems with some of the machinery last week also caused a cancellation of the third ballet of a three-ballet evening and a matinee performance for schools of Gawain . Not a happy state of affairs, but, so soon enough after the opening, to be almost expected. It will be time to worry if the same problems are still occurring two or three months hence .

Naturally, there is a New Labour-ish pragmatism in the company's desire not to alienate its rich patrons, but at heart the Royal Opera means well. (It has to, or its grant increase is threatened.) So far, however, the putting into practice of that well-meaning spirit has eluded Michael Kaiser and his crew. Right at the start of the new era they spectacularly shot themselves in the foot, being obliged to cancel Peter Sellars's staging of Ligeti's Le Grand Macabre , which would have been a wonderfully appropriate way to end the millennium.

The technical staff were unable to turn the stage sets around in time to accommodate rehearsals and performances of the Ligeti, Graham Vick's new production of Verdi's Falstaff , and the ballet programme. Some among us would much rather they had cancelled the Verdi. Great though the work is, productions of Falstaff occur often enough.

But that would have been tantamount to the company shooting itself in a place where the consequences were likely to be terminal. When your star is Bryn Terfel, when you have sold out the entire run at high prices, and when conductor Bernard Haitink - your (rightly) treasured music director - begins to make rumbling noises, you have little choice in the matter.

From the moment Kaiser announced the abandonment of the Ligeti, the Royal Opera returned to the usual uphill battle for its reputation. Letters pages in the national press were crowded with complaints about subscription level changes and the enduring problem of being unable to secure tickets.

And then that infernal trap door. Far worse things happen in theatres all the time, but it became a national story on the back of the Ligeti cancellation. Kaiser should not have landed himself with the problem of what to cancel, lucrative Verdi or loss-making Ligeti, in the first place. Opening the new Royal Opera House was like beginning an entirely new company in an entirely new building. New companies in new buildings need time to establish themselves, to become accustomed to new ways of working. Kaiser should have foreseen the problems of crowding too many productions together as soon as the company returned to the theatre. After the initial fanfares, he should have begun with a slow crescendo.

The tragedy is that in alienating itself and compromising its credibility as a professional organisation so soon after the move, the Royal Opera has set up its staff for a public pillorying that they do not deserve. If they are not very angry with Kaiser, they should be.
