fields.headline: It's better inside
fields.standfirst: No cinema, no train station. But Walsall has something going for it at last - a £21 million art gallery. Well, at least you can go to the pictures now
fields.trailText: No cinema, no train station. But Walsall has something going for it at last - a £21 million art gallery. Well, at least you can go to the pictures now
fields.body:
The last time I was in Walsall was two-and-a-half years ago. I'd come to write about a pub. When I mentioned this to friends, they all misheard what I said. Their surprise, when I explained I was off to the West Midlands and not to some vodka-soaked dive in downtown Warsaw, was obvious. Walsall, let's face it, was not a groovy place to hang out.

The pub was the first sign, however, that Walsall was changing. The Wharf was not just any old pub. Set on the edge of a newly created canal basin, it was designed by a pair of young architects called Jonathan Sergison and Stephen Bates, a duo better known for cutting-edge housing and quirky, original interiors than for gritty drinking dens. With its big, low-slung ceiling that caught the light of the sun glancing off the water, the Wharf was the first of a clutch of buildings in Walsall to self-consciously use high-quality design to promote urban regeneration.

At the time, it seemed like a long shot. The redbrick warehouses and saw-tooth factories with their proud chimneys - the legacy of Walsall's nineteenth-century industrial prosperity - were derelict for the most part. Great swathes of the main shopping drag were boarded up. The place was dead at night. Right up at the top of the European Union's league table of economic deprivation, Walsall, the largest of the six towns in the metropolitan borough of Walsall, looked like a critical - if not terminal - case.

Thirty months on, though, the prognosis is altogether healthier. Walking through the town centre, things have visibly changed. There is a bustle about the place, new shops have opened, trade at the Wharf is growing. There is still no cinema and no mainline train connection but a new bus station designed by architects Allford Hall Monaghan Morris is almost finished which may bring some of the day-trippers who currently exit to Merryhill in to Walsall instead.

The most obvious sign of change, however, is the huge building that looms up at the end of the canal basin, opposite the Wharf. This is the New Art Gallery, the project that kick-started the whole thing, raising Walsall's ambitions, and it opens to the public in a few weeks' time. The £21 million gallery is one of the largest lottery-funded projects outside London. It owes its existence in large part to the energy and vision of a man called Peter Jenkinson, who arrived in Walsall in the late Eighties to run the town's Garman Ryan art collection.

The 350-piece collection is an unexpected gem; a little-known and highly personal assortment of drawings, paintings and sculptures built up by sculptor Jacob Epstein, his wife Kathleen Garman and their friend, the artist Sally Ryan, and given to the town a decade or so after Epstein's death in 1959. Described as an 'A-Z of European art', the collection ranges from Roman busts to Lucian Freud portraits by way of medieval manuscripts and Rembrandt sketches.

When Jenkinson turned up, the collection was housed above the municipal library. He quickly drew up a programme of events to attract visitors - children, in particular - which proved so popular that record numbers flocked to the collection's cramped premises and the seed of an idea for a dedicated building was sown.

In 1995 he organised an international architecture competition. 'The whole idea,' Jenkinson explains as we look at the finished new gallery, 'was about looking above the horizon, about being aspirational - Walsall should have the very best.' What was surprising - astonishing, even - was the winner: Caruso St John, a small practice that had never built anything costing over £1 million. At the time, both partners were under 40, making them also the youngest architects - by quite some way - to win a lottery-funded project. Ripples of excitement spread through the design world because they were known to be interested in a very different approach to architecture.

Canadian-born Adam Caruso and Peter St John, his British partner, describe their work as 'critical' but in some ways it is the reverse. They delight in finding beauty in unlikely places, in ordinary objects. Where many architects seek to tidy the world up, Caruso St John is a loose architecture that takes its cue from its surroundings. 'Architecture,' says Caruso, 'is about amplifying what's there.'

'The reason they won the competition,' Jenkinson says, 'is that they didn't mind having to build next to Woolies and BhS; in fact, they seemed to like the idea.'

From the outside, the New Art Gallery is a seriously tough building. In profile it really is like a castle (complete with turret), an effect only heightened by its severe grey cladding. How on earth can this be a response to its setting? Caruso St John argue that the building reflects its environment (the cladding is terracotta - albeit grey - a material you see all around Walsall) without aping its surroundings. Just as Victorian buildings sit cheek by jowl with Georgian ones in the loose fabric of most towns and cities, they believe the gallery fits in - that it is different yet harmonious.

And yet, if the exterior is severe, the first thing that strikes you when you walk inside the New Art Gallery is how rich it is, how warm and sensuous. Each floor of the building has a different finish. Sure, there is a lot of bare concrete on some levels (although even this is beautifully finished, with the imprint of the wood shuttering just visible) but elsewhere the gallery spaces are wrapped floor to ceiling in a skin of pinkish Douglas fir. Even the handrails thrill to the touch, delicious in a skin of leather. 'Each space is an experience. There's no over-arching rationality that makes it sterile,' St John explains.

The spaces wrap around each other and you quickly lose track of where you are. And, weaving my way around, the feeling that comes to mind is from childhood - that sense of excitement tinged with fear that kids get exploring new places. Caruso St John liken the gallery to a house. And it is: like a big rambling country house, it is a mysterious building, a place that invites participation and adventure.

Walsall is far from unique in using art as a catalyst for regeneration. Pretty much every major town and city you can think of has put in a lottery bid for a new gallery. Since the Guggenheim turned Bilbao from nowhere-ville to top-notch tourist destination, art has moved centre stage when it comes to urban renewal.

In 20 years' time, how many of these buildings will still be around? Who knows, but my guess is not all of them. Visitor attractions like the Dome and Sheffield's Centre for Popular Music are already having problems drawing in the crowds. Besides the fact that it needs relatively few visitors to break even (Jenkinson has calculated a conservative 140,000 a year), what gives me hope about the New Art Gallery is that it is a building that people are likely to go back to - again and again. Entry is free so anyone can drop in as often as they like. With its restaurant, shop, conference room and rolling programme of exhibitions and education it looks set to become part of Walsall life.

'The jury's out at the moment,' says Paul Hinton of the Walsall Express & Star . 'Most people are really proud and amazed that such a big project has come to town. Walsall folk are fairly blunt. Most have seen it only from the outside and are not very struck. They are going to be amazed by the inside and the sense of space.'

Will the gallery expand Walsall's aspirations as Jenkinson hopes? Certainly it will attract visitors - regionally, even nationally - and that will bring investment. The pub and the bus station were both built on the back of the gallery and both are high-quality buildings.

The future is less sure, however. The gallery is certainly proving a catalyst for change: sites on either side of the canal are about to be developed. But, says Hinton, there has never been any consideration of the architecture. A standard retail estate is likely. OK, so it is real investment which isn't to be knocked but is it real investment in Walsall's long-term future? Perhaps if they'd looked above the horizon just that little bit higher, they would really have transformed Walsall into a groovy place to hang out.

REGENERATION THROUGH ART

 The saviour of urban life: today - thanks in large part to the way the Guggenheim museum has turned down-at-heel Bilbao into an international tourist magnet, and the availability of lottery money - art is the new religion.

 In London, Tate Modern - the Tate Gallery's new £134 million South Bank outpost which opens in May - is transforming Bankside into one of the capital's most sought-after addresses.

 In Newcastle, the Baltic Centre for Contemporary Arts - a £46m redevelopment that will turn a 1940s flour mill into a new art venue - is nearing completion.

 Sheffield is in the throes of building the £13m Millennium Galleries on a site near the town hall. The project is due to be finished next spring. It also has the National Centre for Popular Music, which is struggling to attract enough visitors.

 Salford, meanwhile, hopes The Lowry will put it on the map when it opens this April. The £100m building is already being billed as 'Salford's Guggenheim'.

 Liverpool is ahead of the pack. It built the Tate Liverpool in 1988 in a converted warehouse on Albert Dock. The gallery gets an average of 800,000 visitors a year.

webTitle: Britain gets high while the Cabinet feuds over cannabis

fields.headline: Britain gets high while the Cabinet feuds over cannabis
fields.standfirst: The Government's strategy is a palpable failure, reports Patrick Wintour :  Mowlam and Straw must sink their differences on cannabis and get more cash from the Treasury
fields.trailText: Mo mowlam last week became the first Cabinet Minister in history to admit breaking the law on smoking cannabis. She admitted that she had tried marijuana, did not like it, but - unlike President Clinton - had inhaled. Her apparently casual confession put her among the one in three of the UK population who have used illegal drugs.
fields.body:
Mo mowlam last week became the first Cabinet Minister in history to admit breaking the law on smoking cannabis. She admitted that she had tried marijuana, did not like it, but - unlike President Clinton - had inhaled. Her apparently casual confession put her among the one in three of the UK population who have used illegal drugs.

Mowlam, newly responsible for government drugs policy, might have been thought to be reflecting a new softer government line on cannabis, particularly when Home Secretary Jack Straw appeared to offer his support: 'Good for Mo in making this clear!' But the apparently relaxed united front masks deep rifts in the Cabinet - not just on whether some uses of cannabis should be decriminalised but who is in charge of a drugs policy which is palpably failing.

Britain has one of the highest prevalences of drug use in Europe and the Government is losing the fight against serious drug abuse. The price of key drugs such as heroin is falling on the streets, suggesting availability is as good as ever. Official figures for the latest recorded six-month period show that 30,000 new users reported to drug centres for treatment. At the same time the number of residential drug treatment centres is falling.

Inside Whitehall, a turf war is raging over who is responsible for fighting drugs.

All sides agree the extra £217 million put aside in the Comprehensive Spending Review to fight drugs for this year and the next two years looks paltry, given the scale of the problem in Britain.

Moreover, the Government agreed more than a year ago to shift resources from prosecution to prevention, but there is little sign that anything fundamental has happened. The number of drug treatment centres, already woefully inadequate, seems to be falling. Indeed, waiting lists for drug addicts in some places is longer than six months, according to the Standing Advisory Committee on Drugs.

The Whitehall battle is not just over policy, however, but on the co-ordination of it. As we report today, Mowlam would like to adopt a more liberal policy on cannabis use as medicine, and she would probably like to stop seeing possession of cannabis as an imprisonable offence, the likely recommendation of an imminent Police Foundation report, chaired by Lady Runciman.

Mowlam is being blocked by Straw and Downing Street who see any move in this area as the tip of an iceberg leading to the decriminalisation of cannabis.

But the big issue in Whitehall is the debate on how to slow the use of hard drugs and how best to marshall limited resources to break the cycle of drug abuse and crime.

Doubts are starting to be raised about whether Keith Hellawell, the so-called drugs tsar, appointed with much fanfare by Tony Blair and now in the second year of his three-year contract, is the man for the job. His critics do not blame the former West Yorkshire Chief Constable for losing the drugs war, an intractable international problem, but they question whether he is right for the job. One senior critic said: 'He has the mentality of a former policeman_ slightly tunnel vision and very methodical.' Another Hellawell sceptic questioned his staying power. Greater warmth is expressed towards his deputy, Mike Trace.

The Hellawell problem, however, may be code for a deeper malaise in Whitehall about the lack of co-ordination in the fight against hard drugs. Apart from Hellawell, Mowlam, as Minister for the Cabinet Office, is also overseeing the review of policy for this summer's three-year spending review.

At the Home Office, the impressive Charles Clarke is trying to break the link between crime and drugs. The Department for Education also holds a sizeable interest through combating the drugs culture in schools. The Department of Health monitors general drug abuse and funds drug treatment centres. Throw in the probation service and the police, and you have a recipe for chaos. Poor Hellawell, by contrast, is armed with virtually no budget and few powers, save persuasion.

The Hellawell critics say that Whitehall,in the current jargon, is all about addressing 'cross-cutting issues', subjects such as drugs or child poverty that span more than one department.

This requires someone intimate with Whitehall, such as Moira Wallace, the livewire head of the Social Exclusion Unit, or someone with political clout, such as Mowlam, to stop the Whitehall fiefdoms hoarding their information, budgets and time.

A Cabinet Office report, prepared by the Performance and Innovation Unit and smuggled out last month, in effect acknowledged that Hellawell was still not getting the co-operation he had been appointed to secure.

The unit, much favoured by Blair, recommended the anti-drugs work of Department of Health and Home Office should be merged and 'as a first and very early step' their separate teams should be put under one roof.

It also proposed Hellawell be given his own budget so he could showcase his favoured projects. Hellawell and the Number 10 Policy Unit needed to clarify lines of responsibility, the report said, so local Drug Action Teams, the bodies bringing local agencies together on the ground, did not receive mixed signals from the centre. Ian Robinson, deputy director of the drugs advice centre Release and a former action team worker, echoes this. He says: 'Trying to get co-opera tion at local level is one of the worst jobs in the world. You are hardly likely to get co-ordination if the co-operation at the centre is poor.'

The Cabinet Office report also pointed out that some of the performance targets set by Hellawell in his first annual report in May were meaningless. The report pointed out that a key Hellawell target - reducing the level of repeat offending among drug users by 50 per cent by 2008 - was immeasurable since there are no incontestable data on crime committed due to drug taking.

One Minister admitted the quality of much data on drugs in Britain was patchy. The Standing Advisory Committee on Drugs, the Government's official body, also admitted the information on treatment centres, NHS, voluntary and private, was poor. A spokeswoman said they believed there were 560 such centres in the NHS, but the last full survey was undertaken in 1992.

A Department of Health funded survey for the committee also found unacceptable waiting times. It took 14 weeks to get an assessment, another four weeks to get into rehabilitation and at least four months to secure a slot for NHS detoxification as an inpatient. It all looks like a false economy. One survey suggested 700 people committed crimes while waiting for treatment.

For every £1 spent on drug treatment more than £3 is saved on the costs of crime. Even two years after attendance at a drug treatment centre, the likelihood of a drug user committing a crime is greatly reduced. Since some govern ment studies suggest about 50 per cent of crime is committed to feed a drug habit, treatment centres look like a real investment for government.

The Home Office has grasped this insight. It has launched two drives. First, it is piloting Drug Treatment and Testing Orders. Instead of sending a drug addict to jail - like sending an alcoholic to a brewery, some observers have said - magistrates are being asked to dispatch criminals to a treatment centre.

Three pilot studies in Gloucestershire, Merseyside and Croydon suggest the orders are not a panacea. A large number of addicts are breaching their order by failing to attend the centre. In Merseyside half the orders have been revoked due to breaches. This is not due to an over-zealous approach by magistrates. In some cases, the order is still not being revoked until three warnings.

In the Government's second initiative, Ministers are promising to set up arrest referral schemes in every police station by 2001: £20m was set aside to advise people on treatment available.

The Home Office's Drug Prevention Advisory Service praised the idea of drug refer ral units. In a report, Doing Justice to Treatment, it said: 'For most of those involved, drug use got out of control in their early twenties, long after their criminal careers were established. The majority then embarked on lengthy parallel drug and crime careers. Though they were often in trouble with the law, they got little or no effective help for their drug problems.'

The report warned: 'If drug agencies are already fully stretched and lack capacity to absorb extra clients, setting up criminal justice referral mechanisms, such as drug referral units, will simply reallocate available treatment among problem users.

Underlining the scale of the funding, the study told the story of one man arrested and immediately referred for treatment. He then served five months for shoplifting, came out and still found himself fortieth in the waiting list for treatment. Yet Hellawell, in his first annual report last spring, said he wanted to get waiting times down to four weeks. He is a million miles from achieving this aim.

So far, most new money has been pumped into the rapid expansion of drug treatment services inside prisons. Mowlam and Straw, if they can sink their differences over cannabis, need to co-ordinate their line and bid for extra cash from the Treasury.

Otherwise, the drugs tsars will go the way of other tsars, and tens of thousands of children will continue down the one-way street of poverty, drugs, crime and prison.

webTitle: Labour members set to reject Dobson

fields.headline: Labour members set to reject Dobson
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is facing a 'nightmare' result in Labour's bitter contest to choose a candidate for the London mayoralty. Supporters of his favoured candidate, Frank Dobson, privately concede he is likely to lose the ballot of London Labour members which opens this week.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is facing a 'nightmare' result in Labour's bitter contest to choose a candidate for the London mayoralty. Supporters of his favoured candidate, Frank Dobson, privately concede he is likely to lose the ballot of London Labour members which opens this week.

But they believe the former Health Secretary's popularity among fellow MPs will be enough to snatch victory in Labour's complicated electoral college, in which the votes of MPs, trade unions, and individual party members are counted separately.

Dobson supporters will justify the result by saying their man was chosen by 'the people who know the candidates best' - but he will face taunts from other political parties that he was rejected by most of his own supporters.

Livingstone warned yesterday: 'The absolute nightmare will be if Frank wins by about 1 per cent in the electoral college after every constituency party, and every trade union and co-op branch that has balloted its members has voted for me. There will be a media onslaught. You'll all scream that it's a fix, while I shall be out on the knocker working for Frank.

'If I win, then in 18 months Tony Blair and I will be sitting over at Number 10 beside the fire, sipping a nice brandy, wondering what we all got so fussed about.'

But party members who turn out for a rally on Wednesday will hear a different story from the Prime Minister and his Deputy, John Prescott.

Blair is expected to repeat his warnings that a vote for Livingstone will be a throwback to the politics of the early Eighties, which cost Labour a series of elections.

Volunteers at the Dobson campaign headquarters have made telephone contact with about 20,000 party members in London. They calculate that percentage support for the three candidates is: Livingstone 40; Dobson 35; and about 5 per cent backing Glenda Jackson. Dobson's supporters are pinning their hopes on the undecided 20 per cent. They believe the intervention of big name Cabinet ministers will help win them over.

They also believe Livingstone blundered when he told The Observer last week that Labour's candidates for the new London Regional Assembly were 'definitely not our First Eleven'.

The Livingstone camp, which has many fewer volunteers and only recently gained access to complete lists of party members, has contacted about 3,000 party members. It claims his support is at least 66 per cent, with Dobson trailing at 25 per cent. It thinks attacks on Livingstone by Blair and others have backfired, hardening support for him.

Two London constituency parties - Tooting and Hornchurch - have unofficially polled their members, producing majorities of more than two-to-one for Livingstone. But both parties are unusual in that their local MPs are backing Livingstone.

Informal polling in the traditionally left-wing Lambeth party suggests Livingstone has a 60-40 lead, which has narrowed since Christmas. In Greenwich - no longer dominated by the left - Dobson's backers say he has a majority.

fields.headline: Trimble walks the tightrope
fields.standfirst:
The reform of the RUC is to go ahead and there is no sign of the IRA handing in weapons. Henry McDonald reports on the Unionist leader who feels betrayed by Blair
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A bombshell was dropped during talks at Downing Street 10 days ago between Tony Blair and the Northern Ireland First Minister David Trimble. Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, interjected to inform the Ulster Unionist leader that the Government would carry out most of Chris Patten's proposed reforms of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.
fields.body:
A bombshell was dropped during talks at Downing Street 10 days ago between Tony Blair and the Northern Ireland First Minister David Trimble. Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, interjected to inform the Ulster Unionist leader that the Government would carry out most of Chris Patten's proposed reforms of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

The RUC's name would be changed; its Crown and Harp cap badge would be replaced; the number of officers would be dramatically cut; and policing would be controlled by a new board that included Sinn Fein politicians.

Trimble was stunned, say close aides. He had believed until that moment that the Government would dilute aspects of the Patten Report which Unionists hated.

Trimble left the meeting seething with rage over the Government's willingness to implement the former Tory Cabinet Minister's recommendations more or less in full. His fury reached boiling point last Wednesday when the UUP leader launched his most bitter attack to date on the Prime Minister, accusing his Government in the Commons of 'dishonouring itself' over the RUC changes.

Close allies say Trimble felt he had been betrayed. The First Minister had placed great faith in Blair and the Northern Ireland Secretary, providing him with some concessions as cover against attacks from the Right within the UUP. With the party meeting in three weeks to review its role in the power-sharing government in Belfast, the acceptance of the Patten Report was bound to undermine Trimble's precarious position as leader of Ulster Unionism.

Pro- and anti-agreement unionists condemned the Government's decision; distraught RUC widows denounced the name change as an insult and the Police Federation of Northern Ireland even hinted that its members should reject the offer of the George Medal. His opponents within unionism can rightly argue that Trimble has nothing to complain about, that it was he after all who signed the Good Friday Agreement, a key element of which envisaged changes to the RUC. In short, Trimble, on whom the survival of the agreement and the Executive rests, is more vulnerable than ever.

As one close friend of Trimble put it this weekend: 'If the Ulster Unionist Council met tomorrow, the anger over Patten would mean they would vote overwhelmingly in favour of pulling out of the executive now even before we see whether there will be any IRA decommissioning.'

The UUP Council is set to meet on 12 February but the fate of Northern Ireland's fragile three-month old power-sharing government may have been sealed by then. General John de Chastelain, the Canadian sol dier in charge of the body overseeing the destruction of terrorist arms, returns to Northern Ireland this weekend following the death of his mother.

The next two weeks will be the most critical he has spent in the Province. By the end of this month, de Chastelain must determine whether or not the IRA is making progress towards decommissioning weapons. British Government sources have told The Observer that if the general reports there has been no significant movement in that direction they will suspend the Northern Ireland Executive. The thinking goes that this will give the republican movement further space to sell the idea of decommissioning to the republican grassroots by the absolute final deadline contained in the Agreement, May 2000.

'It will go into suspension if de Chastelaine reports a default. The next step then is to correct that default and start the process again,' one British official said.

Trimble, his credibility battered by the criticisms over his handling of the Patten Report and his misreading of the Government's intentions, needed to be sure there would be some sanction if the IRA failed to start the decommissioning process.

Speaking at a UUP meeting in East Antrim on Friday night, he made it clear that 31 January was the real deadline for his participation in the government with Sinn Fein.

'We hope that those who are in a position to enable General de Chastelain to make a positive report on or before the end of January do so. If they do not, questions will be asked of their commitment to peace and political stability.'

The IRA hates unionist-imposed deadlines. A fortnight ago there was a belief in Dublin and London that the IRA was moving towards making a gesture on guns via the one-off destruction of weapons and the sealing of arms dumps in the Irish Republic. According to senior RUC officers, however, those within the IRA leadership in favour of tactical decommissioning have been taken back by the depth of opposition to disarming anything.

The grass-roots opposition to decommissioning was compounded by the impression that Trimble was calling the shots, dictating a deadline he set last November when he agreed to establish the Executive. 'To convince their base about the necessity of decommissioning, the IRA leadership have left themselves a mountain to climb. They have not been marketing decommissioning very well and the leadership don't want to take a gamble that could lead to leakage into dissident groups,' said one senior police officer.

Despite the defiance over decommissioning, there is still some political pain for Sinn Fein if their IRA allies fail to deliver before the end of this month. Twenty-four hours after his bruising encounter with Blair in the Commons, Trimble travelled to Dublin for a far more cordial meeting with the Irish Premier Bertie Ahern.

Although there were no public warnings from Ahern to republicans over the price they will pay for the IRA's refusal to decommission, Irish officials were making it clear this weekend that Sinn Fein would be blamed for the suspension of the Executive.

Today, thousands of republicans will gather in west Belfast in honour of Tom Williams, the young IRA man hanged for the murder of an RUC sergeant in 1942.

On the platform at Milltown cemetery, overlooking the republican plot where scores of IRA members are buried, will be Gerry Adams, Martin McGuinness, Joe Cahill, Pat Doherty and Martin Ferris.

Suspension of the Execu tive may give Adams and his allies time to persuade the republican movement that a one-off act of decommissioning can reap great gains for Sinn Fein.

But the Sinn Fein President knows that if the IRA decommissions then the sceptics will cry 'sell out'. Some may even try to steal the crown of Irish republicanism from the Provos by taking the ultimate step of re-launching attacks on members of the British Army or the police.

The trouble for Adams and his colleagues is that those opposed to the peace process can point to the grave of Tom Williams, a police killer revered in the pantheon of republican martyrdom, as a source of legitimacy for a new phase of 'armed struggle'.

fields.headline: Reid in poll cash scandal
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Embattled Scottish Secretary John Reid was fighting to save his career last night after  The Observer  revealed that he used public money from his Westminster allowances to help finance Labour's Scottish election campaign.
fields.body:
Embattled Scottish Secretary John Reid was fighting to save his career last night after The Observer revealed that he used public money from his Westminster allowances to help finance Labour's Scottish election campaign.

Among those who benefited from the arrangement was his son, Kevin Reid, who was put on the Labour Party election campaign payroll.

A number of campaigners were paid by Reid, a key ally of the Prime Minister, and by Glasgow MP John Maxton. They were listed as House of Commons researchers while they were actually working as full-time election workers in the party's Scottish headquarters.

Apart from Reid, who was the focus of The Observer 's Lobbygate revelations in September last year, the party campaigners who benefited from these arrangements include Chris Winslow, now a special adviser to Scottish First Minister Donald Dewar.

Reid's involvement will cause severe embarrassment to Downing Street and the Scottish Labour leadership, which had hoped to keep the affair secret.

The arrangements will be reported to the Westminster Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards later this week for an independent inquiry. MPs' allowances are gov erned by strict regulations which state they must be 'wholly, exclusively and necessarily' incurred in connection with a MP's parliamentary activities.

Observer inquiries have established that at least three full-time election campaigners were paid as part-time researchers by Reid and Maxton. Their payments are regarded as 'donations in kind' by the independent Scottish Election Commission, headed by Professor Anthony King, which was set up to monitor party funding and spending in the run-up to the Scottish Parliament election last May. Labour failed to disclosed these donations to the commission despite being asked to provide details of all.

The payments were also hidden in Labour's statutory declaration on election spending in August last year.

The declarations, required under election law, showed that Labour spent just under £1 million on the election, £186,000 of which was on staff salaries and expenses. The declaration was submitted for scrutiny to the Cabinet minister responsible, Scottish Secretary John Reid.

According to senior Labour sources, these secret donations in kind were just one of a number of payments concealed to ensure Labour's final election spending figure remained within the £1.5m cap. Party sources say Labour exceeded the £1.5m cap.

The payments by Reid and Maxton began in May 1998 when Labour was neck and neck in the opinion polls with the Scottish National Party but without funds to establish an election fighting machine.

Reid offered his son to party workers following a Strategy Group meeting at the party's Scottish headquarters at Keir Hardie House. Chancellor Gordon Brown, the then Scottish Secretary Donald Dewar, junior minister Brian Wilson and Reid had heard complaints that the party was underfunded, poorly staffed and being outgunned.

According to one senior party source, Reid said: 'My boy Kevin is not doing anything, he can come in and I will find a way of paying him.' His offer was taken up by the party's then general secretary Alex Rowley.

fields.headline: Ultimatum for IRA over arms
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson will dramatically intervene to save the Northern Ireland peace process by suspending the three-month-old power-sharing Executive if the IRA fails to decommission within a fortnight.
fields.byline: Henry McDonald, Belfast, and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson will dramatically intervene to save the Northern Ireland peace process by suspending the three-month-old power-sharing Executive if the IRA fails to decommission within a fortnight.

Mandelson will act in an effort to prevent First Minister David Trimble from being forced to quit as Ulster Unionist leader. Sources at the Northern Ireland Office told The Observer that the Stormont Executive, which includes two Sinn Fein Ministers, will be wound up if General John de Chastelain reports no progress on IRA disarmament by 31 January.

Trimble gave a promise to his party's rank and file last November to resign as First Minister if there was no progress on decommissioning by February. His party is to meet on 12 February and Trimble will have no option but to quit in the absence of a verified handover. His departure would represent a huge setback for the peace process.

Intelligence suggests the IRA will not now decommission by the end of February. Republican sources said the IRA and Sinn Fein leaderships were having difficulty selling a one-off act of tactical decommissioning. The thinking behind the suspension of the Executive is that it will give Sinn Fein more time to persuade the IRA to decommission before the final disarmament deadline of 22 May - the date written into the Good Friday Agreement.

If the IRA fails to move towards decommissioning within the next fortnight, pressure on the republican movement will be applied by both London and Dublin. A senior Irish source said yesterday: 'Trimble took a leap of faith last November and if the republican movement fails to reciprocate, then the fingers will point at them, saying they are the ones to blame.'

But the IRA will not move in the face of what is seen as a Unionist-imposed deadline of February. Ministers are still hoping that the sealing of arms dumps south of the border might be regarded as an acceptable form of decommissioning. However, the Unionists believe this would require a change in the law.

Trimble warned yesterday: 'If things don't work out as we had hoped and if it proves impossible to sustain the administration in its present form, then the only immediate recourse is direct rule.'

The IRA's intentions over decommissioning have become increasingly hard to read given the appointment of three interlocutors to General de Chastelain's International Body on Decommissioning. They include Padraig Wilson, the former IRA leader in the Maze Prison, who hinted in a recent interview that the Provisionals might carry out a voluntary act of disarmament, and Joe Cahill, the republican veteran and former IRA chief-of-staff.

Both men are seen to be close to Gerry Adams and the Sinn Fein leadership. However, the third member of the triumvirate is Brian Keenan, a Marxist hardliner on the IRA's Army Council.

John Taylor, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, said yesterday he was convinced that the British Government would wind up the Executive in the absence of genuine progress on IRA decommissioning.

fields.headline: Mowlam's drug clash with Blair
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Government's policy on drugs was in disarray last night after it emerged that Mo Mowlam, the Minister in charge of tackling the problem, was at odds with Tony Blair and Jack Straw over moves to relax cannabis laws.
fields.body:
The Government's policy on drugs was in disarray last night after it emerged that Mo Mowlam, the Minister in charge of tackling the problem, was at odds with Tony Blair and Jack Straw over moves to relax cannabis laws.

Mowlam, who last week admitted she smoked marijuana in the Sixties, is 'sympathetic' to proposals that those caught for possession of cannabis no longer be jailed. She also believes it should be available for medical use.

But in a sign of tensions at the heart of government over the drugs problem, Mowlam is said to be getting 'absolutely nowhere' with Home Secretary Jack Straw and Downing Street, who see any legal change as 'the tip of a dangerous iceberg' leading to full decriminalisation of cannabis.

The dispute is part of a wider row across Whitehall about the effectiveness of the Government's anti-drugs policy, launched two years ago.

A Cabinet Office study has implicitly accepted that Keith Hellawell, the drugs tsar, has yet to have the impact he hoped in Whitehall. It calls for merging the anti-drugs work of the Department of Health and the Home Office.

The recommendation on lifting penal sanctions for possession is set to be made by a prestigious committee set up by the Home Office-funded Police Foundation and chaired by Lady Runciman, a former member of the Government's Advisory Council on Misuse of Drugs.

Appointed in October, Mowlam is the first senior Labour drugs spokesman to press privately for a change.

The Cabinet Office report also admitted conflicting messages from central government on drugs. Some of the targets set out on the drugs tsar's national plan last year, including a commitment to cut reoffending by drug users, are simply immeasurable, the Cabinet Office found.

Mowlam, anxious to stop inter-departmental jostling and inertia, is determined to raise the profile of the Government's anti-drugs effort.

The campaign to allow cannabis use for medical purposes was given a big boost in November 1998 when the Science and Technology Committee in the Lords recommended that doctors be entitled to prescribe it. The peers said they found enough evidence that the drug was effective against the symptoms of MS, and in the control of pain.

The committee, chaired by Lord Perry of Walton, warned: 'Significant numbers of sufferers are taking cannabis at present, in defiance of the law and without medical supervision or quality control.'

But the Government rejected that report, despite support by the British Medical Association.

Latest Home Office figures, for 1997, show that 45,362 people were cautioned for possession of cannabis, 18,000 fined and about 4,000 put on probation. Just over 500 were jailed.

webTitle: Fast Forward: The Loafer's Guide To Popular Culture

fields.headline: Fast Forward: The Loafer's Guide To Popular Culture
fields.standfirst: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week: William Orbit
fields.trailText: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week: William Orbit
fields.body:
William Orbit. The name seems familiar. Is he a friend of Flash Gordon's? No. Orbit is one of the most successful British musicians of the moment, the knob-twiddler's knob twiddler, the thing in musicbiz history last year - but rumour has it that Madonna offered Orbit $32 million to produce her last album, Ray of Light. He says that's rubbish. Madonna paid him more than that. A backroom boy, then.

So why do I remember his face? Could be because he made the most bizarre and least coherent acceptance speech in the history of the Grammy Awards when he went to pick up his award for producing Ray of Light last year. Maddy had to come and rescue him. It was great television.

Why is he worth so much? Maddie's previous two albums had slumped to sales of five million and three million.She needed to find a new sound. Orbit had remixed 'Justify My Love', and she remembered. He was known in music circles as eccentric and obsessive, but had produced few hits. She took a chance. They hit it off. Ray of Light sold more than 12 million copies and her career was back on course.

Oh God. The new Mike Oldfield? Not quite. Now aged 42, Orbit's path to becoming the most respected British producer of his generation is fascinating. He spent much of the Seventies living in squats. He made three albums with a synth pop unit, Torch Song, playing all the instruments himself. Then he made a series of albums under the name Strange Cargo, which prefigured ambient music, and immersed himself in the emerging Brit house scene, founding a label, Guerilla, that offered a home to some of the most innovative music of that time. He formed another vehicle called Bass-O-Matic and had a big dance hit with 'Fascinating Rhythms'.

So, this classical record. Just how odious is it? Less than you'd expect. The selection of material is judicious, concentrating on fashionably elegiac works by Cage, Gorecki and Beethoven. At the same time, Handel and Vivaldi make cameos and a banging remix of Barber's 'Adagio for Strings' went to Number 4 in the pre-Christmas pop chart. Curious pop pickers will find something to muse over. Classical aficionados may well consider suicide. Which would be a very bad thing for Radio 3.

And next? The new Orbit-produced and co-written Madonna album is said to be nearing completion and slated to appear later this year. Try to remember his name till then.

fields.headline: Generation game
fields.standfirst: Sobering thought for the day - those that 'come of age' this year were born in 1982, which means that...
fields.trailText: Sobering thought for the day - those that 'come of age' this year were born in 1982, which means that...
fields.body:
They have no meaningful recollection of the Thatcher years.

There has only been one Pope.

They were seven when the Berlin Wall came down and do not remember the Cold War.

They have never feared a nuclear war.

They are too young to remember when daytime television meant the test card.

Their lifetime has always included Aids.

They are unlikely to have ever played Space Invaders or Pac Man.

They have never owned a record player.

They have always had an answering machine.

They have no idea who Benny from Crossroads is.

Atari predates them, as do vinyl albums. The expression 'You sound like a broken record' means nothing to them.

They have always had cable and never seen a black and white TV.

They cannot fathom not having a remote control.

Roller-skates have always meant inlines (roller blades) for them.

They never took a swim and thought about Jaws.

They can't imagine what hard contact lenses are.

They do not care who shot JR, and have no idea who JR is.

Michael Jackson has always been white.

They don't have a clue how to use a typewriter.

fields.headline: Heaven and hell
fields.standfirst: Buddhism's most important pilgrimage is to a squalid, dangerous town in India's poorest state. But is building a 500ft Buddha there for $150m the answer to anyone's prayers?
fields.trailText: Buddhism's most important pilgrimage is to a squalid, dangerous town in India's poorest state. But is building a 500ft Buddha there for $150m the answer to anyone's prayers?
fields.body:
In the holy town of Bodhgaya, north-east India, the day starts at an ungodly hour. Before the sun has had a chance to burn away the early morning mist, thousands of pilgrims have settled themselves on to a patch of dust and gravel the size of two football pitches. They sit patiently, blowing steam from cups of tea, waiting for their spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, to begin his teachings.

On the left flank, the Tibetan enclosure is a 200m-deep sea of saffron and gold robes and gleaming scalps; the right, the Westerner's side, is a colour-clash of hippy bags, shawls and personal FM radios (the teachings are broadcast in English, Spanish and Hindu). Ninja-style guards with rifles slung over their shoulders pace along the concrete fence perimeters. When a guttural mantra thunders out of the loudspeaker, everyone rises obsequiously and the Dalai Lama emerges from behind an elevated podium. The Tibetan leader climbs on to his gilded throne, eases himself into a lotus posture that somehow suggests both supreme regality and utmost humility, looks up, and, for no apparent reason, bursts into a peal of laughter.

Fifteen thousand pilgrims and non-believers alike have made the arduous journey to Bodhgaya, a small, unbecoming town in Bihar, India's poorest and most notoriously lawless state, to listen to the Dalai Lama's teachings. They come from places as far-flung as Finland, Melbourne, Trinidad, Israel, Alaska and Plymouth, and together transform an area no bigger than a small English town into a holier-than-thou version of Woodstock. For two weeks, the streets throng with iron-calved rickshaw drivers, serene-looking monks draped in mala beads and shuffling Westerners mumbling Om mantras under their breath.

The sight of doctors, New Age travellers, TV producers and advertising executives mingling with Tibetan monks is startling to behold. Add to this the desperately poor local Indians, the tin-pot beggars and lepers from neighbouring hamlets that besiege Bodhgaya for the duration of the event, not to mention occasional visiting celebrities Richard Gere and the Beastie Boys, and you have the most unlikely gathering of humanity you're ever likely to encounter.

Bodhgaya is perhaps the most important pilgrimage site for Buddhists. According to the scriptures, it is where Buddha attained Enlightenment 2,540 years ago, after sitting beneath a Bodhi Tree for a week, meditating on the causes of suffering. Today, a descendant of the original tree is flanked by a majestic temple, the Mahabodhi Stupa, where a never-ending stream of barefooted Buddhists can be seen prostrating around its pyramidal spire.

The spiritual charm of the place is captivating, yet, for many Western pilgrims, Bodhgaya feels like the most unenlightened place on earth. 'It may be the centre of the universe for Buddhists,' says Robin Stock, from Seattle, sipping a hot lemon and ginger tea in a bamboo shack called Café Om. 'But trying to enjoy yourself here is like having a holiday in hell. Bihar is a harsh place in general; it's full of beggars, dust and dirt. Everybody I've spoken to has become ill - there are just too many people in too small a space.'

From December through February, when Bodhgaya is overrun with pilgrims, the air quality is reminiscent of a London smog. The oppressive dust and low-hanging cloud is made worse by the stench of dried human faeces and auto-rickshaws spitting out diesel fumes; on arriving - assuming you make it past the infamous dacoit bandits who prowl for tourists on the main road from Gaya station ('In the event of a breakdown, run for your life,' say locals) - the first thing you notice is pilgrims with face masks of the kind worn by Tokyo commuters.

There's little doubt that Bodhgaya is ill-equipped to cope with the influx of visitors. In many respects, little has changed here since the time of the Buddha. When the tourist season is over and the pedestrianised centre with its rows of phone booths and stalls selling plastic Buddhas shuts down, you are left with a desperately poor agrarian community. A stone's throw from the international hotels, farmers in threadbare rags steer ox-drawn ploughs, and clusters of women draped in colourful sarongs can be seen carrying water from nearby wells.

The harsh conditions make Bodhgaya the ideal pilgrimage site for the pampered Western temperament. 'The teachings are all about how to see through these distractions, how to go through this suffering and keep a good attitude,' says Stock, who came to India with his wife after selling up and quitting his job because he was fed up of being 'crushed under the wheels of mediocrity'.

'Every day you have an opportunity to practise what you've been taught,' agrees Coco, a 32-year-old dancer from New York city, who came to Bodhgaya for the teachings of Michael Roach, a former director of a diamond company who is now considered a guru among modern Buddhists. 'It's so easy to lose your temper here, and this whole teaching is about how not to get angry, how not to overreact, how not to feel hatred towards people.'

In spite of the irritations and dangers, the number of Westerners coming to Bodhgaya increases every year. The majority are Buddhist sympathisers, who are here to see the Dalai Lama and to give their millennium celebrations a spiritual spin. But, more tellingly, the number of dedicated Western practitioners is rising, too. Most countries with a large Buddhist population have a monastery here in Bodhgaya.

This year, all residential retreats and meditation centres are fully booked. Some, like Christopher Titmuss's, are subscribed twice-over: 'Westerners are sitting up and taking notice of Buddhism in ever greater numbers,' says Titmuss, who first came to Bodhgaya as a monk in 1974 and has been teaching here every year since. 'Ethics like non-violence, right livelihood, meditation, questioning of lifestyle, wisdom, loving-kindness, compassion are taking root in the West. Worldwide, there's a growing number of people who have a great commitment to the "inner work".'

It's a trend that in recent years has coincided with the release of blockbuster movies Seven Years in Tibet, starring Brad Pitt, and Martin Scorsese's Kundun, and has seen the likes of Tina Turner, Courtney Love and Joanna Lumley flirt with the dharma. 'Underlying our modern consumer culture there's a deep sense of spiritual undernourishment,' says Keith O'Neill, a self-confessed dharma-bum from Sydney, who likes nothing more than staying up late in local chai bars sipping sweet Indian tea and debating the scriptures. 'That's why you see people from all walks of life craving greater self-awareness. We are beginning to see Buddhism not as some wacky Eastern religion but as a serious alternative to our waning spiritual beliefs.'

The spread of Buddhism in the West does, however, present a challenge to the Buddhist tradition. Just as Buddhism has had to adapt to a series of ongoing struggles - including the Chinese occupation of Tibet, military dictatorship in Burma, rampant consumerism in Thailand, and an imminent power struggle for a successor to the Dalai Lama - it also has to be careful as it interfaces with Western culture, inclined, as it is, more towards profit than purification. 'The gulf can be bridged,' says Renuka Singh, who has edited several Buddhist texts. 'You need a lot of wisdom to synthesise the two, but it's essentially your attitude to materialism that counts, not actually renouncing it.'

When it comes to marriages between the East and the West, Bodhgaya plays host to the most spectacular and controversial. Take a bumpy rickshaw ride to a fenced-off enclosure on the outskirts of town and you'll find the HQ of the Maitreya Project, which plans to build a Buddha statue that will cost $150m. At 500ft tall, it will be the largest monument in the world and in terms of engineering, the most challenging. Already, over $2m (mostly from Taiwanese benefactors) has been spent on preparing land, commissioning design consultants, social impact studies and building prototype statues. The founder of the idea, the late Tibetan Lama Thubten Yeshe, took this East/West partnership to the extreme, by apparently choosing a Western rebirth. His reincarnation, a 14-year-old Spanish boy, Lama Tenzin Osel Rinpoche, now gives his full support to this vast scheme.

Lord Maitreya is believed to be the future Buddha who stands for loving-kindness and compassion, and who will himself attain Enlightenment in Bodhgaya. Merely glimpsing this statue, according to Maitreya Project director Peter Kedge, will leave a karmic imprint that will have untold positive repercussions in this and future lives. 'All who help build it, and that includes the benefactors, will make enough merit to get a higher rebirth, and maybe become one of Maitreya's disciples,' says Kedge.

'By building this monument, we will give people the chance to make a connection with Maitreya Buddha,' says Kedge. 'Understanding more about Maitreya, being inspired by what will be an incredibly beautiful monument, will also help to promote compassion and concern for others.'

As you'd expect, few people in Bodhgaya disagree with the spiritual intent behind the construction of a Buddha, which will be so big it'll be the equivalent of an ant looking up at a human. But as the costs of the statue have increased over time, so too have the voices of concern, and in recent weeks Kedge and fellow directors have acted to stave off an unholy row by organising a meeting with local villagers and aid workers. 'We are keen to involve local people at every level in this project,' insists Kedge, who is beginning to sound like a reincarnated Peter Mandelson fielding questions about the millenium Dome.

Still, there are those for whom the costs are simply too much, and who feel it is against the original teachings of the Buddha. 'Is it wise and compassionate to build and spend $150m on a huge statue, stuck up there in the clouds half the time, when down at ground level there is such desperate poverty - a poverty, which, by Indian standards, is the worst anywhere?'

Kedge answers the Maitreya Project's critics by saying it is committed to social work in the area. It has promised to build an international standard hospital, a conference and training centre, and to develop a school up to university level. Already, Kedge points out, the project has created jobs, and will continue to do so even after completion, when the local infrastructure develops to accommodate tourists.

Sankrityayan shows me around the inside of a half-built tenement which passes as a school and somehow manages to double up as an orphanage. Construction work stopped when funds ran dry last year. 'Just 150 children from 10 villages are educated here,' he says. Decked out in claret garb, and sporting skinheads and mischievous grins, they could easily pass as West Ham supporters circa 1984. The Indian coach drivers who brought us here stand around impatiently swigging rum, intermittently revving their engines, beeping their horns, or drowning out the monks' chorus with blasts of saccharine Indian pop.

Eva, a businesswoman on pilgrimage from Melbourne, rests her prayer book on her lap and looks up at the prototype statue. 'I wish them all the luck in the world for this. Even if people have no faith at all in Buddhism, just to see this thing will help them in future lives,' she says. 'I just wish it was more modest. I agree with the Dalai Lama. He says it's a very courageous undertaking - I read that as a euphemism for saying it's just too ambitious.'
fields.bodyText: In the holy town of Bodhgaya, north-east India, the day starts at an ungodly hour. Before the sun has had a chance to burn away the early morning mist, thousands of pilgrims have settled themselves on to a patch of dust and gravel the size of two football pitches. They sit patiently, blowing steam from cups of tea, waiting for their spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, to begin his teachings. On the left flank, the Tibetan enclosure is a 200m-deep sea of saffron and gold robes and gleaming scalps; the right, the Westerner's side, is a colour-clash of hippy bags, shawls and personal FM radios (the teachings are broadcast in English, Spanish and Hindu). Ninja-style guards with rifles slung over their shoulders pace along the concrete fence perimeters. When a guttural mantra thunders out of the loudspeaker, everyone rises obsequiously and the Dalai Lama emerges from behind an elevated podium. The Tibetan leader climbs on to his gilded throne, eases himself into a lotus posture that somehow suggests both supreme regality and utmost humility, looks up, and, for no apparent reason, bursts into a peal of laughter. Fifteen thousand pilgrims and non-believers alike have made the arduous journey to Bodhgaya, a small, unbecoming town in Bihar, India's poorest and most notoriously lawless state, to listen to the Dalai Lama's teachings. They come from places as far-flung as Finland, Melbourne, Trinidad, Israel, Alaska and Plymouth, and together transform an area no bigger than a small English town into a holier-than-thou version of Woodstock. For two weeks, the streets throng with iron-calved rickshaw drivers, serene-looking monks draped in mala beads and shuffling Westerners mumbling Om mantras under their breath. The sight of doctors, New Age travellers, TV producers and advertising executives mingling with Tibetan monks is startling to behold. Add to this the desperately poor local Indians, the tin-pot beggars and lepers from neighbouring hamlets that besiege Bodhgaya for the duration of the event, not to mention occasional visiting celebrities Richard Gere and the Beastie Boys, and you have the most unlikely gathering of humanity you're ever likely to encounter. Bodhgaya is perhaps the most important pilgrimage site for Buddhists. According to the scriptures, it is where Buddha attained Enlightenment 2,540 years ago, after sitting beneath a Bodhi Tree for a week, meditating on the causes of suffering. Today, a descendant of the original tree is flanked by a majestic temple, the Mahabodhi Stupa, where a never-ending stream of barefooted Buddhists can be seen prostrating around its pyramidal spire. The spiritual charm of the place is captivating, yet, for many Western pilgrims, Bodhgaya feels like the most unenlightened place on earth. 'It may be the centre of the universe for Buddhists,' says Robin Stock, from Seattle, sipping a hot lemon and ginger tea in a bamboo shack called Café Om. 'But trying to enjoy yourself here is like having a holiday in hell. Bihar is a harsh place in general; it's full of beggars, dust and dirt. Everybody I've spoken to has become ill - there are just too many people in too small a space.' From December through February, when Bodhgaya is overrun with pilgrims, the air quality is reminiscent of a London smog. The oppressive dust and low-hanging cloud is made worse by the stench of dried human faeces and auto-rickshaws spitting out diesel fumes; on arriving - assuming you make it past the infamous dacoit bandits who prowl for tourists on the main road from Gaya station ('In the event of a breakdown, run for your life,' say locals) - the first thing you notice is pilgrims with face masks of the kind worn by Tokyo commuters. There's little doubt that Bodhgaya is ill-equipped to cope with the influx of visitors. In many respects, little has changed here since the time of the Buddha. When the tourist season is over and the pedestrianised centre with its rows of phone booths and stalls selling plastic Buddhas shuts down, you are left with a desperately poor agrarian community. A stone's throw from the international hotels, farmers in threadbare rags steer ox-drawn ploughs, and clusters of women draped in colourful sarongs can be seen carrying water from nearby wells. The harsh conditions make Bodhgaya the ideal pilgrimage site for the pampered Western temperament. 'The teachings are all about how to see through these distractions, how to go through this suffering and keep a good attitude,' says Stock, who came to India with his wife after selling up and quitting his job because he was fed up of being 'crushed under the wheels of mediocrity'. 'Every day you have an opportunity to practise what you've been taught,' agrees Coco, a 32-year-old dancer from New York city, who came to Bodhgaya for the teachings of Michael Roach, a former director of a diamond company who is now considered a guru among modern Buddhists. 'It's so easy to lose your temper here, and this whole teaching is about how not to get angry, how not to overreact, how not to feel hatred towards people.' In spite of the irritations and dangers, the number of Westerners coming to Bodhgaya increases every year. The majority are Buddhist sympathisers, who are here to see the Dalai Lama and to give their millennium celebrations a spiritual spin. But, more tellingly, the number of dedicated Western practitioners is rising, too. Most countries with a large Buddhist population have a monastery here in Bodhgaya. This year, all residential retreats and meditation centres are fully booked. Some, like Christopher Titmuss's, are subscribed twice-over: 'Westerners are sitting up and taking notice of Buddhism in ever greater numbers,' says Titmuss, who first came to Bodhgaya as a monk in 1974 and has been teaching here every year since. 'Ethics like non-violence, right livelihood, meditation, questioning of lifestyle, wisdom, loving-kindness, compassion are taking root in the West. Worldwide, there's a growing number of people who have a great commitment to the "inner work".' It's a trend that in recent years has coincided with the release of blockbuster movies Seven Years in Tibet, starring Brad Pitt, and Martin Scorsese's Kundun, and has seen the likes of Tina Turner, Courtney Love and Joanna Lumley flirt with the dharma. 'Underlying our modern consumer culture there's a deep sense of spiritual undernourishment,' says Keith O'Neill, a self-confessed dharma-bum from Sydney, who likes nothing more than staying up late in local chai bars sipping sweet Indian tea and debating the scriptures. 'That's why you see people from all walks of life craving greater self-awareness. We are beginning to see Buddhism not as some wacky Eastern religion but as a serious alternative to our waning spiritual beliefs.' The spread of Buddhism in the West does, however, present a challenge to the Buddhist tradition. Just as Buddhism has had to adapt to a series of ongoing struggles - including the Chinese occupation of Tibet, military dictatorship in Burma, rampant consumerism in Thailand, and an imminent power struggle for a successor to the Dalai Lama - it also has to be careful as it interfaces with Western culture, inclined, as it is, more towards profit than purification. 'The gulf can be bridged,' says Renuka Singh, who has edited several Buddhist texts. 'You need a lot of wisdom to synthesise the two, but it's essentially your attitude to materialism that counts, not actually renouncing it.' At 500ft tall, it will be the largest monument in the world and in terms of engineering, the most challenging. His reincarnation, a 14-year-old Spanish boy, Lama Tenzin Osel Rinpoche, now gives his full support to this vast scheme. Lord Maitreya is believed to be the future Buddha who stands for loving-kindness and compassion, and who will himself attain Enlightenment in Bodhgaya. Merely glimpsing this statue, according to Maitreya Project director Peter Kedge, will leave a karmic imprint that will have untold positive repercussions in this and future lives. 'All who help build it, and that includes the benefactors, will make enough merit to get a higher rebirth, and maybe become one of Maitreya's disciples,' says Kedge. 'By building this monument, we will give people the chance to make a connection with Maitreya Buddha,' says Kedge. 'Understanding more about Maitreya, being inspired by what will be an incredibly beautiful monument, will also help to promote compassion and concern for others.' As you'd expect, few people in Bodhgaya disagree with the spiritual intent behind the construction of a Buddha, which will be so big it'll be the equivalent of an ant looking up at a human. fields.headline: Beauty report: Lip service
fields.standfirst: Caffeine lipstick and stress-busting creams - 'functional cosmetics' are the future for our faces. Helen Foster reports
fields.trailText: Caffeine lipstick and stress-busting creams - 'functional cosmetics' are the future for our faces. Helen Foster reports
fields.body:
Forget your early morning Starbucks, this week there's a new way to get your coffee kick. Hard Candy's caffeine-containing lipsticks are now available in this country, and they claim to boost your energy with every lick of your lips. Ludicrous? Maybe, but they're part of a growing trend for 'super-cosmetics' that claim to do everything from freshen your breath to improve the memory.

On planet beauty, these lipsticks-cum-lattes, and all their benefit-boosting shelf mates, are known as either 'functional cosmetics' or 'cosmeceuticals'. Whichever, the principle is the same. Traditional beauty products such as moisturisers, shampoo and eyeshadows are enhanced with 'medicinal' ingredients such as vitamins, herbs and pharmaceuticals allowing them to, say, treat spots or affect energy levels, as well as perform their usual function. There are now skincare ranges that claim to treat stress along with wrinkles; eye make-up products to prevent styes or puffiness and blemish cover-ups that heal while they conceal.

According to market researchers Datamonitor, almost a third of the major cosmetic launches in the last year offered some kind of cosmeceutical benefit, and over the next few years hundreds more of these products will be launched. Functional cosmetics are in keeping with the way consumers think at the moment. There is a worldwide demand for dual-purpose products. So, the biggest growing food area in the UK today are 'functional foods'; products such as orange juice or margarine that are fortified with vitamins or other health-giving ingredients. Meanwhile in Japan, millions of yen are being poured into 'functional fabrics' that offer add-on benefits such as sun-protection. Cosmetics are just keeping up.

Also, according to Matthew Jeatt from trends prediction agency Promostyl UK, the idea that women wear cosmetics purely to make them look good has become unfashionable and even undesirable. 'The reasoning is that because our day-to-day lives are busier than ever before, we feel guilty about spending too much time on ourselves. These products allow us to alleviate some of that guilt, firstly by being multi-functional and secondly because their add-on benefits are (albeit vaguely) medicinal or health orientated.' In other words, if your skincare destresses you or your shampoo boosts your energy, it's easier to feel that the time spent using it is dealing with something slightly more valid than vanity.

Not surprisingly, experts claim that we need to look carefully at the health benefits functional cosmetics can provide and point out that none of us should be fooled into thinking that we'll get the same benefits from using, say, ginseng-based energising shampoo as we would by taking the herb in supplement form. 'When you put a herb or a vitamin into a cosmetic product, it's normally altered, for example to make it stable, and this may alter the benefits you get,' says Sally Penford from the International Dermal Institute. 'Levels of the added ingredient may also be low.' The truth is that functional cosmetics need to be seen for what they are. A concealer containing a spot treatment will speed up healing on a minor blemish, but it won't cure acne. Lipsticks containing caffeine will not have the same effect as an espresso. 'Cosmetics are superficial products,' says Penford. 'They have superficial results - we just want to believe that they'll work miracles.'

Tony and Tina Frequency Eyeshadow, £12.95: containing the anti-inflammatory herb camomile, this product claims to decrease eye puffiness. 'When we asked our friends what they wanted in an eyeshadow, the answer was something they could fall asleep in after a party without doing any damage,' says Tony Gill from the company. 'So that's what we created - an eyeshadow for drunks.'

Almay One Coat Gel EyeColour, £5.95: these pencils go on damp to cool the eye, then dry to create long-lasting colour. Aloe vera and cucumber are used to help relieve puffiness.

Elizabeth Arden Lip Lip Hooray, £12.95: this breath-freshening lipstick contains a sulphur neutraliser which attacks any odour as you breathe out - if that doesn't work, the fact that it smells like mints should help.

Hard Candy Caffeine Lipstick, £13.95: delivers a quick pick-you-up 'every time you lick your lips' says the blurb. In truth, it probably won't charge you up too much but it is incredibly moisturising. Shades include Lipachino and Latte Lip.

Té Tao Tea for Hair Shampoo and Conditioner, £2.99 each: Chinese medicine believes that what's going on on the outside reflects the state of your insides. So, if your hair needs calming, so do you. As you wash, natural plant extracts such as bamboo and ginseng aid the hair, while scents of jasmine and lemongrass energise or calm the system.

Lancme Hydra Zen Peaux Seches, £19.50 for 30ml tube or £25 for 50ml jar: the Hydra Zen destressing skincare is Lancme's biggest-selling range. It uses calming, natural ingredients such as royal jelly to soothe the skin and a scent of grapefruit, mandarin and ylang-ylang to calm the nerves. This product, launched last week, is specifically for dry skin.

Urban Decay Urban Camouflage, 3-in-1 concealer, £11: the green concealer in this multi-pack not only eliminates the redness of spots, it also contains salicylic acid to dry them up.

Ultima II Extraordinaire Volumising Lip Gloss, £12.95: the natural alternative to collagen, this transparent lipshader contains dehydrated proteins that enter the lips and as they come into contact with your saliva they swell up, increasing the power of your pout.

A Function Too Far

The following products are only available in the US, thankfully.

 Brainwash shampoo: containing extract of gingko biloba (a herb known to improve circulation to the brain), this shampoo claims to increase memory after each wash.

 Feng Shui Cosmetics: if your love life or finances need sorting out, it's probably best not to rely on this company's theory that wearing the right shade of eyeshadow or lipstick will help.

 PMS nail polish: its function is to demonstrate to others that this week you're hormonally challenged by changing colour as your period is due.

fields.headline: Sex drive
fields.standfirst: The Nissan Skyline GT-R34 turned Miranda Sawyer into a turbocharged lad for the week - and she loved it
fields.trailText: The Nissan Skyline GT-R34 turned Miranda Sawyer into a turbocharged lad for the week - and she loved it
fields.body:
Price £54,000
Insurance group 20
MPG 20
Engine 2.6 twin turbo
Driven wheels active 4WD
Power (bhp) 280
Max speed (mph) 155
0-60 (secs) 4.9

This is the one. This is the baby. If I had the kind of life and riches I believed I was destined for when I was an optimistic six-year-old, then this is the car I would buy. Sod all those classic autos (I've got one, and it drives me... nuts, round the twist, up the wall, anywhere but from A to B). Bin the cute soft-top baubles. Forget the marques of history and breeding. Go for the FASTEST, the SHOWIEST, the FLASHEST, most OBVIOUS AND EMBARRASSINGLY ANTI-ECOLOGICAL LOOK-AT-MY-WAGE-PACKET BIG FAT NOUVEAU RICHE AND PROUD TO SHOUT ABOUT IT STATUS SYMBOL money can buy. Oh yes. If, when your wife empties your pockets at the end of the day, she comes across a spare £54,000 in a brown envelope, then grab it off her and rush to the nearest Nissan showroom. And buy a Skyline.

Imagine if James Bond had been born an Essex Boy. This is his car. Goes like the clappers. Looks like the bollix. Low-slung, shiny, chunky-boy wide, Tonka Toy-wheeled, with a back spoiler like a 1980s coffee table, it turns heads and warps minds wherever you drive it. 'It's the best car I've ever seen,' breathed one friend. 'It looks like the future,' wibbled another. And another sat in the passenger seat for, ooh, about half a minute, before turning pink and murmuring, 'I think I've come.' (Ladies! Forget all that fancy-pants-lacy-bustiers palaver! Just dump him in a Nissan for a few seconds 'til he's hot, then drag him out and tell him to lie back and think of Lada.)

The Skyline GT-R is, essentially, a racing car. The splitter and spoiler and scrape-the-snails-off-the-pavement skirts provide enough down-force to keep you pinned to the road as though God's hand was keeping you there. But it's more than that. Cleverly, Nissan have combined genuine racing technology with boy-racer pizzazz. So the paintwork glistens like thick lipgloss - and covers everything, except mirror, lights, wheels and windows. The disc brakes are show-off yellow. The back lights are round and red. The lines are masculine (no over-curvy Ka-work here). And when you get in, you discover enough gizmos to keep you, Eddie 'Git' Irvine and poor old Q happy for hours. After all, if you've spent all this money, you want some look-at-me extras to show for it.

Switch on the engine and a screen flickers into life. Set above the central console, it zips between graphs, pie charts and strange Japanese phrases (which only come on when you press a button marked TV, and mean: If you want hardcore porn, you have to pre-pay. Or maybe not.) fields.headline: World Wine Web
fields.standfirst: A tasting workshop by Tim Atkin
fields.trailText: A tasting workshop by Tim Atkin
fields.body:
Number 58: Ruby Cabernet

What's the bottle? 1999 Plantation Ruby Cabernet, Stellenbosch

Price and stockist? £4.79 from Safeway

What's interesting about the wine? The result of a University of California crossing of Carignan and the signature grape of Bordeaux, this grape can be surprisingly enjoyable. The idea was to produce good quantities of a Cabernet-style, drinkable red in hot conditions. That's why you'll find it in California, but it's also planted in Australia and the Cape. Made by Kym Milne at Vinfruco, this is much better than most Cape Cabernet Sauvignon under £5.

What does the wine smell and taste like? Part of this wine finished its fermentation in French barrels (a New World technique), and the aromas of vanilla and toast are appealingly apparent on the nose. From its inky hue, you'd expect it to be monstrously tannic, but it's supple on the palate, with soft tannins and youthful blackcurrant fruit. It finishes on a faintly rustic note, but that's part of its appeal to me. This is an extremely distinctive grape.

What does it go with? Perhaps a tuna steak. Otherwise, meat, pasta and cheese dishes.

Serving temperature? 15°C to 18°C. You could try chilling this further to enhance its fruit character.

Will it keep? It's not meant to be cellared, but you could stick it in the wine rack for a year or two.

What are we tasting next week? 1997 Peter Lehmann Shiraz, Barossa Valley (£6.99, Sainsbury's, Waitrose)

Send your views to tim.atkin@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Blend of the affair
fields.standfirst: Which whisky will Robin McKie be drinking on Burns night? Only his own blend
fields.trailText: Which whisky will Robin McKie be drinking on Burns night? Only his own blend
fields.body:
People can be precious when it comes to whisky. While single malts acquire the status of ancient Armagnacs, blends - Bells, Famous Grouse, Johnny Walker and the like - are sidelined as drinks fit only for a drunk in a Glaswegian gutter.

Such dismissal is unfair. True denizens of the Sauchiehall Stree culverts prefer sweet South African sherry, or 'electric soup', as it is known. More to the point, blended whisky is not a drink to dismiss or swill back without appreciation. It is time, therefore, to reappraise the humble blend, particularly as Tuesday is Burns night, the whisky drinker's holiest day. What should he or she be drinking, and how should it be taken? Master blender Billy Walker, of Burn Stewart Distillers - whose 22-year-old Scottish Leader holds the 1999 International Spirits Challenge gold medal, the industry's top award - has firm views on such questions: you cannot beat a good blend.

To demonstrate this point, he laid out a table - at his company's Deanston distillery, near Stirling - that was groaning with bottles of different malts, as well as a couple of grain whiskies. 'Whisky was a local cottage industry until the 1850s,' he explained. 'The chosen spirit was cognac until disease destroyed the French vineyards, and so people turned to whisky.' But distilleries, each producing its own single malt, could not meet the increased demand, and so manufacturers added cheaper, lighter-grain whisky, thus giving birth to the Scotch whisky.

The trick is in the mixing of malt and grain. Over the decades, this undertaking has become something of an art. In a bid to understand it, I followed in Walker's wake, sniffing (but not tasting) the various malts: peaty ones from Islay; rich, sweet ones from the Highlands; slightly softer whiskies from Speyside; and light, dry malts from the Lowlands.

Although I naturally prefer Islay malts, Billy curbed my enthusiasm: only 3 per cent of blends contain these strongly iodine-tasting malts. Instead, I was directed to the lighter, drier end of the market, and in the end created a blend from: Highland Park, from Orkney; Tamdhu, from Speyside; Glenrothes, from the Lowlands; Deanston's own light, slightly fruity malt, and one or two others, as well as grain whisky. The end result was the Science Editor's blend, rated by Billy Walker as 'quite acceptable'. Of course, it was not Scottish Leader, nor is it Billy's favourite among his rivals, Bell's. These are true full-bodied blends, just what you want to compete with a spicy haggis. Drink them, not like cognac, sipped as a digestif, but in a tumbler with a little water (preferable bottled) to release the oils and flavours. The rest will be paradise.

In your report last week on Radio 4 Controller James Boyle's resignation, you included a quote from me, saying that the new Radio 4 was almost indistinguishable from the old. That sentence came from a review published the day after Radio 4 was relaunched, based on the first morning's programming. Since then I've been consistently critical of Boyle's schedule.
Anne Karpf, The Guardian
London EC1
