fields.headline: Readers' rights
fields.trailText: I agree with Edwina Curry when she says 'I think a man's private life should not be held to be an interference with his public duties' (Review 16 January). If, however, it is revealed during his term in office that he conducts his private life as a lying, cheating, deceitful, conniving bastard, then it might just make one a tad less keen to vote for him again when the time comes.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: The husband-and-wife architects behind the London Eye are used to career ups and downs. In the recession, David     Marks and Julia Barfield even turned to domestic work. Then David had a flash of inspiration...
fields.trailText: David     Marks | Julia Barfield
fields.body:
David Marks: We met as 19-year-old architecture students, in London in the early Seventies. We were living on opposite sides of the same street in Stockwell. We still live there, but on the same side now. Then we went to South America for 13 months. I got hepatitis, so Julia ended up working and looking after me. When we came back, we completed our course at the Architects' Association.

We didn't decide to get married until seven years later, on a trip to Mexico and Guatemala. It must have been the beautiful atmosphere: we swam with barracudas, and caught fresh lobster and cooked it on the beach. It was very romantic.

After leaving AA, we weren't making long-term plans. But we had to earn some money. At the time, there wasn't a lot of work in architects' offices. So we set up a model-making business. We worked for most of the big architects in London for a couple of years. It was very successful.

We both took alternate leadership roles. When Julia was doing models for one architect, she would be the person in charge of that client, handling all the accounts, the programming, the costings, making sure the resources were there to complete the models on time. And making them, working all hours. But we really wanted to be architects. We were both making models for Richard Rogers, and managed to switch roles to do architecture.

Julia worked at Richard Rogers' for two or three years, and then moved to work for Norman Foster. I stayed and worked on the Lloyds building. But when Lloyds came to an end, we discussed going it on our own. I left and tried to generate the work for our own business. I got in a few potential projects and persuaded Julia to give in her notice. It was difficult, because working at Foster's is a very clear career path. She was project leader for a new gallery at the Royal Academy of Arts and had the makings of a great future. Then one day, she came back and said, 'I've done it, I've handed in my notice.' I said, 'Great. We've got no work.'

But it was OK. Julia's greatest quality is her spirit of generosity, and she is a natural adventurist. I'm more of a dreamer.

She is more practical, more realistic. I'm the sort of person who would say, 'Come on, let's go to the moon,' and Julia would be the one to say, 'Where's the rocket?' And I'd say, 'Don't worry, I'll find one.'

It has never occurred to me whether I would be as successful without Julia. The strength of what we do is in doing it together. Our career has been a joint thing.

Julia Barfield: The day I gave in my notice at Foster's, all the potential projects that David had lined up disappeared. By that time we had our first child. So we had a young family and a young business growing at the same time. Generally, I always believe David. The belief is absolutely key - it is 150 per cent. And so far, it has paid off.

In 1989, we entered an ideas competition for a Bridge of the Future and won. It generated a lot of publicity and was a good springboard for new work. We were working from home, and we had 14 people working in the living room. Then we won a huge project costing £40 million. But the client insisted that we have a proper office. We managed to get the office and everything in it on the basis of our projected cash flow, we had signed all the leases, and within six weeks, this client said, 'The project's not going ahead.' He went bust and owed £300 million. And we didn't get paid. So from 14 people, we went back down to the two of us, trying to meet all the overheads.

But we never felt we had made a huge mistake. We knew that in due course things would get better. But it was the early Nineties and we were sitting in this office with enormous negative equity. We couldn't sell it. It was a nightmare.

We really had to pull together. We ended up working very long hours, doing whatever we could. Even the odd bit of domestic work. Everything except driving a mini-cab. I had just had our second baby and had to bring her into the office three weeks after she was born.

Then David came up with the idea for the wheel after seeing a competition in 1993 for millennium ideas. I thought it was a bit crazy. 'Barmy' was the word I used. But David's greatest quality is his imagination. We didn't win the competition; in fact, nobody won it. But it gave us the idea. Then in December 1994, it came to the attention of British Airways and we signed a deal with them in January 1995. We are both good persuaders.

We set up a company called The Millennium Wheel. I called up the local planning officer and said, 'It's a 500ft wheel in Jubilee Gardens. I've got the forms, but I don't know which fee to put down.' It is usually based on the square footage of the building. We jointly talked people into giving us planning permission. Some of the presentations David did, some I did. Our strengths are really pretty equal.

As the project developed, David took the lead. It took two and a half years to get planning permission. It was incredibly frustrating, because we knew the clock was ticking; we knew it was going to take two and a half years to construct.

Nobody had built capsules like this before, nobody had built a wheel with just one arm. We coped with that frustration by generating more ideas and more ways to get over the problem. We never felt like giving up.

I think what was achieved for New Year's Eve was immense. OK, it wasn't quite ready - but it was there, it was turning, it was looking fantastic. I didn't see it as a failure, personally. It was a disappointment, but it was great anyway. There's a huge amount of work still to be done. There are more than 20 tests that have to be done on each of the 32 capsules. It's a highly complex piece of machinery that requires exhaustive tests. So it's not quite ready, but it will be.

 Interview by Kim Bunce

fields.headline: Jury rigging
fields.trailText: One of the hallmarks of a fascist police state is the absence of trial by jury. Recent New Labour policies are taking us ever further in that direction.
fields.body:
One of the hallmarks of a fascist police state is the absence of trial by jury. Recent New Labour policies are taking us ever further in that direction.

The erosion of the jury trial principle, the asylum seekers bill, allowing companies to sell electric shock batons and other instruments of torture to the world's most evil regimes, a freedom of information act that spreads the cloak of secrecy so beloved by tyrants the world over. All policies for a new Britain where Straw's goons can drag young black men before the magistrates on trumped up charges and beaten out confessions, safe in the knowledge that a jury won't find them out.

His friend Pinochet must be proud of young Jack.
Mark Best
Otley, West Yorkshire

The erosion of the jury trial principle, the asylum seekers bill, allowing companies to sell electric shock batons and other instruments of torture to the world's most evil regimes, a freedom of information act that spreads the cloak of secrecy so beloved by tyrants the world over. All policies for a new Britain where Straw's goons can drag young black men before the magistrates on trumped up charges and beaten out confessions, safe in the knowledge that a jury won't find them out. His friend Pinochet must be proud of young Jack. Mark Best Otley, West Yorkshire

webTitle: The NHS is sick, but not with flu

fields.headline: The NHS is sick, but not with flu
fields.trailText: 'Hell on wheels' was The Porter's Tale (Focus, last week). Would that Chaucer was alive today to recount those other tales of degradation, courage and desperation that describe the NHS at this time.
fields.body:
'Hell on wheels' was The Porter's Tale (Focus, last week). Would that Chaucer was alive today to recount those other tales of degradation, courage and desperation that describe the NHS at this time. What John Sweeney writes is the truth. Having worked in the NHS for the last 18 years as a nurse, I know that the Government is lying when it says the flu epidemic has caused a crisis in the health service. The health service has been in crisis for many years. Crumbling, poorly maintained buildings are the cradle within which minimal staff, whether they be porters, cleaners, cooks, physios, secretaries, nurses or doctors, strive to provide some kind of service.
Lesley Barrow
Edinburgh

The drug companies must be rubbing their hands with glee at the prospect of the Government being bludgeoned into spending millions more on the NHS. Frankly I'm saddened that I haven't read of anyone asking the unthinkable: Do we need so many drugs?

My experience is that drugs for minor illnesses screw up a perfectly good immune system. When all three of my children were constantly coughing five years ago, asthma was diagnosed. I came home from the chemists with a carrier bag of steroid puffers. Cost? I have no idea. I didn't use them, I ran to a homeopath in desperation. The children all got better and we've never been back to the NHS.
S. Poole
Hove, East Sussex

fields.headline: Phil Hogan gets around
fields.trailText: It was very nice of my estimable chum Euan to put me up overnight on the sofa at his desirable waterside bachelor apartment even though he might have suspected that I am the kind of guest who would clean him out of Twiglets and insist on making buffalo-mating noises with   his saxophone at two in the morning, so   I suppose it is not exactly uncannily in anticipation of my own inebriate hijinks that he has mischievously arranged for Camden Council's refuse barge to come fog-horning past the back window at dawn to wake me up for my early train from King's Cross, which is apparently only minutes away if you have a helicopter.
fields.body:
It was very nice of my estimable chum Euan to put me up overnight on the sofa at his desirable waterside bachelor apartment even though he might have suspected that I am the kind of guest who would clean him out of Twiglets and insist on making buffalo-mating noises with his saxophone at two in the morning, so I suppose it is not exactly uncannily in anticipation of my own inebriate hijinks that he has mischievously arranged for Camden Council's refuse barge to come fog-horning past the back window at dawn to wake me up for my early train from King's Cross, which is apparently only minutes away if you have a helicopter.

Still, I'm up, oyster-eyed and managing to find the kitchen, and - blimey, there's coffee in the pot, though closer inspection of the site reveals it to be last Tuesday's, as evidenced by the adjacent presence of a carbon-dated foil container incorporating an ossified cigarette butt standing upright in a half-eaten Chinese takeaway and an empty whisky bottle where sticklers for household tradition might keep the washing-up liquid.

I pop my head round Euan's door. Needless to say, he is still snoring his head off under a beautiful new Terence Conran duvet with the cardboard still attached. Obviously it's a bit ungracious to wake your host up with his own wind instrument and to be honest I haven't really got the lungs for it, having used all my spare oxygen during the passive smoking semi-finals in the Coach and Horses last night, so pausing only to admire his living room, which he has had remodelled by a local, possibly unemployed, conceptual artist in the manner of Tracey Emin, I pick my way through the unusual, floor-mounted 'Jazz CDs with Three Socks' exhibit and out into the bright new morn.

My plan is to try out my ambitious new millennium experiment of attempting to establish eye contact with someone who works at a railway station kiosk, but immediately fail at WH Smith, whose staff think 'NEXT!' has taken over from 'thank you' in the English Tourist Board's step-by-step guide to what separates humans from the common stoat (retail edition). Still, I do emerge excitedly clutching this month's Men's Health magazine with its free 'Fat Burner's Bible' supplement and a promise to improve my sex life, presumably by ringing my wife and asking why she always goes to bed before the football has finished.

Fifteen minutes later I'm on the train, and naturally I am now myself in the market for a sustaining nap, but foolishly I have reserved a seat in a no sleeping carriage, which stipulates 75 per cent occupancy by mobile phone users with hearing difficulties and features Graham the amplified steward, who on behalf of the Great North Eastern Railways on-board team insists on wishing passengers a pleasant and comfortable journey every time I find myself dropping off, as well as providing a list of which snacks, beverages, light refreshments and Tennent's Extra-drinking football fans are available in the buffet in the part of the train furthest from the first-class dining amenities.

I get out of my seat, fragrantly situated next to the busiest toilet in the Group of Seven leading industrial countries, and proceed in a lurching zigzag movement to the buffet and back, before settling down to leaf through my Men's Health with a large Coke, double bacon bap and chocolate doughnut and learn about the benefits of having a tube inserted up your back passage for medicinal reasons and that if I watched just three more hours of television per day I could use up 1,500 calories a week simply by doing push-ups while the adverts were on. Now that's what I call knowing your readership.

The fields whizz by, and after what only seems like several hours Graham the steward is thanking us all for travelling on Great North Eastern Railways rather than choosing to come to Leeds via Eurotunnel, and pretty soon I'm safely in a taxi up to my in-laws, where I am supposed to be picking up my wife's mother's venerable Mini Metro to drive back down south so that my wife can borrow it indefinitely so she doesn't have to go to work on the train on Mondays and Tuesdays because obviously I tend to need our own car to pop out for a paper and a mid-morning flapjack.

Happily, my wife's mother is expecting me to the extent that she has put her teeth in for the occasion and opened a tin of soup. After lunch, she takes me out to see the car, which although built in medieval times has only ever been used to reverse in and out of the drive when the dustman comes. It is quite a novelty to drive a car which is not only brown but has a cranking handle to save you the bother of having to find your ignition key every time you want to go out, and soon I am flying down the motorway at speeds approaching 25 miles per hour.

Shouldn't take too long to get home. Though, obviously, having four gears would help.

fields.headline: Family business
fields.trailText: I read with interest yesterday Nigella Lawson's article 'Fine line twixt family and work'. In it she holds up an   advertisement I wrote for Brook Street as an example of today's harsh, anti-family work climate.
fields.body:
I read with interest yesterday Nigella Lawson's article 'Fine line twixt family and work'. In it she holds up an advertisement I wrote for Brook Street as an example of today's harsh, anti-family work climate. She quotes the line 'Waiting for home time? You're one your way out', but fails to mention that the ad goes on to say 'You choose the working life that suits your life.' This I think is Nigella's point.

To be fair, Ms Lawson does suggest the advertisement could be used in favour of watching the quality of your work not the clock. It is. I'm proud of my work. But I hate it when I can't get home in time for my son's bath.
Graham Pugh, Copywriter, Team Saatchi
London W1

webTitle: Come back King Alfred, all is forgiven

fields.headline: Come back King Alfred, all is forgiven
fields.trailText: Although I agree very much with Will Hutton's criticisms of this Government and its approach to politics and economics (Comment, last week), may I suggest that a written constitution, whether for Britain or the European Union, will have absolutely no appeal to the average British voter.
fields.body:
Although I agree very much with Will Hutton's criticisms of this Government and its approach to politics and economics (Comment, last week), may I suggest that a written constitution, whether for Britain or the European Union, will have absolutely no appeal to the average British voter.

The English, the majority of British voters, have no respect for intellectual abstractions, paper, or clever people. They are more likely to adopt a political framework based on the laws of tiddlywinks (I forbear to mention cricket) than on anything so rational as a written constitution.

Speaking as an expat Aussie of mixed European origins, I can perhaps speak objectively about the profound English preference for what works in practice. The abstractions and ideals of the French, or the technical minutiae of the German, constitutions are not the English way, which is particularist, illogical, pragmatic and preferably incomprehensible, except as a functioning system.

What we have does not work. The best option may be a return to the regional governments of the Anglo Saxon heptarchy - briefly Wessex, Mercia, East Anglia, Northumbria, Essex, Kent, Sussex. These divisions reflect real geographic, economic and cultural entities, as read 700AD or so. Notice especially that even then the South-East had disproportionate political and economic power. Cornwall and Wales are also regions, and Scotland a separate nation.

The other possibility is to become the fifty-second state of America (Ireland being the fifty-first, America's Trojan Horse in the EU) and it really depends on the quality of individual Englishmen and women, and their demons and aspirations, and not on pieces of paper, which option they will choose. It's clear that the foreign-owned media and its corporate allies will favour US-dominated 'banana republic' status in Britain - with a fig leaf or two - and we are some way down this path and that of hostility to the EU as a rival to the US.
Kamenka Algazi
Edinburgh

Barbara Ellen worries that 'England's colonial excesses make nationalism a dirty word' (Comment, last week) that will be doomed to be forever hijacked by the far Right. May I suggest that any prospective English nationalists on the Centre or Left by-pass this guilt by adopting the methods that have been long favoured by Scottish nationalists. Simply pretend that colonialism and imperialism were all someone else's doing and that you had nothing whatsoever to do with it.
Stephen Connor
Kirriemuir, Angus

webTitle: Is one not quite as desperate?

fields.headline: Is one not quite as desperate?
fields.trailText: In reply to Jay Rayner's article about New Singletons, please allow me a moment of 'smug marrieds' reflection on the piece.
fields.body:
In reply to Jay Rayner's article about New Singletons, please allow me a moment of 'smug marrieds' reflection on the piece.

The more New Singletons there are, the more opportunities there are for market forces to rule their lives... divide and rule to use a well worn phrase. If you are alone, emotionally starved, content but not quite happy you will want toys. These can be anything from comfort food, CDs, computers, cars or just trips out. You are an ideal target for the marketeer who will sell a material idea or concept to fill the emotional void.

Now I am not pretending that married people do not indulge in materialism too, but the 'quiet desperation', as Pink Floyd might have put it, is perhaps not so strong. They are carried through by good old fashioned 'luuurve'.

Let's face it, singledom, however you dress it up, is a waiting room on the way to coupledom, whether you get married or live together. After all, where's the adventure in talking to yourself?
Jeremy Lamond
Shrewsbury

The article concerning 'New Singletons' (Review, 16 January) stated that '30 per cent of households today are occupied by one person'. What the article failed to clarify was what proportion of this figure is made up of the young, single affluent people described. Sociologically, the biggest, and fastest growing group of 'single person households' is made up of the elderly living alone, and a combination of divorce and longer life expectancy mean the greatest number of these are women.
Suzan Dury
London SE26

fields.headline: Rape is wrong
fields.trailText: If, as Sandra Horley of Refuge believes (16 Jan), 'Rape is about power and control, not about sex', how do we explain the fact that rape, by definition, always involves a sexual act? Disputing whether rape is about violence or sex is a waste of time.
fields.body:
If, as Sandra Horley of Refuge believes (16 Jan), 'Rape is about power and control, not about sex', how do we explain the fact that rape, by definition, always involves a sexual act? Disputing whether rape is about violence or sex is a waste of time.

The search for causes in men's biological nature should not be interpreted as an attempt to mitigate rape. The possibility that aggression is rooted in primal human nature does not make it less punishable, since aggressors are punished not for having aggressive instincts but for submitting to them.
R. Canning
Bridge of Earn, Perthshire

fields.body:
Oliver Morgan (Business, last week) repeats claims made by others that British soldiers experienced problems with their SA-80 rifles jamming when they moved into Kosovo last August.

But the comments related to the light machine gun version of the SA-80. Claims about SA-80 rifles jamming are in fact recycled from events which took place in the Gulf war nine years ago.
Martin Howard, Ministry of Defence
London SW1

fields.headline: 'Trash' canned
fields.trailText: Darcus Howe's comments (Interview, 9 January) about Oldham are ill founded, intolerant, meaninglessly judgmental and stereotypical. Above all they are extremely offensive.
fields.body:
Darcus Howe's comments (Interview, 9 January) about Oldham are ill founded, intolerant, meaninglessly judgmental and stereotypical. Above all they are extremely offensive.

Certainly there is some evidence of racial tension but Oldham is no different from any other town where there is a mix of communities. The term 'white trash' will be offensive not just to those to whom it refers living in one of the country's most deprived wards but to people across the whole borough, including those who live less than three miles away in some of England's wealthiest council wards.
Councillor John Battye
Mayor of Oldham

fields.headline: Primal therapy
fields.standfirst: Bobby Gillespie's Primal Scream barely survived their Nineties period of excess. Their new album, though, is a deeper exploration of the rock'n'roll myth, fuelled not by drugs but by righteous anger
fields.trailText: Bobby Gillespie's Primal Scream barely survived their Nineties period of excess. Their new album, though, is a deeper exploration of the rock'n'roll myth, fuelled not by drugs but by righteous anger
fields.body:
The singer, Bobby Gillespie, arrives first. His newly shorn hair accentuates his thin, pale face, his darkly shadowed eyes, but it also, perversely, makes him look 10 years younger. He is edgy and animated. He orders mineral water - 'I hate alcohol, it's too messy' - and, despite his slight frame and pale skin, appears relatively fit and healthy, at least by the rock'n'roll standards his group have, in the past, done their utmost to uphold. Almost immediately, he starts talking about music, enthusing about a Royal Trux show a few nights before, about a recent Iggy Pop gig that blew him away. His enthusiasm for all things rock'n'roll - 'not rock, mind, but rock'n'roll; there's a big difference' - is evangelical, undimmed by time and experience. More than anyone, Bobby Gillespie epitomises the spirit, the essence of Primal Scream.

Close on his heels comes Gary Mounfield, better known as Mani, late of the Stone Roses, Brit-rock's greatest underachievers. Mani still sports a Madchester floppy fringe, grins a lot, and seems Zen happy for a bass player, an occupation that, in my experience, seems to attract individuals of a more stoical, long-suffering bent. He orders beer and takes over when Bobby's eulogy to Iggy finally winds down - 'It were awesome. The best rock'n'roll show I've seen since Motörhead seven years ago.' High praise indeed. Missing in action is Andrew Innes, guitarist, engineer and, it would seem, anchorman of the occasionally anarchic but remarkably durable organism that is Primal Scream. Something to do with the previous night's excesses which apparently culminated earlier around midday. 'Someone,' says Gillespie, only half-jokingly, 'is always carrying the flag.'

These days, the Primal Scream flag is not the rallying symbol it was around the time of 1991's Screamadelica album, when the groups dance-rock anthems - 'Higher than the Sun' and 'Movin' On Up' - perfectly caught the wild and heady tenor of those Ecstasy-fuelled times. Nor, though, is it the ragged and tattered thing that flew at half-mast from about 1992 until 1995, when the band almost self-immolated on bad drugs and trad-rock, looking and sounding like a ghostly pastiche of the Rolling Stones circa 1973. No, these days Primal Scream, despite the welter of recognisable influences apparent on their fired-up, wired-up new album, Exterminator, are very much a law unto themselves, flying an almost lone flag for passion and politics, making a music that manages to merge their undimmed punk attitude with a techno-heavy, post-rock sturm und drang. Not quite zeitgeist music, but utterly, unapologetically modern all the same.

Exterminator could be viewed as a natural progression from 1997's Vanishing Point but only insofar as it manages, in some places, to sound even more malevolent and, in others, even more experimental. Buoyed by mixes from the likes of the Chemical Brothers and David Holmes, and featuring guest appearances by Kevin Shields (late of My Bloody Valentine) on the scorching 'Accelerator' and erstwhile Can drummer Jaki Liebezeit, it crackles with pent-up energy and focused aggression.

The album is, unsurprisingly, a heady brew, wide-ranging and intense; difficult to absorb in one sitting. 'I think both this album and the last one are the results of the stock taking we did back in 1995,' Gillespie elaborates between sips of mineral water in a Soho bar, 'when we took a year and a half off just to refocus. We all listened to loads of different music, from country to punk to glam to disco, just reigniting the flame. I suppose that has spilled into our own stuff, but I think there's a purity about the new stuff, too. It's direct. It's righteous.'

It is also, it can't be overstated, as angry as hell. Hence the album title, which, though it might sit more easily on a Metallica or Motörhead release, does, in its brutal nihilistic way, speak volumes about some of the subject matter of the songs - though outbursts might be a better description - therein. Songs like 'Kill All Hippies', or 'Swastika Eyes', or 'Shoot Speed Kill Light', or, my own personal favourite, 'Insect Royalty'. In places, the record seems shot through with the spirit of Seventies punk, the kind of raw, gut-level frustration and disgust at the world that Rotten and Strummer fed off and spat out. 'We still think of ourselves as a punk band because that's where we started from,' Gillespie tells me, calmly, 'but the anger is more to do with writing about what we see, and what we see is people being betrayed, being dumped on by a government that was meant to be an alternative to Toryism but is simply a continuation of it. If there's a lot of anger on this record, it's the anger of the betrayed.'

On more than one level, then, Primal Scream are the last of the true believers. They believe, in no particular order, in the transformative power of rock'n'roll, in the core principles of punk - passion, energy, polemic - and in the politics of protest and dissent. Any one of those beliefs is enough to make them seem old-fashioned in a world where both politics and pop are caught in a dull consensus of uniformity and overt careerism, but, to their credit, they seem unconcerned by the fact that they are out of step with the culture that produced them. 'We're a working-class band,' Mani tells me touchingly at one point. 'We might live in nice houses, but in here (slaps his heart), the fire still burns.'

And yet that myth seems, at the beginning of this new century, to be, if not dead on its feet, at least staggering under the weight of its unfulfilled promise.

He's like a shaman, a Red Indian warrior, a minotaur and Nijinksky all rolled into one. It's like being hit by lightning. Have you noticed that? They're passable or they're technicians, but nobody's hitting those strings like Keef or Jimmy Page. There's no attitude, no magic.'

Together, they went to see their first gig: Thin Lizzy, Glasgow Barrowlands, 1975.

'At the time, it was great,' Gillespie remembers, 'but that kind of fame is always a bit destabilising. We were just being ourselves but we were in the thick of it, too. Everybody wants to hang out with you - the parties were mad anyway, but they were getting madder. Even by our standards, we were right out there.'

A feature in the music magazine Select described a post-gig bash where cocaine, Ecstasy, amphetamines, magic mushrooms and crystal methedrine were in ready supply alongside the cannabis and Jack Daniels. Stories circulated, too, about their wilfully dissolute rock'n'roll lifestyle: Andrew Innes thrown out of Gracelands in Memphis for, as a press release succinctly put it, 'vomiting copiously on the lawn'; Innes calling the late River Phoenix, who had died from a multiple drug overdose, 'a lightweight'. The blade missed his kidney by a fraction of an inch.

As omens go, it was a salutary one: things were going badly awry, the energy that had characterised Screamadelica now dissipated by increasingly hard drug use and a musical retreat into traditionalism. The follow-up, 1994's Give Out But Don't Give Up, was the best Rolling Stones record in ages. Recorded in Memphis with the cream of the city's older musicians in attendance, it was, though, too close to pastiche to be truly powerful. Primal Scream had lost their way.

When I met the band in New York in the winter of 1994, they were in bad shape, physically and psychologically, and I would not have bet on them staying together for longer than six months. 'You caught us at a bad time, but it got a whole lot worse before it got better,' the ever-candid Gillespie explains. 'Halfway through '92, the rot set in. Cocaine and speed. Then, by Christmas, it was heroin. In '93, we tried to record Give Out..., but it was a disaster. Too many hangers-on in the studio, everybody waiting for the man to come. We were strung out, or smacked out. There was alcohol and speed, too.'

How bad did it get, exactly? Mani says nowt; Gillespie looks at the floor. 'Pretty bad. Three of the band were addicted to heroin; the management, assistant management, crew, mates were all involved. I'd say 20 people in all. It was a collective thing, and that's the messiest scene of all.'

And how did you dig your way out? 'Me and Innes wised up at the same time. We just got sick of the shit, and decided to walk away from it. The music was coming second to the drug-taking. We did a 22-week tour of the States. It was debilitating, too one-dimensional. I remember thinking, "I don't want to do this any more. We have to change or die." Basically, we took a year and a half off, deconstructed Primal Scream, got the man here on board, and started again.' Mani grins his big grin and nods his agreement.

It suddenly strikes me that, following the Stone Roses' messy split, it must have been a bit of a risk to jump on board the mystery train that is Primal Scream, particularly when, like his previous group, they had helped define a time, then utterly lost the plot. 'It were a bit funny at the start, but I'm a big believer in karma. You end up where you're meant to be. With the Roses, it was like we had the world at our feet but it didn't happen. You know why? Cos we couldn't get out of bed at the same time. That's what happens if you let things slide. This lot aren't letting things slide any more.' He looks at Bobby, punches the air, and shouts: 'The spark's been relit!'

The energy and adventurousness of Exterminator would seem to bear out the Mancunian survivor's ever-positive overview, but barely a week before the interview took place, news leaked out that Alan McGee was jettisoning Creation, the label he made in his image to house the likes of Oasis, the Primals and a host of other increasingly eccentric signings. In the music press, the news was reported as an end-of-an-era story, which, in many ways, it is. Oasis are doing a Beatles and setting up their own label; Primal Scream, with two albums still owed to Sony, Creation's mother label, are waiting nervously to see what happens next.

'We could always communicate our ideas to Alan and Dick Green at Creation,' says Gillespie. 'Dick even re-mortgaged his house to help put Screamadelica out, but who knows what will happen with the suits at Sony. We're going to wait and see. It might work out and it might be total war. Whatever, we're ready and fightin' fit! We have our own studio, and we'll make music whatever happens. I mean, look at us,' he adds, laughing. 'I mean, what else could we do?'

Outsiders, misfits, malcontents, magicians: Primal Scream are all of these, and more; would that there were more like them right now in that otherwise wretched place called rock'n'roll.

fields.headline: Tolerance is cardinal sin
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The row over Section 28, or 2A in Scotland, has been bizarre but fascinating, and even comic. The repeal of a statute which stigmatises a minority is going through without much comment in England. In Scotland it has raised a storm fed by tabloid hysteria and the spare cash of Stagecoach boss Brian Souter.
fields.body:
The row over Section 28, or 2A in Scotland, has been bizarre but fascinating, and even comic. The repeal of a statute which stigmatises a minority is going through without much comment in England. In Scotland it has raised a storm fed by tabloid hysteria and the spare cash of Stagecoach boss Brian Souter.

The most curious aspect of the affair has been the behaviour of Cardinal Winning. This prince of the church has shown a marked lack of charity to those not of heterosexual persuasion or nature. The persecution of homosexuals, of course, has been the hallmark of some of the most unpleasant regimes thrown up by modern history. I have read his comments with genuine sadness for they seem out of character.

Furthermore, the cardinal's behaviour has inevitably acquired the appearance of opportunism. He apparently was consulted by Donald Dewar before the intention to repeal the Act was announced, and, according to some accounts, indicated there would be no problem.

Then the spin doctors complicated the tale. They gave the story to two favoured newspapers, hoping to make a sweetheart deal in which exclusivity would be traded for a sympathetic treatment. Such deals may be made in good faith by the journalists involved but are not binding on their editors. The Daily Record 's coverage, in particular, misrepresented the repeal as a licence for the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

This was based on a syllogism which, I dimly remember from my student days, is exemplified by the following: All men are fools, therefore all fools are men. To remove a law banning the promotion of homosexuality was to endorse its promotion, ran the fallacious critique.

But the Record campaign touched a nerve of social conservatism in Scotland, and stimulated a large postbag for MSPs. The affair descended into farce when Souter's PR adviser, Jack Irvine of Media House, claimed the support of various celebrities on the strength of a hoax fax which his company had not troubled to check before noising it abroad.

My impression is that the liberal consensus, involving Labour, Lib Dems and most of the SNP, is holding firm. As usual, the outbursts of intolerance were blamed by some commentators on the hang-ups of a largely presbyterian past and so it was with genuine pleasure that I read on Wednesday that the moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland had spoken uncompromisingly in favour of the Executive's plan for repeal.

The Rt Rev John Cairns asked if it was seriously being proposed that sex education should omit all mention of homosexuality. If so, he rightly said, 'that seems to be a ludicrous situation.' Mr Cairns immediately encountered some criticism from members of his own church. But that is fine; the moderator is primus inter pares and speaks in his own name.

But the Church of Scotland has often suffered because the moderator is in office only for a year and has no time to make any kind of impact. Mr Cairns has reversed that trend and has expressed what seems a more Christian and compassionate view of homosexuality.

The affair, of course, marks a further stage in the slow rupture between the Catholic Church and the Labour Party. Other things which once seemed inviolable are going too. Dewar faces huge opposition to the promise to introduce PR for council elections but seems determined to press ahead.

The Scottish Parliament, by its very existence, has increased the vigour of our national conversation. But I hope it keeps its nerve and has the courage to repeal a statute which is as offensive as it is useless. In France more than 12,000 people, mainly gay couples, have signed up for the new civil pacts since they became available by law last October. This doesn't seems to have caused the end of civilisation. Rather these is an act of social and political generosity which may have made many people happier.

This doesn't seems to have caused the end of civilisation. Rather these is an act of social and political generosity which may have made many people happier.

fields.headline: Drug buddies
fields.trailText: The American Presidential race is in danger of becoming a bore before it has properly started. The wild cards, John McCain and Bill Bradley, are expected to bow out, leaving Al Gore and George Bush to slug it out between them. One outcome seems certain. Whichever of them secures the White House, America will have a President who has admitted experimenting with drugs and who has unequivocally 'inhaled'.
fields.body:
The American Presidential race is in danger of becoming a bore before it has properly started. The wild cards, John McCain and Bill Bradley, are expected to bow out, leaving Al Gore and George Bush to slug it out between them. One outcome seems certain. Whichever of them secures the White House, America will have a President who has admitted experimenting with drugs and who has unequivocally 'inhaled'.

A historic opportunity presents itself. An honest account by a Presidential candidate of his experience of drugs can but throw light onto a debate that has been closed for far too long at the highest levels - the search for alternatives to criminalising users. To avoid this reckoning would be hypocrisy of the worst kind.

fields.headline: Limping liberty
fields.trailText: It was a good week for women. Judy Owen, sent home by her employers, the Professional Golf Association, for wearing trousers, won her sex discrimination case and Kay Swinburne - whose boss publicly accused her of sleeping with a male client - won her case against Deutsche Bank.
fields.body:
It was a good week for women. Judy Owen, sent home by her employers, the Professional Golf Association, for wearing trousers, won her sex discrimination case and Kay Swinburne - whose boss publicly accused her of sleeping with a male client - won her case against Deutsche Bank.

This week the Office for National Statistics will go further and dub the past hundred years the 'women's century'. Advances in voting rights, income, legal status, education and employment opportunities will all be cited in evidence. This is all good news, but we should be wary of premature euphoria. Women still earn only 80 per cent as much as men. Boardrooms remain boys' clubs. Women who have children lose half their lifetime earnings.

Even the inroads that women have made need to be balanced against broader trends which, if anything, seem to indicate regression. Lap-dancing clubs are springing up across our cities. What does this say about prevailing male attitudes? In our use of language, too, there are signs of backtracking. In Britain it is de rigeur to scoff at US political correctness, at rules for office language and behaviour. But the atmosphere of the workplace, inevitably set by largely male managers, matters hugely. It is time that men in positions of power recognised the way the wind is blowing. It is time to take issues of behaviour between men and women seriously. Then there might be something to really celebrate.

webTitle: Gisele finds fame - and sells fashion

fields.headline: Gisele finds fame - and sells fashion
fields.trailText: Enter Gisele Bundchen, a 19-year-old Brazilian model who, in the past six months, has turned the fashion industry on its head and almost singlehandedly portrayed a more curvaceous, healthy ideal of beauty - plus, at 36-24-35, cleavage.
fields.body:
Once there were a handful of women - Naomi, Cindy, Claudia, Linda - so famous they were known by first names. They ruled the empires of fashion and beauty. And then they were gone, supplanted by nameless rail-thin 'waifs' whose looks and postures suggested fashion might, after all, be bad for your health.

Enter Gisele Bundchen, a 19-year-old Brazilian model who, in the past six months, has turned the fashion industry on its head and almost singlehandedly portrayed a more curvaceous, healthy ideal of beauty - plus, at 36-24-35, cleavage.

Gisele's achievement - to lead fashion out of what many see as a dour, minimalist period - has been rewarded with an unheard-of triple, featuring on the covers of the three big US fashion magazines, Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and W, in the same month. Vogue seems smitten with the 5ft 11in, 115lb model, naming her model of 1999 and placing her on its cover four times in as many months.

As the magazine pointed out, 'pretty much everybody in the world wants Gisele to look good on his or her behalf'. And that includes the fashion designers, who place her in pole position in catwalk shows and are prepared to pay millions for Gisele to star in advertising campaigns. Open the magazines and you find page after page of Giselle, employed by Ver sace, Ralph Lauren, Dolce & Gabbana and Valentino.

The great-great-granddaughter of German immigrants to Brazil, Gisele grew up as one of five sisters in a village in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul. On her first trip to Sao Paulo, while eating her first McDonald's, she was approached by a modelling agent and, despite resistance from her father, moved to the city aged 14 to pursue a career.

Her big break came modelling for Alexander McQueen. Soon top photographers were booking her. Then came an issue of the hyper-trendy magazine BIG devoted exclusively to her that, in turn, secured ascendance to the closest thing the world now has to the supermodel, a woman who sells magazines and clothes with face and figure alone.

'She's just a very good model,' says New York stylist Andrew Richardson. 'She turns up on time, she hasn't been out all night doing drugs, she's just committed and sensible.'

Refreshingly, Gisele has no Hollywood dreams, no difficult books by her bedside, no spells in detox. She talks of having children, horses, chickens and dogs on a farm, like her grandparents had in Brazil.

And to the interest of men everywhere, she has no public paramour besides Vida, her Yorkshire terrier. 'No sex-drugs-rock'n'roll,' she recently told Vanity Fair . 'I don't want to look back and feel I did everything wrong.'

webTitle: Drugs giant uses spies to vet 'lefties'

fields.headline: Drugs giant uses spies to vet 'lefties'
fields.standfirst: Secret agents keep French firm union-free
fields.trailText: A leading European pharmaceuticals company secretly employs a team of former military intelligence agents to vet job applicants, including Britons, and rejects any who do not meet its criteria for race, religion, sexual orientation or political conviction.
fields.body:
A leading European pharmaceuticals company secretly employs a team of former military intelligence agents to vet job applicants, including Britons, and rejects any who do not meet its criteria for race, religion, sexual orientation or political conviction.

Documents seen by The Observer show that Servier, France's third-largest drugs company and one of the top 10 in Europe, with annual sales of £900 million, uses one-time operatives from the French secret services DST and DGSE - equivalent to MI5 and MI6 - to weed out non-whites, gays, Jews and anyone suspected of left-wing sympathies.

The group's policy, which contravenes civil liberties and employment legislation in most of the 120-plus countries in which it operates, has been so successful it is the only company of its size in France - where 6,000 of its 13,000 employees are based - to have no union representation.

According to a former military attaché who worked for Servier for nearly a decade, the vetting system is run from the company's headquarters in the Paris suburb of Neuilly by a woman who formerly worked at Arco, the French government agency responsible for finding civilian jobs for retiring servicemen. The confidential documents indicate that 32 operatives, most of them former colonels, generals or admirals from the DGSE, DST or French army, navy and air force intelligence services, are on Servier's books as 'consultants', handling between them 1,300 applications a year.

They are paid £50,000-£60,000 each a year to travel the world, vetting candidates from secretaries to chief researchers. The illegal vetting operation is thought to cost the privately owned company £40m a year. Every applicant is asked to fill in an unusually detailed form stating the age, sex, occupation and employer of their parents, children and siblings.

'That gives the investigators a good start,' said the Observer source, a retired army colonel recently fired for questioning the company's directives. 'If any of the brothers or sisters or parents are teachers, for example, that could indicate leftist sympathies.'

One Frenchwoman was rejected for a job in the marketing department for the reason, underlined in red on the company's Candidate Analysis Sheet, that 'her father was a production worker at Renault', the French carmaker known at one stage for its militant workers. Another dossier seen by The Observer concerns a Polish woman turned down for a job as secretary at Servier's Warsaw subsidiary because her father had served in the chancellery of a former Polish President, and the daughter was thought likely to be Communist.

Candidates are asked for three professional and three personal or character referees. These are questioned minutely but tactfully, with the most important criterion being political belief. In another case seen by The Observer, involving a Cambridge-educated Englishwoman applying to the company's UK offices in Staines, Middlesex, for a post as chief doctor on an international project, the investigator's verdict was favourable. 'The candidate's political convictions are clearly conservative,' the conclusion states. 'Elitist like her entourage, her style and opinions are incompatible with socialism ... Her devotion to the company is assured.'

A German woman was given a resoundingly positive verdict with the comment that 'her family's origins are military and aristocratic'.

Servier also discriminates on religious and racial grounds. The source, who spent five years hiring the first 90 staff taken on at the company's Russian subsidiary, said he was given 'clear instructions not to hire Jews, and if possible only Russian Orthodox Christians'.

A Swiss woman was rejected because 'her environment does not correspond with company interests'. It is clear from her file that the objection was that her husband was African. The report states: 'This black, who was able to enter Switzerland thanks to the marriage, has not been marked by civilisation.'

If the company wants more information it may turn to the French secret services for what is known inside Servier as a 'complementary analysis'. According to the source, this has revealed key facts on at least one occasion - for example, a past membership of the Communist Party that a candidate had tried to conceal. There is also substantial evidence that, in exchange for such information, Servier's vetting network is used for illegal spying missions - particularly in Russia - by the DGSE, France's foreign counter-espionage service.

'I was twice asked to do this kind of work at lunches held in the villa of Jacques Servier, the company's founder,' said the source. 'A DGSE colonel whom I knew was present. I was replaced in Russia by three former officers in army, navy and air force intelligence. They are not just working for Servier.'

The company's spokesman, Michel Hannoun, a former MP from the Gaullist RPR party, denies running an illegal vetting service, saying 'there is no investigation into the private lives of the laboratory's staff'.

That will now be put to the test. A complaint against Servier - based on a tip-off filed last year in the district court at Nanterre, near Paris, by the National Commission on Freedom and Data - alleged specifically that the company had kept on its database of 50,000 dossiers records of a candidate's sexuality.

A court spokeswoman said the police investigation was now complete, and the case is expected to be heard within the next few months.

fields.headline: Ahern's rural journey pays off
fields.trailText: Bertie Ahern took his Cabinet on a rural journey last week. Ministers travelled to Ballaghadreen, a small town in Co Roscommon, for the first ever Cabinet meeting outside Dublin.
fields.body:
Bertie Ahern took his Cabinet on a rural journey last week. Ministers travelled to Ballaghadreen, a small town in Co Roscommon, for the first ever Cabinet meeting outside Dublin.

The point was to emphasise the Prime Minister's commitment to the regions and, in particular, to the west of Ireland, which has suffered terribly from the effects of mass emigration and political neglect.

A new development plan has been announced for the area, which provides for a IR£3.6 billion investment strategy in infrastructure, aimed at attracting hi-tech industries and tourism to reverse more than 150 years of population decline.

The plan is about developing not only the west, but the midland and border counties, economically damaged by violence in Northern Ireland.

Ballaghadreen - population 1,250 - is not equipped for state occasions. One of the objectives of the Cabinet's journey was to allow elected representatives from the area and members of the Western Development Commission to meet Ministers and express concerns. The only place large enough to accommodate this was the canteen of a local school. But this did not dull the enthusiasm of locals who questioned Cabinet Ministers about roads, education, employment and more.

Inevitably, when the excursion to Ballaghadreen was announced there were jeers of derision in Dublin. Some dismissed the Cabinet's trip as 'patronising', others saw it as a typical PR exercise by Ahern, designed to divert attention from the real problems of rural poverty. The meeting's timing did not allow this. It coincided with mass demonstrations by farmers protesting at the low prices being paid by beef-processing plants for cattle. Ahern and Co were greeted by farmers, and other citizens protesting about everything from flooding of the River Shannon to local dump plans.

In spite of all this, the mood in Ballaghadreen was one of satisfaction. There was a readiness to believe that a goodwill gesture could result in positive gains for an area which has long suffered neglect.

In many ways, this Cabinet meeting typifies what is most attractive - and effective - about Ahern as a politician. An unmistakable Dubliner, he has a sure feeling what pleases ordinary people. The meeting in Ballaghadreen gave people in an area long ignored by government a chance to talk to senior Ministers.

Ahern was once described by Charles Haughey as 'the most devious and cunning' of all politicians he knew. He is also clever enough not to come across like that. His unassuming style has stood him in good stead.

Recent weeks have brought problems - public dissatisfaction with the budget, farmers on the streets, a concern that the Northern Ireland peace process could unravel. Yet a poll in the Irish Times last week showed the Government's approval rating has risen by nine points, to 55 per cent, since last November.

Why is it that opposition parties cannot lay a glove on Ahern, despite revelations of sleaze in high places and other problems? On issues which have caused difficulties, like the budget, the answer is that most people are prepared to blame the responsible Minister rather than the Taoiseach.

Even on the North, Ahern cannot fail. In the past, Unionist politicians blamed counterparts in the republic for their woes. David Trimble was in Dublin last Friday, after his angry attack on Tony Blair over the Patten report. After meeting Ahern, Trimble said he had drawn a lot of encouragement on the good relationship which had developed between the Irish Government and the new executive in Belfast.

Ahern's real test on Northern Ireland will come in the next few weeks, when unionists and nationalists will both be watching anxiously to see if he can persuade the IRA to decommission. His Foreign Minister, David Andrews, has announced he is to resign.

This will mean that Ahern is likely to become even more involved in trying to persuade Unionists to be patient, while at the same time putting pressure on Gerry Adams and Sinn Fein on the arms issue. That will be no bad thing. The Irish Prime Minister is adept at soft words, but can wield the big stick when he has to.

fields.headline: Loggers release British hostage
fields.standfirst: A British woman last night told how she was captured by illegal loggers in Indonesia. She gave an exclusive interview to  John Aglionby  in Borneo
fields.trailText: A British woman last night told how she was captured by illegal loggers in Indonesia.
fields.body:
When one of Faith Doherty's kidnappers slammed a custom-made revolver down on the table in front of her, the British environmentalist thought she was about to be shot.

Her Indonesian colleague Ruwi was already covered in blood, having been punched until he collapsed and then repeatedly kicked in the head. Doherty was in agony, a finger having been dislocated in an assault. The posse of screaming and shouting thugs was becoming increasingly violent.

'I thought we were going to die,' said the 39-year-old researcher with the British and US-based Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA). 'I really thought they were going to kill us.'

The gun was not fired, but a terrifying 48-hour hostage drama in the wilds of the jungle in Indonesian Borneo was only just beginning.

It had all the hallmarks of a thriller: two environmental groups were taking on a baddie worthy of a James Bond film who has been ruthlessly riding roughshod over the local authorities to tear down thousands of square miles of rainforest.

In cameo roles are an Indonesian government minister, the World Bank, the British ambassador, a handful of concerned detectives and dozens of hired thugs.

'We were kidnapped, we were assaulted, we were held hostage, we were constantly terrorised and intimidated,' Doherty told The Observer in an exclusive interview yesterday as she and Ruwi enjoyed their freedom again, in Banjarmasin, a large city on the island's south coast.

The story began last June when the EIA and Telapak, an Indonesian environmental group published The Final Cut , a report into illegal logging in two of Indonesia's national parks that are home to the majority of the world's orangutans.

Among those singled out was Abdul Rasyid, an illegal logger in central Kalimantan (the Indonesian half of Borneo) with an air of false respectability earned by getting himself elected to the parliament in Jakarta.

Through his network of sawmills, plywood and mouldings factories, palm oil plantations, barges, tugboats and cargo ships, Rasyid has turned thousands of square miles into his personal fiefdom called Tanjung Lingga.

As the report and this week's hostage crisis show, the local authorities are helpless in the face of his overt bullying tactics backed by enormous financial wealth.

Concerned about the huge depletion of Indonesia's rainforests - illegal logging outstrips legal felling according to one recent study - the World Bank is holding a forestry seminar next week, in advance of crucial talks between the Indonesian gov ernment and international aid donors.

Ruwi, Telepak's executive director, was invited to give a presentation and wanted to update his data. So he and Faith returned to Tanjung Putting National Park in central Kalimantan last Monday. Making no attempt to hide their identities, the two entered Rasyid's sawmill to assess the level of theft from the park.

'The security guards asked us what we were doing and we explained we wanted to see Mr Rasyid,' Doherty said.

Doherty and Ruwi were collected by three large men from their hotel. 'They were very friendly,' she said. 'We had no idea what was about to happen.'

After arriving at the Tanjung Lingga head office in Pangkalan Bun, they were met by Mr Rasyid's nephew Sugianto. Along with some of his colleagues, Sugianto started berating his 'guests' for the contents of the report. One of the bodyguards explained that The Final Cut ' had cost Tanjung Lingga billions of dollars.

Then the company's general manager, a woman named Een, took over. 'She went on and on and on at Ruwi,' Doherty said. 'Shouting, talking, prodding pointing. She then took her shoe off and started hitting him over the head with it.'

Eventually the police arrived but that only ended the initial physical torture. Two nights of mental anguish were about to begin.

Cooped up in the police station from Thursday evening, it soon became clear that Rasyid's influence extended to the local police chief. Interrogations went on throughout Thursday night.

'We were also given no food,' said Ruwi, 'just a cup of sweet tea.' The following morning the senior detective said the two exhausted prisoners could go. But as they were about to leave Col Coto arrived with a local TV crew in tow and blocked the move.

'It was the lowest moment of the two days,' said Doherty. 'I really thought we were going to go. At that point we became hostages again.'

The police were at the company's beck and call. The loggers demanded that the environmentalists apologise for the report and retract everything they had said in it.

webTitle: Why the West must swallow gene foods

fields.headline: Why the West must swallow gene foods
fields.standfirst:
They're boycotted by British shoppers, and this week an international conference will decide if trade in GM organisms should be controlled. But many scientists believe they are the solution to starvation in the Third World, reports Robin McKie
GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Consider the tomato - so much a part of everyday life that we hardly notice it. Yet it has a murky past, and it is one that scientists should note carefully.
fields.body:
Consider the tomato - so much a part of everyday life that we hardly notice it. Yet it has a murky past, and it is one that scientists should note carefully.

In the nineteenth century, the tomato was known as the wolf's peach, and Europeans and Americans believed it was deadly poisonous. In 1820, New York forbade its consumption and only relented when Colonel Robert Johnston announced that he would eat an entire bag of them outside the courthouse in Salem, New Jersey. Two thousand people turned up to watch him die, while a band played a funeral march. But Johnston ate the lot and announced: 'This luscious, scarlet apple will form the foundation of a great garden industry.'

For such prescience, Johnson deserves canonisation as the patron saint of hothouses, though his story has far more than historical importance, for it shows there is nothing new in misplaced hysteria about food.

As David Aaron, US Under-Secretary for Commerce, warned a conference on 'Biotechnology: The Science and the Impact' in The Hague last week: 'Last century it was the tomato, this time it is biotech food.'

But there is a crucial difference today. We no longer have the time to indulge in fantasies and misconceptions about food, and in particular about gene foods. One billion people - more than the combined population of the United States and Europe - now survive on $1 or less a day, and are starving.

The UN has pledged to halve that number by 2015, a startlingly ambitious goal - for it means farmers will have to match mankind's entire food production of the past 10,000 years in the next one and a half decades.

There is only one way to achieve this dramatic goal, experts warned delegates, and that is by exploiting biotechnology, the science of manipulating the genes of living organisms.

However, this route is now being seriously hindered by Western consumers who, with increasing vehemence, are rejecting biotechnological products, mainly GM foods, and blocking their testing and funding.

These are the killer tomatoes of today, they claim. 'Unfortunately, consumers think products like genetically modified foods pose risks and offer no benefits,' said Sir Robert May, the Cabinet's chief scientific adviser. 'It is the attitude of a privileged élite who think there will be no problem feeding tomorrow's growing population.'

Such prejudices form the background for this week's international talks in Montreal when nations will discuss imposing limits on the safe handling, transfer and use of genetically modified organisms that could have an adverse effect on the environment. At issue is the fear that the US and its partners are trying to monopolise trade in GM crops, a bid that has made many other countries, includ ing Third World nations, suspicious of such products.

The irony is that without biotechnology, there will be no salvation for developing nations, delegates heard. To save 500 million people from starvation, they will have to increase meat production by an estimated 114 per cent, and milk output by 133 per cent.

For mighty conglomerates, that would be a tall order. For poor smallholders, the main providers of Third World crops, it would be impossible without the geneticist.

The aim is to develop techniques best suited to the Third World, ideas that include modifying crops so that their stems, used as animal feed in developing nations, are more nutritious, thus boosting livestock quality, or adding genes that will improve the vitamin content of maize or rice.

A perfect example of this type of technology was provided by Tony Irvin, of the International Livestock Research Institute, who has discovered a breed of sheep called the Red Masai, herded by East African nomads.

'These animals have developed a unique resistance to parasitic worms,' he said. Such parasites take a terrible toll of sheep in farms throughout the world, and Irvin and his colleagues believe they can develop techniques to transfer resistance to other breeds.

But this raises other headaches. How can politicians ensure the Masai people will benefit? Will they not suffer the fate of other indigenous peoples whose products have been pilfered and exploited without financial return?

Consider another fruit: the Chinese gooseberry, grown for centuries by Chinese farmers. Then a group of wily New Zealanders adopted, marketed and renamed it: the Kiwi fruit. They made a fortune. Chinese farmers got nothing.

There are scores of other examples, with developing countries accusing Western corporations of trying to patent the genetic codes of dozens of their native plants, including basmati rice, turmeric, black pepper, cotton - even the 'sacred' neem tree.

And such cases worried Irvin, as well as the World Bank vice-president Ismail Serageldin. 'We have got to make sure this does not happen with the Red Masai,' said Serageldin. 'Perhaps we will have to license the gene and use the proceeds to set up a trust fund for the Masai. Whatever else, we have a moral obligation to these people.

'Essentially, we are seeing a scientific apartheid being established between the Northern and Southern nations. It is not the science that divides them but the intellectual property rights that underpin products. We have got to find ways to make these available - perhaps by shortening the lifetime of patents from 17 to five years, or only asking for low, flat fees for access to technologies.

But there were encouraging signs, the delegates heard. Pharmaceutical giant Merck recently gave away its river blindness drug to the Third World, as did Novartis with its leprosy medicine.

Far more important for the question of feeding the world, however, has been the development of 'golden rice', a genetically modified strain that can impart doses of vitamin A, which standard rice lacks. 'Four hundred million people suffer from serious vitamin A deficiency, of whom one million die every year,' geneticist Chris Somerville of Stanford University told delegates. 'However by using genes from the daffodil, we have created rice that is not only yellow, but contains vitamin A. That crop was created with Rockefeller Foundation cash and will be distributed throughout the Third World in the next couple of years.'

But Somerville added that it took 12 years to develop golden rice. In that time, the world's population increased by another billion to its current six billion.

'In other words, if we want to make breakthroughs we are going to have to develop a lot more products like golden rice and do it a lot more quickly than we are doing at present.'

Yet the West, and in particular Europe, is now dragging its heels more and more in the face of intense customer hos tility to genetically modified foods, the continent's killer tomatoes.

'I think Europeans are going to have to carry a very heavy moral burden over their attitude to biotechnology,' Somerville added.

In the end, what is needed is a glamorous GM product that would change the image of biotechnology, May concluded. 'We need a GM apple that will make you thin and wicked. I suspect that would do the trick.'

webTitle: Scots fight to stay in closet

fields.headline: Scots fight to stay in closet
fields.standfirst: A cardinal, a tycoon and media players are out to keep the clause, say  Arnold Kemp and  Alex Bell
fields.trailText: For gays and lesbians, Edinburgh is the City of Light.  Time Out says it is a centre of 'pioneering work', praising its bars, clubs, 'relaxed' saunas and liberal civic governance. Its annual Pride march attracts 10,000 people. It was not surprising the new Scottish Executive should think one of its first and easiest tasks would be the repeal of a discredited statute banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
For gays and lesbians, Edinburgh is the City of Light. Time Out says it is a centre of 'pioneering work', praising its bars, clubs, 'relaxed' saunas and liberal civic governance. Its annual Pride march attracts 10,000 people. It was not surprising the new Scottish Executive should think one of its first and easiest tasks would be the repeal of a discredited statute banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

But beyond the bright lights of the capital's 'pink district', in the suburbs, towns and villages where the nation is more truly defined, lies a darker Scotland, conservative and fearful, where machismo sits down with homophobia. And in the old industrial west a prince of the Roman Catholic Church, with an eye on the Vatican and the papal succession, is leading a charge against the liberal consensus in general and the repeal of Section 28 (or 2a in Scotland) of the Local Government Act 1968 in particular.

Cardinal Thomas Winning has built a coalition with millionaire Stagecoach boss and evangelical Christian Brian Souter to sink the repeal. Among his most powerful allies are Martin Clarke, editor of Scotland's top-selling tabloid the Daily Record , and 'Jolly' Jack Irvine, former tabloid editor and now, as a director of the PR outfit Media House, Scotland's answer to Max Clifford.

The Scottish Executive, led by First Minister Donald Dewar, now faces an extraordinary political and popular challenge to a piece of legislation it believed to be innocuous, and one which is supported by all the main political parties and is going through with barely a murmur in England.

MSPs, radio phone-ins and newspaper editors all report a massive postbag. Harry Reid, editor of the Herald , Glasgow, said he had never seen anything comparable. Opinion, he thought, was evenly balanced. Polls suggest opposition is concentrated among older Scots, fearful of yet another threat, along with drugs, to the health and happiness of their children. But the immediate justification advanced by the executive for the repeal paints a much dark picture. The section makes it difficult for teachers to deal with homophobic bullying which is a scourge of Scotland's playgrounds.

Cardinal Winning's spokesman denies he is mounting a political challenge to New Labour and Tony Blair, with whom he has bitterly tangled in the past on the issue of abortion. It is, the spokesman insists, a matter of morality and decency. But few observers doubt there is a political subtext: over the years, notably on abortion, Winning has threatened to break the historic bond between Scottish Catholics and the Labour Party. Insiders say that at the Scottish elections in May he was narrowly restrained from endorsing the Scottish Nationalists.

Last week he raised the stakes again. In Malta, where he was addressing the Catholic Families movement on Friday, he spoke darkly of a 'militant and homosexual lobby' threatening family values all over Europe. Earlier in the week he branded homosexuality a 'perversion', provoking the Rt Rev John Cairns, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland - rooted in the Presbyterian tradition often blamed for Scotland's sexual hang-ups - to come out with a ringing endorsement of repeal.

The debate rests on one central question. Does the removal of a ban on promoting homosexuality mean pupils will be encouraged to become gay? Winning says he has been shocked by literature and videos which would be allowed into schools after repeal, but Dewar has given assurances that homosexuality will be treated sensitively within the context of sex education. According to a Mori poll for BBC Scotland, repeal is supported by most of Scotland's secondary teachers.

For the executive, the affair got off to a disastrous start. Just before the repeal was announced last October by Communities Minister Wendy Alexander, Dewar's political adviser John Rafferty - since dismissed - briefed the Scotsman and Daily Record . It was supposed to be a sweetheart deal that would guarantee sympathetic coverage. But Clarke's doubts quickly surfaced. 'Do Scots pupils really need lessons in homosexuality?' asked an article in the Record of 29 October. As a swelling postbag confirmed evidence of popular disquiet, the Record campaign has grown in stridency.

The executive has every reason to feel surprised by the strength of the reaction. It had consulted with due care and talked to the main Churches. The established Church of Scotland and the Episcopal Church, part of the Anglican communion - both largely liberal bourgeois institutions - raised few substantial objections to repeal.

The Observer can reveal that a subsequent meeting was held between Donald Dewar and Cardinal Winning. Dewar looked Winning in the eye and promised that despite the repeal of Section 28 there would be no promotion of homosexuality. The cardinal left, according to executive sources, saying he was satisfied.

But by 7 November he was backtracking. In an article in the Scotsman , he wrote: 'Donald Dewar is a wise man. He is also a sincere man. And so when he fixes you with that intense and convinced look, you know that he means what he says.' But as the press campaign mounted, Winning became convinced the legislation might have unintended consequences. He emphasised the Church was against homosexuality itself, not homosexual people, but added: 'I fear that a careless repeal _ will bring about the complete opposite of what is intended. Much more misery, not less, will ensue.'.

Now enter Souter and Irvine. Souter, perhaps Scotland's most successful entrepreneur, is much admired by the political classes. He started as a bus conductor and is now worth £600 million. He has hitherto only dabbled in politics, flirting with both the SNP and Labour.

But as a member of the Church of Nazarene he has now waded into the moral maze by using his charitable trust to bankroll opposition to repeal, offering up to £1m to the Scottish School Boards Association. And his PR man is Irvine, whose own column in the Scottish Mirror has distinctly homophobic undertones, on one occasion using the phrase 'slobbering old queer'.

Last week Irvine's promotion of the campaign descended into farce. Irvine, with his jaunty showman's air and boxer's face, blithely claimed that celebrities were lining up to support 'Keep the Clause'. He named chef Nick Nairn and Kwik Fit tycoon Sir Tom Farmer. Both quickly distanced themselves from the claim, which turned out to have been based on a hoax fax that Media House had not troubled to check.

The question now is whether the Scottish Parliament will hold its nerve in the media firefight. Friends of Donald Dewar say he is determined not to be bullied. He is said to believe, with many academic commentators, that Labour's bonds with the Catholic Church are already much looser and that it is possible to overrate the cardinal's influence over his flock. Above all, he is said to be determined that the Scottish Parliament will not flinch in its task of building an open and tolerant society.

In one of Edinburgh's gay cafés, Blue Moon, yesterday, customers said they hoped the executive would not 'bottle out'. Paul Duff said he was badly bullied at school. The class would pick on him, although as individuals they were tolerant.

'It would be lovely if the politicians had the courage,' said Jane Christy, wolfing down a fried breakfast. 'It would set an example to other parliaments and show what Scotland hopes for the future.'

Against

Brian Souter Boss of Stagecoach and one of Scotland's richest men: 'I do not condemn homosexuals. I respect them as individuals and respect their rights. But what happens between adults is one thing. What we teach our children in our schools is something else.'

Jack Irvine of Meda House PR: 'We are now seeing what one of my colleagues dubbed as thenew phenomenon of heterophobia.'

Cardinal Thomas Winning: 'Our warning is this: any repeal must not leave the way open to a new form of values-free political correctness which would impose an "anything goes" morality on our children.'

For

Rt Rev John Cairns Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland: 'Section 28 is a completely useless thing. All it has done is create fear and stigma against people.'

Donald Dewar First Minister: 'There are significant and far-reaching guidelines for schools. The real protection for our children is those guidelines, properly administered.'

Wendy Alexander Labour Minister for the communities: '[The repeal] is a victory for common sense and decency ... There are child protection systems in place, we can deal with any risks and we can assure any parents.'
