Last week Irvine's promotion of the campaign descended into farce. Irvine, with his jaunty showman's air and boxer's face, blithely claimed that celebrities were lining up to support 'Keep the Clause'. He named chef Nick Nairn and Kwik Fit tycoon Sir Tom Farmer. Both quickly distanced themselves from the claim, which turned out to have been based on a hoax fax that Media House had not troubled to check. The question now is whether the Scottish Parliament will hold its nerve in the media firefight. Friends of Donald Dewar say he is determined not to be bullied. He is said to believe, with many academic commentators, that Labour's bonds with the Catholic Church are already much looser and that it is possible to overrate the cardinal's influence over his flock. Above all, he is said to be determined that the Scottish Parliament will not flinch in its task of building an open and tolerant society. In one of Edinburgh's gay cafés, Blue Moon, yesterday, customers said they hoped the executive would not 'bottle out'. Paul Duff said he was badly bullied at school. The class would pick on him, although as individuals they were tolerant. 'It would be lovely if the politicians had the courage,' said Jane Christy, wolfing down a fried breakfast. 'It would set an example to other parliaments and show what Scotland hopes for the future.' Against Brian Souter Boss of Stagecoach and one of Scotland's richest men: 'I do not condemn homosexuals. I respect them as individuals and respect their rights. But what happens between adults is one thing. What we teach our children in our schools is something else.' Jack Irvine of Meda House PR: 'We are now seeing what one of my colleagues dubbed as thenew phenomenon of heterophobia.' Cardinal Thomas Winning: 'Our warning is this: any repeal must not leave the way open to a new form of values-free political correctness which would impose an "anything goes" morality on our children.' For Rt Rev John Cairns Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland: 'Section 28 is a completely useless thing. All it has done is create fear and stigma against people.' Donald Dewar First Minister: 'There are significant and far-reaching guidelines for schools. The real protection for our children is those guidelines, properly administered.' Wendy Alexander Labour Minister for the communities: '[The repeal] is a victory for common sense and decency ... There are child protection systems in place, we can deal with any risks and we can assure any parents.'

fields.headline: Your country needs US
fields.standfirst: First it was burgers and movies. Now Uncle Sam has a finger in everything British, laments  Richard Reeves
fields.trailText: Overpaid, oversexed and over here: the Brits have seen the arrival of Yanks as a mixed blessing ever since the friendly GI invasion of the Second World War. Now, just as their airmen are heading home from UK bases after 'winning' the Cold War, battalions more of our US cousins are arriving, taking over historic institutions, businesses and neighbourhoods.
fields.body:
Overpaid, oversexed and over here: the Brits have seen the arrival of Yanks as a mixed blessing ever since the friendly GI invasion of the Second World War. Now, just as their airmen are heading home from UK bases after 'winning' the Cold War, battalions more of our US cousins are arriving, taking over historic institutions, businesses and neighbourhoods.

There are 200,000 US citizens living in the UK, twice the number of 10 years ago, despite a sharp drop in military personnel. Counter-colonisation is in progress. US luminaries who have been parachuted in include Michael Kaiser, head of the Royal Opera House; George Mitchell, harbinger of peace in Northern Ireland; and Barbara Cassani, head of British Airways' cheap fares offshoot, Go

When we are in trouble it seems we can't help looking west. When the Jubilee Line extension hit the rocks, in rode Cliff Mumm, a South Dakotan from Bechtel Corp, who took over and finished the job.

The image of the American is someone who will Get the Job Done, while we Brits just fiddle about. 'The British take on every project like a game of chess,' says Mumm. 'They worry endlessly about rules and procedure. But when we got this job we put together an Anglo-American team and said "Let's do what it takes".'

George Mitchell, one of the world's smoothest diplomats, tells a similar story. 'I don't want to take anything away from the British and the Irish,' he has said. 'They are warm and wise and articulate. But sometimes you get the feeling these guys are so articulate they could go on talking for ever. Americans are more likely to say "Enough already, let's get the thing done".'

It is difficult to argue with success. The US economy is in the longest expansion of its history. It is the richest nation there has ever been. Its stock market is propping up the global currency exchange market. America dominates in sport, economics, military power. A survey conducted by BT shows senior British business people agreed that a 'can do' attitude was the most important determinant of commercial success. Sixty per cent thought American business culture exemplified this attitude. Only 10 per cent thought it applied to home-grown companies.

There are some jobs Americans are likely to be better suited to in any case, simply because the US is further ahead. Raising money, for example, is virtually a US monopoly. Trained in a nation which gives more money to charity than the rest of the world put together, and where universities, schools and arts companies have rarely been state-funded, money-getters from across the pond are in huge demand. Alice Gosling, the Illinois-born and raised fundraiser for Lincoln College, Oxford, says British institutions are adapting to a new, harsher financial world. 'In the US, colleges have been aggressively fundraising for 25 years. Here, development is fairly new in lots of areas - higher education, museums, the ballet. The industry is simply more developed in the US.'

Some are worried about the influx of Americans into the British cultural world. Scottish Ballet has an American artistic director, Robert North. The principal guest conductor to the Royal Scottish National Orchestra is New Yorker Marin Alsop. The South Bank is being recast by Oregon architect Rick Mather for £70 million. And - most shocking - the BBC Symphony Orchestra has appointed American conductor Leonard Slatkin. Which means the Last Night of the Proms is to be led by a native of a nation which fought us for its independence.

For years, the Brits have been able to cede most other areas of superiority to the Americans, confident at least in our greater culture and knowledge: let them eat their McDonalds, we sneered, at least we understand Mahler. What now?

Even if we can accept the expertise Americans bring to areas such as fundraising, and the diversity of the international arts scene, the Americanisation of other areas can cause the hackles of the British bulldog to rise. The Monetary Policy Committee of the Bank of England - which sets our mortgage rates - includes a US economist, DeAnne Julius. She insists the trend we are seeing is less Americanisation, more internationalisation. 'There has been a globalisation of human capability. There are more Americans and more people of other nationalities too,' Julius says. 'All fields are now more global - business, the arts, sports.'

Two of the most powerful magnets for Americans are the City of London and the English language. London is a major financial centre, US finance firms are powerful, so it is inevitable that the Square Mile will be filled with New York twangs. Half of all US investment in Europe is in the UK. London is a bridgehead for many American companies which also operate on the Continent.

But the traffic isn't one way. While we fret about Americans taking over our august institutions, they are watching Brits fill up their faculties as part of the well-publicised 'brain drain' across the Atlantic. And though Jaguar is now owned by the American company Ford and Wal-Mart has swallowed Asda, at least Burger King is owned by a British firm.

None the less, our tendency to reach for the transatlantic hotline may reflect a feeling of national inferiority, warns Richard Hoggart, author of First and Last Things . 'We are in the middle of a serious period of self doubt, of doing ourselves down. So people come over the pond to help us out. Whether they are actually more successful or not remains to be seen.'

Some imports have been high-profile disasters: Michael O'Neill resigned on his first day as chief executive and 'saviour' of Barclays Bank, citing ill-health before getting the plane back to California. The Bank of Scotland ended its dealings with Pat Robertson, a right-wing evangelical Christian, after he shared his views on the evils of homosexuality.

Even some of the Americans think our Yankophilia is overdone. 'Brits can be quite romantic about how efficient we are and about our business practices,' says Mather.

And American directness can cause problems, says Gosling. 'In the US, enthusiasm is seen as a good thing; here it seems like you are trying too hard. If you prepare for a meeting, people seem to think you are pushy.' She also says fundraising can be challenging in a country where discussion on money 'leaves people's fingers dirty. The British don't like talking about money.'

Mather is glad to be in Scotland, where the locals have their own brand of brash. 'In England you are never supposed to say what you think, but everyone is supposed to know what you think. In Scotland, like America, you can actually say it.'

Even our language is under attack as never before. US spellings are gaining ground, helped by the hegemony of West Coast software firms and computer spell-checkers. Color will surely be in the Oxford English Dictionary soon.

The outposts of US culture - huge bookshops, coffee shop chains, long working hours, fast talking, high divorce rates, 'dress down' Fridays - are everywhere. The number of coffee shops has increased tenfold in five years. Friends and Frasier are ubiquitous. And US policies and phrases have been adopted wholesale by the Blair Government.

Can we stem the invasion? And do we really want to? Perhaps we rather like economic success, people who talk to strangers and good coffee after all.

One American director of the UK branch of a US company captured the fears - or hopes? - of many.

'Everybody says it is not like America yet,' he said. 'But it will be. It will be.'

One Yank and it works...

 When British Airways was feeling the heat from its budget-fare rivals, what did it do/ It invented its own cheapo offshoot, Go, and then had to call on an American, Barbara Cassani, to take charge of the enterprise.

 Michael Kaiser's appointment as head of the Royal opera House is only one of many US inroads into the British culture. Dictionaries contain ever more Americanisations, and even the Last Night of the Proms is now to be led by an American.

 The strong points of British culture are rapidly falling to the transatlantic invader. London's South Bank, a hub of the artisitc world, is to be recast at a cost of £70 million. And the man for the job, architect Rick Mather, comes all the way from Oregon.

Additional research: Jackie Drennan

webTitle: What bribe? It was just an 'arrangement fee'

fields.headline: What bribe? It was just an 'arrangement fee'
fields.trailText: The government has tried to tackle the black economy in hundreds of different ways over the years. One that particularly surprised people came in 1993 when the Inland Revenue oversaw the introduction of legislation to stop businesses getting a 'tax deduction' for 'a payment that constitutes a criminal offence'.
fields.body:
The government has tried to tackle the black economy in hundreds of different ways over the years. One that particularly surprised people came in 1993 when the Inland Revenue oversaw the introduction of legislation to stop businesses getting a 'tax deduction' for 'a payment that constitutes a criminal offence'. It surprised people that businesses had hitherto been able to claim bribes, protection money or payments to prostitutes, as tax deductible expenses in the company accounts.

But this had been happening on a larger scale than you might think - and, despite the legislation, is unlikely to change. It was a particular problem in Northern Ireland, where many businesses were paying protection money to the IRA or to the Loyalist paramilitaries. Of course, you do not call it 'protection money' in your accounting records: you call it 'consultancy fees'.

Similarly, many a sales department has gone a long way to entertain its valued customers. Again, they probably prefer to use the headings 'conference costs' and 'payments to conference hall staff' rather than to say plainly 'prostitution charges'.

And many a besuited arms dealer is used to offering large sums of money to contacts in the Middle or Far East. If the payment goes through the books, it will be called a 'consultancy' or 'arrangement' fee, because that sounds rather nicer than 'bribe'.

webTitle: Operating on the shady side? It could be you

fields.headline: Operating on the shady side? It could be you
fields.standfirst: You may think you are an upright citizen, but it is easier to transgress than many imagine. Here are 10 ways in which you - or your respectable neighbours - could be participating in the black economy
fields.trailText: You may think you are an upright citizen, but it is easier to transgress than many imagine. Here are 10 ways in which you - or your respectable neighbours - could be participating in the black economy
fields.body:
1: Making or recieving cash-in-hand payments
You may do this for building work, child-minding, cleaning or gardening. Many of these payments will be quite above board - your gardener, for instance, may be registered self-employed and declaring those payments. But there appears to be widespread tax evasion over the payment of nannies. Only 23,000 people are on the Simplified Deduction Scheme for paying domestics, even though 50 per cent of mothers of pre-school children go out to work. Many parents say they pay their nanny about £80 a week, producing a salary just below the £4,335 personal allowance for income tax. But if mother and nanny fall out, the parents can end up getting a knock on the door from the Inland Revenue later on.

Another difficult area is the payment of cleaners. Although the Inland Revenue is hot on the tail of office cleaners, domestic cleaners have largely been ignored. Most cleaners bear the hallmarks of being employees - they work in your house, you fix their hours, you pay them a fixed hourly rate, and they use your equipment. There is a way round it if you want to suggest they are self-employed (and therefore that sorting out tax is their responsibility). If you accept that Mrs Mopp could send round her daughter instead, you would be agreeing that you are buying the service rather than employing the individual. But, for the time being, most people do not have to worry too much. Many of the 'ladies that do' earn less than the personal allowance - and the Revenue has bigger fish to fry.

You can theoretically get into big trouble with Customs & Excise by making a payment to, say, a builder, when you know that he is not declaring that payment for VAT, but Customs rarely goes after the person who paid the money.

2: Breaking the customs rules on tobacco, drink and perfumes
If you are buying for your own consumption, there is no duty to pay on alcohol bought in other EU countries. If you are selling it on to others, you should pay UK excise duty. So keep your daughter's wedding invitation to hand as proof, if you are shopping in Calais for the drinks you will offer guests on the happy day.

3: Understating your taxable income
The Inland Revenue is constantly on the look-out for self-employed workers who exaggerate their expenses or understate their earnings in order to pay less tax. It can levy penalties equal to 100 per cent of the tax you tried to evade if it feels you were deliberately trying to cheat. In very rare cases of fraud it brings a criminal prosecution on the charge of 'cheating'. In 1998/99, it launched 52 criminal prosecutions. 'The vast majority of self-employed people are incredibly fair,' says Richard Murphy, of accountant Murphy Deeks Nolan. 'But the Inland Revenue does not like the self-employed and doesn't understand self-employment.'

In 1998/99, the Revenue launched nearly 250,000 'inquiries' into information put on to tax returns. Completely innocent people find themselves under suspicion. Murphy adds: 'Some people who choose to be self-employed don't want to make a lots of money. But the Inland Revenue staff are taught the economic view that people are profit-maximisers.'

4: Doing undeclared work:
Many is the time that someone drifts into becoming self-employed and does not get round to sorting out their tax for several years. Accountants regularly find that a new client went freelance six or seven years ago but has not paid a penny in tax during that time. The Inland Revenue has used the 1996 introduction of self-assessment to get tougher with people who do declare themselves as taxpayers - but it has not done a great deal to tackle people who stay outside the system.

In most sectors of the economy, you can remain undetected for quite a long time. The toughest areas are, arguably, journalism and the media. Newspapers, for instance, have to give lists of their freelance contributors to the Revenue - but if you are a self-employed therapist, garden designer, Yoga teacher or computer consultant, the Revenue may have very little information about you.

5: Giving away your home to avoid paying for residential care
The country is being turned into a nation of 'cheating grannies', according to former Minister of Welfare Reform Frank Field. Most people resent the possibility that the home they spent their life struggling to pay for has to be sold to pay for nursing home fees. So there is widespread activity among the elderly to avoid this possibility. If you share your home with others, you are less likely to be forced to sell it. You certainly cannot be required to sell if your spouse or partner lives there. If you gave your house to your daughter years before going into a home, you are probably in the clear. But sooner or later, local authorities will start pursuing the elderly in bigger numbers to recover a house that was given away only to avoid paying nursing home fees.

6: Fiddling expenses at work
Most people will consider cheating in one form or another. Even Hillary Clinton has been accused of inflating bills to clients when she was an attorney in Arkansas. Many accountants, solicitors and other professionals who charge by the hour are encouraged to overstate their hours so that their firms' bills are higher. This may not be the mainstream of the black economy - but it is yet more proof that education and being middle-class do not preclude you from cheating.

Many of the 2 million company car users go on mad dashes in March to get their mileage above the crucial thresholds for reducing the taxable 'benefit in kind'. This practice is a culturally accepted form of fraud usually practised by middle managers. You should keep a log of your business travel to ensure you have proof. The Revenue can pick up irregularities in this area when it performs its audits of employers' records. It aims to visit each employer once in every five-year period. If it finds that there are not enough driving logs or receipts for meals, taxis, hotels or other expenses, it might charge the employer 'back tax'. In most cases, the employer does not ask the employees to pay.

7: Exploiting charitable status
Another favourite of middle-class scam is to get charitable status for a business activity and so remove the need to pay income tax. The trick is to convince the Charity Commissioners that you are involved in a recognised charitable purpose such as the alleviation of poverty or promotion of education. Accountancy firms often advise clients on how they can describe their trading activities in terms of which sound pious enough to apparently meet the criteria. 'The Charity Commissioners do not do a very good job in checking,' says Murphy. 'The accounting regulations on charities are horrible. Most charities cannot comply with them. And only one in six church accounts complies with the law. This area could be abused.'

8: Milking Government grants
The Government is increasingly trying to encourage local communities to develop their own regeneration plans. Millions of pounds of government, European Union and other money has been provided to help people in deprived areas - in Liverpool, depressed parts of London and bombed-out areas of Belfast, remote rural locations and other areas of need. Much of this money has been either deliberately or negligently used. In many cases, people have appointed themselves project directors with large expense accounts - but, at the end of the day, little of any lasting value has emerged.

9: Not declaring your assets when making a benefits claim
If you have more than £3,000 in savings or other assets, your ability to claim JobSeekers' Allowance, income support and other means-tested benefits will be reduced. (People getting residential care have the higher threshold of £10,000). So you will be asked what your savings are. The truth is that the Benefits Agency or local authority officials may never discover the facts if you do not tell them. They are very unlikely to find out about the £1,000 you have stashed away in a building society. Many claimants may find themselves 'forgetting' some details when they apply for benefit. Some people find themselves being caught out, however, after they fall out with a partner, relative or someone else who knows that they have been cheating. People are often shopped to the Department of Social Security.

10: Working while claiming benefits
This is much easier to do than you might think - especially if you are doing little bits of freelance to get yourself back to work or if your income fluctuates. If you lost your job a few months ago and are now being offered an evening's work in a bar, you will probably dislike the idea that you should declare all to the Benefits Agency and lose benefit as a result. This type of 'poverty trap' encourages people to break the rules. Since April last year, the Revenue and the Benefits Agency have had new powers to share information on individuals with each other.

The cleaner claiming benefit

'She was the best cleaning lady I ever had,' says Cathy, an executive in a publishing house. 'I paid her cash - but we never broached the subject of tax and National Insurance. I felt uncomfortable - but I also felt she would be uncomfortable if I asked too many questions.

'I used to hear tales of her life. She had a son whose relationship fell apart. She discovered that his child, her grandchild, was being abused by his ex-wife's new partner. So she took him in to look after him. But her former daughter-in-law reported her to the DSS. Then my cleaning lady had to admit to me that she had been claiming disability benefit for a bad back. She was very matter-of-fact and honest about it.

'I didn't begrudge her. She and her family lived in a council house and there was no way they were wealthy people. I think the extra money made a big difference to them. I really liked her; she was a force for good. She also cared for her neighbour's child, the child of a teenage mother. If those children hadn't been looked after by her, presumably someone would have had to be paid to do it.

'I certainly didn't see her as a leach on society.'

So keep your daughter's wedding invitation to hand as proof, if you are shopping in Calais for the drinks you will offer guests on the happy day. 3: Understating your taxable income The Inland Revenue is constantly on the look-out for self-employed workers who exaggerate their expenses or understate their earnings in order to pay less tax. It can levy penalties equal to 100 per cent of the tax you tried to evade if it feels you were deliberately trying to cheat. In very rare cases of fraud it brings a criminal prosecution on the charge of 'cheating'. In 1998/99, it launched 52 criminal prosecutions. 'The vast majority of self-employed people are incredibly fair,' says Richard Murphy, of accountant Murphy Deeks Nolan. 'But the Inland Revenue does not like the self-employed and doesn't understand self-employment.' In 1998/99, the Revenue launched nearly 250,000 'inquiries' into information put on to tax returns. Completely innocent people find themselves under suspicion. Murphy adds: 'Some people who choose to be self-employed don't want to make a lots of money. But the Inland Revenue staff are taught the economic view that people are profit-maximisers.' 4: Doing undeclared work: Many is the time that someone drifts into becoming self-employed and does not get round to sorting out their tax for several years. Accountants regularly find that a new client went freelance six or seven years ago but has not paid a penny in tax during that time. The Inland Revenue has used the 1996 introduction of self-assessment to get tougher with people who do declare themselves as taxpayers - but it has not done a great deal to tackle people who stay outside the system. In most sectors of the economy, you can remain undetected for quite a long time. The toughest areas are, arguably, journalism and the media. Newspapers, for instance, have to give lists of their freelance contributors to the Revenue - but if you are a self-employed therapist, garden designer, Yoga teacher or computer consultant, the Revenue may have very little information about you. 5: Giving away your home to avoid paying for residential care The country is being turned into a nation of 'cheating grannies', according to former Minister of Welfare Reform Frank Field. Most people resent the possibility that the home they spent their life struggling to pay for has to be sold to pay for nursing home fees. So there is widespread activity among the elderly to avoid this possibility. If you share your home with others, you are less likely to be forced to sell it. You certainly cannot be required to sell if your spouse or partner lives there. If you gave your house to your daughter years before going into a home, you are probably in the clear. But sooner or later, local authorities will start pursuing the elderly in bigger numbers to recover a house that was given away only to avoid paying nursing home fees. 6: Fiddling expenses at work Most people will consider cheating in one form or another. Even Hillary Clinton has been accused of inflating bills to clients when she was an attorney in Arkansas. Many accountants, solicitors and other professionals who charge by the hour are encouraged to overstate their hours so that their firms' bills are higher. This may not be the mainstream of the black economy - but it is yet more proof that education and being middle-class do not preclude you from cheating. Many of the 2 million company car users go on mad dashes in March to get their mileage above the crucial thresholds for reducing the taxable 'benefit in kind'. This practice is a culturally accepted form of fraud usually practised by middle managers. You should keep a log of your business travel to ensure you have proof. The Revenue can pick up irregularities in this area when it performs its audits of employers' records. It aims to visit each employer once in every five-year period. If it finds that there are not enough driving logs or receipts for meals, taxis, hotels or other expenses, it might charge the employer 'back tax'. In most cases, the employer does not ask the employees to pay. 7: Exploiting charitable status Another favourite of middle-class scam is to get charitable status for a business activity and so remove the need to pay income tax. The trick is to convince the Charity Commissioners that you are involved in a recognised charitable purpose such as the alleviation of poverty or promotion of education. Accountancy firms often advise clients on how they can describe their trading activities in terms of which sound pious enough to apparently meet the criteria. 'The Charity Commissioners do not do a very good job in checking,' says Murphy. 'The accounting regulations on charities are horrible. Most charities cannot comply with them. And only one in six church accounts complies with the law. This area could be abused.' 8: Milking Government grants The Government is increasingly trying to encourage local communities to develop their own regeneration plans. Millions of pounds of government, European Union and other money has been provided to help people in deprived areas - in Liverpool, depressed parts of London and bombed-out areas of Belfast, remote rural locations and other areas of need. Much of this money has been either deliberately or negligently used. In many cases, people have appointed themselves project directors with large expense accounts - but, at the end of the day, little of any lasting value has emerged. 9: Not declaring your assets when making a benefits claim If you have more than £3,000 in savings or other assets, your ability to claim JobSeekers' Allowance, income support and other means-tested benefits will be reduced. (People getting residential care have the higher threshold of £10,000). So you will be asked what your savings are. The truth is that the Benefits Agency or local authority officials may never discover the facts if you do not tell them. They are very unlikely to find out about the £1,000 you have stashed away in a building society. Many claimants may find themselves 'forgetting' some details when they apply for benefit. Some people find themselves being caught out, however, after they fall out with a partner, relative or someone else who knows that they have been cheating. People are often shopped to the Department of Social Security. 10: Working while claiming benefits This is much easier to do than you might think - especially if you are doing little bits of freelance to get yourself back to work or if your income fluctuates. If you lost your job a few months ago and are now being offered an evening's work in a bar, you will probably dislike the idea that you should declare all to the Benefits Agency and lose benefit as a result. This type of 'poverty trap' encourages people to break the rules. Since April last year, the Revenue and the Benefits Agency have had new powers to share information on individuals with each other. The cleaner claiming benefit 'She was the best cleaning lady I ever had,' says Cathy, an executive in a publishing house. 'I paid her cash - but we never broached the subject of tax and National Insurance. I felt uncomfortable - but I also felt she would be uncomfortable if I asked too many questions. 'I used to hear tales of her life. She had a son whose relationship fell apart. She discovered that his child, her grandchild, was being abused by his ex-wife's new partner. So she took him in to look after him. But her former daughter-in-law reported her to the DSS. Then my cleaning lady had to admit to me that she had been claiming disability benefit for a bad back. She was very matter-of-fact and honest about it. 'I didn't begrudge her. She and her family lived in a council house and there was no way they were wealthy people. I think the extra money made a big difference to them. I really liked her; she was a force for good. She also cared for her neighbour's child, the child of a teenage mother. If those children hadn't been looked after by her, presumably someone would have had to be paid to do it. 'I certainly didn't see her as a leach on society.'

fields.headline: Black books
fields.standfirst: Politicians to window cleaners - they're all dabbling in the undeclared economy, writes  Neasa MacErlean  which is cosing up to pc of GDP
fields.trailText: Politicians to window cleaners - they're all dabbling in the undeclared economy, writes Neasa MacErlean which is cosing up to pc of GDP
fields.body:
The chancellor could knock at least 3p off the basic rate of tax tomorrow if he could strike out the black economy. But this flourishing sector of the marketplace, has existed since taxes were invented and at best can only ever be contained.

In the UK, as many as one in eight jobs is 'undeclared', according to 1998 research conducted by the European Commission. But we are not the worst offenders: the figure in Greece could be as high as 35 per cent, and in Spain it is estimated at somewhere between 10 and 23 per cent. A research project from the University of Birmingham last year put the UK black economy at 20 per cent of gross domestic product - double the figure that is usually produced as a 'guesstimate'.

Both the British government and the European Commission are stepping up their efforts to crack down on wrongdoers in this field. Gordon Brown is considering announcing new measures in his March Budget after he receives a report from Lord Grabiner QC. These could include requiring people to sign on daily if they are suspected of working while claiming benefit. Another move is a major attack on self-employed computer industry contactors, many of whom, from 6 April, will be forced to pay tax under the harsher regime of employees - even though they are self-employed.

Conservative politicians at their annual conference often promise a crackdown on shirkers and cheats. The Labour government is now borrowing some of this clothing. A revised 'Construction Industry Scheme', introduced last August, makes it harder for builders to deal in undeclared cash. Inland Revenue and Customs & Excise fraud experts are working together in a pilot scheme to tackle the black economy. And every few weeks, a government spokesperson pops up to condemn the extent of cheating on housing benefit.

But tax, VAT and benefits experts think that government departments spend too much time penalising people who are in the system and should divert some resources to those who never declare their earnings.

Alun Mathias of Deloitte & Touche says: 'Customs spends a lot of time dealing with people who are registered for VAT. The full force of the law comes down on them if they get things wrong. But there are people who exist right outside the system, whom it seems very difficult to reach.'

The black economy seems to flourish in all parts of society. It is a myth to believe that only certain criminal classes practise it. Consider the number of politicians and businessmen who are exposed as having at least dabbled, if not immersed themselves in it. Perhaps it is linked more to the ease with which opportunities can be seized than to individual moral weakness. Ramped up the mileage on the company car? Paid your window cleaner in cash? You may be part of the black economy yourself.

webTitle: Nannies' tax is not child's play

fields.headline: Nannies' tax is not child's play
fields.trailText: It was one small step from motherhood to the black economy for Zoe Baird, who fell from grace as President Bill Clinton's choice for US Attorney General because she paid her nanny cash in hand.
fields.body:
It was one small step from motherhood to the black economy for Zoe Baird, who fell from grace as President Bill Clinton's choice for US Attorney General because she paid her nanny cash in hand. As the person who would be chasing tax dodgers, she found her position untenable. Another nominee, Kimba Wood, also had to renounce the coveted title because of her domestic arrangements.

Millions of working mothers are tempted to forget about deducting tax and National Insurance - not just to save money but to avoid tedious hours of paperwork.

Mother of three and practising actuary Nicola Foote has been deducting tax and NI from her nanny's pay for 12 years. It is one of the least fulfilling aspects of motherhood. 'It is quite a time-consuming exercise to do it properly. I have a degree in mathematics and my husband is an accountant, but we still found it quite difficult.'

The first step is to contact your tax office when you start employing your nanny. It should send you a pack for the 'Simplified Deduction Scheme' - a Revenue concession aimed at reducing the red tape for people employing a maid, gardener or one or two domestic staff. But you will still have your work cut out.

Ms Foote, a partner in actuary Watson Wyatt, was sent the wrong forms at first - but eventually she was put on the right track. 'First of all you want a day reading the right form. Then you probably need a full afternoon to work it all out.'

A particular problem is that the Revenue provides tables telling you how much you should deduct from gross pay. But most nannies negotiate over the amount they get net - and so employers often have to calculate the tax and NI due from the net amount. The Observer has urged the Inland Revenue to add in an extra set of tables to facilitate this.

The difficulties in sorting out the deductions are a disincentive to parents to give their nannies a pay rise. If you are not happy using a calculator, you have another reason not to bother to do this.

Ms Foote and her nanny Katie have usually found individual tax staff very helpful to deal with. But hiccups regularly occur. 'Six months ago a tax payment went astray,' says Ms Foote. 'The process hasn't been revisited in a long time.'

Get the 'Simplified Deducation Scheme' pack from your tax office. Contact the Revenue's Employment Support Helpline on 0345 143143 if you have problems.

webTitle: Come up and see my profit

fields.headline: Come up and see my profit
fields.standfirst: The etchings that helped seduce Twenties flapper girls are back in fashion, writes  John Windsor
fields.trailText: The etchings that helped seduce Twenties flapper girls are back in fashion, writes John Windsor
fields.body:
When the flighty young flappers of the Twenties were invited to 'come up and see my etchings', what - apart from the obvious alternative - did they find?

The etchings, printed on paper in black ink from copper plates, were probably real enough. There was a mania for them. Artistic young toffs would subscribe to the London dealer Colnaghi, pay 12 guineas (£12.60) for the latest etching by a big name of the day, such as James McBey, then bung it into a Sotheby's auction, where it would fetch five times more.

The market boomed, and then went spectacularly bust in 1927. Etchings became deeply unfashionable. The depressed Thirties dem-anded colour, and print makers turned to bright woodcuts and linocuts.

It is only in recent years that British etching has begun to be appreciated as something more than a catchword from Whitehall farce. Perhaps today's dung paintings and unmade beds have triggered a nostalgia for skill-based art, fine drawing and mature technique.

In fact, the forgotten generation of etchers that flourished during the first three decades of the last century developed a quintessentially British genre. Their fav-ourite subjects were landscape, disappearing country life, urban demolition works and city street life. Their honest, direct observation was reminiscent of etchings by Rembrandt and Van Dyck. Much of their work can still be bought for less than £200 - or much less in fairs and markets where their names are unknown.

Oxfordshire print dealer Elizabeth Harvey-Lee specialises in the work of pre-war etchers, including many she has catalogued as Unsung Heroes. 'Their work is British in character and immediately recognisable. It has a realism modified by a romantic intensity,' she says.

The etchings of Rembrandt and Van Dyck were out of fashion for two centuries until Victorian times, when the visionary Samuel Palmer, the raffish James McNeill Whistler and his brother-in-law, Seymour Haden, revived their techniques.

By the Twenties boom-time, the most bankable names in the Colnaghi stable were McBey, Muirhead Bone, Frederick Griggs and Lionel Lindsay. Today, Harvey-Lee sells McBey's etchings for between £200 and £300 for quiet landscapes and £500 for early Scottish views, to £1,000 for his etchings of Venice.

Her prices for Bone's fluid landscapes and town views in drypoint (in which the copper is scored with a sharp tool rather than acid-etched) range from £500 to £1,000. Griggs' etchings of country architecture, closely worked in the manner of Palmer, sell for between £500 and £800 and his later, Gothic visions for £1,200-£2,000.

Lindsay, however, who returned to his native Australia when the print boom collapsed, is one of her unsung heroes. His European town views and landscapes sell for only £200 to £300.

The single most formative influence on the pre-war generation of etchers was the kindly Frank Short, who was the Royal College of Art's first director of engraving, from 1913 to 1924. His students, all art school graduates, had already excelled at drawing and, partly due to his promotion, their outstanding etchings became the mainstay of the boom.

Short wrote: 'My aim with pupils is to make them craftsmen first and foremost, and complete masters of their material, so that they shall be able to do what they intend, and there shall be no room for accidents. My chief business is to equip them with the means to express the artist articulately.' A far cry from conceptual art now.

But many of Short's pupils, acclaimed in their day, are neglected now. They include Constance Pott, who was Short's technical and teaching assistant. Her architectural studies have a strong line, and show an appreciation of Whistler. Her 1905 study of The Strand , is priced at £240.

She dedicated this to Short's pupil, Nathaniel Sparks. While still at the RCA, Sparks assisted Whistler in printing his Venice plates. He bought his own press and printed about 100 plates of architectural subjects during the print boom. Today's prices are from £180 to £300.

Malcolm Osborne was a contemporary and friend of Sparks, who succeeded Short as professor at the RCA. His architectural and landscape etchings are now priced from £200 to £300.

Martin Hardie, another of Short's pupils, was a part-time etcher who had graduated in classics from Cambridge. He became keeper of prints at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. He is best known for his writings and annotated catalogues on etchers, rather than for his own drypoints of old buildings and country lanes. Prices: £100-£250.

Charles William Taylor, a commercial engraver trained at evening classes in Wolverhampton, was 30 before he became a pupil of Short's at the RCA. He was preoccupied with the effects of light, and his landscapes have been said to blend the familiar with the unfamiliar, the particular with the universal. Prices: around £250.

Will collector-investors tire of conceptual art and embrace pre-war etching? Two things are certain: British conceptual art can hardly get worse and, since its golden decades, etching is unlikely to get better.

 The Unsung Heroes catalogue is available at £5.50, including post and packaging, from Harvey-Lee at 1 West Cottages, Middle Aston Road, North Aston, Oxon OX6 3QB. Tel: 01869 347164.

fields.headline: Questions
fields.standfirst: With-profits bonuses
fields.trailText: With-profits bonuses
fields.body:
Why do I hear about bonuses each year for my with-profits life insurance policy, but not for my unit-linked one?

The two types of policy grow in different ways. The end-of-year value of a unit-linked policy depends on how the investments in its fund have increased, or fallen, over the previous 12 months. The value can be higher or lower than the previous year. Money in a with-profits fund is invested more cautiously, so your returns are steady, rather than swinging up and down.

Q What are these bonuses?

A There are two: an annual bonus and a final bonus. Annual bonuses, historically called 'reversionary' bonuses, are added every year. Once added, they are guaranteed to be paid out when the policy matures, either when it has run its full length or when the person whose life is insured dies. The final, or terminal, bonus is paid only in the year that the policy matures.

Q Will I get these bonuses if I cash in early?

A You will get some annual, and possibly final, bonus. How much depends on the insurance firm.

Q Why are there two types of bonus?

A Insurance companies like to keep their options open. The advantage to you, and drawback to them, is that they are committed to paying out the annual bonuses they have promised, even though this can be 25 years in the future. They do not have to decide how much the final bonus will be until they know how much profit they have made. Some companies pay low annual bonuses, with terminal ones worth more than half the total payout; this is riskier for investors. A few pay higher annual bonuses with lower final payments.

Q How do I get this bonus?

A It is shown on your annual statement as a percentage figure based on the guaranteed sum assured.

Q How much are bonuses?

A 'With-profits' means you are sharing the profits made by the insurance company, so it depends how profitable the insurer is. Companies are starting to declare the bonuses that will apply to policies in 2000. Even though the stock market did well last year, some will still cut annual bonuses if they expect to earn less in future. They can apply different rates to short- and long-term policies.

Q Do bonuses go up each year?

A In the Eighties they did, but when the stock market began falling, insurance companies had to cut the rate they paid. But even when the bonus rate is lower than the previous year, your policy will still be worth more: the percentage is calculated on the original sum assured plus the guaranteed annual bonuses already earned.

Q What is the difference between a with-profits insurance policy and a with-profits bond?

A With endowment policies you pay regular premiums for a fixed number of years. With-profits bonds are lump-sum investments with no set timescale.

Q Do bonuses go up each year? A In the Eighties they did, but when the stock market began falling, insurance companies had to cut the rate they paid. But even when the bonus rate is lower than the previous year, your policy will still be worth more: the percentage is calculated on the original sum assured plus the guaranteed annual bonuses already earned. Q What is the difference between a with-profits insurance policy and a with-profits bond? A With endowment policies you pay regular premiums for a fixed number of years. With-profits bonds are lump-sum investments with no set timescale.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Regular readers of 'What's the Catch' will know the importance of studying the small print of any contract.
fields.body:
Regular readers of 'What's the Catch' will know the importance of studying the small print of any contract.

But few of us are perfect, so when when one reader was offered breakdown cover in the course of buying car insurance from Direct Line, he accepted without paying much attention to the details. For £55, Direct Line's Rescue policy would provide roadside assistance in the event of a breakdown or accident, and if unable to mend the car within an hour, Direct Line would transport it to a single destination of the reader's choice within 10 miles, or to a suitable repairer in the vicinity of the breakdown.

All seemed fine until Christmas Eve, when the car juddered to a halt in a central London car park. 'I had to drive to my family home about 70 miles from London and it was 7pm - too late to hire a car or to try to get someone to fix it. The car was just about going, so I decided to ring Direct Line to find out what would happen if I broke down en route.'

Our reader was told that if the car was too difficult to repair at the roadside, he would be transported to the nearest garage. However, as it was Christmas Eve, the choice was likely to be limited, and the reader would be charged £1 per mile for any part of the journey in excess of 10 miles. He says: 'At the end of the conversation, the Direct Line operator said "quite honestly mate, you're snookered!".'

Not the response you'd expect, but Direct Line's terms do clearly state that the Rescue policy does not cover charges where transportation exceeds 10 miles. And, says a spokeswoman, these apply to Christmas Eve and Christmas Day just like any other day of the year.

webTitle: Are bricks and mortar a safe bet?

fields.headline: Are bricks and mortar a safe bet?
fields.standfirst: An architect with no pension  asks Margaret Dibben  if she'd be wise to put her savings into property
fields.trailText: Victoria Perry
fields.body:
Victoria Perry

Age: 33

Lives in: London

Occupation: Architect

Income: Fluctuates between £28,000 and £36,000

Mortgage: Paid by husband

Debts: None

Investments: £12,000 in instant access account

Pension: None

Aims: To plan a pension

Victoria Perry is a self-employed architect with an 11-month old son, Joe. She shares offices in London's Portabello Road with two other architects and, since having Joe, works a four-day week. This means her earnings have dropped. She and her husband would like to have another child but she is not sure how she would manage financially if they did.

As she is self-employed, she gets only the minimum maternity benefits so, over the past year, she says, she has used up quite a lot of her savings. She now has £12,000 left in an instant access account with HSBC. The only other money that she is putting aside is her child benefit which goes into a savings account in her son's name. This is for his university education. When she returns to full-time working, her income will improve but she is aware that architects are vulnerable to recession so cannot be confident that she will always earn a good salary.

She is now starting to worry about a pension as she has made no provision for her retirement. She says: 'I looked into it about two years ago but I didn't get any further.' She had been attracted by the idea that, rather than contributing to a pension, she would buy a house to renovate and rent out. She explains: 'I wanted to think about an alternative approach.' As an architect, she felt she could use her skills to advantage. And, knowing she would have more time at home with a child, she thought she might be able to invest her time usefully refurbishing a property. But then the baby arrived and she did nothing about it. She has not even had the chance to get to grips with her own home which still needs a lot of work. The plan is that her husband's salary pays the mortgage and bills and only he has a credit card. Victoria pays for the crèche and half the food bill. Any left over is put into a fund to restore their own home.

But it is the lack of a pension that worries her most. 'That is my main concern,' she says. She is still interested in the idea of funding her retirement by buying an investment property to do up and rent out, but she is not sure if this is the best way.

Adviser 1: Julia Lord, certified financial planner and managing director of Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff.

Victoria should forget the investment property idea until she has considered basic financial planning and ensured she will be financially independent. She seems particularly vulnerable, with little savings, no pension, children and a hazy idea of what she wants.

I believe it is a big mistake to consider investment property as a replacement for a basic pension as there are too many problems. The rent will be taxed at her highest rate. She appears to have a major job in restoring her own home so how can she practically utilise her time refurbishing another property as well? And she would need more than £12,000 to get a reasonable property worth renting out in London. She should start a pension of at least £250 per month - she is late in starting a pension at 33. She needs a flexible pension that does not penalise her for stopping or starting her contributions and one with a waiver of premium benefit to maintain her contributions if she is ill. There is no mention of life insurance, serious illness insurance or any kind of income replacement and I regard family protection as essential. For income replacement she needs to work out the minimum income required if she could not earn, to pay for Joe's creche and her other outgoings.

She should discuss finances with her husband and calculate their requirements for life assurance and critical illness cover based on their current and desired lifestyles. For the longer-term, they should invest the child benefit, and for themselves, in stock market-related areas. It seems that, as things appear disorganised, there is no will in place and I suggest that this is done as a matter of urgency.

Adviser 2: Ian Millward, investment marketing manager of Bath-based Chase de Vere

As money is needed for work on their home and maybe more children, Victoria really needs a 'rainy day' fund. Ideally, she could save £3,000 in a Mini Cash ISA with Smile Internet Bank (smile.co.uk), paying 6.75% tax-free on £1 or more. If Internet access is hard she could use Coventry Building Society which pays 6.55%.

The remaining £9,000 could be with Bristol & West which is paying 6.80% gross from 1 February.

For Joe's university education they should consider stocks and shares, probabaly through regular savings. They could start a tracker fund such as L&G UK Index although, as the timescale is more than 15 years, she could consider the spicier Framlington NetNet fund.

Pension plans must be flexible. Stakeholder pensions - the government's new low cost and flexible scheme - won't be introduced until April 2001 but she must start a pension now. Suggestions are Scottish Mutual and Scottish Equitable. If she has a lump sum she could also 'carry forward' and 'carry back' for past years' unused contributions, as this may be abolished. Victoria really should consider life assurance. For around £17 a month she could be insured for £200,000 for the next 25 years. Try L&G and Scottish Provident.

Victoria needs to decide if critical illness or health insurance is affordable. To add critical illness on to the life cover increases the premiums to around £62 a month and suggestions are BUPA Health or CGU Health. This is important protection, but the family may have other priorities.

webTitle: Sell here, buy in France: Vive la différence

fields.headline: Sell here, buy in France: Vive la différence
fields.standfirst: Natalie Sutton has just bought a place  à la campagne. In the first of an occasional diary, she rejoices in the ease of conveyancing Gallic style
fields.trailText: Natalie Sutton has just bought a place à la campagne. In the first of an occasional diary, she rejoices in the ease of conveyancing Gallic style
fields.body:
Anybody who is about to buy or sell a property in London deserves as much sympathy as they can get. They are about to plunge into the estate agent-infested waters of bidding wars, gazumping and over-your-head mortgages.

I am now well away from all that - buying a place in a remote area of France, and my dealings with a French estate agent have (so far) been a walk in the park compared with the angst-ridden wranglings I suffered at the hands of their London counterparts when selling my flat in Battersea six months ago.

The first major difference between British and French property purchasing is, obviously, the price. It sounds absurd, but for approximately two-thirds of the price of the aforementioned flat, I am about to become the proud owner of an isolated but nonetheless entire hamlet in sunnier climes. The property consists of five buildings (admittedly, some are in need of substantial repair) and 60 acres of land (though on the side of a mountain and of little use to anybody apart from the Forestry Commission). And no, it's probably not quite as well served as Battersea in terms of commuting, general transport and local facilities. There is no electricity or gas, the water comes from a spring and getting to the nearest town involves 7km of 'off-roading' or a good day's walk with emergency rations. Curiously, there seems to be a telephone line, but at this stage we are not sure how. Piffling details aside, however, I do feel we are getting rather more for our money.

We viewed the hamlet with all the suspicions of those jaded by the horror stories of back home. Before we even allowed ourselves to feel interested, let alone excited, we wanted to know whether anyone else had made an offer on the property, resigned to the fact that we would walk away if anybody had so much as sniffed around. Françoise, the estate agent, was horrified by our attitude. In France, once an offer has been made and accepted, both sides are contractually bound to complete the sale. The very fact that we were being shown the property meant that nobody else had put in an official offer.

In London, it's a very different story. Rumours abound of people being asked to make an offer on a property before they could even make an appointment to see it. As a recent vendor, it seemed normal practice to wait until several people had made firm offers before eventually closing the doors to further viewers. There are no scruples, and gazumping is perfectly acceptable behaviour. Indeed, the initial valuation on my flat was made in the confident expectation that, once an adrenaline-fuelled bidding war was in full swing, it would increase by at least £5,000.

The most significant difference appears to be that once an offer is made in France, both estate agent and vendor regard this as tantamount to a done deal. Furthermore, an initial signing of the contract can be done by fax (accompanied by a 10 per cent deposit to the notaire). These formalities need take only two or three days, as they did in our case.

A secondary reason for long, tense delays in the UK is the time it takes for a surveyor to give a property his seal of approval. Mortgage lenders will insist on a valuation by a surveyor and it seems common practice to get the property checked out by an independent one, even if no money lending is involved. In France, it seems common practice to accept the judgment of the estate agent and your own eye. Should that prove too great a leap of faith, you can have a mason or a 'maitre d'oeuvres' look at the property.

The 'expert immobilier' exists mostly for commercial sites and is rarely called in for residential property, although an 'expertise' or full structural survey could provide complete peace of mind if added cost is not an issue. In either case, approximately three weeks' waiting time is removed from the process. We decided that there was no need for a survey which we may, of course, live to regret. Any structural works carried out by local builders should be covered by a 10-year guarantee.

We are fully aware that there is no water and electricity. Oh, and that two of the buildings have no roof, although they seem structurally quite sound. As the hamlet has withstood exposure to the elements for more than 300 years, we're willing to give the walls the benefit of the doubt.

A document called a 'Promesse de Vente' (Promise to Sell) is signed by both parties immediately and, rather than having two sets of solicitors bandying documents and negotiations to and fro, each blaming the other for holding up the proceedings, the notaire handles everything as a neutral arbiter with everybody's interests at heart. Actually, he probably has nobody's interest at heart but he gets paid substantially more (7 per cent of the purchasing price, although this includes the stamp duty and land registration fee). It sounds a lot but, by the time one has paid a surveyor, all the taxes and the solicitor's fees in the UK (not forgetting the therapy to recover from the experience) the margin of difference between French and British costs narrows. In addition to which, it is 7 per cent of substantially less.

One of the few difficulties for a foreigner buying a property in France is the question of transferring money. Given the effect of the exchange rate on large sums of francs, it may be advisable (if only for peace of mind) to negotiate a forward contract if the rate appears particularly favourable prior to the date of transferring funds. Opening a French bank account requires a whole range of documents proving birth, marital status and general existence.

In the UK, banks and building societies are falling over themselves to handle the financial side of property acquisition: in France, the state of indebtedness is less easily arrived at - a bank account must always be kept in funds and a mortgage is not the mere calculation of income and multiplier that it is in the UK.

We come eventually to the phase of crossing fingers and waiting for the deal to be done. In the UK, no news is bad news and fraught calls to the solicitors soon ensue. Vendors' solicitors blame purchasers' solicitors for the delay as specific information is requested but not supplied and estate agents start making threats.

'If the surveyor hasn't been round within seven days, the deal's off,' said one. 'If the exchange date isn't fixed by the end of the month, the property's back on the market,' said another. There seems to be no code of honour, no question of a gentleman's agreement. A purchaser may have already forked out anything up to £800 for an independent survey and could innocently be waiting for the mortgage company to complete the paperwork but, if a higher offer on the property comes in, it's tough luck. Purchasers panic and start calling the vendor direct, desperate for reassurance. Everyone loses sleep, patience and, sometimes, money.

All seems much calmer across the Channel, at least in a rural location. Once a piece of land is under offer, the notaire notifies the Société d'Aménagement Foncier et d'Etablissements Rurales (SAFER). This organisation protects the right of local farmers, who are given first refusal to buy the land themselves. This is a formality which takes two months and which, in our case, is unlikely to cause problems since the land in question is of no agricultural interest to anybody.

In the meantime, the notaire is collecting all details relevant to the exchange of ownership of the property. In our case, he has no difficulty in obtaining deeds and documents because, as the only notaire in the area, he has nobody else to deal with and his office probably drew them up in the first place. For him, it is a simple case of transferring ownership within a time limit which he dictates.

There is no need for us to harangue the vendor and, indeed, the estate agent does not expect us to have any contact with him until the day when we all gather in the notaire's office, sign, hand over a big cheque and collect the keys. I pester Françoise, our estate agent, with nervous telephone calls on a regular basis and she explains everything with the patience of a saint. Call me old-fashioned, but it seems so much more civilised.

I could be proved wrong in the long term. We've no guarantee that once the deal is signed, actually reinstating and maintaining a property abroad is not far harder than expected.

We'll see.

fields.headline: Versailles fraud doubled turnover
fields.trailText: Versailles, the collapsed trade finance company, fictitiously inflated its turnover by more than 100 per cent in a long-running fraud against banks, creditors and investors
fields.body:
Versailles, the collapsed trade finance company, fictitiously inflated its turnover by more than 100 per cent in a long-running fraud against banks, creditors and investors, The Observer has established.

Around £50 million of cash is also so far understood to have flowed out through paper companies which were not genuine trading partners.

Profits at the group, which was worth £630m until its shares were suspended before Christmas, were also illusory, investigative sources say.

The firm, which is under investigation by the Serious Fraud Office, was put into receivership on Thursday after discovery of the fraud by investigating accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

The SFO has already issued 'Section 2 notices' - which compel co-operation - to the company, to its auditor Nunn Haywood and to accountants KPMG, Baker Tilly and Levy Gee, which had already investigated Versailles after a DTI probe.

The collapse has wiped out the £330m paper fortune of Carl Cushnie, founder of Versailles and the UK's most successful black businessman. The extent of the fraud was discovered only after last week's suspension of finance director Frederick Clough.

'Real turnover was less than half the £230m in the audited accounts. Cheques were being cross-fired all over the place to gross up apparent revenue,' one source said.

Cushnie is co-operating with receiver PwC, sources say. Clough has left the firm and could not be contacted.
fields.bodyText: Versailles, the collapsed trade finance company, fictitiously inflated its turnover by more than 100 per cent in a long-running fraud against banks, creditors and investors, The Observer has established. Around £50 million of cash is also so far understood to have flowed out through paper companies which were not genuine trading partners. Profits at the group, which was worth £630m until its shares were suspended before Christmas, were also illusory, investigative sources say. The firm, which is under investigation by the Serious Fraud Office, was put into receivership on Thursday after discovery of the fraud by investigating accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers. The SFO has already issued 'Section 2 notices' - which compel co-operation - to the company, to its auditor Nunn Haywood and to accountants KPMG, Baker Tilly and Levy Gee, which had already investigated Versailles after a DTI probe. The collapse has wiped out the £330m paper fortune of Carl Cushnie, founder of Versailles and the UK's most successful black businessman. The extent of the fraud was discovered only after last week's suspension of finance director Frederick Clough. 'Real turnover was less than half the £230m in the audited accounts. Cheques were being cross-fired all over the place to gross up apparent revenue,' one source said. Cushnie is co-operating with receiver PwC, sources say. Clough has left the firm and could not be contacted.

fields.headline: Money writes
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Breakdown in AA payout | Learning from endowments | Making up for lost years
fields.body:
Breakdown in AA payout

Although entitled to vote in Centrica's takeover of the AA, my daughter was not entitled to a payout because she was deemed not to have paid the subscription herself.

She used my credit card at the time so that she could pay over the telephone, but this was only ever a temporary arrangement.

JT, Newcastle upon Tyne

THE AA has taken a hard line on these payouts. Unless you paid for your membership yourself, you are not entitled to a windfall, which rules out anyone who received AA membership as a present. But the AA has looked again at your daughter's file and agrees that her situation is different.

It accepts that she did in fact pay for her membership herself, because she refunded you the money. This means she is entitled to a payment and should by now have received a cheque from the AA for £248.56.

Learning from endowments

I October 1985, my ex-husband and I took out an endowment policy with Standard Life to repay our £22,000 mortgage in 2010. Two years ago, I paid off the mortgage with an inheritance from my mother, but continued with the endowment. My ex-husband is to assign his interest in the policy to me so I can use the money to help pay for our sons' university education - but I will need the mon

re 2010.

Would I be better to cash in or sell the policy, and invest the proceeds for when they reach 18?

MM, Cricklade

Financially, you will be better off keeping this policy until it matures. If you cashed in now, you would get £10,680; if you cashed it when your first son goes to university, say in 2005, you might get £19,000 if it performs well; on maturity five years later, you could get more than £30,000.

The problem is that you bought the policy for a 25-year commitment and now need to use it for a shorter one.

You could borrow from Standard Life against the policy when your sons go to university. Today, you could have £8,434 at base rate plus 2.5 per cent, making the interest rate 8.25 per cent. You repay the loan when the policy matures. Alternatively, your sons could fund their education with student loans, which you could repay when the policy matured.

Making up for lost years

Is there any point in my son paying three missing years of National Insurance contributions, amounting to £861, when, at 52, his state pension so far stands at £25. I think he should pay but he says

not worth

<

is right?

MJ, Rottingdean

It depends how long he lives after starting the State pension at 65. Everyone is allowed to miss about five years' contributions and still earn the full state pension. Your son needs to have made National Insurance contributions or earned credits (perhaps his earnings were below the threshold for contributions, or he was on a state benefit) for 90 per cent of his working life.

If he works from 18 to 65, his working life is 47 years and, to meet the 90 per cent rule, needs contributions for 42 years. So, if your son is three years short because he worked for only 44 years, he still gets the full pension. But if he will be three years short of 42, he will get 93 per cent of the state pension.

On today's rates, this gives him £3,228 instead of £3,471 a year, a difference of £243. If restoring this shortfall costs £861, it will take him 3.5 years to earn it back, so it will have been worth paying if he is still alive at the age of 68 years and six months.

One mortgage too many

In May 1995, I took out a £54,000 mortgage jointly with my wife to buy a house in Manchester costing £60,000. It is now worth about £73,000. In June 1997, we separated and my ex-wife has paid the mortgage since August 1998. I moved b

my mother'

<

low and still live there.

My mother died last March, leaving this three-bedroom home, worth £58,000, to my brother and me; my brother wants the cash from his half share, so I need to remortgage to buy him out. But I am hindered by the outstanding joint mortgage with my wife. Who can I ask for help?

AE, Harlow

Ask your brother if he would take his money in instalments. Under the government Rent-A-Room scheme, you can earn £4,250 a year tax-free from a lodger. You could pay your brother his £29,000 within seven years.

Or perhaps you could mortgage the bungalow for £45,000; give your brother £29,000 and your wife £16,000 to reduce her debt to £38,000, with an agreement on eventually splitting the equity. On her earnings plus maintenance, she could just afford a mortgage in her own name, releasing you to take out the new mortgage.

Discuss this with several lenders directly or talk to a few mortgage brokers. Brokers are listed in telephone directories but pick those that have taken mortgage exams.

Share sale lost me money

Recently I instructed Dresdner RCM Investment Trusts to transfer a number of shares in its Charter European Trust into an Isa in my wife's name. The shares were sold on 11 November at 553p each but it was not until nine days later, when they were worth 588p, that they

ought back

<

e Isa, thus incurring a loss of £440.

How can such a delay be justified when dealing with a product which we are told can be bought and sold quickly?

EC, Sunderland

You may have regarded this as a family tidying-up exercise but you still get caught in the technicalities of share-dealing. This timescale is the number of days demanded by Stock Exchange rules and financial regulation: selling shares takes five days before the cash is available; a cheque is then sent to the Isa administrator, who waits three days for the cheque to clear; when the cheque has cleared, the administrator leaves a four-day cooling-off period before buying new investment trust shares for the Isa.

For the whole period, you are at the mercy of share price movements which could, of course, go as easily in your favour as against. A financial adviser, if you had used one, should have alerted you to the danger, although it may be some consolation that the shares now stand at 656p.

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.
