fields.headline: At your senior's service
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean  on how to look after an elderly relative's money
fields.trailText: So your elderly parent has just gone into an old people's home and you are responsible for handling their investments. Help the Aged's helpline is constantly bombarded by callers who suddenly have £50,000 to £100,000 to invest - perhaps after selling the family home.
fields.body:
So your elderly parent has just gone into an old people's home and you are responsible for handling their investments. Help the Aged's helpline is constantly bombarded by callers who suddenly have £50,000 to £100,000 to invest - perhaps after selling the family home.

The first calamity to avoid is trouble with the Benefits Agency. In most cases the elderly person is assessed by Social Services to agree a care package and 'means-test' their resources. If you are managing their assets, you are responsible for declaring all their income and capital. But, says Sam Harney of the Reading Community Welfare Rights Unit, people who get 'power of attorney' - taking over responsibility for the person's property - often face problems: 'They get into terrible trouble with the Benefits Agency because they didn't realise that the person had a works pension, for instance. They then become liable for an overpayment of welfare benefits. We have had a fair amount of success in winning appeals against this, but it is difficult.' Appeals are usually won if there are extenuating circumstances, such as difficulty in obtaining information.

An alternative is being made an 'appointee'. Appointees have the power to manage the assets, but the final responsibility still lies with the old person. The Benefits Agency has fewer rights to pursue appointees.

When investing for an old person, you need to make sure some of the money is easily accessible to pay monthly care fees. You will also want the investment to grow. A place in a nursing home often costs £20,000 a year, and a place in a residential home can easily cost £15,000. So the proceeds of the house sale can be swallowed up in three or four years. Philip Spiers, of the Nursing Home Fees Agency (NHFA), which runs Help the Aged's helpline, says: 'The people with the power of attorney often just don't take advice and leave the money on deposit. When it runs out, they find that Social Services caps the amount it pays a week, that there is a shortfall and that the home owner will not reduce the fee.' He says that in the home counties, for instance, local authorities typically pay a maximum of £320 a week for nursing home fees, although the actual cost is likely to be £80 more.

So, how should you invest that £50,000 to £100,000? Justin Modray of financial adviser Chase de Vere says the shorter the life expectancy, the less you will want to be exposed to risk. The most cautious response is to put most of it on deposit, where the capital is guaranteed but the return is likely to be low. Even for cautious people, some of the money could go into a cash-Isa: up to £3,000 can be put into cash before 6 April under the individual savings account rules. This ruse is worth taking advantage of before the end of the financial year, since next year's limit will be just £1,000. (See the best buy tables on page 14 for the best rates). Modray suggests that even cautious investors 'should put some of the investment into the stock markets'.

For people with a longer life expectancy, Modray says: 'You will want to make the money work for you, so you will take a bit of risk.' He suggests with-profits bonds as a fairly cautious way of investing in the stock markets, as well as corporate bond Isas. But he suggests that 'the first two or three years' money could be kept aside in cash'.

Spiers, of the NHFA, suggests another element to the investment plan - the purchase of a long-term care insurance policy - so that fees are definitely covered. Costs vary depending on the terms of the policy, but Spiers says expect about £25,000 to £30,000 in most cases. 'Always leave a bit on deposit for little extras,' he says. Home residents are often expected to pay for their own television set, telephone and other routine expenses. As people get older, there are likely to be more medical costs too.

Some financial advisers offer a free initial meeting. Help the Aged, through the NHFA, offers a free 'personal report' outlining how you might invest the sum. It hopes that people will then buy the products through them so that the commission can be split between the NHFA and the charity. But people can ask for the report and then buy the products themselves or through someone who will rebate the commission if they wish.

Age Concern: 0800 009966; Help the Aged's Care Fees Advisory Services helpline: 0500 767476; NHFA website: www.nhfa.co.uk.

Investments for older people's funds

Low-risk investments

Instant access accounts: from building societies and banks
Internet/postal accounts: often offer slightly better rates
Notice accounts: rates are higher to reflect notice period
Period accounts and bonds: usually fixed for 1,2 or 3 years
National Savings: range of products, many low-risk
Cash Isas: tax-free accounts, some very attractive rates

Medium-risk investments

With-profits policies: look for hidden high charges
Guaranteed income bonds: fixed return, main risk is that inflation rises while you are locked in
Guaranteed equity bond : no risk to capital usually; often hidden high charges; inflation risk
Corporate bond Isa: tax-free plan based on fixed-interest products; inflation risk

High-risk investments

Index-tracking unit trusts: a relatively cautious way to start stock market investments
Equity Isas: tax-free stock market investments; start with unit trusts

Note: Be wary of risky equity investments - such as direct shareholdings in companies or investments in emerging markets. These are really only suitable for people who expect to invest for long enough to see out medium-term stock market fluctuations - that could be 10 or 20 years. Avoid any clever schemes you do not understand: these have probably been made deliberately complicated to hide something.

Fred is 74. You have £70,000 to invest for him

Fred has raised £70,000 from the sale of his home in Kent. He is a widower and lived alone - so the proceeds are mainly to be used to cover his residential home care fees. He suffers from dementia, so cannot manage his own affairs. But he is in good physical health and could need to live off this money for many years. You are his closest relative. How do you invest the money for him? This is what Help the Aged's Care Fees Advisory Service said:

1 Assumed financial position

Basic state pension £67.00 per week

Higher rate attendance allowance £52.95 per week

Occupational pensions £60.00 net a week

Total income £179.95

Care fees £300.00

Shortfall £120.05 per week

2 Recommendation

Assume client has lucid moments so that you can establish an enduring power of attorney under which his family can manage his financial affairs. Assuming that the objectives with the money are to create certainty of income for life, and protecting some of his capital, the monies should be invested as follows:

- A specialist care fees payment plan (cost circa £33,000 from an insurance company) to produce income equivalent to £120.05 per week. Payment tax-free is then made by the insurer direct to the care provider.

- Balance of capital to be invested between monies on deposit for any special items and personal expenditure: £7,000 in a growth Isa, with the remainder of £30,000 in an equity-based investment with capital guaranteed on death.

3 Outcome

Monthly fees matched by additional income without imposing extra income tax liability. Preserving part of assets, which could be allowed to grow over time. If nursing home care were needed at a later date, income could then be generated from other investments and/or the purchase of a further care plan.

This also avoids problems of relying on Social Services and possibly having to move to a cheaper home.

Key objective is peace of mind to meet residential care costs for life, as well as ensuring inheritance for estate beneficiaries.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Late returns are as bad as never | Costly car cover | Roving rates | Bonds that free
fields.body:
Late returns are as bad as never

Get your tax return in by 7.30am on 2 February if you want to avoid a £100 fine. The final deadline has shifted from midnight on 31 January - the date officially set in legislation - to 31 hours later. This is the result of a little-known challenge to the Inland Revenue, in a case, Steeden v Carver, which was decided recently by the Special Commissioners.

The Revenue has done nothing to publicise the judgment, but a spokeswoman confirmed the impact: 'If the return is on the doormat at 7.30am on 2 February it will be accepted as if it had been received on 1 February. Following on from the case heard by the Special Commissioners, we will accept returns received by us on 1 February and won't charge a penalty.'

Tax experts successfully argued in the case that a day needed to elapse after the deadline before a taxpayer would be deemed late; the taxpayer's guilt could not be established in the passing of one second at midnight.

Tax returns need to be delivered to tax offices. It does not need to be the office you deal with; any tax office will do. Since the offices do not monitor the time envelopes are posted throughout the night, tax officials assume that all correspondence which is on the mat in the morning came through the letterbox before midnight.

Anyone who is sent a tax return is legally obliged to complete it and send it back. About 3 million people are thought to be struggling to reach the January/February deadline. If you have mislaid your tax return, you can download a new one from the Revenue's website at (www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk) or call the helpline on 0845 9000 444.

Costly car cover

Car insurance premiums are continuing to soar but there may be light at the end of the tunnel. AA Insurance's premium index shows that premiums for comprehensive cover have gone up by more than £28 in the past three months, and by £68 since last January.

The average comprehensive policy now costs more than £507. Motorists who shop around should be able to reduce their premiums by 36 per cent; the AA's shoparound premium, the average of the three lowest quotes obtained, worked out at £325. 36. Though 36 per cent lower than the average premium, this best-buy rate increased by 6.5 per cent during the final quarter of 1999.

Insurers continue to blame a combination of factors for the increases. The market is competitive and premiums are too low, they say, to cover the cost of claims.

Insurers are paying £1.15 in claims for each £1 taken in premiums. Hospitals are now claiming from insurers for the cost of care for road accident victims.

Actuary Bacon & Woodrow says that insurers made heavier losses on motor cover than ever before in 1998. But recent increases in premiums should mean a return to profitability this year.

Motorists cannot necessarily expect a fall in premiums next year, however. Large companies are becoming more dominant in the market, which means that there will be less competition for customers.

Roving rates

Mortgage lenders continued to announce rate rises last week following the previous week's increase in bank base rate. The standard variable mortgage rate among banks is now hovering around 7.49 per cent, although many building societies are charging less.

Most savers are still in the dark about the next move in their rates although there have been rises on a small number of accounts. Banks and building societies are expected to cherry-pick their flagship accounts for the most favourable rises, while many accounts will see increases well under the 0.25 per cent rise in base rates.

Banks and societies have, however, been launching fixed-rate deposit bonds. Northern Rock has three bonds, with rates fixed over one to three years. The top rate of 7.3 per cent is paid on the three-year bond and the minimum investment on each is £1,000 (0845 600 4466). Cheltenham & Gloucester is paying 7 per cent on a minimum of £500 over two years (0800 717505); Abbey National is paying 7 per cent until April 2002 on a minimum of £1,000 (0800 174 635); and Bradford & Bingley is paying 7 per cent on a minimum of £1,000 over three years (0800 570800). See databank, page 14

Bonds that free

Rates on guaranteed income bonds are also ris ing, to levels that make them attractive investments for taxpayers, according to Baronworth Investment Services.

fields.bodyText: Late returns are as bad as never Get your tax return in by 7.30am on 2 February if you want to avoid a £100 fine. The final deadline has shifted from midnight on 31 January - the date officially set in legislation - to 31 hours later. This is the result of a little-known challenge to the Inland Revenue, in a case, Steeden v Carver, which was decided recently by the Special Commissioners. The Revenue has done nothing to publicise the judgment, but a spokeswoman confirmed the impact: 'If the return is on the doormat at 7.30am on 2 February it will be accepted as if it had been received on 1 February. Following on from the case heard by the Special Commissioners, we will accept returns received by us on 1 February and won't charge a penalty.' Tax experts successfully argued in the case that a day needed to elapse after the deadline before a taxpayer would be deemed late; the taxpayer's guilt could not be established in the passing of one second at midnight. Tax returns need to be delivered to tax offices. It does not need to be the office you deal with; any tax office will do. Since the offices do not monitor the time envelopes are posted throughout the night, tax officials assume that all correspondence which is on the mat in the morning came through the letterbox before midnight. Anyone who is sent a tax return is legally obliged to complete it and send it back. About 3 million people are thought to be struggling to reach the January/February deadline. fields.headline: Mean times over Greenwich
fields.trailText: It was a bad start to the Government's new millennium relations with industry, just as the furore over the problems of the Health Service shows disillusionment among the general public about the gap between expectations and reality under New Labour.
fields.body:
On New Year's Eve a prominent industrialist and his party were kept waiting for two-and-a-quarter hours for their tickets to the millennium celebration at the Dome. Since the firm had had its arm twisted to support the Dome to the tune of £12 million, the industrialist was not amused. The further 90-minute wait to pass the Dome's security point did not go down well either. Then came the announcement that the drinks had run out and the sideshows were closed.

'Never mind,' they were told, 'there is a special Tesco pack to be distributed, containing a quarter-bottle of champagne and an assemble-it-yourself champagne glass.' This sounded pretty naff, but was nonetheless welcome in the circumstances. But, hang on a minute, the Tesco packs ran out too. The industrialist had his first new millennium drink when he got home in the small hours. 'As far as I'm concerned, New Labour can wait for their £12m,' he said.

There were presumably many other such examples. It was a bad start to the Government's new millennium relations with industry, just as the furore over the problems of the Health Service shows disillusionment among the general public about the gap between expectations and reality under New Labour.

But let's have a commercial break for the good news. Those of us who spent much of the 1980s and early 1990s campaigning against economic policies that produced very high levels of unemployment cannot but welcome the news that what is known as the 'headline' total of unemployment is down to a 20-year low, at 1.164m, or 4 per cent of the workforce.

On the other hand, it has to be noted that this is the statis tic produced after many revisions to the calculations and benefit rules under successive governments since 1979. What is described as the Government's 'preferred measure' - those seeking work but not necessarily claiming benefit - is still 5.9 per cent, or 1.726m. I do wonder how long the Government will go on preferring this measure.

The Chancellor is especially enthusiastic about the vacancy figures, which he believes show - provided the Government's 'active employment' policies do their job - that there is work out there for almost everybody. And this is after a year of relatively slow - 2 per cent - growth.

Nevertheless, there are some dark clouds around, and they hover in particular over manufacturing. The headlines were wonderful last week - 'industry growing at fastest rate since 1995' - but when you looked at the figures you found that in November 1999 the output of Britain's manufacturing industry was a mere 3.5 per cent above its 1995 average. Some growth.

Now, before Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells writes in and tells me that manufacturing no longer matters, I ask him or her to look around their home, note everything they see or use outside that home, and tell me if manufacturing has really disappeared from the scene. They might also cast an eye over the number of manufactured items the so-called 'service industries' seem to regard as indispensable to their routine tasks.

Labour's conversion to the importance of business and entrepreneurship is welcome. Many people in the Party during the 1960s and 1970s were plain anti-business. This government is, if anything, too subservient, but it will no doubt learn the hard way.

The problem is that while paying lip, and indeed financial, service to business and entrepreneurs, the Government is presiding over a potential disaster, namely an excessively strong pound. The International Monetary Fund believes the equilibrium rate for the pound is DM2.44. The Confederation of British Industry would not want to enter the euro at above DM2.65. Lord Paul, the Labour peer and industrialist, believes the 'hands-off' approach to the exchange rate is damaging to British manufacturing.

The real concern of overseas firms with direct investments in this country seems to me to be not so much our policy towards the euro as our high and rising exchange rate. Paul believes we should have joined the euro at its inception, which would have given a rate of DM2.76, as opposed to the DM 3.20 that was touched last week.

The strong pound is at least one of the factors behind the problems of Geoffrey Robinson's Transtech. People say industry is coping and adjusting; but it is coping and adjusting by re-sourcing abroad. This means export figures will have a higher import content. There are always time lags before the full damage becomes apparent, but become apparent it will.

There is a fascinating historical parallel developing. The reasons why the pound was not put into the European exchange rate mechanism in 1978-79 were partly 'political', but there was also a fear that Britain would suffer an overvalued exchange rate, and lose the freedom to adjust, if we joined the ERM.

The pound proceeded to experience what was described by the President of the Bundesbank as the largest overvaluation of any major currency in recent financial history. Manufacturing suffered severely.

One of the economic reasons for not joining the euro was, and is, fear about an overvalued exchange rate. Yet here we go again. And I write as one who had and has many reservations about Britain joining the euro.

webTitle: Why King of Prussia rules the US drugs world

fields.headline: Why King of Prussia rules the US drugs world
fields.trailText: Philadelphia - Glaxo SmithKline's new operational headquarters - lies at the southern tip of the US pharmaceuticals industry's equivalent of Silicon Valley.
fields.body:
Philadelphia - Glaxo SmithKline's new operational headquarters - lies at the southern tip of the US pharmaceuticals industry's equivalent of Silicon Valley.

Pennsylvania's biggest city was the birthplace of SmithKline Beckman, the US firm which in 1989 kicked off a decade of huge deals in the sector by merging with Britain's Beecham.

The 80-mile stretch running north-east from Phil-adelphia, through the Ivy League university town of Princeton to New Bruns-wick, and Madison in neighbouring New Jersey, is also home to many of the biggest US drugs companies, including Merck, American Home Products, Bristol Myers Squibb, Schering Plough, Warner Lambert and Johnson & Johnson.

It is a magnet for skills and expertise, and with increasing globalisation it poses a growing challenge to the other traditional centres of drugs excellence: the UK, Switzerland and Sweden.

SmithKline's two big US R&D facilities, Upper Merrion and Upper Providence, are in the quaintly named King of Prussia, a pleasant 45-minute drive through countryside from Philadelphia. The huge development zone, home to the Atlantic seaboard's biggest shopping mall, also houses the blood and plasma operations of Franco-German drugs giant Aventis.

King of Prussia has attracted several British firms serving the industry, such as Sechi, an Oxford-based pharmaceutical software company. 'It's really the happening place to go,' said chief executive Mike Buckle. 'We're not the only UK firm there.'

Other US states, too, find it tough to compete with 'Drugs Valley'. With nearly half the merged Glaxo SmithKline's sales in the US, the group's 13,000 US staff are worried. Where are the 'savings' to be made? Perhaps the most worried will be the 5,000 at Glaxo's research, development and manufacturing complex at Triangle Park in North Carolina. It is the firm's biggest single facility worldwide - but it's American and it's outside the increasingly important Prussian zone.

fields.headline: Glaxo merger's acid test
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan  on fears over the future of R&D
fields.trailText: 'We see ourselves unabashedly as a science-based, R&D-driven company.' Which FTSE 100 executive said this? Gerald Corbett, head of Railtrack? Obviously not. Robin Saxby, head of ARM? Warmer. Dr James Niedel, head of science and technology at Glaxo Wellcome? Correct.
fields.body:
'We see ourselves unabashedly as a science-based, R&D-driven company.' Which FTSE 100 executive said this? Gerald Corbett, head of Railtrack? Obviously not. Robin Saxby, head of ARM? Warmer. Dr James Niedel, head of science and technology at Glaxo Wellcome? Correct.

But the question is not so much who said it, but when. It was said not last Monday, when Glaxo announced its £114 billion merger with SmithKline Beecham, to become the world's biggest drugs company, with 7.3 per cent of the global market for pharmaceuticals, but back in November 1995. He said this after Glaxo had paid £9.1bn for Wellcome, and when the new drugs colossus unveiled what was billed as the most vital plank of its integration - its R&D strategy.

The company had spent the time since the March deal reviewing its R&D projects. The aim was simple - to bring three financially important products to market each year from 2000. Has it worked?

Analysts are sceptical. Lehman Brothers' Ian Smith expresses a common view. 'You can easily make a case that it has not delivered on its R&D promises,' he says. This is galling for the R&D staff who lost their jobs when the group's R&D workforce fell from 11,500 to 9,700 - 1,800 out of the total of 7,500 jobs lost.

The brunt of the cuts were borne by Wellcome staff at the company's research HQ in Beckenham, which lost most of its 1,600 employees.

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, says: 'Glaxo effectively finished Wellcome. This was supposed to be an R&D-driven company, yet they finished off the Beckenham site, which had been the centre of great research and important discoveries.'

The scars of what MSF calls the 'gutting' of Wellcome remain. Last year, when Glaxo announced a further 1,700 job cuts, they were focused on another former Wellcome site, at Dartford.

Few would argue about Glaxo Wellcome - which accounts for a fifth of total UK R&D expenditure - being the UK's primary research-based company. But Smith and others suggest its record over the past five years is mixed.

He points to good results, such as the Aids combination therapy Combivir, released in 1997, with annual sales of $750 million. Asthma drug Seretide, approved in Europe last year, has done well and promises $1bn sales if it gains US approval this year.

But there have been outright flops - Ultiva, an anaesthetic, and Pylorid, a Zantac replacement on which Glaxo set much store, disappointed.

This year, hopes centre on a treatment for irritable bowel called Lotronex which, if approved, analysts have slated in at $1bn a year. But the 2000 target looks shaky. There has been nothing to replace Zantac or products such as Astra Zeneca's Losec or Eli Lilley's Prozac, says Smith. Even flu treatment Relenza made only $75m in its first eight months.

Smith says: 'Some people say Glaxo is following the Star Trek syndrome of R&D - boldly going to areas where no one has gone before. It's instinctive, but it is risky.'

Some believe the Smith- Kline marriage - which allows Glaxo to fill its own R&D desert with products such as SB's diabetes drug Avandia - reflects this failure. Sir John Robb, Wellcome chief executive until the 1995 deal, says: 'I don't think big is necessarily beautiful in R&D terms. These mega-mergers are driven more by financial benefits - this must have been the case with Glaxo Wellcome because Glaxo's Zantac patent was expiring and Wellcome was losing Zovirax. What that merger has not delivered is a strong pipeline. So . . . the next move is another merger.'

While productivity was intended to rise from 1995, spending did not. It was to be held at around £1.2bn, but in fact the 1995 R&D budget of £1.2bn went down 3 per cent (£39m) in 1996 and fell a further 1 per cent in 1997, before recovering 1 per cent in 1998.

Restraining R&D for earnings caused problems. Merril Lynch's James Culverell says: 'They promised stable earnings in 1998 which they just about achieved. The reality was it would probably have been better not to have delivered on that and spent more on R&D.'

Last year things got worse. Glaxo chairman Sir Richard Sykes had promised a return to double-digit growth. In July he told investors that this would not happen. It did not go down well.

The twin disappointments make an important point, which will be the acid test of the next mega-merger. In the words of one analyst: 'Pharmaceuticals is a long-term game, and much of the far-off stuff can only be understood by people with strong scientific backgrounds. The City, on the other hand, thinks after lunch is a long time away.'

When Glaxo SmithKline set out its stall last week, it said: 'This combination will help Glaxo SmithKline to become the most productive research organisation in the pharmaceuticals industry.' Of the £1bn savings it is looking for from the merger, £250m will be ploughed into R&D. The key R&D sites, at Stevenage and Harlow, will remain.

'The merger is good news,' says Richard Ley, spokesman for the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry. 'It takes an average of £350m to bring a drug to market. And it is good news for the UK, which already spends more of its wealth on R&D than Germany or France.'

The stakes are high. The Government has placed R&D at the centre of its drive to create a knowledge-based economy. In last year's Budget, Chancellor Gordon Brown introduced a £150m package of tax credits for R&D which would cut research costs. Supporters of the policy say it will give a fillip to small businesses. But sceptics say the scope of the initiative is too small to have much impact.

Unsurprisingly, there are doubts about the implications of the Glaxo merger for R&D in the UK. MSF's Lyons says: 'What happened last time does not fill us with hope. They may not close Stevenage and Harlow tomorrow, but this company is being run from the US. Will investment go into the UK or the "research triangle" facilities in the US?'

One industry insider says: 'The Glaxo Wellcome deal as a forerunner to Glaxo Smith- Kline is not great - it was essentially little more than a cost-saving operation.' Dr Michael Clark, chairman of the Commons Science and Technology Committee, agrees: 'This could lead to a fall in spending in the short term, and less competition and possible innovation in R&D.' However, he believes the combined group in the long term would make sense.

The question is, is it different this time? Smith says: 'It is. The way the industry does its R&D has changed dramatically in the past five years.'

The change involves advances in 'genomics'. Drug 'targets' - the estimated 5,000 possible treatable conditions to be discovered through genetic analysis - will be identified by isolating the genes that cause diseases and aiming treatments at them. This requires a list of genes, knowing which ones cause which problems, the ability to access them and finding a chemical combination to treat them.

Industry analysts say SmithKline Beecham is the expert in genomics while Glaxo, through its Affymax subsidiary, acquired in 1995, is one of the world leaders in 'combinational chemistry' - the ability to process huge amounts of chemical data to find answers to genomic questions quickly.

Smith says: 'Those who get ahead in the next five years while there is the scramble to answer these questions will reap the rewards.' But two years ago - before the personality clash between Sykes and SB head Jan Leschly sank the previous merger - might have been better timing. US genomics firm Celera, for example, saw its shares rise 28 per cent this month when it announced it had decoded 90 per cent of the human genome and is expected to finish mid-year. The company has seen its value quintuple since October. It has partnerships with giants including Pfizer and Pharmacia & Upjohn.

Concern within the company and the scientific community will focus on whether the new GlaxoSB can beat the gold rush.

The way the industry does its R&D has changed dramatically in the past five years.' The change involves advances in 'genomics'. Drug 'targets' - the estimated 5,000 possible treatable conditions to be discovered through genetic analysis - will be identified by isolating the genes that cause diseases and aiming treatments at them. This requires a list of genes, knowing which ones cause which problems, the ability to access them and finding a chemical combination to treat them. Industry analysts say SmithKline Beecham is the expert in genomics while Glaxo, through its Affymax subsidiary, acquired in 1995, is one of the world leaders in 'combinational chemistry' - the ability to process huge amounts of chemical data to find answers to genomic questions quickly. Smith says: 'Those who get ahead in the next five years while there is the scramble to answer these questions will reap the rewards.' But two years ago - before the personality clash between Sykes and SB head Jan Leschly sank the previous merger - might have been better timing. US genomics firm Celera, for example, saw its shares rise 28 per cent this month when it announced it had decoded 90 per cent of the human genome and is expected to finish mid-year. The company has seen its value quintuple since October. It has partnerships with giants including Pfizer and Pharmacia & Upjohn. Concern within the company and the scientific community will focus on whether the new GlaxoSB can beat the gold rush.

fields.headline: Verdict threatens all insurers
fields.trailText: The financial strength of the entire UK life insurance industry could be undermined by Friday's court decision against Equitable Life, industry analysts said this weekend.
fields.body:
The financial strength of the entire UK life insurance industry could be undermined by Friday's court decision against Equitable Life, industry analysts said this weekend.

The ruling puts a new question mark over the future of with-profits investments, already under a cloud because of falling returns on mortgage endowments.

Nick Holmes of ratings agency Moody's said the Court of Appeal decision that ruled that Equitable should not have cut bonuses on pensions that policyholders believed offered guaranteed returns, could set an important precedent. It threatens the considerable flexibility insurers have over deciding the bonuses they pay on with-profits policies.

Equitable intends to appeal to the House of Lords, but if the final ruling goes against it, other insurers could be vulnerable to court challenges over the way they set investment returns.

Holmes said: 'If they have flexibility to set bonuses, they are financially a lot stronger. They can tailor bonuses to reflect their financial performance. What is particularly interesting about the Equitable case is that it is calling into question that flexibility. That could lead to a weakening of the financial strength of the whole industry.'

Moody's is already considering downgrading Equitable's rating: it is currently A1, several rungs below Moody's top rating of AAA.

The Appeal Court's deci sion seems at first glance to be a victory for policyholders. If upheld by the Lords it should certainly benefit the 90,000 people who believed their pension plans guaranteed them a certain level of income -much higher than the equivalent policies would pay today. But other industry experts maintain this could be at the expense of other policyholders .

Insurers are already cutting bonuses on with-profits investments, adding to concerns about the ability of mortgage endowments to repay homeloan debts. Some firms of advisers are already reluctant to recommend with-profits policies, and several mortgage lenders have stopped selling endowments.

 Disquiet is growing among homeowners about endowment shortfalls and other problems associated with the investments. New figures from the Personal Investment Authority Ombudsman show that he took on 709 cases between last April and the end of 1999. This compares with 209 in the whole of the previous year.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText:
Sweet smell of sex-cess
They are just finishing cleaning up after the world's first Internet sex convention in Las Vegas, which seems to have been a rip-roaring success. More than 5,000 people attended the convention looking to strike deals, buy state-of-the-art technology, and register domain names. Considering tickets were $275 each, the Internet sex industry is obviously in rude health.
fields.body:
Sweet smell of sex-cess
They are just finishing cleaning up after the world's first Internet sex convention in Las Vegas, which seems to have been a rip-roaring success. More than 5,000 people attended the convention looking to strike deals, buy state-of-the-art technology, and register domain names. Considering tickets were $275 each, the Internet sex industry is obviously in rude health.

Boo-hoo
This week's etailer is boo.com which has bowed to the inevitable and announced an end-of-season sale. Slated for its dreadful web design, poor marketing and the fact that its goods were often just as expensive as in the shops, boo, which describes itself as the 'first truly global urban sportswear on-line retailer', is in desperate need of some positive PR. The sale, which lasts from this Thursday to 10 February, will see prices slashed by up to 40 per cent. If this doesn't work ...

Where there's a warehouse...
The future belongs to the dull. While everyone gets very excited about e-commerce, those who are really cleaning up are companies lurking in the background ensuring little Johnny gets his Pokémon delivered on time from an etailer. FPD Savills, the property agent, predicts a need for an extra 13 million sq ft of warehouse space to cope with the expected etail boom over the next five years. Warehouse firms - the new .com businesses.

UK netheads rule
The 'web-tastic' news (their phrase, not ours) from package delivery firm UPS is that Britain is leading the rest of Europe in electronic commerce. According to a survey of 'senior business opinion', 55 per cent of British executives said they used the Internet for electronic commerce, compared with 38 per cent in Belgium, the second most technologically aware nation. British business executives receive more e-mails per day than any other western European nation - 29 compared with the average of 20.

Coming up roses
Flowers Direct Ltd, the UK on-line florist, is auctioning its Internet address - flowersdirect.co.uk - through electronic auction house eBay. The anticipated price at auction is a whopping £5 million. Interest has apparently been so intense that the auction's closing date for interested parties to register has been pushed back from 17 January to this Thursday.

fields.headline: No buyers for Kwik Save
fields.trailText: Somerfield, the beleaguered food retailer, will this week reveal that it has managed to offload most of the large stores it put up for sale but faces big write-offs on Kwik Save stores.
fields.body:
Somerfield, the beleaguered food retailer, will this week reveal that it has managed to offload most of the large stores it put up for sale but faces big write-offs on Kwik Save stores.

The group will also reveal a sharp deterioration in its trading as it announces its delayed interim results. Some estimate that its sales over the key Christmas periods were down by well over 20 per cent compared with the same period last year.

The store disposals were announced in November as part of a series of measures aimed at reversing disastrous performance following Somerfield's acquisition of Kwik Save two years ago. The group will now focus on the high street: it is selling around 130 large stores and 350 Kwik Save stores which are not suitable for conversion to the Somerfield format.

It is believed that all the major supermarket groups, including Asda, Waitrose, Safeway and Sainsbury, are taking some sites; others are going to non-food retailers such as Peacocks or to property developers. The scale of interest means the superstores are likely to fetch more than the £400 million-£600m estimated by analysts when the sales were announced.

But industry sources say it is having far less success with the sale of the Kwik Save stores. The performance of these stores has been deterio rating most sharply. Somerfield revealed in November that sales had been dropping by 16.2 per cent, and analysts believe the position will have weakened significantly.

Negotiations have been hampered by Somerfield's insistence that any sales are unconditional. Many buyers want to be able to seek recompense from Somerfield if, for example, the landlord makes excessive demands.

Concern in the City that these stores will not raise significant funds pushed Somerfield's shares down from 84.25p to 61.75p during the week. Sentiment was also hit by rumours that finance director Martin Gatto was leaving but this was denied.

webTitle: Tone-deaf conductors of a symphony of gloom

fields.headline: Tone-deaf conductors of a symphony of gloom
fields.standfirst: On the press
fields.trailText: On the press
fields.body:
Suddenly the lost tribes of Fleet Street are on the march again. You can smell the blood duly summoned, and the acrid stench of fear on the wind. The Guardian clears its front page. The Mail goes into overdrive. Politics, proper politics, is back.

The worshipful company of Lobby correspondents has, by and large, had a thin time of it since New Labour took over. Lead stories have come few and far between. Too little raw drama, too much smooth spin. Political editors who thought they ruled the world have watched showbiz reporters and e-commerce specialists begin to leave them behind. Readers vote when they yawn.

But now, abruptly, the yawning would seem to have stopped. 'Blair's 25 per cent polls slump,' said the Mirror last week: and those papers who'd toiled to produce just such a diminished (49 per cent) popularity rating reached for the vitriol. Ministers on the interview circuit junked their old litany about 'health and education' being the real issues. Health, in particular, had become an issue so real it was biting their legs off. A Government in a muck sweat was running for cover.

Such excitements can, of course, be overdone. Tony Blair's 'slump' (it later emerged in the Guardian ) hasn't remotely harmed his party: one point down on last month's approval ratings against one puny point up for the Tories. Non-epidemics of flu will surely fade from the headlines with the first crocuses. Agendas move on.

Nevertheless, the media lesson of January is that Labour, all angry bleats and furrowed brows, is wobbly on health. There will be much more of the same before the election, and it's instructive to see how the sides line up, to compare and contrast. When Mrs Mavis Skeet from Wakefield is 'Condemned to Death' on the front page of the Mail - because her cancer operation was cancelled four times - Mr Blair is there in person to 'accept the responsibility' for putting this 'dreadful' wrong right. When the famous Lord Winston tells the New Statesman about his 87-year-old mum's 13-hour ordeal on a trolley waiting for a bed, the entire press rallies behind his indignation.

Such horrors knock directly on Whitehall's doors. Doctors are acknowledged experts on the workings of the NHS. Their word is law. Nurses are angelic, blonde and beautiful (like staff nurse Marilyn Hayes, pictured embodying all those qualities on the front of the Times).

Let's, for a moment, talk instead about that other great state employer - education - and cull a few headlines from recent months. 'Hundreds of bad teachers sacked' (the Independent). 'Teachers too ashamed to admit inability in maths' (Guardian). 'Smarten up if you want a pay rise, teachers warned' (Sunday Telegraph). 'Incompetent teachers face life ban' (Express). And these are only the first few bars of a symphony of gloom.

Mr Blair would never take personal responsibility for your kid's 'dreadful' exam results. Blame would stay with the teachers, the head, and possibly the local authority. Lord Winston would never extrapolate general disaster from one school admissions muddle. He'd kick the people on the ground. Leaders of the NUT pleading poverty would get short shrift from the Mail; leaders of the BMA, however, are treated with earnest reverence. There are, apparently, thousands of lousy teachers - but only devoted doctors and nurses.

And from this curious premise, some profoundly curious conclusions flow. Newspapers which would otherwise find nothing good to say about Europe - that geriatric, mollycoddled, failed union of quasi-socialist states - are suddenly loud in their praise for what happens over there. 'Germany spends 10.7 per cent of GDP on health care, France spends 9.7 per cent and Italy 7.8 per cent, while Britain lags with just 6.9 per cent,' according to the Mail.

So we must catch up. But how? Enter the arch-populist, Richard Littlejohn in the Sun: 'It's time we all grew up and accepted that in the 21st century we can no longer expect governments to provide a "free" cradle-to-grave health and welfare system.' Littlejohn wants Sun readers who spend a fortune on cars, stereo and foreign holidays 'to shell out a few hundred quid a year on private medical insurance'. It seems, somehow, an unlikely call to arms.

This was 'the week that New Labour spun out of control,' said the Mail on Sunday - 'the week Britain woke up to Labour', echoed the Mail. Certainly it was a week which left the Government tattered and torn. But it was also a week without a hint of structured debate or rational conclusions.

There were plenty of horror stories. The Telegraph leader writer found one in the case of 'three-year-old Hannah Smith, whose heart operation was postponed seven times - twice for want off intensive care beds, twice because of "administrative errors" and three times because she was too ill'. Fair enough. But what were those 'administrative' cock-ups, who made them, and why? If the hapless administrator had worked for Lambeth education, we'd have known soon enough. If he'd toiled for the European Commission, he would have been hanged, drawn and quartered before breakfast.

More money for health (and defence after Kosovo, and the police after the crime figures)? Of course. That's the collective wisdom of the press, raising two fingers to spin as the Lobby breaks free. But compare and contrast. Could we have a little hard analytical reporting, too?

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText:
Bet your boots
Boots, already one Observer correspondent's retail tip of the year, is worth an in-depth look - and not just following the flu epidemic. The retailer's brand roll-out in Japan has, of course, been well flagged. Closer to home, fears of competition from Tesco and Asda, though real, must now be all out of proportion to the threat. Broker Charterhouse, a long-term bear, thinks so, and has now switched to a buy stance.
fields.body:
Bet your boots
Boots, already one Observer correspondent's retail tip of the year, is worth an in-depth look - and not just following the flu epidemic. The retailer's brand roll-out in Japan has, of course, been well flagged. Closer to home, fears of competition from Tesco and Asda, though real, must now be all out of proportion to the threat. Broker Charterhouse, a long-term bear, thinks so, and has now switched to a buy stance.

In 1999, Boots was one of the worst performers in the sector and the slide has continued into the new millennium. At 492.5p now - and stripping out Boots Healthcare International, Boots Opticians, overseas retail, property and the new Internet interests - the shares value the core Boots the Chemists chain and manufacturing arm at less than eight times prospective earnings.

So far, Boots has not cropped up on the gossip mill as a target for Knutsford, Philip Green or other high street raiders. At these levels, according to banking sources, it is sure to do so soon. On fundamentals alone, Charterhouse values the shares at 750p before any bid speculation has set in. Buy.

No regrets
Did we predict 'euphoria' last week when the merger of Glaxo Wellcome and Smith-Kline Beecham was finally unveiled? Well, immediately at least, we couldn't have been more wrong. Shares in Glaxo and SmithKline fell 4.7 and 6.9 per cent respectively after Monday's announcement, giving up all the previous week's gains. With Glaxo ending at 1625p on Friday, and SmithKline at 736p, the slide just continued.

Disappointment at the level of cost savings did much of the damage. With analysts expecting £1.5 billion or more, the £1bn announced seemed miserly. That estimate is likely to be conservative. Why, with all the sensitivities involved and intense US scrutiny likely, should chief executive-elect Jean Pierre Garnier make a rod for his own back from the outset?

Broker Commerzbank for one is expecting Glaxo SmithKline to restore its rating. To put Britain's drugs duo on a par with their international peers, the broker has set a target of 2,150p for Glaxo and 975p for SmithKline before the deal is completed. So keep on holding on.

High-tech magic
One broker looking decidedly clever in high-tech last week was Granville's information technology analyst, Roger Phillips. His latest note, days before FI Group's £670m bid for IT consultancy Druid, recommended holding on to Druid shares despite the firm's recent profit warning. He tipped quoted rivals Axon and Diagonal as 'buys'.

And the result of last Monday's latest piece of consolidation in the sector: Druid is being taken out at £28.53 against £19.18 beforehand; Diagonal has leapt to 570p from 363p; and Axon is nicely ahead at 997.5p from 715p.

So do you now take profits or not? At Axon, definitely not, says Phillips. Once out, it's difficult to get back in. The firm is sure the stock will hit £10 by the year-end.

Diagonal, too, remains a long-term buy. But in the aftermath of the Druid deal, there may be scope to lock in profits on Diagonal now and buy again on any future drift.

Go for value
More recommendations for 2000 land on our desk - this time from Charterhouse, which expects sentiment to turn to value stocks. Its key buys in the FTSE-100 index, therefore, are engineers Rolls-Royce and Invensys, electricity and water firms Scottish & Southern and United Utilities, property giant Land Securities, insurer CGU and fund manager Amvescap. Alone among high-tech stocks, Cable & Wireless makes the list on recovery and bid potential, especially if Hong Kong Telecom is spun off.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText:
In the frame
It's not quite Banquo's ghost - but it's the next best thing. Nails are being gnawed in Canary Wharf Towers over the artwork in the former Mirror Group Newspapers' boardroom. Directors of TrinityMirror, the newly merged company, are wondering what to do with the oils - no doubt including 'Crying Child set against Black Velvet' - that adorn the walls. The pictures originally came from ousted chief executive David Montgomery's second wife (keep up), Sophie Birdwood. fields.body:
In the frame
It's not quite Banquo's ghost - but it's the next best thing. Nails are being gnawed in Canary Wharf Towers over the artwork in the former Mirror Group Newspapers' boardroom. Directors of TrinityMirror, the newly merged company, are wondering what to do with the oils - no doubt including 'Crying Child set against Black Velvet' - that adorn the walls. The pictures originally came from ousted chief executive David Montgomery's second wife (keep up), Sophie Birdwood. Given the unpleasant circumstances surrounding Monty's departure, which was hardly voluntary, the new board are not sure they want a persistent reminder of the former CEO hanging round at every meeting. 'I think we'll have to find a way of, ahem, disposing of them,' confessed one director. 'They're not quite to our taste.'

But all this begs the question of whether they actually belong to the company. Surely, as Mrs Monty was a procurer of fine art, is it not possible that the former CEO spent company money buying art from his wife's clients? In which case TrinityMirror should give them back to the rightful owner forthwith. Either that or a trip down to the prestigious Hyde Park 'railings' gallery for a quick disposal.

Gregwatch: a reprieve.
This week to the stockbrokers where G Dyke, incoming director general of the BBC, has popped in to sell his £6 million of Granada shares with rather bad grace. Not only is there to be a whopping capital gains tax on the disposal, but Dyke is also clearly piqued at having to dispose of one of the Observer's shares tips for the coming year.

Something he might like to do with the proceeds is invest in dramatising his predecessor Sir John Birt's stonking three-part autobiography - working title My Life, My BBC and My Management (the third instalment is, in fact, a free subscription to the McKinsey Quarterly).

Death warmed up
The departure of Sir John Birt from the BBC is apparently being celebrated - or commemorated - with the relaunch of The Listener on-line. Like the European.com there seems to be a sudden vogue for publications which couldn't make their sums add up on paper reviving over the Internet. Could this mean the revival of Now!, Today and perhaps even the London Illustrated News, on a website near you soon?

The picture of Andy Gray
We have no beef with What Satellite? magazine, but we do wonder who reads it. Or rather who votes in its awards. In the category 'most fanciable male on satellite TV' - an important area of performance thus far overlooked by the Baftas - George Clooney and Matt Le Blanc were seen off by the chiselled features of Andy 'he's got to hit the target from there' Gray. And in the corresponding female awards, the victor was not, as one might expect, Jennifer Aniston or Sarah 'Buffy' Michelle Geller but doughty Sky news anchor Kay Burley, for the second year in a row. We hope that with ITN planning its own satellite news channel some time in 2000, Gray will be beaten off next year, so to speak, by their new political supremo, John 'something for the ladies' Sergeant.

fields.headline: Title fights stoke freesheet war
fields.standfirst: The UK press is locked in its bloodiest battle for years, says  Emily Bell
fields.trailText: The UK press is locked in its bloodiest battle for years, says Emily Bell
fields.body:
What's in a name? If you are thinking of launching a free morning newspaper anywhere in the UK and using the name Metro, the answer is a lot of grief and a costly court case.

What started as the bright idea of a Scandinavian publishing company in 1995 has now become the most fiercely and acrimoniously contested newspaper battle seen in Britain since Rupert Murdoch lowered the price of the Sun and the Times more than five years ago.

Given the warnings of plummeting newspaper circulation - and, as one regional press executive put it last year, '10 years of the industry having the last rites read over it' - the frenzied rush to stuff every railway carriage, every Tube train and every bus with free morning newspapers looks not only curiously anachronistic but commercially suicidal. Yet no side seems prepared to give ground in what is escalating into a copyright battle of international significance.

Last week saw two separate court cases involving three separate publishers fighting over the right to publish a free morning newspaper bearing the name Metro in one form or another.

Last Wednesday, Guardian Media Group, owner of The Observer, the Guardian and the Manchester Evening News, took out an injunction stopping Daily Mail and General Trust's Associated Newspapers from continuing to put out a 'Metro' free morning newspaper in Manchester. Associated was ordered to withdraw its Metro Northwest title from distribution by tomorrow, and this weekend the company is believed to be working on an alternative plan which, if necessary, will change the paper's title in order to keep a freesheet presence on Manchester's streets.

Meanwhile, over the Pennines and up the A1 in Newcastle the war is spreading. Here, TrinityMirror, publisher of regional morning paper the Journal and the Evening Chronicle, obtained a licence from Associated Newspapers to print - of course - a Metro freesheet, which it started distributing two weeks ago.

Then, last Monday, the Vikings invaded. The Modern Times Group, from Sweden, launched its own Metro, distributed on the the public transport systems of Tyneside. The barrage of free newspapers was followed by a fusillade of expensive legal documents as TrinityMirror took High Court action against Modern Times to stop it using the title.

At Modern Times's London HQ in Curzon Street there is general bemusement and some bitterness over the turf war the five-letter word has prompted on the streets of the UK's major cities. Modern Times is, after all, the company that pioneered a transport system-based distribution network for a free morning newspaper in Stockholm five years ago.

There, the selection of national and international stories thrown together with little reverence for standard newspaper design and layout acquired a circulation of more than 240,000 a day among commuters. With the adaptability of the idea evident to MTG's Stockholm-based management, the paper rolled into one territory after another, with notable success. It soon became the leading morning newspaper in Prague and Budapest, and a further eight versions were launched in the Netherlands.

It was only a matter of time before the Nordic marauders arrived on the UK's shores, snow on their boots and in their hand a rolled-up newspaper with which to batter the incumbent press groups.

One man quick to spot the potential competition was the late Lord Rothermere, who noted the success of the Stockholm operation, and watched its roll-out with some apprehension, wondering what might happen to his own London Evening Standard , not to mention the Daily Mail's extensive range of regional papers, should the Swedish paper ever arrive in the UK.

The outcome of his musing was an absolutely unashamed copy of the Swedish prototype, complete with the controversial title, which appeared on the London Underground last spring.

The strange truth is that despite originating the idea, Modern Times's Newcastle launch last week marked the first time its product had landed in the UK market. Editor Adrian Martin outlines the newspaper's philosophy: 'We don't editorialise; we don't tell our readers what to think or do. We just supply them with a digest of the day's stories.'

He believes there is a market for what the newspaper connoisseur may consider a crude product. 'I have spent 19 years in the regional press, and we are told that readers, - particularly young people - are getting their information from other sources. If this introduces a different sort of newspaper or exposes people to newspapers for the first time, it has to be a good thing.'

With many millions of pounds being invested in this pernicious conflict, what is most startling is that in the areas where Associated in particular has moved to protect its home advantage, there has been little impact on the paid-for titles such as the Standard. This could be because there is a concerted effort to keep the giveaway Metro on the streets at times when the Standard isn't - a similar move was made in Newcastle - but it could also suggest that regional brands which run campaigning and editorialised coverage should have more confidence in their own robustness.

But the fear of an interloper, however editorially unsophisticated, looks likely to keep the battle alive, not only between the miffed Swedes and the British press, but also between UK newspaper groups.

A menacing Associated, stung by the ruling affecting the North-West, insisted: 'There will be one morning free title in Manchester, and it will be one of ours.'

So how long will it be before newspaper companies that once screamed blue murder over the subsidised pricecutting antics of News International find themselves in the dock for similar anti-competitive practices? As the conflicts spread, the time may come when the Competition Commission, with its brief to regulate the regional press, is forced to take a view.

webTitle: Internet eggs the Pru on to a great performance

fields.headline: Internet eggs the Pru on to a great performance
fields.trailText: There can be few better testaments to the success of Sir Peter Davis's reign as chief executive of Prudential than last week's new business figures. Performances everywhere were stunning. In Britain, insurance and investment sales rose by 53 per cent. Even excluding the £583 million contribution from M&G, the US posted a 43 per cent rise, and Asia staged a dramatic recovery.
fields.body:
There can be few better testaments to the success of Sir Peter Davis's reign as chief executive of Prudential than last week's new business figures. Performances everywhere were stunning. In Britain, insurance and investment sales rose by 53 per cent. Even excluding the £583 million contribution from M&G, the US posted a 43 per cent rise, and Asia staged a dramatic recovery.

Sir Peter cannot take all the credit - the industry is enjoying a boom sparked by low interest rates, booming stock markets and a campaign by everyone from the Government down to persuade us to save. But he can take credit for the dramatic changes at the Pru which underlie this performance, and have made it one of the industry's frontrunners.

Five years ago, Prudential was embroiled in a bitter, debilitating battle with regulators. Davis realised he could not win, and switched his focus to positioning the business for the future.

The most dramatic change has been in the sources of its business. Five years ago, three-quarters came from the so-called industrial branch - its army of 6,000 door-to-door salesmen. Now 75 per cent comes through independent financial advisers (IFAs). The process of reducing the importance of the industrial branch was started by Davis's predecessor, Mick Newmarch. Sir Peter's skill was in ensuring that shrinking the direct salesforce did not mean shrinking the business.

He made the salesforce more productive by targeting more affluent customers, and introduced better training and better service. The result is that a third as many sales staff now produce the same revenue as four years ago. Premiums generated per head have risen from £42,000 a year to £92,000. The target of £100,000-plus is well in sight.

But the real success has been in expanding the other parts of the business. The biggest step was through the acquisition of Scottish Amicable, with its respected brand name and network of IFAs. The Pru has used this to push its own products, such as the spectacularly successful Prudence bond, out through the IFA network. The results are demonstrated in the new business figures.

The second acquisition, M&G, has been with the group only 10 months, so it is too early to say how successful it will be. To justify the price, it will have to make Scottish Amicable look pedestrian.

Now there is a proposed deal with the Bank of Scotland, but the business really exciting the City is not an acquisition but home-grown - Egg, the runaway Internet success. Opinions are divided over whether Davis can take the credit for this, or whether it was a happy accident. What is clear, however, is that he has been prepared to support it while it absorbed far more investment - and suffered far more glitches - than anyone had expected. The result is that its position as the Internet financial services brand will be hard for rivals such as Halifax, only now entering this market, to emulate.

Jonathan Bloomer, Sir Peter's deputy and former finance director, who is stepping up to the top job, will set out his strategy when the group announces its results next month. There is unlikely to be any significant change - the two were a very close team and Bloomer is widely respected. If there is a shift, it will be in emphasis, perhaps a greater focus on consolidating changes already made.

The shares have enjoyed a dramatic rerating, having almost doubled in value in little over a year, although its status as a quasi-Internet stock means it has been jittery this month. They could have further to go. As one analyst put it, they offer real assets, real profits, real growth - and the kicker of an attractive virtual business.

Don't Photo-Me
In the Sixties, it was possible to go into a kiosk like a photo booth and make your own record. The lack of a decent backing band, not to mention the horror of hearing your own voice on scratchy plastic, meant the idea never really caught on. Thirty years and a technological revolution later, Photo-Me International has decided that offering other people's music is a better bet.

Its plans to build up to 5,000 kiosks offering to download CDs is just one initiative which is set to transform the business, and has already transformed the share price.

The other is PhotoPlanet, a joint venture with BT to build a new generation of booths offering Internet access, customised postcards, fun stickers and identity cards in addition to the traditional passport photographs.

Both ideas are interesting. Offering Internet access to people on the move is undoubtedly attractive - mobile phone companies have already woken up to the idea, and mighty Microsoft is developing a kind of miniature handset. The risk is that anyone so desperate to get their email that they would consider a booth will surely have one of these, or an account at an Internet café.

The appeal of downloading music is similarly difficult to gauge, and trials due to have started this month in the US and next in Europe have been delayed, albeit by 'a couple of weeks'.

Meanwhile, having ruled out being acquired, Photo-Me has decided it wants to be the acquirer and is searching for content to push through its booths. BT is paying for the substantial extra investment required to make the booths Internet-friendly, and Photo-Me is rolling out new ones twice as fast as its normal openings programme.

This could pay off dramatically, but until the booths are up and running it is impossible to tell. The soaring share price has made it as risky as any dot.com stock. Buy at your periI.

Exit Eidos
Eidos, the computer games company, is a clear demonstration that even a technology stock can have feet of clay. Investors seemed willing to forgive the profits warning last autumn, convinced that the Internet still offered staggering potential. They should not forgive the current one.

Eidos is anxious to find a successor to its blockbuster heroine Lara Croft. Even so, a company with its rating and reputation should not be suffering from problems with timing its launches. More serious, however, the indications are that the games market is softening and price competition intensifying. Look at the figures from retailers such as Dixons and Electronics Boutique.

The launch of Playstation 2, the next generation, may help. But in the meantime, sell the shares.

fields.headline: IRA faces 14-day guns deadline
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson will dramatically intervene to save the Northern Ireland peace process by suspending the three-month-old power-sharing Executive if the IRA fails to decommission within a fortnight.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson will dramatically intervene to save the Northern Ireland peace process by suspending the three-month-old power-sharing Executive if the IRA fails to decommission within a fortnight.

Mandelson will act in an effort to prevent First Minister David Trimble from being forced to quit as Ulster Unionist leader.

Sources at the Northern Ireland Office told The Observer that the Stormont Executive, which includes two Sinn Fein Ministers, will be wound up if General John de Chastelain reports no progress towards IRA disarmament by 31 January.

Trimble gave a promise to his party's rank and file last November to resign as First Minister if there was no progress on decommissioning by February. His party is due to meet on 12 February and Trimble will have no option but to quit in the absence of any verified handover. His departure would represent a huge setback for the peace process.

Intelligence suggests the IRA will not now decommission by the end of February. Republican sources said the IRA and Sinn Fein leaderships were having difficulty selling a one-off act of tactical decommissioning.

The thinking behind the suspension of the Executive is that it will give Sinn Fein more time to persuade the IRA to decommission before the final disarmament deadline of 22 May - the date written into the Good Friday Agreement.

If the IRA fails to move towards decommissioning within the next fortnight pressure on the republican movement will be applied by both London and Dublin. A senior Irish source said yesterday: 'Trimble took a leap of faith last November and if the republican movement fails to reciprocate then the fingers will point at them, saying they are the ones to blame.'

British sources believe they have offered the IRA a string of concessions including reform of the RUC, but the IRA will not move in the face of what is seen as a Unionist-imposed deadline of February. In one slim hope of a compromise, Ministers are still hoping that the sealing of arms dumps south of the border might be regarded as an acceptable form of decommis sioning. However, the Unionists believe this would require a change in the law.

Trimble warned yesterday: 'If things don't work out as we had hoped and if it proves impossible to sustain the administration in its present form, the only immediate recourse is direct rule.'

The IRA's intentions have become increasingly hard to read given the appointment of three interlocutors to General de Chastelain's International Body on Decommissioning. They include Padraig Wilson, the former IRA leader in the Maze Prison who hinted in a recent interview that the Provisionals might carry out a voluntary act of disarmament, and Joe Cahill, the republican veteran and former IRA chief-of-staff.

Both men are seen to be close to Gerry Adams and the Sinn Fein leadership. However the third member of the triumvirate is Brian Keenan, a Marxist hardliner on the IRA's Army Council.

Opposition to decommissioning is greatest in areas such as South Armagh. Jim McAllister, a former Sinn Fein member from Crossmaglen, said decommissioning was a 'bridge too far for many republicans'.

John Taylor, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, said yesterday he was convinced that the British Government would wind up the Executive in the absence of genuine progress on decommissioning.

If the IRA fails to move towards decommissioning within the next fortnight pressure on the republican movement will be applied by both London and Dublin. A senior Irish source said yesterday: 'Trimble took a leap of faith last November and if the republican movement fails to reciprocate then the fingers will point at them, saying they are the ones to blame.' British sources believe they have offered the IRA a string of concessions including reform of the RUC, but the IRA will not move in the face of what is seen as a Unionist-imposed deadline of February. In one slim hope of a compromise, Ministers are still hoping that the sealing of arms dumps south of the border might be regarded as an acceptable form of decommis sioning. However, the Unionists believe this would require a change in the law. Trimble warned yesterday: 'If things don't work out as we had hoped and if it proves impossible to sustain the administration in its present form, the only immediate recourse is direct rule.' The IRA's intentions have become increasingly hard to read given the appointment of three interlocutors to General de Chastelain's International Body on Decommissioning. They include Padraig Wilson, the former IRA leader in the Maze Prison who hinted in a recent interview that the Provisionals might carry out a voluntary act of disarmament, and Joe Cahill, the republican veteran and former IRA chief-of-staff. Both men are seen to be close to Gerry Adams and the Sinn Fein leadership. However the third member of the triumvirate is Brian Keenan, a Marxist hardliner on the IRA's Army Council. Opposition to decommissioning is greatest in areas such as South Armagh. Jim McAllister, a former Sinn Fein member from Crossmaglen, said decommissioning was a 'bridge too far for many republicans'. John Taylor, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, said yesterday he was convinced that the British Government would wind up the Executive in the absence of genuine progress on decommissioning.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future?  Catch up here...
fields.trailText: * James Surowiecki <A HREF="http://www.slate.com"
fields.body:
* James Surowiecki <A HREF="http://www.slate.com"

"We're" TARGET="_NEW">www.slate.com

"We're familiar with the avalanche of dot com advertising that buried us last year, but while these ads are mainly about a grab for market share and brand identity via the familiar techniques of jittery cameras, hyperbolic humour, and a measure of association with the quality we now call 'extreme-ness', the most interesting new internet ad campaign offers none of these.

"That campaign is by advertising internet discount retailer buy.com. Which is pretty much all the campaign advertises. In contrast to the frenetic style of most dot com ads, the buy.com TV ad features the company name in small, white lowercase letters on a black background. That's it. No music, no voiceover. Just 30 seconds of a name and silence. If it works we'll have a flood of these campaigns, and you won't be able to remember any of them. Here's one place where the first-mover advantage is real."

* Matthew Yeomans <A HREF="http://www.theStandard.com"

"The" TARGET="_NEW">www.theStandard.com

"The long march to digital hegemony continues. The number of Chinese with internet access has jumped from 2m to 8.9m in two years. The enormous task of plugging in China, on its own, won't clear the way to smooth communication online. That's because language - specifically, written language - is the barrier to life online for the Chinese. So far, there has been no easy way of punching Chinese characters into the web. But now a Canadian software company has developed a program to enter Chinese characters, ideally with the keypad of a PDA or cell phone or a TV remote control. Will the rest of the world soon need to buy Chinese-language software or even learn Chinese? That seems unlikely in the short term, but who's to say multilingual software won't be standard in the years to come?

"'Today more people than ever are interested in the Chinese language,' says Wenze Hu, a professor at Harvard. 'All of it driven by the sociopolitical state of the country. If China becomes a powerful country, if you want to know about it, you will have to learn Chinese.' That's where having the largest online population might attract attention."

*Michael Wolff nymag.com

"A few days before the [AOL-Time Warner] announcement, I saw a CNN show with [Time Warner boss] Gerry Levin, Kurt Andersen [also a former Timer], and [the New Yorker's] Ken Auletta, talking about the future of the media. Levin started to talk about governments fading and some new sort of corporate city-states rising and how the world would be mediated in a vaguely sci-fi-ish New Agey Rollerball digital way. Everybody else treated his remarks as the most egghead-ish of hypothetical futurist stuff. Well, OK."

webTitle: Depressed and in fear of losing your job

fields.headline: Depressed and in fear of losing your job
fields.trailText: I am suffering from depression and worried about losing my job. My employers want me to discuss the issue with them even though I am currently signed off work by my doctor. Can I be forced to go to a meeting even though I feel I can't take the pressure of it?
fields.body:
I am suffering from depression and worried about losing my job. My employers want me to discuss the issue with them even though I am currently signed off work by my doctor. Can I be forced to go to a meeting even though I feel I can't take the pressure of it?

This is a common nightmare. Your employer can dismiss you, to take the worst case. To do this, the company has to (a) get medical evidence, and (b) consult you. The medical evidence will come from your GP or, if the company wants, from an expert it nominates.

You cannot be forced to go to a meeting, but they could offer to come to your house, for instance. This flexibility would look good if they sacked you and you ended up taking them to an employment tribunal. But you do have various protections.

If your employer has a staff of 15 or more, you are covered by the Disability Discrimination Act. This makes it very hard for them to dismiss someone with depression. If you have been there at least a year, you could also consider suing for unfair dismissal if they fire you. But the area is very grey.

The employer's hand is strengthened if (a) your absence could be prolonged; (b) it is very disruptive because you are in a senior position or are the only person who can do your job; and (c) the business is a small one where your absence causes difficulties.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: Make that organisation work for you
fields.body:
Make that organisation work for you

Management guru Tom Peters says he knows of few people who have made successes of their careers without cheating.

By cheating, of course, he does not mean lying or being dishonest: he means manipulating company resources to achieve the best for the individual and the organisation. In other words, he sees making the organisation your servant and not your master as a necessary prerequisite for commercial success.

And that, I suppose, is a 'value' - a buzzword in any discussion on healthy companies. When I looked up the word 'value' in my dictionary, it said 'that which renders anything useful or estimable' - not a bad definition for something which can create and maintain healthy organisations and motivated individuals.

You may work in such a company, in which case you are fortunate, and perhaps already encouraged to seek self-development and use your initiative. The addictive Post-It notes were produced, just as blotting paper was, by an employee developing a use for a product discovered by accident. Companies such as Hewlett Packard encourage employees to develop their ideas, offering them support as necessary, and giving them recognition whether or not they succeed.

Such companies also encourage all staff, not just managers, to develop themselves by undertaking courses and guided reading, and also by arranging personal coaching and mentoring, inside or out of their organisations.

Without such resources, self-development can be like pulling yourself up to the ceiling by your shoe-laces. Many wise and experienced mentors now offer not quick fixes, but sensitive and relevant guidance which can unlock an individual's full potential.

In short, they add value, turning men and women into what Peters also describes as 'self-reliant CEOs of their own professional service company'.

And that is a value every organisation appreciates.
