webTitle: Free car parks to take a walk

fields.headline: Free car parks to take a walk
fields.standfirst:
Joanna Walters on a key plank of the Transport Bill
More about transport
fields.trailText: Free parking at work for up to 13 million commuters is under threat as the Government tries to solve Britain's traffic problems by taxing office car parks.
fields.body:
Free parking at work for up to 13 million commuters is under threat as the Government tries to solve Britain's traffic problems by taxing office car parks.

The so-called workplace parking levy is a central feature of the Transport Bill, which has just begun what could be a year-long passage through Parliament.

The levy is often mentioned in the same breath as congestion charging as one of the two traffic and pollution reduction measures local authorities will be able to adopt under new legislative powers. The aim is for councils to invest in public transport improvements using loans, repaying the money with revenue raised from motorists. But while business leaders are cautiously supporting congestion charging, they are opposed to the workplace levy.

The Government has not discussed figures, but well informed speculation suggests that £200 a year for each space would be typical. Official figures show that about 70 per cent of the workforce of 24 million drive to work and, of these, 75 per cent have parking provided by their employer. Making allowances for shift work, holidays, sick leave and travel habits, the Government estimates there are about 10 million free workplace spaces in the UK.

If these are taxed at £200 a year, which the British Chambers of Commerce believes will turn out to be a conservative figure, £2 billion would be raised by local authorities for transport improvements. No other country has adopted such a scheme. In the areas that introduce it, employers would have to apply for a licence for car parks, choosing whether to absorb the cost or pass it on to workers. Licensing would also apply to schools and colleges, which could tax sixth-formers and students as well as teachers.

FoE's Roger Higman said: 'The levy is much easier to implement than congestion charging. It is a way of getting employers to think about using parking spaces for something else, while providing a revenue stream to improve public transport.' But the CBI's Michael Roberts said congestion charging would better influence behaviour because it charges per journey, with different rates at different times, and shares the burden across the travelling public. The workplace levy, he said, simply targets business, which is already paying through rates.

The Government's advisers - the Commission for Integrated Transport - officially support the levy. But one commission member, Vauxhall chairman Nick Reilly, opposes it. He said it represented a straight tax on employers rather than an effective way of easing traffic. And, he said, employers had traditionally been forced to provide parking as a condition of planning permission.

The Government is holding discussions with city, borough and county councils in England that have expressed an interest in congestion charging or the workplace parking levy (they will be discouraged from introducing both). Here representatives of both sides of the argument get to put their case.

webTitle: Too big for your bottom line

fields.headline: Too big for your bottom line
fields.standfirst: Management:  The merger bandwagon rolls on.  Simon Caulkin asks why
fields.trailText: Every time you thought it was impossible for deals to get bigger, they double in size. Just two weeks into January, two new megadeals - AOL's $183 billion agreed bid for Time-Warner, and the £110bn drugs tie-up between Glaxo Wellcome and Smith-Kline - put the first year of the millennium well on target to match or beat 1999's record total of $3 trillion-worth of mergers.
fields.body:
Every time you thought it was impossible for deals to get bigger, they double in size. Just two weeks into January, two new megadeals - AOL's $183 billion agreed bid for Time-Warner, and the £110bn drugs tie-up between Glaxo Wellcome and Smith-Kline - put the first year of the millennium well on target to match or beat 1999's record total of $3 trillion-worth of mergers.

Nothing like this merger orgy has been seen before, in either size and quantity. For many companies, it seems, mergers have become a substitute for management. As for quality - well, that may be a different matter. In a recent study, consultancy KPMG found that, one year after the deal, 83 per cent of a sample of large mergers had created no shareholder value, and more than half had actually destroyed it.

The KPMG study is only the latest in a long line which underline the same thing: mergers are hard to carry off and, at least in shareholder value terms, many fail. So what's the attraction - and where does it end?

Deals seem to promise to remedy several sets of problems. Laggards and companies in mature industries like them for the opportunities they provide for stripping out cost - witness the BP strategy. For others (Glaxo-Smith-Kline) the logic is one of scale, in this case for expensive R&D. In other cases again, a huge spike of change across whole industries (pharmaceuticals, telecoms, the Internet) provides opportunities for strategic realignments of the AOL-Time Warner type. 'The more change there is around, the less chance com panies think they have of surviving by doing nothing,' says KPMG partner Colin Cook, one of the report's authors.

It is also the case, points out Duncan Angwin, a merger specialist at Warwick Business School, that worldwide deregulation and advances in management technologies such as communications have swept away the old rules about what is and isn't possible.

Feed into that the strong Anglo-Saxon predilection for the deal as an instrument of change and self-gratification (a condition which is steadily infecting the rest of the world), add in sky-high stock market valuations, and most observers agree that the scene is set for the great merger bandwagon to roll on merrily for a while yet. 'There are just too many forces for change in most industry sectors,' says Cook. 'I struggle to find one which is not consolidating or responding to major market changes.'

Is there a point where big becomes too big? 'Size may not in itself be the evil it once was,' says Angwin. At Ashridge Strategic Management Centre, which has done groundbreaking work on merger synergies, director Andrew Campbell agrees. It's diversity and complexity that are the real killers, rather than size, he maintains. 'The improved economics of combining companies in the same industry look compelling,' he says. 'What we won't know for 10 years is how far the costs - for example, in forcing together different cultures - will cancel out the benefits.'

In the meantime, he warns that as well as opportunities for a daring industry-defining coup, today's sky-high share valuations also create the opportunities for megafoolish extravagance. To name just one, the combined AOL-Time-Warner will be a diversified conglomerate - just the sort of beast which has found synergies elusive to vanishing point in the past. And although it's now conveniently forgotten, AOL has had precious little out of its $4bn acquisition of Netscape just nine months ago, not even a new browser: its 20 million subscribers are still using Microsoft Explorer. Several other recent megamergers also look rocky, to say the least.

Single-industry consolidation only has so far to run. Airframe manufacturing, cars, accounting, oil and mobile phones must soon reach unacceptable limits of concentration. But some take a more apocalyptic view.

Robert Baldock, author of the The Last Days of the Giants? (John Wiley) and previously a global partner at Andersen Consulting, be-lieves the current merger wave is the last throw of the big corporations, a largely doomed attempt to shore up their position in the face of the threat from e-commerce.

The Internet, he argues, is dissolving the economic glue that holds traditional compa nies together. In many cases, it is now cheaper, quicker and easier to buy and combine resources on the Net than to co-ordinate through a hierarchy. So the value of a company doing everything (like AOL-TW or Glaxo-SmithKline) gets lower and lower.

'What we'll see is companies dissecting the value chain, deciding which bit of it they do best and outsourcing the rest,' he predicts.

In the case of Glaxo-SmithKline this might be research and manufacturing. For all the partners' vaunted distribution clout, the running in the key US market is being made, he warns, by online companies such as drugstore.com, driving prices downwards.

Baldock believes the great companies of the future will be large chiefly in name alone. Their most important attributes will be configuring their offerings to the customer: to deliver them they will use networks of alliances with third parties. The models are Yahoo!, Amazon and Virgin, not AOL or Glaxo - which will now be spending years implementing the merger instead of focusing on customers. 'Think of it as the twentieth-century diet,' says Baldock. 'You can't run as fast if you're several times as heavy as your competitor.'

Disappointing harvest of five doubtful deals

 AOL/NETSCAPE It was a $4bn deal but AOL has little to show for it - not even a new browser.

 PRICEWATERHOUSE/COOPERS & LYBRAND 1998 merger of top accountants and consultants cost more than expected, and led to expensive conflicts of interest in the US.

 DISNEY/INFOSEEK Mickey spent $3bn on a portal and the result was a duck: it's still not clear how Disney shareholders will benefit.

 DAIMLER/CHRYSLER Daimler shareholders miffed at low returns. Meanwhile, Chrysler executives drive off into the sunset.

 PHARMACIA/UPJOHN: Five years on, cultural differences are still giving the $7bn Swedish-American drugs firm migraines.

webTitle: Lovers of learning make fresh starts pay off

fields.headline: Lovers of learning make fresh starts pay off
fields.standfirst: But it can also help your career, says  Jonathan Gregson
fields.trailText: There is a greater choice of postgraduate courses now than ever, both in terms of their content and how you can study. They vary from mainly-taught Masters' courses to pure research degrees. These can be done full-time, part-time, through distance learning and via block release schemes designed for people who remain in full-time jobs while studying for a further degree.
fields.body:
There is a greater choice of postgraduate courses now than ever, both in terms of their content and how you can study. They vary from mainly-taught Masters' courses to pure research degrees. These can be done full-time, part-time, through distance learning and via block release schemes designed for people who remain in full-time jobs while studying for a further degree.

The choices are almost endless, which is why careers advisers such as Elizabeth Wilkinson at the University of London suggests that prospective postgrad students shop around before deciding what is right for them. And the Postgraduate Study and Training Fair in London next week provides an unusual opportunity to see what is on offer.

When evaluating a course, says Wilkinson, basic questions should include what subjects are covered, who does the teaching, how the course is assessed, the quality of library and computer facilities and - most importantly for long-term career moves - what previous graduates from that course do now.

It helps, she says, if prospective students 'have a clear idea of what they want to do in the long term'. And if they're taking a postgraduate degree mainly to improve their career prospects, they are 'most likely to do so if the subject is closely related to their area of employment, if the academic department has good links with employers, and the students strengthen their CVs with relevant activities and experience'.

This is all sound advice about choosing a course and perhaps entering a rewarding career at the end of it. But what about the initial motivation? Why are an increasing number of students choosing to continue to postgraduate level?

When the graduate job market is difficult, Wilkinson notes that more students see 'prolonged study as a constructive alternative to taking a low level job'. But that is hardly the case right now, especially in the South East. 'Around here employment markets are buoyant,' says the University of Reading's Stephen Wallis, 'but there is still strong demand for postgrad courses - such as land management, which enables people looking for a career change to go off and qualify as chartered surveyors.'

Greater career flexibility - and the need to retrain or acquire new skills - may be one factor that is fuelling the postgraduate element in the explosion of 'lifelong learning'. So, too, is competitive pressure in the workplace. With far more graduates in the UK jobs market, there is a strong incentive to go one better and get a postgraduate degree. 'It's a way of distin guishing themselves, of gaining a competitive advantage,' says Dr Pat Rickwood of the Open University.

But what about more personal, less utilitarian motives? Adrian Furnham, professor of psychology at University College, London, says that with some recent graduates the desire to stay in higher education is 'a postponement of adulthood' - the university offering 'a cosy environment which might seem preferable to going out into the real world'.

They may be encouraged in this by their teachers. But, Furnham adds: 'There are also those clearly set on a research or academic career, and those in professions such as chemistry, where postgraduate study is needed for full qualification'.

As for more mature postgraduates - those who return to higher education from their thirties onwards - Furnham discerns four main types of motivation. 'Some who are, to use Charles Handy's term, "portfolio workers", see taking a higher degree as means of expanding their portfolio of skills, and want to take their career in a new direction. Others may have been made redundant, or can see the writing on the wall. They are retraining.'

But there are also 'empty nesters', who see a further degree as filling a gap in their lives. Finally, there are people who have spent years in high-earning jobs which, appear to them to have 'low intrinsic value', says Furnham. 'They are looking for something more meaningful, whether it is writing a dissertation on philosophy or fine art, or taking a course which will qualify them to be social workers.'

Careers advisers and psychologists tend to label people, and this doesn't necessarily work when trying to discover why intelligent and articulate people who already have one degree want to become students again. That much was apparent from talking to three mature postgrad students of modern languages, literature and culture at Queen Mary and Westfield College, London.

Kathryn Michael returned to study aged 50 after a successful career in advertising, ending up as a director of one of the larger agencies. 'At work the learning curve had dropped right off, and I wanted to start out on a big new project,' she says. The teaching of critical theory has helped her go back to literature she enjoyed as a young person and to read it 'with more depth and pleasure'.

Having graduated last month, she is 'taking a breather' and thinking about continuing to a PhD. 'I'm loving learning,' she says.

Sue Alexander is continuing from the BA she took in English Literature, starting at the age of 31. Her decision to take an MA in literature, culture and modernity was based partly on a desire 'to get more out of reading', and because she thought it would help her write creatively better than a course in journalism or creative writing.

Cengiz Soyee started his MA concurrently with taking a PGCE to qualify as a teacher, and for the past two years has been teaching at Holland Park Comprehensive in West London, while completing his MA in European languages, literature and thought part-time. 'I needed to work,' he says, 'as I was paying for the course myself.' The critical theory he has learnt 'helped a lot with what I was doing as a teacher'.

The three returned to study with different aims, but had in common a love of learning. This is why most people take up postgraduate study and participate in what politicians call the lifelong learning experiment.

The Postgraduate Study and Trading Fair 2000 is at the Business Design Centre, in Islington, on Wednesday and Thursday.

webTitle: Find a niche - but don't get stuck

fields.headline: Find a niche - but don't get stuck
fields.standfirst: As MBAs proliferate, it becomes increasingly difficult to choose the right course, says  Jonathan Gregson
fields.trailText: There are 118 business schools in the UK offering MBA courses. The number of options - full-time, part-time, broad-based or niche - continues to grow exponentially. For aspiring managers intent on finding the right course, it may seem as though it's an MBA jungle out there - which is why many will be attending the MBA Fair 2000 in London next week.
fields.body:
There are 118 business schools in the UK offering MBA courses. The number of options - full-time, part-time, broad-based or niche - continues to grow exponentially. For aspiring managers intent on finding the right course, it may seem as though it's an MBA jungle out there - which is why many will be attending the MBA Fair 2000 in London next week.

MBA courses aimed at particular sectors have mushroomed. It began with courses for those working (or planning to work) in the public sector, in banking/finance, or in marketing. But now it is possible to take niche courses adapted to business sectors from oil and gas exploration to football management.

It is perhaps fitting that Liverpool should be the first university in the world to offer an MBA in football-related industries (soccer, not American football, in which some US colleges offer PhD courses). Sam Johnstone, lecturer at the Football Research Unit, says: 'This is the third year we have run this programme, and from the outset there was tremendous interest.

'In our first year we had 1,500 enquiries and took 20 students. Our last intake was 40, with students from the UK, Brazil, Japan, China and all over Europe. They mostly come to work out what careers they want within the game.'

The one-year course is split into three equal parts: a normal MBA's content; a research dissertation which could involve a placement with a club or one of the marketing companies associated with the industry; and a taught course on the business of football and its relationship with the City and the media.

Even within such a specialised sphere, motivations are very different. 'Some people arrive thinking they'll make a lot of money out of football and switch to trying to help lower-league clubs survive,' says Johnstone.

Football is just one of many niche MBAs on offer. Churchmen can take an MBA in church management at Bishop Grosseteste College in Lincoln. Leicester University offers 11 specialised MBAs, including maritime management.

Dundee provides the specialist input to MBAs aimed at people in oil and gas, mineral resources and water industries, with the general MBA content coming from Heriot-Watt's Edinburgh Business School.

Niche MBAs may be attractive to people already working within a particular sector who want to build their management skills. But do they offer the same learning experience as the classic, generalist MBA? Probably not, though if you plan to continue working in the same place and the same sector they may suit you.

But if your game plan includes changing jobs, upping your earnings potential and moving around, the classic MBA is still the best bet. Most employers look first at where you gained your MBA, not its content. This is particularly true of the high-earning finance and consulting industries, which are generally unimpressed by sector-specific qualifications - though they may value work experience.

The directors of classic MBA programmes also value their intake's previous experience as managers. Mark Oakley, of the Aston Business School, says its students' average age is around 30, and they learn a great deal from each other's experience.

Richard Kerley, director of the full-time MBA course at Edinburgh University, concurs: 'We believe the MBA should be a generalist course where people already have the management experience to help each other learn.'

A growing number of MBA courses accept students who have just graduated, with the result that there are effectively two streams: the older managers, who have something to contribute in seminars, and the 21-year-olds who - no matter how bright - just don't have that experience. This can lead to friction between the two age groups.

Rather than dilute the experience of their MBA programmes, both Aston and Edinburgh encourage recent graduates to take an MSc in Business Studies - the emphasis being more on teaching and the dissertation than on the interactive learning typical of the classic MBA. If MSc graduates later want to do an MBA, Aston exempts them from the parts they have already completed.

Kerley agrees that the MSc is best for younger students, but argues that management knowledge is evolving so rapidly that it is best for MBA students to start afresh. The classic MBA is, he insists, a very different type of qualification - both in content and in what it says to the marketplace. Like many others in leading business schools, he is worried that the proliferation of courses styled as MBAs will lead to it being devalued.

Guidance is available through the accreditation scheme run by the UK- based Association of MBAs (AMBA). Of the 118 universities and colleges in the UK, only 35 have received accreditation.

Equis is a Europe-wide accreditation programme run by the Brussels-based European Foundation for Management Development. So far, only four British business schools have been accredited; a whole raft of similar institutions in France have accreditation.

If an MBA is only as good as the school or university it came from, it is worth choosing very carefully. Accreditation offers guidance. But it is worth going to see for yourself at the MBA fair in London next week.

The MBA 2000 Fair is at the Business Design Centre, Islington, Wednesday 26 January from 12.30 to 8.30 pm, and Thursday 27 January from noon to 7 pm.

fields.headline: UK 'faces big euro entry bill'
fields.standfirst:
There are no special deals for latecomers, central banker Duisenberg tells The Observer
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The price of Britain not joining the euro at the outset is that its eventual membership will be at a punishingly high exchange rate for the pound, the president of the European Central Bank warned today.
fields.body:
The price of Britain not joining the euro at the outset is that its eventual membership will be at a punishingly high exchange rate for the pound, the president of the European Central Bank warned today.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer, Wim Duisenberg said this country could expect no special treatment. If Britain wanted to join, it would 'have to comply with all the convergence criteria that applied to all the founding fathers of the euro area'.

The pound would have had to remain stable in the two years ahead of its entering the euro - effectively ruling out a devaluation to gain entry on comfortable terms.

Sterling is currently trading at nearly DM3.20, which is almost the least competitive real exchange rate since the Second World War.

Duisenberg's words make it clear that if a UK referen dum on the euro were won in 2002, Britain would have to accept entry at an exchange rate close to current levels, which has already severely damaged many export-oriented British businesses.

Currency analysts suggest that the pound will remain at over DM3 for at least the next two years. Sterling currently stands at 109.6 against the current trade-weighted index of European currencies. Barclays Capital estimates that this will rise to 110.9 by the end of this year, implying an exchange rate with the mark of 3.50, falling to 107.5 - about DM 3.10 - by the end of 2001.

If Britain had joined at the launch of the single currency, the rate would have been DM2.76.

Duisenberg does not believe that British entry would imply the massive tax increases or spending cuts that British Euro-sceptics believe would be needed to offset the expansionary impact of lower interest rates.

He says the Irish Republic - where, as in Britain, the housing market is sensitive to short-term interest rates because many homeowners have variable-rate mortgages - has successfully managed euro membership without tightening fiscal policy or seeing inflation take off.

'Inflation in Ireland is around 2 per cent, despite fears of overheating. That may be an indication that behavioural relations of consumers, of investors, of government have changed through the structural shock that has taken place by par ticipating in the single currency area.'

After a week in which the ECB Council did not raise interest rates, Duisenberg said that while Portugal, Ireland, the Netherlands and Belgium were 'close to overheating', the opposite was the case in two big economies - Germany and Italy.

Kitty Ussher, chief economist for the Britain in Europe campaign, said: 'Ruling out the option to join the single currency, as the anti-Europeans would like, would undoubtedly be damaging to Britain. Mr Duisenberg is right to rebut some of the myths put about by the anti-Europeans.'

Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: 'Inward investors are already making investment plans for the next five to 10 years. If they believe that the UK won't join, they are less likely to increase their investment here.'

fields.headline: Never mind the politics...
fields.standfirst:
Does joining the euro make economic sense?
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The political discussion about the pound and euro has taken over from the economic. Most people assume that it all depends on when or whether there will be a sufficient swing in public opinion for the Prime Minister to call a referendum he can win. Such is the political dominance of the debate that the British government's 'five economic tests' (see below) have been ignored.
fields.body:
The political discussion about the pound and euro has taken over from the economic. Most people assume that it all depends on when or whether there will be a sufficient swing in public opinion for the Prime Minister to call a referendum he can win. Such is the political dominance of the debate that the British government's 'five economic tests' (see below) have been ignored.

Yet they are important. Test number 4 - the impact on our financial services industry - is taken seriously by both the Government and the Bank of England. Fears about our exclusion from the Eurozone having a deleterious impact on the City have diminished in the past year. Even the recently retired Lord Mayor of London, Lord Levene, has acknowledged that the City has been prospering outside the zone.

Another of the tests - the effect on investment - is also of concern. Hardly a week goes by without a scare story about Japanese or other companies threatening to relocate if Britain does not join. The Blair government is sensitive to such concerns.

But inward investment is only part of overall new investment and, in the long run, what is important in the euro decision is the performance of the whole economy. For example, a British government that adopted the euro out of fear of losing foreign investment may live to regret it if it joined at too high an exchange rate.

At all events, fear of losing inward investment is one reason for the Government stressing that we are preparing to join during the next Parliament. Here we come to an important aspect of the five conditions. These were published on 27 October 1997 in an attempt to quell speculation about an early entry and to kick the euro question into touch.

Whatever the fears about the impact on the City, or inward investment, it was difficult to argue that the economic policies of Euroland were appropriate to the UK when interest rates looked set to be double those on the Continent for the near future.

Number one, and easily the most crucial of the five tests, is 'whether there can be a sustainable convergence between Britain and the economies of a single currency'. Given the efforts of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) to slow down our economy and ward off incipient inflationary pressures, the idea that our interest rates could swiftly come down to the ECB's 3 per cent is laughable.

The questions are when, and by how much, they next rise. To offset the boost to demand from such lowering of interest rates, the Chancellor would feel obliged to introduce a tax rise of the sort New Labour would not dare try to get past the Daily Mail readers with whom it is so obsessed.

There would probably also have to be intervention in the housing market - the kind of credit controls that are repugnant to the conventional wisdom Labour adopts. Otherwise, the concern about mortgage demand and rising house prices would turn into panic.

The prospect for the rest of this year is rising interest rates, which will probably be greater than any introduced by the ECB. This can hardly be called 'early convergence', yet what else does convergence imply except the same interest rate being appropriate to Euroland and the UK. And the pound - already too high for many domestic manufacturers and inward investors - is at levels which ECB President Wim Duisenberg suggests would put the UK at a chronic disadvantage within the single currency.

It is the prospect of permanently fixed exchange rates vis à vis continental Europe that most worries those who study the British economy. But, via his 'anti-boom-and-bust' policies, and emphasis on a flexible labour market the Chancellor is hoping to make the need for Britain to devalue a thing of the past. At current interest and exchange rates the economic case for early entry is hard to sustain.

If Blair and Brown produce an economic miracle, the British economy may be able to withstand the competitive pressure of the single currency in some years' time. But, ironically, the economy would have a reasonable chance of doing so only if we entered at a much lower exchange rate. As the Governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, has made it clear, the MPC is not authorised to aim at a specific exchange rate target, but to achieve the 2.5 per cent inflation target.

That the UK may devalue sharply sparks worries about the impact this may have on that target. Under the Maastricht rules, the UK would have to shift to an exchange rate target well before a projected entry date. At present the Government is too proud of the kudos it earned for its counter-inflation effort to contemplate this. And, even if devaluations are needed, any government is reluctant to initiate them.

Brown's five tests for membership

1 Whether there can be sustainable convergence between Britain and the economies of a single currency

2 Whether there is sufficient flexibility to cope with economic change

3 The effect on investment

4 The impact on our financial services industry

5 Whether it is good for employment

And the pound - already too high for many domestic manufacturers and inward investors - is at levels which ECB President Wim Duisenberg suggests would put the UK at a chronic disadvantage within the single currency. It is the prospect of permanently fixed exchange rates vis à vis continental Europe that most worries those who study the British economy. But, via his 'anti-boom-and-bust' policies, and emphasis on a flexible labour market the Chancellor is hoping to make the need for Britain to devalue a thing of the past. At current interest and exchange rates the economic case for early entry is hard to sustain. If Blair and Brown produce an economic miracle, the British economy may be able to withstand the competitive pressure of the single currency in some years' time. But, ironically, the economy would have a reasonable chance of doing so only if we entered at a much lower exchange rate. As the Governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, has made it clear, the MPC is not authorised to aim at a specific exchange rate target, but to achieve the 2.5 per cent inflation target. That the UK may devalue sharply sparks worries about the impact this may have on that target. Under the Maastricht rules, the UK would have to shift to an exchange rate target well before a projected entry date. At present the Government is too proud of the kudos it earned for its counter-inflation effort to contemplate this. And, even if devaluations are needed, any government is reluctant to initiate them. webTitle: A sticky end ... or happy ever afters?

fields.headline: A sticky end ... or happy ever afters?
fields.standfirst:
Jamie Doward looks for something solid to justify the leap in value of new Internet company Jellyworks

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward looks for something solid to justify the leap in value of new Internet company Jellyworks
fields.body:
If ever there was an illustration of how Internet companies can seemingly suck money out of thin air it is to be found at the plush London offices of Jellyworks. The paint has yet to dry on some of the walls in the Internet investment firm's Westminster HQ. Its website is still under construction. In the boardroom, which overlooks St James's Park, roller blinds lie on the floor, waiting to be put up.

Through the window looms the Treasury. What Iron Chancellor Gordon Brown would make of Jellyworks can only be imagined, but the prudent Scot is unlikely to find any evidence of neo-classical endogenous growth in the month-old company's brief history. Floated just before Christmas, Jellyworks has seen its market value soar from £10 million to more than £240m.

The reason for this gravity-defying leap is that the City is betting on a hunch. Investors in Jellyworks believe the company has the expertise and access to capital that will allow it to invest in those fledgling technology businesses which may become the Microsofts of the future.

Much of the euphoria surrounding the company's share price stems from a feeling of déjà vu. The company's chief executive is 24-year-old Jonathan David Rowland, who left Bedales after his GCSEs, tried his hand at a number of jobs, and now finds himself under the Square Mile's spotlight. The putative investment guru is the son of David Rowland, the property magnate and legendary fixer who reputedly made his first million by the age of 23, earning himself a place in City folklore and the sobriquet 'Spotty' to boot.

Rowland senior's later business dealings were not so coruscating. Williams Hudson, a Rowland-controlled conglomerate, went under in the 1970s. A Rowland-backed takeover of Hibernian football club ended up in receivership.

Now it is up to Rowland junior to prove he has his father's precocious alchemic touch. The story goes that Rowland senior gave his son £8m to set up Jellyworks. The money came from a firm called Easton Investments, a Guernsey-based company owned by the Rowland family's trusts. A family friend, Edward Guinan (Rowland senior was his best man), invested £1m and is now the company's chairman.

The two older men are adamant that it will be Rowland junior who calls the shots. One obvious reason is that, as a tax exile, Rowland senior could attract the attentions of the Inland Revenue if he were seen taking a part in the company's activities.

'I respect what my father's done. He's a clever guy,' says Jonathan Rowland. 'He has left us alone and he's not involved day to day. If I see him for dinner, we chat and that's about it. He trusts my judgment and trusts Ed.' Never the less, the links to the Rowland family seem extremely strong. Even the Jellyworks HQ is rented from the family.

The idea of floating an Internet investment vehicle seems to have been Rowland senior's as well. Says Jonathan: 'I got married in October, and when I got home I spoke to my father who said "you should put together a public company which will be investing in Internet stuff". I spoke to Ed. He'd been having the same thoughts for six months.'

The company's name came from a brainstorming session between chairman and chief executive. 'We sat around trying to dream up something whimsical but unforgettable which had a .com still available,' Guinan recalls.

Guinan, a former Wall Street trader, claims Jellyworks has huge resources. 'We are unique in that we are not restricted by access to capital. If we saw an opportunity we wanted to deploy serious amounts of money to, we could do it. We have serious firepower. We're looking at larger transactions now. If we saw a £100m deal today we could do it.'

So far, Jellyworks has done little to earn its stellar value. The company has made, or has options to make, investments in a number of Internet firms including EPO.com, a Swedish online investment bank; Antfactory, a US incubator for early-stage technology companies; and Orchestream, a software company specialising in solving Internet congestion problems. Orchestream's chief executive, Ashley Ward, is JellyWorks' sole non-executive director.

Guinan is 52. Rowland insist theirs is a partnership of equals. Guinan is an expert in corporate finance while Rowland, who once worked in the family's property business as a trainee surveyor, is strong on identifying investment targets.

Guinan says: 'This was a lucky relationship. We were old friends anyway. It's a very powerful situation. We have some deep brainstorming sessions. Jonathan and I could go and have a beer in a pub and create a new company, literally.'

Rowland got the thirst for seeking out investment targets after working for his father. 'I decided 18 months ago the best thing to do was work with the old man, who had a proven track record. I'd resisted it for five or six years. I sat under his guidance, listened and learned.'

He then started to identify Internet investment targets. 'I understood it better than he did. I started to source deals, ring people up, meet people.'

Some of Rowland's earliest investments included Autonomy (an Internet software company) and Demon, an Internet Service Provider.

Now things have changed. Answering to shareholders rather than to the Rowland family creates new pressures to deliver returns - either through selling Jellyworks' investments at a premium to trade or through Initial Public Offerings. This hybrid firm - a blend of venture capital outfit and shell company - may be a strange beast to UK investors, but it is not without successful precedents.

Rowland cites as the company's role model CMGI, the US investment powerhouse which started out as a direct mailing firm and has now made billions by investing in technology stocks, notably Internet search engine Lycos.

Of course, such success can be sustained only if the value of Jellyworks shares remains buoyant. If sentiment turns against the firm, chances are its boasts of being able to secure access to capital will wear thin.

Guinan is dismissive about this possibility: 'We were asked "is your company money for old rope?". I'm not entirely sure what that comment meant. We see ourselves as building a billion-pound company.'

Jonathan Rowland has even greater designs: 'I respect what Richard Branson's done with Virgin. I think we can make Jellyworks a similar sort of brand in the future.'

The Internet - it's a wibbly, wobbly world.

Job title: Chairman of Jellyworks

Born: 7 October 1947

fields.headline: Work isn't working
fields.standfirst: This week, Eileen Mulligan takes us through a programme for getting the best from work.
fields.trailText: Eileen Mulligan takes us through a programme for getting the best from work
fields.body:
What is life coaching?

Life coaching is the newest, fastest and most effective way to reassess and rework any area of your life. What a personal trainer does for your body, a life coach does for the rest of your life. Your coach will meet you, get to know you, discover what areas of your life you feel dissatisfied or confused about, then help you develop a strategy for improving them. After an initial meeting, most coaching is done by telephone, with your coach pushing you, encouraging you and generally watching over you, making sure that you turn your plans into action. Coaching is not therapy. "Coaching is more pragmatic and goal orientated," says Eileen Mulligan, our life coach for this series. "We don't focus on the roots of problems, but on their solutions."

Whatever your problems, the techniques of life coaching can help you become your own life coach, and give you new and effective ways to deal with them.

Creating the perfect job

I'm not going to tell you that you can do any job you want to - there may be good reasons why you can't. But I believe there may be less stopping you going after the career you really want than you think.

Some of us know what our perfect job would be - but not how to get it. For others, even deciding what their perfect job would be is difficult. If this is your problem, it can be useful to revisit the personal core values list from lesson one. This is a list of the ten values (in order) that are most important to you. Common examples include love, security, respect, money, health, friendship, freedom, achievement, family, travel, etc. Creating your core values list can be hard - you may need to rework it before it really reflects how you think and feel.

Once it's done, look at the list. If money, achievement and success are high on your list, work is obviously a priority. You can think big, but you need to ask yourself what else you are prepared to give up to achieve the things you want. If your core values are headed by things like family, relationships, independence, these are the clues you need to read in thinking up your perfect job.

Working against your core values will never really make you happy, and will always feel harder and more stressful than doing work that reflects them. Try this simple exercise:

A: Imagine your ideal job. Write it down in as much detail as possible: what exactly does your work entail, what will you be doing, what kind of hours will you work, what are the salary and benefits like?

B: Imagine that you are interviewing somebody for that job. Prepare a detailed questionnaire and application form, and specify relevant qualifications. What sort of experience would the candidate require? What sort of person are you looking for?

C: Fill in the questionnaire and application form. Include your CV.

D: Did you give yourself the job? If not, how could you get it next time? What skills, training, or information do you need?

Means and ends goals

Throughout this life-coaching course, we have stressed the importance of setting goals. Of course, we all have different requirements from our work. Your goal may be to have a job with the ultimate aim of making lots of money. The bit in the middle - the work you do - may be less important, and job satisfaction may not be the goal you have set. But because work accounts for so much of our time, you need to be sure about what your means and ends goals are. Can you contend with a boring job? Will the pay be enough compensation? Are the demands on your time affecting your wellbeing? Is the end really enough to justify the means? Give this careful thought when you set your work and career goals. The end goal - such as making lots of money - may look attractive, but as you're carrying the bit in the middle, are you sure you've made the right choice?

The list

If you've been following this series from week one, you'll know that this list is the template for all the life coaching lessons. On paper, write down these five headings: goals, personal strengths, immediate challenges/ blocks/problems, development skills, achievements. Keep your work issues in mind. Do you want to change career? Improve your performance at work? Get promoted? Feel less stressed? Begin to fill in your list.

Goals: Remember to keep these positive, so: "I want to get promoted in the next six months" rather than "I don't want to feel so undervalued", and make them relate directly to you and your issues. So "I want to improve my relationship with my boss" rather than "I want my boss to stop bullying me". Bear in mind your means and ends goals - think very carefully before deciding what you really want to achieve, and what you might have to do to achieve it. Some examples of your work goals might be: improve my performance, build better relationships with clients and colleagues, find a better-paid job, work fewer hours.

Personal strengths: Here, you should list your personal strengths at work. Focus on the strengths you have that can help you achieve your goals. So if your goal is to be promoted, a strength that might support that would be "I am determined", or "I am hardworking". If your goal is to change career, your strengths might include "I am a fast learner" or "I'm very motivated". Other strengths could be: "I'm a self-starter", "I'm highly organised", "I'm flexible", "I have the right skills", "I'm a good team player", etc.

Immediate challenges/blocks/problems: Go back to your goals. They tell you what you want to achieve. Now think about what is standing in your way. Again, I must stress that you should keep the focus on yourself and the way the problems or blocks directly affect you. Blaming others: "My boss undervalues me", or "my team don't give me enough support" takes away your power to solve the problem. So instead of saying that your boss undervalues you, you can turn your problem around to "I allow myself to be undervalued". If the problem lies with you and your behaviour, you have the power to change it. Other problems and challenges might be "I'm not very good at organising myself", "I take on too much", "I'm feeling bored and stuck".

Development skills: Your development skills are areas where you can begin to change and improve and take yourself forward. Again, you should focus on the skills that will be most useful in achieving your goals. Some good examples could be: "Learn to relax and switch off", "improve my sales skills","become better organised", "take some additional courses or training programmes", "work on having a more positive attitude".

Achievements: This is where you list all the achievements you have made at work. It's important to see what you've achieved at work, and to remind yourself how much you are capable of. This is a list you should be adding to daily. For example: "I had good sales figures last month", "I was recently promoted", "I can get excellent references".

Developing positive thinking

Keeping a positive mental attitude can help you with any problems or issues in your life. Putting a positive 'spin' on issues can powerfully affect your thinking and behaviour, and the way that other people react to you. Try these simple techniques.

Police your thoughts. Remain conscious of what and how you think. For example, a colleague makes a silly mistake and you think: "What an idiot". When you make a mistake, and think you're the idiot, you'll understand why a better alternative is: "We all make mistakes". If you know that you're inclined to think and speak negatively about other people, you'll become your own victim.

Convert a negative to a positive. Every time you find yourself thinking negatively - stop. Make a conscious decision to change that thought to a positive one. At first, you have to be very conscious of this, but, as time passes, thinking positively becomes a habit.

Handling problems. If problems are blocking you, write them down. They look less threatening that way. Once they're on paper, treat them like a puzzle - it's a fundamental of life coaching that a puzzle requires only a solution or a formula, whereas a problem calls for an answer.

Ask the right questions. Your brain will always try to find an answer when you ask it a question, so it's better to ask the right question, which means a positive one.

Ask yourself: "Why can't I solve this?" Are you getting any useful answers? Now try this: "How can I crack this problem?" Do you see the difference? Asking "why is this happening" is counter-productive, whereas "how can I make it work for me?" pushes you into solution mode.

Use affirmations. Affirmations are great for boosting your self-esteem and confidence, because although they may sound contrived at first, your subconscious mind will accept them. Set some affirmations specific to your situation, eg: "I am committed to changing my situation", "I will set goals and achieve them". As soon as you think "I can't do this", replace it with "I can, and I will".

Jane's story

Eileen (the coach): Jane had been in her job as a manager for 10 years. Her problem was that she was dissatisfied with her work, but didnÍt know what else she wanted to do. Her situation was complicated by the fact that her boss was also a close friend, which had both advantages and disadvantages. Jane felt taken for granted and undervalued - "like part of the furniture". On the surface, Jane seemed poised, confident and assertive, yet her consultation revealed a much lower self-esteem and a sensitive nature. Her colleagues may have taken her at face value and assumed she didn't need as much support as she actually does.

When Jane produced her list of core values, she listed things like friendship, honesty, integrity and understanding. These are very people-orientated values, and it suggested that Jane's core problem with work lay not in the work itself, but in her work relationships. She was feeling bored and stuck after being in the same place for so long. I did not think Jane really needed or wanted to leave her job. She's very good at what she does, and that aspect of her working life is satisfactory. She is also security conscious, and had some fear about leaving a job she's done for so long. I felt it was more important for her to build up her self-esteem where she is before thinking of moving on. I suggested that she work on her current work relationships, including setting some boundaries with her boss and improving communication. It can be very empowering for clients to see how they can improve their situation by simply adopting a different attitude. If problems like these aren't worked out, they can follow an employee into their next job.

Jane (the client): I've never been wildly ambitious, but I felt that I should be - I've seen how satisfying work can be for some of my friends, and thought that if I could just discover the right kind of work, I'd feel the same. Discussing why I felt unhappy with my job, and then producing my core values, made me see my situation differently.

It's very important to me to respect and like the people I work with - and the company I work for. That's a far bigger issue than the work I do, which I quite like and know I do well. I realise now that work just isn't my number one priority in life - but that I need to restructure my life, and adjust my attitude and way of working so that I don't feel so taken for granted. The best thing about life coaching is that you suddenly see your issues quite clearly and as puzzles to solve, rather than this rather depressing cloud that they'd felt like before. I've learnt some techniques for dealing with my boss, and I'm considering keeping my job but going part-time as a freelance and taking on another client. This would give me some variety and rejuvenate me. I know it won't be easy to do these things all at once, but my situation seems a lot clearer and more positive.

Final checklist

 Information is your ally. If you want to change jobs, find out as much as possible about the area you want to move into.

 Develop a clear, positive attitude.

 Be clear about your means-and-ends goals.

 Create your perfect job.

 Review your list, and make sure you have a clear time-frame and plan of action.

Achievements: This is where you list all the achievements you have made at work. It's important to see what you've achieved at work, and to remind yourself how much you are capable of. This is a list you should be adding to daily. For example: "I had good sales figures last month", "I was recently promoted", "I can get excellent references". Developing positive thinking Keeping a positive mental attitude can help you with any problems or issues in your life. Putting a positive 'spin' on issues can powerfully affect your thinking and behaviour, and the way that other people react to you. Try these simple techniques. Police your thoughts. Remain conscious of what and how you think. For example, a colleague makes a silly mistake and you think: "What an idiot". When you make a mistake, and think you're the idiot, you'll understand why a better alternative is: "We all make mistakes". If you know that you're inclined to think and speak negatively about other people, you'll become your own victim. Convert a negative to a positive. Every time you find yourself thinking negatively - stop. Make a conscious decision to change that thought to a positive one. At first, you have to be very conscious of this, but, as time passes, thinking positively becomes a habit. Handling problems. If problems are blocking you, write them down. They look less threatening that way. Once they're on paper, treat them like a puzzle - it's a fundamental of life coaching that a puzzle requires only a solution or a formula, whereas a problem calls for an answer. Ask the right questions. Your brain will always try to find an answer when you ask it a question, so it's better to ask the right question, which means a positive one. Ask yourself: "Why can't I solve this?" Are you getting any useful answers? Now try this: "How can I crack this problem?" Do you see the difference? Asking "why is this happening" is counter-productive, whereas "how can I make it work for me?" pushes you into solution mode. Use affirmations. Affirmations are great for boosting your self-esteem and confidence, because although they may sound contrived at first, your subconscious mind will accept them. Set some affirmations specific to your situation, eg: "I am committed to changing my situation", "I will set goals and achieve them". As soon as you think "I can't do this", replace it with "I can, and I will". Jane's story Eileen (the coach): Jane had been in her job as a manager for 10 years. Her problem was that she was dissatisfied with her work, but didnÍt know what else she wanted to do. Her situation was complicated by the fact that her boss was also a close friend, which had both advantages and disadvantages. Jane felt taken for granted and undervalued - "like part of the furniture". On the surface, Jane seemed poised, confident and assertive, yet her consultation revealed a much lower self-esteem and a sensitive nature. Her colleagues may have taken her at face value and assumed she didn't need as much support as she actually does. When Jane produced her list of core values, she listed things like friendship, honesty, integrity and understanding. These are very people-orientated values, and it suggested that Jane's core problem with work lay not in the work itself, but in her work relationships. She was feeling bored and stuck after being in the same place for so long. I did not think Jane really needed or wanted to leave her job. She's very good at what she does, and that aspect of her working life is satisfactory. She is also security conscious, and had some fear about leaving a job she's done for so long. I felt it was more important for her to build up her self-esteem where she is before thinking of moving on. I suggested that she work on her current work relationships, including setting some boundaries with her boss and improving communication. It can be very empowering for clients to see how they can improve their situation by simply adopting a different attitude. If problems like these aren't worked out, they can follow an employee into their next job. Jane (the client): I've never been wildly ambitious, but I felt that I should be - I've seen how satisfying work can be for some of my friends, and thought that if I could just discover the right kind of work, I'd feel the same. Discussing why I felt unhappy with my job, and then producing my core values, made me see my situation differently. It's very important to me to respect and like the people I work with - and the company I work for. That's a far bigger issue than the work I do, which I quite like and know I do well. I realise now that work just isn't my number one priority in life - but that I need to restructure my life, and adjust my attitude and way of working so that I don't feel so taken for granted. The best thing about life coaching is that you suddenly see your issues quite clearly and as puzzles to solve, rather than this rather depressing cloud that they'd felt like before. I've learnt some techniques for dealing with my boss, and I'm considering keeping my job but going part-time as a freelance and taking on another client. This would give me some variety and rejuvenate me. I know it won't be easy to do these things all at once, but my situation seems a lot clearer and more positive. Final checklist  Information is your ally. If you want to change jobs, find out as much as possible about the area you want to move into.  Develop a clear, positive attitude.  Be clear about your means-and-ends goals.  Create your perfect job.  Review your list, and make sure you have a clear time-frame and plan of action.

fields.headline: Germans seek link with AOL
fields.trailText: Mannesmann, the German conglomerate trying to fight off the world's largest hostile takeover bid, is talking to America Online (AOL), the Internet service provider which is merging with media giant Time Warner, about creating a series of alliances.
fields.body:
Mannesmann, the German conglomerate trying to fight off the world's largest hostile takeover bid, is talking to America Online (AOL), the Internet service provider which is merging with media giant Time Warner, about creating a series of alliances.

The potential link-up with AOL would see Mannesmann's mobile phone users able to access a raft of exclusive content. This could strengthen Mannesmann's attempts to remain independent of Vodafone AirTouch, which is offering an all-paper deal worth around £95 billion.

A source close to Mannesmann said: 'AOL is an interesting potential partner. It is one of many. I wouldn't rule out building that relationship in the next few months.'

Steve Case, chief executive officer of AOL, is a good friend of Klaus Esser, top man at Mannesmann.

The two are understood to have discussed a partnership between their two companies.

The most likely link would be an alliance between Mannesmann. and AOL Europe, jointly owned by AOL and Germany's Bertelsmann.

Last week Mannesmann dismissed Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent's latest attempt to woo German shareholders. Gent held out the prospect of a 'modest' increase in the offer if Mannesmann dropped its defence to the bid. Currently Vodafone is offering Mannesmann shareholders a 47.2 per cent stake in the combined company, but Gent has hinted that this could go up to 49 per cent if the German firm's management was helpful.

Mannesmann's advisers suggest Gent's offer may backfire. One source close to the German company said: 'It was ill-advised. It makes it much more difficult to bring both sides together. A 1.7 per cent improvement is not going to cut the cake. It must be an insult to Klaus Esser.'

Esser has said he would consider a deal only if Mannesmann shareholders gained 58.6 per cent of the combined company.

But Vodafone's advisers believe they will win the backing of most Mannesmann shareholders anyway. A company source said: 'We're still very confident that we will get more than 50.1 per cent.'

fields.headline: UK supermarkets 'are not a rip-off'
fields.trailText: An international comparison to be published this week shows little difference between grocery prices in Britain and abroad.
fields.byline: by Sarah Ryle and Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
An international comparison to be published this week shows little difference between grocery prices in Britain and abroad.

The findings will dent the Rip-off Britain campaign, fuelled by Chancellor Gordon Brown and Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers, whose department ordered the research, a member of the Government admitted this weekend.

The comparison, recommended in a Consumer White Paper, proved difficult to make because British shopping habits and products differ from continental ones.

'It looks to me as though we don't pay overly for food,' the Government source told The Observer . 'The differences are small, and they are not all one way.'

This is a remarkable admission. The Government-ordered Competition Commission inquiry into supermarket pricing reaches a milestone this week, when the biggest supermarkets expect letters setting out issues the regulator wants to raise following months of questioning.

The source also pointed to research which showed that electrical goods were good value in the UK. 'When Dixons got Arthur Andersen to do a very intensive survey of white goods, this country came out rather well.'

However, the Government is unlikely to drop the Rip off Britain slogan. 'It has entered into common parlance. The whole point about launching the price comparison is to test it,' the source insisted.

But retailers are delighted with the admission that there is little difference between UK prices and those abroad.

'We are very pleased that the Government is beginning to understand the complexities of pricing and what goes into pricing,' said Ann Grain communications director at the British Retail Consortium.

The BRC will unveil the results of a report on interna tional price comparisons by Professor John Kay of the London Economics tomorrow. It is expected to support its arguments that if British prices are higher, it is due to regulations, manufacturers' price differentials and the exchange rate rather than to anti-competitive retailers.

The supermarkets' case is strengthened by a study conducted for Tesco by AC Nielsen, the company that is carrying out the research for the DTI price comparison.

AC Nielsen found that the Tesco shopping basket is 5.7 per cent cheaper than that of continental rivals'. It will find it difficult to contradict this when it supplies final figures to the DTI on January 31.

Tesco's marketing director Tim Mason said: 'Britain has been unfairly labelled as expensive. However, these figures confirm that the British food shopper gets the best deal.'

Asda said its own price check of 1,200 goods each week showed it was 5 per cent cheaper than Tesco.
